DOC.HEAD: One Dead, Five Injured in Oakland Hotel Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire at a downtown hotel Thursday killed one person and injured five others. ``The fire broke out on the sixth floor of the Harrison Hotel and spread to a portion of the seventh,'' said fire Battalion Chief John McPartland. The fire was reported at 6:28 p.m., and was brought under control in a little over half an hour by 65 firefighters, McPartland said. The identity of the person who died was not released. One firefighter suffered chest pains and was taken to a hospital as a precaution, McPartland said. Four occupants of the hotel suffered smoke inhalation. McPartland estimated damage to the seven-story structure at $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Internal Inquiry Found Misconduct By Ritter
DOC.TEXT: An investigation ordered by Covenant House's board of directors determined the organization's founder, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, engaged in sexual misconduct with young men at shelters for runaways, says a published report. The article in Friday's New York Times cited unidentified people who had read the investigative report. The report is to be released Friday, the newspaper said. The report describes sexual activity that some Covenant House resident said they engaged in with Ritter, the Times said. Investigators interviewed one person who told of seeing the priest lying in bed with a young man, the newspaper quoted two sources as saying. Investigators also talked to other Covenant House residents who said Ritter made sexual overtures toward them that were spurned, the Times said. The four-month investigation was headed by Robert J. McGuire, a former city police commissioner. Ritter, 63, has vehemently denied the allegations, has declined to be interviewed for months and is said to have refused to cooperate with McGuire's investigation. The former head of Covenant House is believed to be living in New Jersey and considering leaving the Franciscan order. The McGuire report is said to have found no evidence that Ritter misappropriated funds. But the Times said the report blamed Covenant House's board of directors for failing to oversee Ritter. The board did not even know Ritter was receiving an annual salary of $98,000, the bulk of which was going into a secret personal fund, the Times said. The fund, called the Franciscan Charitable Trust, had accumulated nearly $1 million. Plans now call for it to be liquidated and for the assets to go to Covenant House, as Ritter says he intended all along. Had Ritter not resigned last February, the board would have had to dismiss him, the Times said. Allegations against Ritter surfaced last December when Kevin Lee Kite, 26, a drifter from Texas, accused the priest of luring him into a sexual relationship. Kite's accusations were followed by similar allegations by two others, including Darryl Bassile, 31, a social worker from Ithaca, N.Y. McGruire's investigation concluded that Bassile was the most credible of Ritter's public accusers. Since spring, more than half the 17 Covenant House board members have resigned. Donations have fallen and cutbacks have been made. Sister Mary Rose McGeady, senior Catholic Charities official in the borough of Queens, is to replace Ritter as head of the shelter on Sept. 1. Ritter founded Covenant House in 1968. Today the shelter serves 28,000 youths in 15 U.S. cities, Canada and Central America each year. The Manhattan district attorney concluded an investigation into Ritter's finances without bringing charges against him. The state attorney general's office has not yet concluded a similar probe.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Reports 10 `Close Calls' in Three Years for NASA Training Jets
DOC.TEXT: The supersonic jets used by NASA to train space shuttle pilots were involved in ``close calls'' with other aircraft at least 10 times since 1986, according to a federal report released Wednesday. The incidents occurred in the three years period before a near collision in May 1989 between a T-38 training airplane piloted by astronaut David Walker and a Pan Am airbus carrying 166 passengers, according to the report by the National Transportation Safety Board. The report was carried in Thursday's editions of The Orlando Sentinel. Last month, the space agency grounded Walker, a Navy captain and a native of Eustis, Fla., for 60 days, citing ``various infractions'' while he was flying the training planes. The NTSB report included details of Walker's near-collision and brief mentions of the other 10 incidents. NASA officials said they couldn't comment on the report because they had yet to see it. The report doesn't offer specifics on the incidents, other than to say they happened between April 1986 and April 1989. Air safety investigators said the close calls were included among 22 ``operational hazard'' and ``hazardous air traffic'' reports they obtained from NASA, all involving the T-38s. ``Ten of the reports dealt with `close calls' with another aircraft,'' the NTSB stated. NASA defines a close call as any incident involving the planes ``which possesses a high potential for a mishap.'' Jeff Carr, a spokesman at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, said no one there had any information about the NASA reports cited by air safety investigators. The T-38 trainers, based at the Houston center, are flown mostly by space shuttle pilots preparing for missions, but they are also used by about 15 civilian instructor pilots, Carr said. On May 15, 1989, Walker flew one of the T-38s from Houston to Andrews Air Force Base near Washington for a meeting with President Bush. In making his approach, he descended to 7,000 feet _ 1,000 feet lower than he had been cleared _ and passed 700 feet in front of the airbus. Walker and another shuttle pilot, Navy Cmdr. Robert ``Hoot'' Gibson, were both grounded by NASA on July 9. Gibson's suspension was for his involvement in a mid-air collision at a Texas airshow that left the other pilot dead.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Leader, 112 Trinidad Militants Surrender, Free 46 Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with deputy prime minister saying rebels had surrendered unconditionally and Robinson still prime minister; DELETES outdated material. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos POS100,101, LaserColor POS201
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Coup leader Abu Bakr and 112 militant Moslem followers surrendered Wednesday and freed 46 hostages they seized five days earlier in a failed bid to overthrow the government, officials said. State radio said a wounded hostage freed on Saturday died on Wednesday in a hospital. That raised the death toll in the uprising to at least 10. Deputy Prime Minister Winston Dookeran said the rebels, who appeared not to have any significant support among the people, ``surrendered unconditionally'' and were under heavy guard at an army base. He said they would face ``the appropriate charges,'' but did not elaborate. Dookeran told reporters that Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson had not resigned, as he had offered to while held hostage. ``Prime Minister Robinson is the prime minister of Trinidad and Tobago,'' Dookeran said. ``There is no intention to resign.'' ``We have made no deals with this extremist group,'' said Dookeran, who was held hostage on the first day of the coup attempt. Bakr released Dookeran on Saturday, saying he wanted the deputy prime minister to head a caretaker government that would hold new elections in the Caribbean nation. The attempted coup began Friday when armed rebels stormed the state television station and the Parliament building, taking top government officials and other captives. Bakr had demanded the resignation of Robinson, whom he accused of corruption. The 63-year-old prime minister was freed Tuesday and hospitalized for treatment of a leg wound suffered in the takeover as well as exhaustion and glaucoma. Bakr blamed Robinson for widespread poverty in this former British colony of 1.3 million people. Bakr was among the rebels who surrendered at the television station, where the first group of hostages was freed. Government spokesman Gregory Shaw said 113 rebels, including Bakr, took part in the coup. He said 46 hostages held at Parliament and the TV building one mile away were released Wednesday. Shaw and army spokesman Maj. Dave Williams said all hostages and rebels had been evacuated and taken to separate army bases. State radio identified the former hostage who died Wednesdey as Leo des Vignes, a junior minister. It said he died of a heart attack in the hospital after being shot in the heel during the takeover. The rebels released him on Saturday, the broadcast said. The radio said heavy gunfire was reported Wednesday evening in Champs Fleurs, about 10 miles east of Port-of-Spain. There was no official explanation, but soldiers have been firing blank bullets to scatter would-be looters for several days. The 29 captives at the TV station were all station employees. The remaining 17 hostages at the Parliament building included seven Cabinet ministers. In a live broadcast, state radio described the haggard-looking captives filing out of the television station, one by one. Soldiers searched each one in the street, because the militants had claimed at one point to have wired the captives with explosives and threatened to blow them up. After the prisoner release, witnesses said about 50 rebels left the television building, dropped their weapons and surrendered to soldiers. Witnesses said Bakr emerged wearing a fez, a white tunic and white trousers. Like the other rebels, he dropped his gun and put his hands behind his head. After boarding an army bus, Bakr shouted: ``Allahu akhbar!'' or God is great. Hostages began leaving the Parliament building at 5:10 p.m. EDT. The first to leave was a woman who held a white handkerchief to her face. An army truck rolled up to the red, colonial-style building to provide cover for soldiers who escorted her down the street. A few minutes later, the finance minister, Selby Wilson, emerged, followed by another man who had a white handkerchief tied across his face. The two men walked unescorted to a security van. The hostages walked along a sidewalk to a security area at the end of the street, where they emptied their pockets and were searched before getting onto an army bus. Some of the hostages jogged down the street; others walked. Justice Minister Selwyn Richardson, reportedly shot in the leg during the Parliament takeover, walked with a noticeable limp. Applause broke out as he boarded the bus. State radio said the rebels were taken to army headquarters at Chaguerames in northwest Trinidad and the freed hostages to Camp Ogden, an army base about five miles west of Port-of-Spain. A local reporter who spoke with the former hostages at Camp Ogden said they told him they had not eaten since Friday but were otherwise OK. They were all undergoing medical exams in a tent. At Ogden Camp, freed hostage Grensell Kissoon, told a reporter, ``I'm glad to be alive.'' TV station worker Raul Board held onto a post, saying he feared he might faint from hunger. ``You know why I'm holding the post? I'm afraid I might fall.'' The capital was quiet Wednesday. A 6 p.m.-to-noon curfew remained in effect throughout most of Trinidad following earlier widespread looting. Bakr's Jamaat al-Muslimeen group, which means the Moslem Group in Arabic, was founded in 1984 and is believed to have 250 to 300 members. It is also believed to have received financing from Libya. Gargano had said 200 troops from neighboring Caribbean nations were on neighboring Barbados and ``could be here in 45 minutes,'' but that Trinidad and its sister island of Tobago had not asked for help.

DOC.HEAD: Bolt Is Named Texas News Editor
DOC.TEXT: John A. Bolt, business editor in the Dallas bureau of The Associated Press since 1989, has been named news editor for Texas. The appointment was announced Wednesday by Chief of Bureau John Lumpkin. Bolt, 38, succeeds Sue Cross, who has become Illinois news editor. Bolt joined the AP in Atlanta in 1983. He became Atlanta's night supervisor in 1985 and in 1989 was appointed to the new position of Texas business editor in Dallas. Before joining AP, he worked on newspapers in South Carolina for the Greenville News-Piedmont Co., and the Anderson Independent-Mail. A native of Asheville, N.C., Bolt graduated from Clemson University.

DOC.HEAD: African Leaders Concentrate on Internal Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thurday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: With decolonization complete, African leaders are turning to conflicts within their own countries that have killed millions of people, maimed countless more and created 5 million refugees. Those internal wars, some decades old, have been largely ignored by the Organization of African Unity, which devoted itself to supporting guerrilla movements in South Africa and colonies ruled by Europeans. Civil wars were considered beyond the bounds of the OAU, whose charter forbade meddling in the internal affairs of member states. Last month, a change began. For the first time since its birth in 1963, the organization declared that ballots should determine the future of the continent's 550 million people, not force of arms. It did not change the charter, but clearly shifted emphasis. ``The issue of restoring peace and stability to African countries and of dismantling the apartheid system was the dominant theme of discussion during the 26th OAU summit,'' the English-language daily Ethiopian Herald said in an editorial. The paper is published in Addis Ababa, headquarters of the OAU. In African eyes, the continent became free of colonies when Namibia gained independence from South Africa in March. Africans viewed Namibia, which South Africa governmed under a U.N. mandate withdrawn in 1966, as a colony of the white-ruled country. The OAU and United Nations have long recognized South Africa as an independent nation, but have tried to end the apartheid racial policy that maintains supremacy for 5 million whites over 28 million blacks. In previous years, the OAU has committed itself to financing guerrilla armies in areas ranging from Cape Verde, when it was a Portuguese colony, to the British territory of Rhodesia, now black-ruled Zimbabwe. It ended the June summit with the usual condemnation of apartheid, but for the first time omitted mention of continuing to support guerrilla-backed movements like the African National Congress or Pan-Africanist Congress. Instead, Africa's leaders committed themselves to increasing democracy within their own countries and finding peaceful solutions to civil wars in progress from the Western Sahara in the far northwest to Mozambique in the southeast. Here is a look at the long-running wars: ANGOLA _ Portugal, the colonial power, pulled out of this agriculturally rich West African territory in 1975, leaving three anti-colonial guerrilla armies to fight for the spoils. The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola won. Since then, the Marxist government has battled Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, which has U.S. support. Zaire is mediating peace talks. CHAD _ This landlocked desert nation in north central Africa, independent from France since 1960, has been torn by rebellions and three civil wars. Virtually all involved meddling and military incursions by Chad's northern neighbor, Libya, with which it has a border dispute. President Hissen Habre's army scored a major victory over the Libyans in 1987, but skirmishing continues between government forces and Libyan-backed rebels. ETHIOPIA _ For 29 years, Africa's longest civil war has raged in northernmost Eritrea Province, where rebels of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front control virtually all the countryside and the port of Massawa, one of Ethiopia's two Red Sea harbors. The Eritreans, loosely allied with the Tigre People's Liberation Front in neighboring Tigre province, want independence for Eritrea, a former Italian colony federated with Ethiopia in 1952. The Tigreans want to overthrow the central government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The two conflicts and the famines they spawned have claimed more than 1 million lives. MOZAMBIQUE _ After Portugal granted independence in 1975, a rebel army called the Mozambique National Resistance, known as Renamo, was organized within Mozambique by the white military of neighboring Rhodesia. Mozambique was the main springboard for incursions by guerrillas bent on toppling Rhodesia's white-minority government. White-ruled South Africa took over Renamo after Rhodesia became Zimbabwe in 1980, but now says it has ended support of the guerrillas. Hundreds of thousands of people have died and other hundreds of thousands have fled Mozambique. Preliminary peace talks began last year, but no real progress is evident. SOMALIA _ Since 1969, when he took power in a military coup, President Mohammed Siad Barre has ruled this Horn of Africa nation with what human rights groups describe as nearly unmatched brutality. Insurgents in the north have fought his regime for a decade and new rebel organizations sprang up in the south last year. The president has promised a referendum on a new constitution later this year and multiparty elections early in 1991. SUDAN _ For seven years, southern rebels who are mainly Christian or animist have been fighting for autonomy from the Moslem-dominated central government in Khartoum. Former President Jimmy Carter arranged peace talks last year that failed to settle the conflict. As in Ethiopia, the fighting has led to periodic famine and the loss of hundreds of thousands of lives. WESTERN SAHARA _ Morocco and the Polisario Front, a Marxist group, have been at war since 1977 over the desolate Western Sahara. Spain as the colonial power, granted the region to Morocco and Mauritania in 1975, but Mauritania later abandoned its claim. The Morocco-Polisario conflict has been largely at stalemate in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans Worried About Price Tag on Cold War Conclusion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: West Germans are getting out their calculators and pondering whether they will be economic victors or victims as foreign troops begin leaving over the next few years. West Germany sees its mighty economic machine growing even stronger when land now occupied by foreign forces is made available for German development for the first time in four decades. But many Germans have become hooked on cash-carrying Cold Warriors, and they are clearly concerned. ``If all the Americans leave, it's going to hurt each and every German. Americans spend enormous amounts of money here,'' said Harry Spittler, who owns a gift shop in Kaiserslautern. American officials say West Germany gets an annual infusion of about $8.75 billion because of the U.S. troop presence alone. About 200,000 Germans earn their livings directly from the American deployment. If all goes well at conventional weapons talks in Vienna, the United States and Soviet Union will each lower their troop levels in central Europe to 195,000 apiece. Under that plan, about 59,000 U.S. troops will leave West Germany over the next five years. There are currently 250,000 American soldiers here, a figure that does not include dependents. Britain has said it also plans to reduce its troop levels in West Germany by the mid-1990s, halving the current number of about 66,700. The Kaiserslautern area _ with about 70,000 American troops and their dependents plus civilian workers _ has the greatest concentration of U.S. troops outside the continental United States. Some of the largest U.S. military installations in Europe are in Kaiserslautern, including Ramstein Air Base, European headquarters for the U.S. Air Force. Spittler, 64, is a classic example of how some West Germans hav developed an economic addiction to the foreign troops. His clientele at Harry's Gift Shop is almost exclusively American. They are drawn by his huge stock of beer steins, nutcracker dolls and cuckoo clocks _ German souvenirs that are especially coveted by GIs scouting gifts to send to their families stateside. The store clerks and Spittler speak fluent English. Instead of hearing ``Guten Morgen,'' customers are greeted with a cheery ``Good morning!'' If that doesn't make an American GI feel at home, there's always the selection of American music coming from the shop's stereo system. ``On Top of Old Smokey'' was playing one recent day. No one expects the U.S. military to pull completely out of West Germany in the near future. Chancellor Helmut Kohl has said repeatedly West Germany must continue to house American troops because there is always the chance a military threat to Europe could arise again. But even the most optimistic government officials concede that whatever troop cutbacks are in store, weaning West Germans from four decades of military-supplied economic nourishment will not be easy. ``American soldiers have their apartments here and they spend a lot of money shopping and in restaurants. When disarmament comes, naturally jobs will be lost as well as some economic power,'' said Juergen Dietzen, spokesman for the Interior Ministry of Rhineland-Palatinate state. Rhineland-Palatinate is home to 64,000 American troops. More than 40,000 state residents earn their livings either directly or indirectly from the American military presence, Dietzen said. The state is already making plans for what to do after the closure of a major U.S. air base at Zweibruecken. The base is to be shut in 1993, and there is concern for the more than 340 German nationals working there. But the closing also demonstrates how West German officials seem to have optimistic views of life after the soldiers leave. Rhineland-Palatinate is charting plans to develop the base site into an industrial park with a commercial airport, providing jobs for thousands of civilians. ``We try not to get caught up in the problems that lie before us,'' Dietzen said. ``We like to think of the new possibilities.'' Some West German communities are even trying to get the U.S. government to include them as Washington decides where to make its troop cuts. Frankfurt, for example, has been eyeing military sites nearby as possible places for economic expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Sue to Block Shipment of Chemical Arms to Pacific
DOC.TEXT: Three groups filed suit Wednesday to block the Army's plan to ship chemical weapons from West Germany to Johnston Atoll, saying the muntions pose a threat to the environment and people of the Pacific. Meanwhile, leaders of the 15-nation South Pacific Forum, meeting in Port Vila, Vanuatu, issued a communique saying U.S. plans to incinerate chemical weapons at Johnston Atoll could turn the Pacific into ``the toxic waste disposal center of the world.'' The communique called for closing the disposal plant once its current operations are completed. Greenpeace, the Institute for the Advancement of Hawaiian Affairs and the World Council of Indigenous Peoples-Hawaii contend the Army hasn't adequately considered the risks involved in shipping the American-owned weapons across the ocean and incinerating them at the atoll 800 miles southwest of here. ``We emphatically support the destruction of these weapons, but not at the expense of the Pacific environment,'' said David Chatfield, chairman of Greenpeace USA. The groups, represented by the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund, said incineration of chemical weapons is an unproven procedure. They said the government hasn't adequately considered other means of disposal, including chemical neutralization. They are seeking an injunction from the U.S. District Court here to block further movement of the munitions. Some 100,000 rounds of nerve gas projectiles are to be shipped to Johnston Atoll during the next few months. The Army plans to store them at the facility and destroy them in an incinerator that is still being tested. The suit names Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Michael P. Stone, secretary of the Army, as defendants. ``The Army's action is also illegal because the Army has done an extremely shoddy job of assessing the environmental impact of this scheme,'' said Skip Spaulding, a staff attorney for the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund. ``Indeed, it appears that this shipment is merely a political gimmick to get (West German Chancellor Helmut) Kohl re-elected at the expense of U.S. environmental laws.'' The weapons from West Germany would add 100,000 rounds to the 300,000 rounds of nerve and mustard gas stored at Johnston Atoll since 1971. They will be put in storage on Johnston Atoll until the Army finishes testing an incinerator for the munitions. The tests are to be completed late next year, and full-scale destruction is not expected to begin until 1992. The Army has said moving the weapons and destroying them at Johnston Atoll would have minimal public health, safety and environmental effects. At the meeting of the South Pacific forum, Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia argued in favor of the plan, saying scientific evidence indicated the incineration was safe. He said the project was in the interests of worldwide disarmament. The Pacific leaders, whose governments represent about 25 million people, will discuss the issue Friday with a U.S. delegation.

DOC.HEAD: United Negro College Fund President Announces Retirement
DOC.TEXT: Christopher F. Edley, who as president of the United Negro College Fund helped raise $556 million dollars over 18 years, announced Wednesday that he will retire at the end of the year. Edley, 62, who had a heart bypass operation seven years ago, is retiring because of health problems, the organization announced. Under Edley's leadership, the fund adopted its now-famous advertising slogan, ``A Mind Is a Terrible Thing to Waste,'' and became one of the best known charities in the nation. The fund raised $10 million the year before Edley became president. Last year, it took in more than $50 million. The fund also runs a capital campaign with a goal of raising $250 million, mainly for building projects. Money from the fund helps pay operating expenses at 41 institutions that enroll 48,233 students. Edley earned a law degree at Harvard University after graduating from Howard University in 1949. He was an assistant district attorney in Philadelphia before becoming an officer at the Ford Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori Starts Strong, Asserts Authority, Initial Reaction Good
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: During his first week in office President Alberto Fujimori has quickly shaken up top government echelons, and popular opinion seems to support his drive to stabilize the battered nation. Just hours after taking office on Saturday, Fujimori strolled into the Presidential Palace for a ritual hand-shaking ceremony with the commanders of the army, navy and air force. When the names of the military chiefs were called, Peruvians were startled to learn that the heads of the navy and the air force weren't the same officers who had been in power at lunchtime. Asked at his first news conference on Sunday why he had removed Adm. Alfonso Panizo and Air Gen. German Vucetich, Fujimori replied, ``The laws give this right to the president.'' Insiders said the president acted because the navy was rumored to have been fomenting a coup attempt and the air force general had been linked to corruption in the military. Fujimori later fired the nation's four top police officials, and his government called it a ``staff renovation.'' But rumored corruption in law enforcement agencies was the likely reason. The 52-year-old president, a mild-looking agronomist of Japanese ancestry, won an upset victory in June for a five-year term as president of Peru's 22 million citizens. He promised fairness in government and honesty in leadership, but no one expected him to act so decisively so quickly. So far, the public's reaction has been mostly positive. ``Fuji Does Not Tremble.'' the newspaper Novedades proclaimed in a front-page headline. To prepare measures for combating ruinous inflation, the president declared a two-day bank holiday. He promised Peruvians he would not touch individual savings accounts, as happened earlier in the year in neighboring Brazil. Fujimori said people shouldn't panic, and they didn't. Caretas, Peru's largest weekly news magazine, called Fujimori a ``house on fire'' and said he appeared to be ``shaking things up by going after everybody.'' El Comercio of Lima, Peru's biggest newspaper, reported that a vast majority of people questioned after his inauguration gave Fujimori a ``good'' rating. ``The most important thing is the morality part,'' said Javier Juaman, a Lima store clerk. He was referring to Fujimori's inaugural pledge to crack down on government corruption and make bureaucrats more sensitive to the problems of Peru's so-called ``ordinary people.'' Fujimori called Peru's legal system unfair to the masses of poor people and said the Justice Palace is better known on the street as ``the Injustice Palace.'' One of Fujimori's biggest challenges is the leftist Shining Path insurgency, which has wreaked havoc in Peru for years and defied military efforts to stifle it. The president says the best way to defeat the rebels is by raising Peruvians' living standards and promoting economic development. On Tuesday, Fujimori took a walk for several blocks in downtown Lima. Onlookers cheered, and children shrieked, ``Foo-hee, Foo-hee'' _ which is how the first half of the president's name is pronounced in Spanish. It was too early to tell how Fujimori's street popularity would affect his ability to work with Peru's many political parties. His grassroots coalition, Change 90, suffered serious defections before the inauguration and no one from the coalition wound up in Fujimori's Cabinet. The coalition is in the minority in both houses of Peru's Congress. ``He appears to be truthful, but he's also being very generic,'' said Sen. Miguel Cruchaga Belaunde of the Democratic Front coalition. That group's presidential candidate, famed novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, lost to Fujimori in the most stunning upset in modern Latin American politics. Fujimori had scored under 1 percent in opinion surveys at the beginning of the year, but he swept to the front during the spring presidential campaign when voters became alienated by Vargas Llosa's vow to introduce tough austerity measures to revitalize the economy. The novelist was also tainted by the support he received from traditionally discredited political parties. Running on a platform emphasizing ``consensus,'' Fujimori took a centrist position in his campaign and managed to draw supporters from across party lines with his populist image. Legislators from many parties whooped and cheered during Fujimori's inaugural address in the House of Representatives. Minutes earlier, the same lawmakers had booed and banged on their desks when the outgoing president, Alan Garcia, tried to make a farewell speech.

DOC.HEAD: A Comparison of the Military Forces of Iraq and Kuwait
With BC-Iraq-Kuwait Chronology, Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Here is a comparison of the military forces of Iraq and Kuwait:

The numbers of Iraqi servicemen and weapons dwarf those of Kuwait. Iraq has been engaged in a major defense buildup since President Saddam Hussein came to power in 1979. Its combined military forces are estimated at 1 million, with roughly half as active reservists. The army encompasses five armored, two mechanized and 39 infantry divisions with 20 special forces brigades. Equipment includes 4,500 Soviet and 1,500 Chinese tanks, according to figures from the 1989-90 Statesman's Yearbook. The air force has about 500 combat aircraft. The planes are in large part Soviet-designed, including 30 Su-7 and 50 Su-20 fighter-bombings. There are an unknown number of MiG-29s and 90 MiG-23 interceptors and fighter-bombers. Military service of up to two years is compulsory for all men at 18 years of age. On Tuesday, as Iraqi and Kuwaiti envoys met to discuss their border and oil dispute, diplomats said Iraq had massed 100,000 troops on Kuwait's border. That was more than triple the number estimated earlier. The reported Iraqi troop buildup included hundreds of tanks and armored personnel carriers.

Kuwait has a total of about 20,300 troops in its military. It maintains a small but well-equipped army with two armored divisions, a mechanized infantry brigade and a surface-to-surface missile battalion. Its air force, initially a small combat force, has grown to include two squadrons with 25 Mirage F1-C fighters and two squadrons with 30 Skyhawk attack aircraft. For most Kuwaitis, military service is compulsory for 24 months.

DOC.HEAD: China Executes Two for Murdering Party Official
DOC.TEXT: Two men have been executed in the southern city of Fuzhou for murdering a retired party official, a radio report said. The death sentences were among hundreds handed down so far this year as China goes through one of its periodic anti-crime campaigns. The campaigns have not halted a rising crime rate. Wednesday's report by the Fujian Provincial radio service said Chen Shangzhi and Fu Rongwen were convicted of murder at a public rally July 23 in which 186 criminals were tried and sentenced for commiting 101 serious crimes, including murder, robbery and theft. Chen and Fu were executed immediately after the rally, it said. In China, executions are usually carried out with a single bullet to the back of the head.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 5,000 People Caught For Spitting Or Littering
DOC.TEXT: In the first day of a nationwide crackdown on public nuisances, more than 5,000 people were caught spitting or littering and about half of them were fined, officials said today. Wednesday was the first day of an indefinite police crackdown on petty crimes such as spitting, letting dogs run stray and littering. Violators can be fined $5.50 each under a new petty crime control law. Topping the list of violations were 2,789 people who littered streets with cigarette butts, followed by 1,226 people caught spitting or urinating in public places, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Between Kuwait and Iraq Collapse
With AM-Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with reported Iraqi invasion; UPDATES pvs; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON7
DOC.TEXT: Iraq pulled out of talks Wednesday on a 2-week-old border, oil and money dispute with Kuwait shortly before it reportedly sent its forces to invade the oil-rich neighbor. Kuwaitis tried to fend off the Iraqis with heavy artillery, said Kuwait government officials contacted by telephone from Bahrain said. Iraq had no immediate comment. Earlier in the day, Kuwait, faced with the buildup of an estimated 100,000 Iraq troops at its border, had tried to give a new impetus to talks. Kuwaiti officials had offered to move negotiations to either of their capitals. Izzat Ibrahim, deputy chairman of Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council, left the Saudi summer capital early Wednesday without holding a scheduled second round of talks with Kuwait's Crown Prince and prime minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah. He gave no explanation for his abrupt departure. In Baghdad, deputy prime minister Sa'doun Hammadi said the two sides failed to reach an agreement because Iraq ``did not see any seriousness by Kuwaiti officials in tackling the major damage inflicted on Iraq due to their recent behavior and stands against Iraq's fundamental interests.'' Hammadi had told the official Iraqi News Agency that the talks would continue as agreed with mediators, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. Ibrahim's sudden departure tensed nerves in the oil-rich Gulf region even before the evasion was reported by Kuwait. Oil executives said the price of oil shot up by 50 cents a barrel. Fahd had arranged for Sheik Saad and Ibrahim to hug and embrace after their arrival in the Saudi summer capital on Tuesday, and feted both delegations at a dinner banquet. Crown Prince Abdullah brought the two sides together for two hours of talks, including a tete-a-tete between the delegation leaders. Sources close to the conference said Iraq maintained a hard-line stance. Baghdad insisted the Jiddah session be a protocol meeting to be followed by a working meeting in Baghdad. The Kuwaiti delegation held extensive talks with the Saudi leadership after the departure of the Iraqis. Before his own departure, Sheik Saad issued a statement affirming his country's faith in continuing the dialogue. Also indicating Kuwaiti acquiescence to Iraq's demand for moving the talks to Baghdad, Sheik Saad said: ``I look forward to continuing the meetings and continuing the negotiations in each of the two sister countries to reach a solution to all issues.'' Conference sources had said the Saudi monarch would try to arrange a summit between Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and Kuwait's emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah to break the deadlock. Saddam began the dispute on July 17 by accusing Kuwait of costing Iraq $14 billion by pumping more oil than the quota assigned to it by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. He said Kuwait stole $2.4 billion in oil from a field along their disputed border and demanded Kuwait write off billions in loans left over from the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Iraq's complaints about the oil glut had seemed appeased by Kuwait's firm pledge to respect the new OPEC production agreement reached last week in Geneva. Kuwait responded to the Iraqi threats by airing its own grievances against Iraq for failing to agree to the demarcation of post-colonial borders. But the country apparently was induced by the Arab mediators to ignore the troop buildup and opt for negotiations. Until the past few days, the Iraqi government media had waged a vitriolic propaganda campaign against Kuwait. Charges included that Kuwait was a stooge of the United States and that the leadership was attempting to destroy Iraq's oil and economic development.

DOC.HEAD: Government Announces S&L `Clearance Sale'
DOC.TEXT: The federal savings and loan bailout agency wants America to know it's ready to deal. Under mounting political pressure to speed the pace of the thrift cleanup, the Resolution Trust Corp. announced a ``clearance sale'' Wednesday, aimed at unloading $50 billion in assets from failed S&Ls. L. William Seidman, chairman of the agency, called it an ambitious goal that, if met, would ``move the process along in a really expeditious way.'' But Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a House Banking task force on the bailout, said he wasn't impressed by the sales push, given the huge task ahead. ``If you set low expectations, maybe you'll achieve them,'' Vento said. ``It seems to me they're drowning in the job.'' However, Seidman said, ``The RTC operation is a complicated and difficult job. It has taken us a little time to get organized. We are organized now and we are under way.'' In another S&L development, the General Accounting Office, Congress' auditing and investigative agency, told the Senate Banking Committee that it sees ``strong indications'' the Justice Department is gearing up to go after S&L criminals. However, it said it is too early to determine if the effort will be enough. The GAO said the Justice Department needs to devise a better system to allow top officials in Washington to track the progress of the fraud fight in regional U.S. attorney and FBI offices. What Seidman dubbed ``the great fall inventory clearance sale'' marks the second phase of his agency's cleanup effort. In the first phase, called ``Operation Clean Sweep,'' the RTC concentrated on selling the failed institutions and their deposits. But it ended up keeping a large share of the failed thrifts' sour loans, problem real estate, junk bonds and other assets. Vento and other Democrats in Congress had complained that selling institution franchises represented scant progress unless accompanied by substantial asset sales. Phase 2 is aimed at whittling the RTC's inventory. Sales proceeds will offset what the agency has spent to pay off depositors or to entice private investors into taking over insolvent institutions. ``The bottom line is the better job we do, the less the taxpayer has to pay,'' Seidman said. Among the sales techniques employed will be an international satellite auction of 71 major properties, ``bulk sales'' of packages of similar properties and the use of 15 special sales offices stretching from King of Prussia, Pa., to Costa Mesa, Calif. The satellite auction is scheduled for Nov. 15 in Dallas. Bidders in nine other U.S. cities and London and Tokyo will be able to participate via satellite television hookup. The other U.S. cities are Chicago, Denver, Houston, Los Angeles, Miami, New Orleans, New York, Phoenix and San Antonio, Texas. Seventy-one properties, valued at $300 million, will be offered: 38 in Texas, 12 in Florida, eight in Colorado, six in Arizona, four in California, two in Louisiana and one in Illinois. They range from Kings Crossing Golf Course & Club in Corpus Christi, Texas, to the opulent Western Savings Corporate Center in Phoenix. Two bulk sales _ one of hotel properties in the East, another of apartments in Florida _ will be ready to go by the end of August. In all, the RTC plans by Dec. 31 to sell $13.7 billion in assets left over from previous S&L sales: $6.7 billion in single-family mortgages, $3.3 billion in securities, $1.6 billion in real estate and $2.1 billion in other assets. It plans to get rid of an additional $36 billion in assets either by selling them directly from failed but still-operating thrifts in its control or by selling the assets when it sells the institutions. Also, an estimated $30 billion in assets will be put under the management of 200 to 300 private contractors. The RTC by June 30 had seized 454 failed thrifts, ``resolving'' 207 of them. It plans to resolve an additional 130 by the end of the year _ 77 in the July-September quarter and 53 in the October-December period _ leaving it with 117 institutions. However, Seidman cautioned that the cleanup would not be even half finished. Officials expect at least 250 more failures and possibly as many as 450. Seidman warned, as he has previously, that the RTC's plans depend on Congress providing new money for the bailout in September.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Kuwait:

LAND _ Kuwait, which has 6,880 square miles, is bordered by Iraq to the north and west, Saudi Arabia to the south-southwest, and the Persian Gulf to the east. The oil-rich country is flat and very dry. The nation gets an average of 5 inches of rain a year.

PEOPLE _ About one-quarter of Kuwait's 1.7 million residents live in the capital of Kuwait city and its suburbs. More than half are foreigners, mainly Arab, including 300,000 Palestinians. Most Kuwaitis are Sunni Moslem, but 30 percent adhere to the rival Shiite sect. Shiites of Iranian descent number nearly 150,000. The al-Sabah clan has ruled Kuwait as an emirate since they settled there in 1756 after trekking from the Arabian hinterland. More than 70 percent of the people speak Arabic, the official language, while 10 percent speak Kurdish and 4 percent Iranian (Farsi). A constitutional monarchy rules the country.

ECONOMY _ Oil is the chief resource of Kuwait, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Only 1 percent of the land is cultivated. Per capita income in 1986 was $13,890. Oil revenue reached $30 billion in 1983, but has been declining since because of a drop in oil, prices and production curbs. Kuwait currently produces about 1.5 million barrels of oil a day and has reserves of 89.7 billion barrels, 12.8 percent of world reserves and enough to last for more than 250 years. Little grows in the desert climate, so the emirate has to import nearly all its food.

HISTORY _ The Mongols, Arab caliphs and Ottomans were in turn overlords of the bleak and largely unpopulated land until 1899, when the British became the dominant power in the region. Kuwait gained its independence in 1961. It is a member of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council, a defense and economic alliance.

DOC.HEAD: Research Suggests Gene Can Lead to Early Cancer for Smokers
DOC.TEXT: Smokers carrying a still-unidentified gene are more likely to develop lung cancer at an early age, according to a study that traced smoking and lung cancer histories in 337 Louisiana families. The study, published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute on Wednesday, said there was a clear genetic component to the early onset of lung cancer among smokers. However, it said the gene plays a lesser role in cancer among smokers late in life. ``If you smoke long enough, it'll get to you eventually, regardless of what genes you are carrying,'' said Thomas A. Sellers, a University of Minnesota scientist who was the lead researcher in the study. ``The genetic component influences the age of onset of the disease.'' He said that statistically, about 27 percent of the smoking population will get lung cancer over a lifetime. But in Sellers' study of lung cancer and smoking in the Louisiana families there was a clear indication that some were more likely to get lung cancer at an early age. The pattern, he said, was suggestive of an inherited gene that leads to an earlier onset of the disease. The study involved white families of about the same economic status, Sellers said. The study gathered data through interviews of family members and took into account the amount of smoking of those with lung cancer. Sellers said the statistical model derived from the study shows that the influence of both smoking and the gene would result in 70.6 cases of lung cancer per 100,000 people at age 50. Cases attributable to smoking alone, when the gene is not present, would be about 46.7 per 100,000, and cases due solely to the gene would be about 46.4 per 100,000, he said. As the population ages, however, the effects of the gene shrink while the influence of smoking alone goes up. At age 60, Sellers said, there would be 330 cases per 100,000 due to the interaction of the gene and smoking, with 473 cases attributed to smoking alone and 116 to the gene alone. At age 70, said Sellers, the vast majority of lung cancers among smokers must be attributed to smoking alone. He said the cases resulting from an interaction of the gene and smoking would be about 498 per 100,000, while the number attributable to smoking alone would be 2,776 per 100,000. Cases among non-smoking carriers of the gene would be 359 per 100,000. The study said the suggested gene, interacting with tobacco smoke, would account for 69 percent of the lung cancer cases among 50-year-old smokers; 47 percent among smokers aged 60, and only 22 percent among those still smoking at age 70. ``We're reasonably confident that there is a gene involved here,'' said Sellers, but identifying the gene will require sophisticated genetic studies of blood samples. He researchers now are collecting those blood samples. In a Journal editorial commenting on the study, George E. Bonney, an epidemiologist at Howard University Cancer Center in Washington, said the study was so large and the observed genetic effect ``appears so strong'' that the conclusion about genes influencing the early onset of lung cancer among smokers ``is unlikely to be false.'' The National Cancer Institute, which publishes the journal, is one of the government's National Institutes of Health. Studies in the journal are evaluated by experts in the appropriate academic fields before the work is published.

DOC.TEXT: Johnny Carson didn't monkey around when a zoo in his native Nebraska needed help. He donated $55,000 to give Reuben the chimp new digs. Northeast Nebraska Zoo has only one chimpanzee, but the donation from ``The Tonight Show'' host may be enough to acquire a female companion for Reuben as well as build a permanent primate exhibit, zoo officials said. The 7-year-old chimp is housed in a fortified mobile home at the zoo in rural Royal, near Carson's hometown of Norfolk, but the monkey has grown too strong for his quarters. Construction should begin next week on a new enclosure.

Introducing Evan James Springsteen _ the Boss' firstborn. Bruce Springsteen's girlfriend and backup singer, Patty Scialfa, gave birth to the boy July 25 at Cedar-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. But it wasn't until Wednesday that the rock singer's spokeswoman announced the baby's name. Evan James weighed in at 7 pounds, 11 ounces, publicist Marilyn Laverty said. Ms. Scialfa, 36, joined Springsteen's E Street Band in 1984. Springsteen, 40, was born and raised in New Jersey and has a home in Rumson.

The casting call's gone out for parts in a movie starring Edward James Olmos. Filming for the baseball movie, tentatively called ``A Talent for the Game,'' begins here and in two other Idaho spots later this month. Paramount Pictures' auditions today and Friday are for local actors who want to be extras or take on a few speaking roles, said casting agent Tamara Thomson. Olmos portrayed teacher Jaime Escalante in the movie ``Stand and Deliver'' and played taciturn Lt. Castillo on ``Miami Vice.''

The first episode of Roseanne Barr's show since she butchered the national anthem had an 11 percent smaller audience than the week before. Tuesday's episode of ``Roseanne'' was a rerun. Larry Hyams, ABC director of prime-time audience research, on Wednesday blamed the drop of nearly 1.5 million homes more on strong CBS competition _ an installment of the 1987 miniseries ``Murder Ordained'' _ than to viewer backlash. The Nielsen ratings for NBC's competing series ``In the Heat of the Night'' also were down from the previous Tuesday, he said. Barr's antics at a San Diego Padres baseball game last week included grabbing her crotch and spitting on the ground. She drew the wrath of baseball fans and President Bush alike. Barr later apologized.

Princess Anne's work for poor children around the globe has earned her a Nobel Peace Prize nomination. President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia said Wednesday he nominated the 39-year-old daughter of Queen Elizabeth II. She has traveled to 26 countries in Asia, Africa, Latin America and the Middle East since she became president of the Save the Children Fund 20 years ago. ``She loves people,'' Kaunda said in a BBC interview. ``She has extended that love to working for helpless children in many parts of the world. That is love in action.''

BAGHDAD: was overthrown.
DOC.TEXT: The council headed by Saddam, in power since 1979, issued a statement saying Iraqi troops crossed the border in response to a request from the revolutionary government in Kuwait. ``Iraq has responded to the request from interim government of free Kuwait and decided to cooperate with it,'' the statement said. It said the troops were in Kuwait to defend the revolution and the Kuwaiti people. There was no further identification of the revolutionary government. Iraq warned that any foreign troops trying to interfere with its actions would be attacked. There was no immediate report on casualties. ``Our armed forces will close in an iron rank against those who try to challenge us and will make Iraq and Kuwait a grave yard for those who launch any aggression,'' the Iraqi statement said. It addeed that Iraq would withdraw its forces within days or weeks depending on how fast the situation stabilized. The council announced a state of emergency and mass mobilization in Iraq itself. The official radio started playing martial music. Iraq and Kuwait are OPEC partners but have had a long dispute over their common border and oil revenues from a dispute oilfield.

DOC.HEAD: Government Opens New Investigation into Murder of Solidarity Priest
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Ministry has launched a new investigation into the 1984 police killing of a pro-Solidarity priest to determine if higher-ups of the former Communist government were involved. A new inquiry into the slaying of Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko officially was opened July 24, the Justice Ministry said Tuesday in a statement to the official PAP news agency. The murder of the popular priest shocked the nation, which last year elected a Solidarity-led government to replace the Communists. Popieluszko's sermons counseling perseverance after the imposition of martial law in 1981 to crush Solidarity had drawn tens of thousands of people and made him a national symbol of resistance to authoritarian Communist rule. Four Security Service officers were convicted in a hastily held trial of abducting, beating and drowning Popieluszko in October 1984, but Communist prosecutors at the time said there was no evidence of higher involvement. However, the convicted ringleader of the killers, Capt. Grzegorz Piotrowski, hinted in a letter to former Interior Minister Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak made public last month that the killing had been carried out with the knowledge of superiors. The opening of the new inquiry comes only three weeks after the resignation of Kiszczak, who as head of the Interior Ministry was in charge of the Security Service at the time of the Popieluszko killing. The Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki now has a civilian in charge of the Interior Ministry who is systematically scouring the department and replacing personnel.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Backs `Orderly' Force Reduction
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Bush departs for Aspen at 10 a.m. EDT, arrives 1:40 p.m. EDT, meets Thatcher at 2:30 p.m. EDT; will be led
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, proposing an orderly, long-term reduction in the nation's military arsenal, is backing a 25 percent cut in the armed forces by the mid-1990s, administration and Pentagon sources say. Bush was slated to make the proposal in a speech today in Aspen, Colo., as his $307 billion defense budget for fiscal 1991 has come under severe attack on Capitol Hill. ``The president will lay out the broad outlines of his new strategy for the nation's defenses and how our military must respond, based on the changes in the world that have occurred,'' said a senior administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In a speech to the Aspen Institute, Bush planned to offer support for two hotly debated weapons programs _ the B-2 stealth bomber and the Strategic Defense Initiative _ and support a 25 percent cut in the armed forces by the end of 1995, the source said. A similar cut in the nation's arsenal of troops and weapons was laid out by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney as an option for budget negotiators in June, but it was derided as ``overly cautious'' by critics seeking additional budget savings. Bush planned to make the address after conferring with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Aspen. It will be the fourth time Bush and Mrs. Thatcher have met in as many months. Bush's speech comes two days after the House Armed Services Committee cut $24 billion from the $307 billion the president had requested for defense spending in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The panel voted to halt production of the B-2 bomber and slashed almost $2 billion from Bush's request of $4.7 billion from the anti-missile Strategic Defense Initiative, commonly known as Star Wars. It also cut military personnel by 129,500 and scaled back on two nuclear missile programs. In June, Cheney said a 25 percent force reduction could save $8.6 billion over five years as the Pentagon retired six active duty Army divisions, 111 Navy ships and 11 Air Force tactical fighter wings, and removed 442,000 men and women from the military's 2.1-million-member active duty ranks. Appearing Wednesday evening on public television's ``MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour,'' the defense secretary hinted that even more changes could be in store. He said he had ``new base closings'' to announce, possibly as early as next week. But Cheney also complained that while the House wanted him to cut personnel, members were balking at closing unneeded bases. Bush said on July 20 at a Strategic Air Command base in Cheyenne, Wyo., that, ``We must have an orderly build-down, not some kind of a fire sale'' in defense. He indicated then that he could live with the $18 billion that the Senate Armed Services Committee voted to cut from his defense budget, but he implored Congress to ``hold the line at (that) already painful reduction.'' The senior American official said the president's remarks would follow along the lines of those made by Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Both have called repeatedly for an orderly, planned reduction in troop strength so that the all-volunteer force is not gutted and morale destroyed. Powell has ordered a study to assess the ``base line force'' that the nation needs to be a superpower, another source said. Mrs. Thatcher is scheduled to address the closing session of the Aspen Institute conference on Sunday. Like Bush, she is under pressure at home to deliver a peace dividend reflecting the changing face of Europe and reduced East-West tensions. While the United States grapples with how to reduce the Pentagon budget, Mrs. Thatcher's defense secretary, Tom King, announced plans last week to reduce the size of the British army by 25 percent over five to seven years and cut its forces in West Germany in half. King also outlined cuts in the British air force and navy but said Britain would retain its nuclear arsenal. Cheney was flying separately to Aspen to attend the symposium at the non-profit institute, marking its 40th anniversary of bringing political, business and cultural leaders together to discuss global issues.

DOC.HEAD: House OKs Farm Bill Despite Administration Opposition
DOC.TEXT: The House easily approved a 1990 farm bill that limits subsidies but is faulted by the Bush administration for not achieving enough savings. ``I think the basic skeleton of legislation will stay together,'' Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said Wednesday night after the House's 327-91 vote. ``The main problem is going to be numbers, with the budget summit.'' The administration has threatened a veto if costs in the bill are not decreased. ``The administration wants no program,'' said de la Garza. ``They are trying to use the budget to achieve that end.'' But he said the votes in the House and Senate, where a version of the bill was approved 70-21 last Friday, show strong congressional intent to continue farm support programs. The cost for the price support programs in the bill is between $53 billion and $55 billion over the measure's five-year life, nearly the same as the Senate version. Besides setting subsidy levels for many crops, the legislation establishes programs for agricultural exports, nutrition, conservation, food safety, forestry, research and virtually every other endeavor of the Agriculture Department. Congress writes a new farm bill every five years. The support limits in the House bill represent a critical difference with the Senate measure. De la Garza said he believed they would be retained by the joint conference committee that will create a final version of the legislation. Rep. Edward Madigan of Illinois, ranking Republican on the Agriculture Committee, voted against the bill, saying it would be too costly. He said he thought it more closely resembled the policies of the 1981 law, which led to record spending, than the 1985 law that Congress and the administration said initially would be the 1990 bill's model. Rep. Jerry Huckaby, D-La., an Agriculture Committee member, offered the amendment to the bill that caps subsidy payments. That proposal, approved 375-45, would impose limits of: _$100,000 a year on the total deficiency payments paid to a single farmer. These are the direct subsidies paid when market prices are below a target price established by the government. _$100,000 a year on marketing loans to one farmer. This is the money farmers keep if world prices are less than the government established loan rate paid farmers to cover the cost of planting. _$200,000 a year on all payments to a single farmer. Supporters of Huckaby's amendment fended off a coalition led by Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., who wanted $50,000 limits on the payments and other restrictions. The House also put the honey program on a sliding subsidy scale, going from a maximum $200,000 per producer in 1991 to $100,000 in 1994. The debate over limiting subsidy payments led to angry shouting between members about fiscal responsibility. The most emotional moments, however, came when Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., proposed to cut spending on food stamps and other nutrition programs that were expanded by the bill. That section of the legislation is called the Mickey Leland Domestic Hunger Relief Act, in memory of the Texas congressman killed last August in a plane crash in Ethiopia while visiting refugee camps. Leland chaired the House Select Committee on Hunger. ``I think it's a sad commentary,'' Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said of Frenzel's amendment. ``The costs of this bill are included in the budget resolution and they meet the requirements of the budget resolution,'' said Panetta, who is chairman of the House Budget Committee. ``In the name of Mickey Leland, in the name of the right kind of priorities, in the name of human decency, defeat this amendment.'' The House agreed with Panetta, rejecting the amendment, 336-83. Other amendments added to the House bill Wednesday brought it into conformity with the Senate breakthroughs in food safety and environmental protection. These include a ban on exports of pesticides not allowed for use in the United States and a requirement that farmers keep records of the pesticides they use.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Farm Bill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
The 1990 farm bill approved by the House calls for about $53 billion to $55 billion in spending on crop support programs over the five-year life of the bill. Here, at a glance, are the major provisions and how they compare to the Senate version of the bill.
The bill:
_Freezes target prices at $4 a bushel for wheat; $2.75 a bushel for corn, $2.61 for sorghum; $2.36 for barley; 73 cents a pound for cotton and $$10.71 per hundred pounds for rice. Same as Senate. Oats would be set at $1.55 for 1991, with an increase each year of 10 cents up to a maximum of $1.85. Same as Senate. _Freezes milk prices at $10.10 per hundred pounds. Same as Senate. _Continues the sugar price support at 18 cents a pound. Same as Senate. _Establishes a loan rate for soybeans of $5.25 a bushel, but gives the agriculture secretary the option of making adjustments up or down 5 percent depending on surpluses, though not to exceed $5.40 in 1993. Establishes a marketing loan for soybeans, sunflower seed, canola, flax and safflower. Similar to Senate, though Senate loan rate is $5.50 a bushel. _Limits commodities deficiency payments to $100,000 for a single farmer; marketing loans to $100,000; and total payments to $200,000. Not in Senate bill. _Gives agriculture secretary authority to reduce loan rates on wheat and feed grains by 10 percent if necessary to compete on world market. Senate bill as a provision but it is different. _Establishes grain quality standards. Similar to Senate. _Limits payments to wool and mohair producers to $250,000 a year. Same as Senate. _Puts honey program on a sliding support scale starting at maximum of $200,000 per producer in 1991 to $100,000 in 1994. Senate bill phases out the program. _Establishes expansion of food stamp and other nutrition programs in honor of the late Rep. Mickey Leland, killed last year while on a mission as chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger. Not in the Senate bill. _Prohibits export of pesticides banned from U.S. farm use. Similar to Senate. _Requires farmers to keep records of pesticides they use. Similar to Senate. _Authorizes $40 million annually to be spent over five years to help farmers learn how to use fewer chemicals. Similar to Senate. _Sets the national standard for use of the ``organically grown'' label on food. Similar to Senate. _New protections to wetlands. Similar to Senate.
Major provisions of the Senate bill not in the House version are:
_Reorganization of the crop insurance program. _Public-private partnerships to protect 25 million acres of private forests and aims at protecting another 482 million acres of private forests through conservation easements and other incentives. _A requirement that 20 percent of the money used for agricultural research by 1993 to go toward finding industrial or other non-food uses for farm products.

DOC.HEAD: Interferon Provides First Cure for Hepatitis B
DOC.TEXT: Scientists today reported finding the first treatment capable of relieving and even curing chronic hepatitis B, one of the world's biggest killers. A study in the New England Journal of Medicine indicates that shots of a synthetic form of the natural protein interferon can prevent the virus from destroying the liver in nearly half the people chronically infected. One in 10 victims can be cured, while the drug had no benefits for 60 percent of the 169 people studied in clinical trials, researchers said. Hepatitis B is the chief underlying cause of liver cancer and cirrhosis and the world's ninth-leading cause of death, just behind lung disease and well ahead of AIDS, according to the World Health Organization. An estimated 1 million to 1.5 million people in the United States are long-term carriers of the hepatitis B virus. At least half of them have liver disease. Worldwide, 300 million people, or 5 percent of the world's population, are chronically infected. Until now, there has been no treatment or cure for the virus. ``This is an encouraging result. All of us would feel a lot happier if we had a better treatment. This spurs us on to find that,'' said Dr. Baruch S. Blumberg of the Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia. Blumberg won the Nobel Prize in medicine in 1976 for identifying the virus. The latest research, which involved 169 people at 12 hospitals, confirms several smaller studies suggesting that interferon works. Other studies have also shown that interferon works against hepatitis C, another serious but less common variety of the virus. Although the Food and Drug Administration has not yet recommended interferon for hepatitis B, physicians can use it any way they choose, and Blumberg said some doctors have already begun prescribing it for this disease. Doctors said the latest study is big enough so physicians can use the results to predict how interferon will affect their patients if _ as seems likely _ it becomes the standard medicine for hepatitis B. ``We can be relatively sure what doctors will find in practice: Ten percent will be cured and 40 or 50 percent will be made better and their liver disease will be stopped in its tracks,'' said Dr. Robert P. Perrillo of the St. Louis Veterans Affairs Medical Center, the principal author of the study. He defined a cure as the complete disappearance of the virus. Experts cautioned the treatment should be used only for those with chronic infections who show signs of liver damage. The results were published along with an editorial by Dr. Jay H. Hoofnagle of the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases. ``For now, interferon alpha offers the best hope'' for treating chronic hepatitis B, Hoofnagle wrote. Hepatitis is likely to become the first major use for interferon. Isolating the natural disease-fighting substance was one of the early goals of genetic engineering. In a decade of testing, interferon has turned out to be useful against a variety of diseases, none as common as hepatitis. The FDA has approved use of the drug for hairy-cell leukemia, AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma and genital warts. In hepatitis B, Perrillo said the treatment appears to offer the best chance of a cure if given during the first two years of infection.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-at-a-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Iraq:

LAND _ Iraq, the biblical Mesopotamia, or ``the land between two rivers,'' took its name from ``uruq,'' Arabic for rocks. Present-day Iraq covers 263,090 square miles with mountains in the north and marshy flatlands in the south. The Tigris and Euphrates Rivers converge in the southeast to form the 120-mile waterway known as Shatt-al-Arab that flows into the Persian Gulf. Iraq is bounded by Turkey to the north, Iran to the east, the Persian Gulf to the southeast, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia to the south and Jordan and Syria to the west.

PEOPLE _ A majority of Iraq's 16 million people are Shiite Moslems, but the country is ruled by Sunni Moslems. There are small Christian communities and an enclave in the north where most of the country's rebellious 3.5 million Kurds live. The national language is Arabic, spoken by 81 percent of the population, while another 15 percent speak Kurdish. Baghdad, the capital, has approximately 4.6 million people.

ECONOMY - Iraq has oil reserves of more than 100 billion barrels. The 1980-88 war with Iran sent oil exports plummeting, but the Iraqis built pipelines through neighboring Turkey and Saudi Arabia and production is now back to at least 3 million barrels a day. The war left Iraq with a foreign debt of about $70 billion.

HISTORY - Iraq, part of the Ottoman Empire from the 16th century, was captured by British forces in 1916. In 1921 it became a kingdom under a League of Nations mandate, administered by Britain. Iraq became independent on July 14, 1958, in a coup which established a military-led Council of Sovereignty headed by Gen. Qassim. Qassim was overthrown in 1963 and Gen. Abdul Salam Aref became president, succeeded by his brother, Abdul Rahman Aref, in 1966. In 1968 a successful coup brought by the Ba'th Party placed Gen. Ahmed Al Bakr in power. Saddam Hussein, Bakr's vice president since 1969, became president in 1979 in a peaceful transfer of power. In 1980, Iraq invaded Iran in a territorial dispute over the Shatt-al-Arab waterway that evolved into a nearly eight-year war. A U.N. cease-fire halted the fighting on Aug. 20, 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Charts Detail Alleged Drug Activity by Barry
With PM-Barry Trial Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In the beginning there were the charts _ huge sheets of cardboard resembling the visual aids a teacher uses to hold the class' attention during a complicated lesson. There was the time-line chart, ranging from 1984 to 1990, with bright red and green blocks signifying the months or seasons when various witnesses said they had used drugs with Mayor Marion Barry. There was the lengthy ``Locations'' chart, subdivided into hotels, businesses, private residences, government offices and boats. And there was the ``Drug Activities with Charles Lewis'' chart, neatly broken down by date, place and drug. Barry himself, subdued and somber, sat directly under the Lewis chart during closing arguments in his drug and perjury trial Wednesday. His chin resting in his hand, he listened intently as Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin recapped allegation after allegation of drug use and his own lawyer acknowledged that Barry was a cocaine user. ``The chief executive officer of our city, the chief law enforcement officer of our city ... was using drugs,'' Retchin said emphatically to the jury, her gold earrings glinting and her hand chopping the air. ``There are no saints among us,'' Barry's lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, said later, after the defense had covered up all the charts. The mayor swaggered in Wednesday wearing a bright yellow, red and green kente cloth, an African neck scarf. But he took it off as the jury filed in and the mood in the spare, crowded courtroom turned businesslike. His wife and mother endured the proceedings from the second row. Only 18 tickets were available to the public, and some people came as early as 8 p.m. the night before in hopes of getting one. The passes were distributed amid controversy over who had arrived first. And someone who wasn't fast enough was thwarted trying to enter the courtroom on a forged pass. Those who made it heard some brutally pointed final volleys from Retchin. She called Barry paranoid, compulsive, irresponsible, a liar. She compared him to the hub of a wheel, with spokes pointing to all those who helped him maintain his secret drug habit. She likened him to a child who blurted out a lie _ that he had not given his friend Charles Lewis any drugs. She compared him, finally, to a treacherous general abetting the enemy. ``It was his choice and he could not say no,'' she said. ``The general was working with the other side.'' Mundy, who was finishing his presentation today, maintained the government had not proven its case. But his characterizations of his client were scarcely more flattering than Retchin's. ``We do not intend to indicate or claim that Mr. Barry did not use cocaine,'' he told the jury. ``Nor do we mean to indicate that there was not some kind of conduct that was not popular or not appropriate.'' If Barry was particularly disturbed by any of this, he did not show it by changing his expression. During breaks he casually combed his hair, made a phone call, offered his opinions of the sketches drawn by the front row of courtroom artists. The artists had started the day abuzz over an accusation by the mayor's press secretary that they were deliberately darkening the skin of a government prosecutor _ thus stressing that Barry was being tried by a fellow man and, by implication, undercutting charges that the government was unfairly going after black officials. One artist for a television network contemplated the professional problem of depicting a light-skinned black. ``Maybe I need a new marker,'' she said. ``No one ever noticed this before.''

DOC.HEAD: Number of Single Mothers Grows Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The number of never-married women rearing children on their own increased almost as much in a new two-year survey as it had in the previous seven years, the Census Bureau says. In a biennial report released Wednesday, the bureau and the Department of Health and Human Services said that in 1987 there were 2.6 million never-married women with children under 21 whose fathers were absent from the home. In 1985, the last previous count, the figure was 2 million. In 1983, it was 1.9 million. It was 1.7 million in 1981 and 1.4 million in 1978, when the first survey was made. Although the survey showed that women were doing better than previously at getting child support, those who had never married were faring much more poorly than those who were divorced or separated. The report said support payments received by women with children under 21 in 1987 averaged $2,710, an increase of 16 percent over 1985 after adjusting for inflation. Of mothers who were separated or divorced, 74 percent were getting child support. For those who had never married, the rate was 20 percent. Commenting on the report, Jo Anne B. Barnhart, assistant secretary of health and human services for family support, said, ``We must never lose sight of the fact that both parents have an obligation to financially care for the children they bring into the world.'' HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan said the report ``indicates that progress is being made, but vigorous enforcement of child support laws must continue.'' The report said 9.4 million women age 18 and over were rearing children under 21 whose fathers were not living in the household. This is an increase of 7 percent since 1985. The total amount of child support received in the year was $10 billion, or 69 percent of the total of $14.6 billion due. About one-third of the mothers were living in poverty. The poverty rate for black women was 53 percent, about twice that for white women but about the same as the rate for Hispanics.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Hail End Of Most Censorship Rules
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers that once trumpeted government propaganda have now hailed the end of most censorship rules, even printing the official approval stamp of the censor agency that was once illegal to mention. ``Goodbye, censorship,'' read a headline in Izvestia about the Soviet Union's first press freedom law, which took effect Wednesday and guarantees broad rights for journalists and potential publishers. ``Almost everything was forbidden, even mention of the existence of (the censorship agency) Glavlit itself,'' said Izvestia, the main government newspaper. ``The truth was the main secret.'' Izvestia celebrated the occassion by publishing a photograph of Glavlit's approval stamp on its front page. That minor act of rebellion marked a watershed day in the gradual freeing of speech since Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. ``The press and other mass media are free'' and ``censorship of the mass media is forbidden,'' says the new law passed by the Supreme Soviet legislature in June after months of debate. Editors said in their news pages that the new legal guarantees won't stop attempts at interference overnight. The new law does not abolish Glavlit, which stands for the Main Administration for Safeguarding State Secrets in the Press. Glavlit will still have the power to censor articles construed as calling for the violent overthrow of the government, promoting racial or religious intolerance, or publishing propaganda for war, violence or cruelty. In addition, the shortage of newsprint and its increasing costs could be a major barrier for independent publications. The most daring editors have been pushing the limits of Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness, since he came to power. Tass, the official government news agency, already has a competitor in Interfax, a news service set up by Radio Moscow last year to earn hard currency. Sent to subscribers by facsimile machine, Interfax quickly earned a place on the pages of world newspapers with scoops like Gorbachev's plan to ask the Communist Party to give up its monopoly on power. The government's Novosti press agency chose Wednesday to announce that it is being transformed from a propaganda-publishing institution to an ``information agency,'' albeit one dedicated to reporting on Gorbachev's reform policy, called perestroika. ``It is felt that Tass and the daily newspapers must advise on the events of the day, so we are obligated to integrate more facts'' into our work, said Novosti chairman Albert Vlasov in Izvestia on Wednesday. Just two weeks ago, Gorbachev issued a decree loosening controls on the state television monopoly. Until then, only groups approved by a state committee had access to Soviet television, and as a result the Communist party received large segments of air time. The decree said no one party or group should monopolize air time. Some of the most dramatic changes are in the works at the feisty weekly Moscow News, which is planning to go independent of Novosti, selling stock, ads and subscriptions. Seven years ago, it was a multilingual propaganda sheet, known for articles that claimed 12 million people were starving in the United States. Now its weekly thrust into forbidden territory has made it one of the most popular newspapers in the country. But its faithful readers must crowd around the copies posted on the newspaper's wall in downtown Moscow because it has been barred from selling subscriptions for its Russian-language edition inside the Soviet Union. Editor Yegor Yakovlev announced in this week's edition that the newspaper will ignore the restrictions and start a subscription drive in hopes of earning enough to pay for the additional, extremely scarce newsprint. Tass reported Wednesday that market reforms are bringing an abrupt jump in the price of newsprint and printing services. It predicted that the retail price of most publications will double and that many of them will die off.
