To establish a new publication or news organization, the new law says Soviets need only provide their name, address, frequency of publication, circulation figures and source of financing. Journalists' new rights include the right to attend meetings and be present at the scene of disasters, the right to refuse to prepare reports that go against a journalist's convictions, and the right to hold interviews with officials. They now can withdraw their byline if the contents of a story are distorted by editing.

Here is the text of a statement read by deputy White House press secretary Roman Popadiuk on the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait early Thursday. Popadiuk telephoned the statement to news agencies in a conference call at 1:30 a.m.

National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft has been chairing an interagency task force in the situation room monitoring the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The president was informed of the initial signs of the Iraqi action at approximately 9 p.m. yesterday by National Security Adviser Scowcroft and has been receiving periodic updates since. The United States is deeply concerned about this blatant act of aggression and demands the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of all Iraqi forces. We do not have exact details at this time concerning the extent of the Iraqi action although it is clearly extensive. We have no reports of any harm to American citizens. The State Department is in constant contact with our embassy in Kuwait concerning the status of U.S. citizens. At the urging of Kuwait and the United States, the United Nations Security Council will be meeting early this morning to consider this matter. In addition, we have been informed that the Arab League and the Organization of the Islamic Conference will be convening to review the situation. We are urging the entire international community to condemn this outrageous act of aggression. The United States is reviewing all options in its response to the Iraqi aggression.
Late Wednesday night, Popadiuk read this statement:

The United States strongly condemns the Iraqi military invasion of Kuwait and calls for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of all Iraqi forces. We have conveyed this message to the Iraqi ambassador in Washington and to the Iraqi government through our embassy in Baghdad. We deplore this blatant use of military aggression in violation of the U.N. charter. Together with Kuwait we are calling for an emergency session of the U.N. Security Council.

DOC.HEAD: Senate to Begin Considering Defense Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush-Defense Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is relying on the Senate to salvage his 1991 military budget after the House Armed Services Committee significantly cut the B-2 bomber and the Strategic Defense Initiative. The fate of the stealth aircraft, which at nearly $865 million each is the costliest airplane ever built, was expected to be the first issue today as the Senate begins considering its version of the defense bill. Bush, meanwhile, was expected to use an address today to call for a 25 percent reduction in military forces by the mid-1990s while maintaining support for the B-2 stealth bomber and the anti-missile Strategic Defense Initiative, administration and Pentagon sources said. ``The president wants a rational build-down,'' one source said in advance of Bush's planned speech at the Aspen Institute in Aspen, Colo. Last month, the Senate Armed Services Committee approved a $289 billion defense package that leaves intact the president's request for $4.6 billion for two radar-evading B-2 bombers in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Since the panel's action, congressional support for the planes has continued to diminish, with the latest blow coming Tuesday night when the House Armed Services Committee agreed to halt production at the 15 bombers in development. The House panel also cut $24 billion from Bush's overall request of $307 billion in military spending for fiscal 1991, slashed nearly $2 billion from the budget request of $4.7 billion for the Strategic Defense Initiative, or Star Wars, and reduced military personnel by 129,500. The Senate Armed Services Committee was kinder to Bush's proposal, trimming $1 billion from SDI and cutting active duty troop strength by 100,000 as well as agreeing to the B-2 request. Possible amendments to the defense bill include one from Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the committee, and Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican, to set aside procurement money for the B-2 until critical tests have been completed. That provision may undermine harsher amendments that could come from Republican Sen. William Cohen of Maine and Democratic Sen. Patrick Leahy of Vermont. One amendment from the two B-2 opponents would halt production of the aircraft for one year. Another amendment would allow six planes to be built and the testing program to continue. Privately, lawmakers who oppose the aircraft say they have 40 votes to prevent Bush from building a fleet of 75 aircraft. Recently, Nunn and Warner warned the president that unless he lobbies personally for the aircraft, it will fail in the Senate. But their possible amendment might prevent the B-2 program's demise in the Senate. Other possible amendments include one to reduce funds for the Phase 1 of the SDI program, restore the $1.1 billion that the Senate panel eliminated for the MILSTAR communications satellite program and a provision to cut U.S. troops in South Korea from 45,000 to 30,000. One provision certain to set off a firestorm of protest, and possibly delay completion of the bill, is an amendment to permit abortions at military hospitals abroad. Currently a ban exists on using Defense Department money to pay for abortions, except when the life of the mother is in danger. The ban does not say whether military personnel who pay for the procedure can use government facilities. Sen. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., co-sponsor of the amendment, said in a recent interview that ``enlisted people in the military should not be treated like second-class citizens.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets to End Production of Rail-Based ICBM
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union announced today that it will stop making a rail-based mobile intercontinental ballistic missile, but did not commit itself to removing those already in place. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze made the announcement after two days of talks in this eastern Siberian city with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and before reporters had learned of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Both officials told reporters outside a guest house where they met that their 10 hours of discussions produced no major breakthroughs on what had been expected to be their main focus, the 12-year-old civil war in Afghanistan. But the announcement about the Soviet SS-24 missile indicated they had made some progress on arms control. The meeting, the 11th this year between Baker and Shevardnadze, was the most informal. The diplomats cruised the Angara River and went fishing. Shevardnadze landed a trout, but Baker came away empty-handed. Shevardnadze, standing along with Baker on a patio, said the Soviet military would cease production of the missiles on Jan. 1. He said the Soviet military would continue to deploy until 1991 ``not many'' of the missiles it has already produced. The removal of missiles already in place, he said, was a subject of negotiations between U.S. and Soviet teams in Geneva. According to the 1989 edition of the annual U.S. Defense Department publication ``Soviet Military Power,'' the Soviet Union began deploying the rail-based version of the SS-24 missile in 1987 and had about 58 of them. The SS-24 carries 10 warheads and has a range of abut 6,200 miles. Limits on mobile land-based missiles were one of the outstanding issues in START talks on slashing the superpowers' stockpiles of long-range nuclear weapons. Other bigger sticking points in the negotiations are curbs on modernizing the Soviet Union's biggest strategic missile, the SS-18, and the Backfire bomber, and on transfers of missiles to third countries. Shevardnadze did not say why the Soviet Union was taking the step, but the Kremlin is under pressure to cut its defense budget so it can spend the money on solving chronic economic problems. ``We welcome the announcement,'' Baker said before flying to Mongolia for the last stop on his four-nation Asian tour. He added, however, that ``It doesn't at this point, at least, change our negotiating position in START.'' U.S. officials indicated earlier this year that they might offer to give up plans for a rail-based MX missile if the Soviets give up the SS-24. Baker and Shevardnadze discussed the war in Afghanistan on Wednesday night and this morning, but the Soviet envoy told reporters, ``I cannot say we can report any kind of breakthrough on Afghanistan.'' The Soviets arm the Afghan government, while the Americans supply the guerrillas fighting it with military aid. Baker told reporters there were two main stumbling blocks to a settlement: _The makeup of a commission to ensure ``free and fair'' elections. _Which powers the current government, headed by pro-Soviet President Najibullah, might transfer to an interim government during elections so candidates are ensured a ``fair shake.'' Baker said Soviet and American experts will try to resolve differences over these points when they meet in Washington. He did not say when the meeting would take place. U.S. and Soviet officials reportedly have been working on a plan for Najibullah to hand over some power to a council of Afghan forces as a run-up to a nationwide election. The composition of the council is now in dispute. U.S.-backed Afghan rebels disagree about who should be on the council. Baker alluded to that at the news conference. ``We are moving closer together on Afghanistan. Having said that, I don't think you should take that to mean necessarily that those whose interests we have been allied with in the past are necessarily moving together,'' he said. In three meetings, including one Wednesday night in a river-side fishing lodge in the Siberian wilderness, Baker and Shevardnadze also discussed preparations for a third summit meeting between Bush and Gorbachev. Shevardnadze said not date had been decided for the summit, but that it would be held in Moscow. He also announced that Baker, U.S. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and leading American businessmen would travel to Moscow in September for talks on U.S.-Soviet economic cooperation. Baker indicated this primarily would involve ways of stimulating U.S. business investment in the Soviet Union, in dire need of Western help to cure its ailing economy. A Soviet source said that during their Wednesday morning meeting, Shevardnadze gave Baker a 15-page outline of areas for economic and scientific cooperation. The envoys meet next in Moscow on Sept. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Dealer, Investors, Bankrupt Firms Among Biggest Scofflaws
DOC.TEXT: Most of the 13 million scofflaws who owe a total of $66 billion in federal taxes are ordinary workers and businesses, but the biggest include a drug dealer, some rich oil investors and a half-dozen giant bankrupt companies. The Internal Revenue Service says 21 taxpayers owe more than $50 million apiece, a total of $3.6 billion among them. About 3,300 are responsible for more than $14.5 billion of the agency's accounts receivable. IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee on Wednesday that the agency is making progress in reducing accounts receivable, which are taxes that have been assessed but not paid. He noted, for example, that the IRS this year is collecting $472,000 in delinquencies for each staffer in the collections division, up from $388,000 two years ago. ``At the same time, however, I want to emphasize that we have a long way to go and the task is exceedingly difficult,'' Goldberg said. Making a serious dent in accounts receivable, he said, will require modernization of the agency's 30-year-old computer system, more money for more personnel and training and further simplification of tax laws. Paul L. Posner, associate director of Congress' General Accounting Office, said the IRS is losing the battle because accounts receivable over the past six years grew twice as fast as total tax receipts. Continuation of that trend ``could have a serious negative impact on voluntary taxpayer compliance,'' he said. ``This rapid, out-of-control growth in unpaid taxes threatens to overwhelm the IRS and is absolutely unacceptable,'' said Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee. Accounts receivable grew from $30 billion in 1984 to $66 billion last year. The figure represents a six-year accumulation of income, payroll and other taxes assessed but not paid. It does not include $27 billion that the IRS believes will never be collected because of death, bankruptcy and inability to locate the debtor. Because of errors and duplication, the IRS and GAO agree the $66 billion figure may be exaggerated by as much as 50 percent. Accounts receivable are not the same as the ``tax gap,'' which is the difference in income taxes that are collected and what would be collected if individuals and businesses correctly reported their income and deductions. The gap is expected to be about $100 billion this year alone. Goldberg said 0.25 percent of the accounts receivable cases represent more than 20 percent of delinquent dollars. Other highlights: Six cases totaling $1.4 billion involve bankruptcies; five cases totaling $1.06 billion involve erroneous assessments (IRS made three of the errors and taxpayers made two) and are being closed; one $61 million case is awaiting a court decision; one worth $73 million involves an unidentified drug dealer. Two cases worth $191 million involve a dispute over the now-repealed windfall-profits tax on oil production, and $362 million at stake in two cases likely will never be paid for a variety of reasons, including fraudulent investments. Goldberg said President Bush's IRS budget for next year is a good start toward reducing accounts receivable because it would allow hiring 1,050 new collection personnel. He said a two-year hiring freeze has left the agency is such a state that nearly 800,000 accounts totaling $1.8 billion cannot be worked because of lack of personnel. John Pepping, an IRS collections officer in the Laguna Niguel, Calif., district, said the personnel shortage there is so severe that as a rule, no account under $50,000 is sent to the field for collection. He testified on behalf of the National Treasury Employees Union, which represents most IRS workers.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Charges Said Aimed at Preventing Revelations of Army Trafficking
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Filipino authorities claim that murder charges against three Americans and 13 Filipinos were filed to keep them from exposing narcotics trafficking within the military. On Wednesday, the military charged three Drug Enforcement Administration agents and 13 Filipino policemen with murder in the killings of three soldiers, including two officers, during a reported drug bust last month. In Washington, the acting chief of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Terrence Burke, said the allegations against his men ``have no merit.'' The DEA suggested the charges may have been intended to prevent the three agents from testifying about drug trafficking by Filipino military officials. Today, Epimaco Velasco, the most senior Filipino charged in the incident, resigned as assistant director of the National Bureau of Investigation. He called the allegations ``malicious, unfounded and baseless.'' ``This is a very sad day ... for other peacekeeping and law enforcement people because for performing their duty, this is what they get,'' Velasco said. ``Do you mean to say that if military people are involved, we will just close our eyes and let these things go?'' Brig. Gen. Gerardo Flores, chief of staff of the Philippine Constabulary, filed charges against Philip Needham of the DEA's Bangkok office, Andrew Fenrich, chief of the DEA section in Manila, and DEA agent Jake Fernandez. U.S. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said all three left the country and ``have no plans to return.'' Flores said 10 of the Filipinos were charged before a military court. The Integrated National Police is part of the armed forces. Under Philippine law, prosecutors decide whether to indict those charged by police. The charges stem from a July 10 incident in which Col. Rolando de Guzman, deputy chief of the Northern Luzon Command; his intelligence officer, Maj. Frank Calanog, and another soldier were slain during what police said was a shootout during a drug bust. DEA spokesman Cornelius Dougherty said in Washington that the agency was invited to testify before a commission formed by President Corazon Aquino to investigate allegations of drug trafficking by members of her armed forces. He said Fenrich had planned to testify, but the charges ``rather effectively put the kibosh on any testimony about the facts concerning the armed forces. ... I'm suggesting there's probably a cause-and-effect situation there.'' The National Bureau of Investigation claims de Guzman and the other soldiers tried to sell $10 million worth of heroin to Needham, who was posing as a buyer. Shooting broke out when the three resisted arrest, it claims. U.S. Embassy officials have not commented on the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 30,245.18, down 592.81 points, or 1.92 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: HHS Won't Help Pay Hospital Costs for AIDS Experiments
DOC.TEXT: The same federal department that leads the fight against AIDS refuses to help pay the hospital costs of poor people who receive experimental drugs for AIDS-related infections. That policy of the Department of Health and Human Services blocks treatment of thousands of people whose AIDS-weakened immune systems make them the prey of microbes that most people would only sneeze at, witnesses told a House Government Operations subcommittee Wednesday. HHS also governs the Medicare and Medicaid programs, which refuse to allow reimbursement for experimental treatments, even if those are the only effective ones available for AIDS-related infections. Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, head of AIDS research in HHS, was among the critics of that policy. ``We do not agree from the biomedical, research and health care delivery standpoint with that philosophy,'' said Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases at the National Institutes of Health. Fauci told the subcommittee on human resources and intergovernmental relations that he has brought up the gap in biweekly meetings of the interagency HIV Leadership Group. HIV is the human immunodeficiency virus that causes AIDS. The response within the department is that ``they were very sympathetic with the difficulties this is posing for us in the conduct of our trials, but a solution is not readily at hand,'' Fauci said. He said the problem is an unwillingness to spend more money on reimbursements that are already stretching the government for non-experimental hospitalizations. Hospitalization is required for AIDS patients with opportunistic infections _ those that a person with a normal immune system would resist _ because such infections are usually acute and patients must be monitored around the clock, said Dr. Fred R. Sattler of the University of Southern California's School of Medicine. The hearing was called to examine the status of research into drugs used to prevent or treat opportunistic infections, and the priority given by the NIH to research into those drugs rather than an overall cure for AIDS. The institutes have recently indicated they would spend a larger share on the drugs against opportunistic infections. NIH announced Tuesday that it would give $2.8 million to six teams of scientists for research on such drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Candidates Vie to Lead Alaska Through Expected Oil Bust of 1990s
DOC.TEXT: Alaska's next governor knows that as the flow of Alaskan oil dwindles in the '90s, so will the river of petrodollars that has filled the state treasury for more than a decade. The hard part will be convincing Alaskans that oil's free ride is almost over and that they may have to start paying their own way for state services. And so the nine candidates vying to succeed Democratic Gov. Steve Cowper are skirting specifics about what programs they would cut to deal with the massive deficits forecast for the coming decade. And no candidate has embraced new taxes as a solution. ``It would be suicide for anyone to come out and be very specific about what they would do,'' said Clive Thomas, a political science professor at the University of Alaska Southeast. ``If they did they would not win.'' Part of the problem for the candidates is that many Alaskans have been lulled into a false sense of security about the economy, Thomas said. Employment and wages are up, homes are selling and international trade is growing. ``How do you lead the Alaska public to believe they need to cut back? Basically you're asking them to have a lower standard of living,'' Thomas said. ``That's not going to go down well with people.'' Dave Dittman, an Anchorage pollster, agrees. He said most Alaskans feel they are doing well, and they don't want to hear threatening talk of another oil-related recession. ``They don't want a change. They're not looking for a Moses. They want a guardian, someone who can protect their interests,'' Dittman said. Oil taxes and royalties support 85 percent of the state budget. Alaska has no statewide sales or income taxes. The next governor likely will be forced to propose broad cuts, new taxes or both. Of the nine candidates vying to replace Cowper, who announced in March 1989 that he would not seek a second term, five are considered serious contenders for the Republican and Democratic nominations in the Aug. 28 primary. The frontrunner in the GOP race is state Sen. Arliss Sturgulewski of Anchorage, who lost to Democrat Cowper in 1986. The other main GOP contenders are Jim Campbell, a former Anchorage assemblyman and businessman; and state Sen. Rick Halford, who operates a hunting lodge and flying service. The Democratic race is between former Anchorage Mayor Tony Knowles and Lt. Gov. Stephen McAlpine. So far the differences among the candidates have been less obvious than the similarities. All say they favor environmentally responsible oil exploration and development, and all say Alaska needs to expand its development of other natural resources as well. Their campaign commercials have been full of feel-good images, cliches about leadership and the ``Alaska spirit,'' and little else. ``No one, in my opinion, has really taken anything on,'' Dittman said. ``They're all saying the same thing in a very typical, non-creative manner.'' That may be changing as the primary nears. The Republican contest recently began to heat up when Campbell, in commercials aired in Anchorage and Fairbanks, challenged the legislative records of Sturgulewski and Halford. Many observers expect the Democratic race to heat up as well if McAlpine continues to lag behind Knowles in the polls in the final weeks. The lesser known candidates are Republican Don Wright, a retired construction contractor from Fairbanks making his fourth bid; Democrat Ryal White, an Anchorage construction worker; and Alaska Independence Party candidates John Lindauer of Anchorage and William DeRushe of North Pole. The feisty Campbell is the only candidate who has been moving up significantly in the polls recently. He said he's now aiming primarily at Sturgulewski. Sturgulewski responded quickly to the Campbell commercials, using humor to counter what she saw as a subtle reference to her gender. In one of the Campbell ads, the narrator speaks of the need to maintain state roads and buildings. He concludes: ``Maintenance isn't sexy, it's just wise. You can vote sexy or you can vote wise.'' After responding to Campbell's other charges, the matronly Sturgulewski looks into the camera and says, ``He's even accused me of being sexy. Well, he might be right about that.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Relations With Persian Gulf Countries Often Rocky
With PM-US-Iraq-Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The United States has viewed the oil-rich Persian Gulf region as a vital part of the world since the end of World War II and has deployed a continuous naval presence in the region since the late 1940s. The United States has based its policy in the region on the need to maintain the free flow of oil from Saudi Arabia, with the world's largest proven oil reserves, and Iraq, which ranks second in proven reserves. But U.S. relations with the major powers in the area _ Iraq, Iran and Saudi Arabia _ have often been rocky. With the outbreak of the 1967 Middle East war between Israel and its Arab neighbors, Iraq broke relations with the United States over its support for Israel, and U.S.-Iraqi relations plunged into a deep freeze for more than 15 years. Iraq was placed on a list of countries that support terrorism as the United States accused the Baghdad government of financing Palestinian terrorist movements. The region grew even more vital to this country when the oil-producing Arab countries imposed an embargo against the United States and other Western nations in 1973, sending oil prices soaring and exposing the vulnerability of U.S. consumers to the volatile developments in the Persian Gulf. As relations with Iraq and the other oil producers deteriorated, U.S. links to the government of Iran improved. Iran, too, was rich in oil and the United States could count on steady supplies from the late Shah Reza Pahlavi in return for consistent sales of American weaponry to build up his military forces. Relations with Iran came to an abrupt and tragic end when Moslem Shiite fundamentalists under the spiritual guidance of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini deposed the shah and took over the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, holding more than 50 Americans hostage for 444 days beginning in 1979. With its relations with Baghdad and Tehran mired in hostility, the United States strove to develop good ties with the small monarchies bordering Iran, Iraq and Saudi Arabia. These oil-rich countries, in the shadow of their powerful neighbors, turned to the United States for weapons sales and political support. Their dependence on the United States grew as Iraq became increasingly menacing after it launched its September 1980 war against Iran. Official U.S. policy was to remain neutral in the eight-year war. But in an effort to obtain the release of American hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Moslem extremists, the United States in 1985 began secret arms sales to the Khomeini government. Just before that, the United States and Iraq resumed diplomatic relations, but the United States refused to sell Iraq any weapons. As the war dragged on and both combatants launched a barrage of attacks on oil tankers plying the gulf, the United States spread its protection over Kuwait, agreeing to put U.S. flags on Kuwaiti oil tankers. Ships from the U.S. Seventh Fleet escorted Kuwaiti tankers through the gulf. Although still remaining neutral, the U.S. action was seen as benefiting Iraq because it helped keep open the shipping channel that Iraq needed to get its oil to foreign markets. With the end of the Iran-Iraq war, the United States set about to substantially improve relations with the government of Saddam Hussein, extending credit programs for U.S. farm sales to Iraq. U.S. oil companies sharply increased their purchases from Iraq, providing the Iraqi government with badly needed cash. American businesses pressed the Bush administration to provide additional loan guarantees so they could enjoy an expected boom from Iraq's postwar reconstruction. However, tensions between Washington and Baghdad escalated again earlier this year when U.S. Customs agents, in cooperation with British authorities, intercepted a shipment of devices said to be intended for Iraq's nuclear program. Iraq vehemently denied the allegation, but Congress was skeptical, citing Iraq's continued development of chemical weapons. In recent days both the House and Senate have moved to adopt sanctions against Iraq, even as the administration was considering similar steps of its own.

DOC.HEAD: US Condemns Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait; Is ``Reviewing Options''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs 9th graf: ``The United,'' to point out that Gulf patrols protected Kuwaiti ships
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait early Thursday morning and said it was ``reviewing all options in its response to the Iraqi aggression.'' White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said the United States deplored ``this blatant use of military aggression'' and called for ``the immediate and unconditional withdrawal'' of hostile troops from Kuwait. Popadiuk said national security officials were monitoring the hostilities but had no exact details about the extent of the Iraqi offensive. Iraq claimed in a radio broadcast from Baghdad that it had overthrown the sheikdom. A U.S. official speaking on condition of anonymity said of Iraq's claims, ``We don't think that's the case.'' Nevertheless, this official said Iraqi troops had moved into the capital city in force. ``They seem to have taken over several government buildings,'' the official said. The White House said it had no reports of harm to Americans. The United States has extensive business ties to Kuwait, and the State Department said 3,800 Americans were believed to be in Kuwait at the time of the invasion. The U.S. Embassy in Kuwait has a staff of about 80, half of them military. ``The United States is deeply concerned about this blatant act of aggression and demands the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of all Iraqi forces. We are urging the entire international community to condemn this outrageous act of aggression,'' Popadiuk said in a statement read to news organizations in a 1:30 a.m. conference call. In addition, the spokesman said the administration was ``reviewing all options in its response to the Iraqi aggression.'' The United States, whose Persian Gulf naval patrols protecting U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tankers helped Iraq defeat Iran in the 1980-1988 war, has six warships in the area. They have been conducting exercises since July 24 with forces of the United Arab Emirates, some 700 miles southeast of Kuwait. The naval force includes four frigates, one destroyer and the command ship USS La Salle. Two KC-135 aerial refueling tankers also have been taking part in the exercises. The nearest aircraft carrier battle group, the most powerful naval force in the fleet, is headed by the carrier USS Independence somewhere in the Indian Ocean. That could be about 800 miles from Kuwait, where the gulf opens into the Indian Ocean at the Straits of Hormuz _ or it could be many thousands of miles away. Pentagon officials declined to identify the carrier's whereabouts. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft was chairing a hastily assembled task force in the White House situation room, Popadiuk said. President Bush was informed of the invasion about 9 p.m. Wednesday. A State Department official said the department had received reports of gunfire in the heart of Kuwait city, which sits on the gulf, and there appeared to be ``some penetration'' into the heart of the country. Popadiuk said the White House delivered its message to the Iraqi ambassador in Washington and to the Iraqi government through the U.S. embassy in Baghdad. The Kuwaiti embassy in Washington confirmed Iraq had launched an offensive. Faleh Bader, director of the ambassador's office, said, ``We confirm there is an offensive at Kuwait border and we have no comment.'' The attack started about midnight, Kuwaiti time (5 p.m. EDT), Bader said. Hours before the attack, Iraq's ambassador, Mohamed Al-Mashat, was summoned to the State Department for a meeting with Assistant Secretary John Kelly. Kelly repeated to the Iraqi envoy the U.S. desire for a peaceful solution to the tensions with Kuwait and urged Iraq to respect to sovereignty of all nations in the region. Kelly told a House subcommittee Tuesday that while the United States has no treaty obligations that would mandate military support for Kuwait, the United States does believe strongly in respect for territories of all states in the region. Congress has been pressuring Bush to impose new sanctions on Iraq over its belligerent moves toward Mideast neighbors. On Wednesday, the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved by voice vote a bill seeking an end to Iraq's $200 million line of credit through the Export-Import Bank. The measure also requires the United States to vote against any loan sought by Iraq from international institutions like the World Bank. It also would force any U.S. exporter wishing to sell items to Iraq to first prove that they will not be used to develop chemical or biological weapons or ballistic missiles, or to enhance Iraq's ability to support terrorism. The bill's author, Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., said the United States must register its disapproval of Iraq's aggression. ``The lesson of Iraq is clear,'' Berman said. ``You win nothing by appeasing a bully. He merely becomes a bolder and more dangerous bully.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said late Wednesday night that the Iraqi offensive ``shows that dangers in that part of the world are becoming more than just dangers and actual war.'' Last week, similar sanctions were added to the 1990 farm bill during House and Senate floor consideration. Those sanctions included an end to U.S. loan guarantees under which Iraq now can buy up to $1 billion a year in agricultural commodities. Iraq had moved about 100,000 troops to its border with Kuwait after claiming that Kuwait's production of oil beyond quotas of the OPEC cartel had depressed the world price, thus diminishing Iraq's revenue, and that Kuwait had been stealing oil from a field that straddles the border. Iraqi officials on Wednesday walked out on talks in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia aimed at resolving the 2-week-old crisis and complained that Kuwait was not negotiating seriously. Iraq threatened to invade once before, in 1961 after Britain ended its protectorate over Kuwait. Iraq then claimed Kuwait as part of its territory, but the appearance on the Kuwaiti side of the border of troops from Britain and other Arab states deterred further action by Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Senate OKs Limits on Campaign Spending
With PM-Campaign Finance-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Congress, responding to a spate of ethics scandals, is taking its first step toward curtailing lawmakers' ``money chase'' for campaign funds as senators also vote to quit accepting outside speaking fees. The Senate's Democratic majority overrode Republican opposition Wednesday night to approve the first change in federal election laws since Congress voted 16 years ago to publicly finance and limit spending on presidential elections in wake of the Watergate scandal. On a 59-40, largely party-line vote, the Senate approved a campaign finance bill to place similar limits on congressional candidates' spending, provide them with subsidies to buy television advertising and outlaw special-interest political action committees. ``We have a system out of control,'' said Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., the bill's chief author. ``The money chase has not slowed down.'' House leaders hope to take up similar legislation Friday before Congress begins a five-week vacation _ but without the ban on political action committees, or PACs, that grew up after the 1974 law. Such committees contributed nearly one-fourth of the $185 million spent on Senate races and 45 percent of the money spent by House winners in the 1988 election. Outnumbered Republicans, vehemently opposed to spending ceilings and any form of public financing, said President Bush would veto the Senate version. But leaders in both parties expressed some hope that a spotlight on the fall election might force the White House into negotiations when lawmakers return in September. ``The issue is going to get hotter, hotter and hotter as we move toward November,'' said Boren. ``If I were president, I would want to find a compromise for the members in my party before the election.'' Boren said the bill contains several measures that Bush said must be part of any reform package: outlawing PACs, an end to honoraria for speeches and a ban on incumbents' use of franking privileges to mail newsletters at government expense to voters in election years. Nonetheless, Senate GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas complained that the bill ``only reforms Republicans'' by limiting how much money can be spent by candidates and their fund-raising national and state party organizations, where the GOP excels. Untouched by the bill, Republicans complained, is the millions of dollars in their members' dues that unions spend on voter registration and turnout, 90 percent of it in favor of Democrats. ``In my view, the die is cast on this bill,'' Dole said. ``It seems not possible, but it may be possible yet to arrive at a bill a great majority could support. Maybe something will come out of all of this.'' Possible areas of compromise, according to congressional sources, include uncapping how much candidates could raise in small amounts from in-state donors, making unions disclose more of what they spend on politics and reducing the impact of PACs without outlawing them. Five Republicans _ one of them just disciplined and another under investigation in ethics cases _ joined 54 Democrats in favor of the bill. The only Democrat to oppose it was South Carolina Sen. Ernest Hollings, who argues that anything short of a constitutional amendment will fail to stem the influence of money in politics. The Republican supporters were Sens. John McCain of Arizona, James Jeffords of Vermont, William Cohen of Maine, David Durenberger of Minnesota and Larry Pressler of South Dakota. Durenberger was denounced by his colleagues on a 96-0 vote last week for violating Senate rules by skirting the current limits on honoraria through a book publishing deal. McCain _ along with four Democrats _ is among the ``Keating Five'' senators now under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for interceding with savings and loan regulators on behalf of Lincoln Savings & Loan Association. The regulators now claim that the collapse of the thrift last year will cost taxpayers up to $2 billion. Its principal owner, Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating Jr., had contributed a total of $1.3 billion to the five senators' campaign efforts. The bill aims to close loopholes in the 1974 law that allowed Keating and other executives to ``bundle'' contributions from their employees and present them to candidates. By limiting for the first time how much state parties can spend on elections, it also would effectively stop the use of those organizations by wealthy contributors to funnel gifts in blocks of $100,000 to presidential campaigns. Both Bush and Democratic presidential candidate Michael Dukakis received millions of dollars in 1988 through such back-door ``soft money'' contributions not subject to Federal Election Commission reporting requirements.

DOC.HEAD: Would-be Cowboys: No Home on the Range
DOC.TEXT: Inspired by Hollywood Westerns, many Europeans want to come to Wyoming and become cowboys. Most are plum out of luck, pardner. Unless they have guaranteed job offers, there is no home on the range for them. News reports earlier this year about a shortage of experienced ranch hands whipped up a stampede of inquiries from would-be cowboys in East Germany, Britain, Czechoslovakia, Australia and Canada, state and private agencies say. Steffaen Petry, 22, was one of two East Germans to make his way to Wyoming recently in search of ranch work. ``From the time I was very little, I wanted to be a cowboy,'' he said through an interpreter last month. ``From a little boy, I knew about John Wayne.'' But both he and his countryman were turned down for lack of experience and work papers, said Oralia Mercado, executive director of Mountain Plains, a Casper organization that helps ranchers find experienced hands. ``I've been getting a lot of calls,'' Mercado said Tuesday. ``Initially, it was five to 10 calls every half hour. One whole day, that's all I did.'' Foreigners looking for employment in the United States cannot get a work visa without an American sponsor and a guaranteed job offer. And getting a offer to work as a ranch hand isn't easy for a European tenderfoot. Wyoming ranchers occasionally sponsor workers from Mexico and Peru, where ranches are similar, with lots of wide open space for grazing.But ranches in Europe don't offer experience that is practical in Wyoming, Mercado said. ``Germany does not have a lot of land where they graze animals,'' she said. ``They have lot of pastures and farms and that will not qualify them for the type of work we are dealing with.'' Petry spoke only one word of English _ ``cowboy'' _ when he arrived at the Cheyenne airport in July. With help from an airport maintenance worker and state officials he was taken in by rancher Sloan Hale, who speaks German. For several weeks, Petry pulled weeds and planted trees on Hale's ranch in Cheyenne, but Hale needed no permanent help and Petry had to leave the state. Petry had sold all his possessions to get to Wyoming. He was released last December from an East German prison after two years behind bars for trying to escape to the West. ``Not until I am a real cowboy, after I work for a year as a cowboy, will I wear a cowboy hat,'' he said. ``Then I will be a real cowboy.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Tell Supreme Court Nominee He'll be Questioned Closely
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Key senators promise to question David H. Souter closely on controversial issues, and the Supreme Court nominee says he will be ready to respond when his confirmation hearings begin next month. As he made his get-acquainted rounds on Capitol Hill, the reserved federal judge from New Hampshire said Wednesday he is looking forward to the start of the hearings Sept. 13. He suggested that his appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee will end his string of ``no comments.'' ``It's going to destroy my reputation for not saying much,'' he said. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., said he was favorably impressed after meeting Souter. But Kennedy, a leading liberal, said Souter's apparent opposition to some forms of affirmative action ``concerns me,'' and he indicated he would question him on the issue at the confirmation hearings. ``Those will be certainly matters that will be brought up,'' Kennedy said. ``The judge knows there will be a full and complete hearing, a wide variety of different areas that are going to be covered. I think that's what the Constitution requires.'' In a 1976 commencement speech, Souter used the term ``affirmative discrimination'' in describing federal programs that give special preferences to minorities. Souter also visited Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., who said afterward the nominee told him he ``would be prepared to answer questions on the issue of the right of privacy.'' ``I don't think you ought to ask him would you reverse Roe vs. Wade,'' the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion, Heflin said. ``But I think you will find there are legitimate areas of inquiry that will be raised.'' Souter let others do the talking on the latest potentially controversial issue to surface _ a legal brief he submitted to the Supreme Court in a civil rights dispute 14 years ago. Souter was New Hampshire's attorney general in 1976, working for arch-conservative Gov. Meldrim Thomson, when the state opposed a federal regulation requiring states to submit racial breakdowns of their employees. The regulation ``proceeds from the cynical assumption that the fairest employer cannot be trusted any more than the most biased. And it ends in treating every employer as if he were a suspected bigot and lawbreaker,'' the brief said. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission rule requires states to submit a racial breakdown of employees as a means of assuring equal opportunity for minorities. New Hampshire was the only state that challenged the regulation. The state's position was defended Wednesday by Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., a leading supporter of Souter's nomination. Rudman said the EEOC case originated while he was New Hampshire's attorney general and continued under Souter. ``We felt strongly that the federal government had no right to impose those rules on sovereign states. We didn't have a problem defending the state,'' Rudman said. He added he still believes ``the federal government is guilty of unwarranted intrusion.'' In the 1976 case, a federal judge ordered New Hampshire to abide by the EEOC rule. The 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, on which Souter now sits, upheld the judge's ruling. Souter, as state attorney general, then asked the Supreme Court to declare the federal regulation unconstitutional. The brief he signed said the rule requires states to ``become color-conscious rather than colorblind'' and could lead to racial quotas. ``Quotas are an impermissible end. And accordingly so too should be the means to that end,'' it said. The brief also said the regulation violates the rights of each worker to be free ``from having his or her own skin color eyeballed, recorded and reported.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Warn That GOP Attacks Will Hinder Budget Work
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats are warning President Bush and Republican leaders that fingerpointing over the budget stalemate will only jeopardize efforts to forge a deficit-reduction agreement in September. Serious budget bargaining is on hold until Congress returns from its month-long August recess. Republicans promised on Wednesday to spend the break telling the public that Democrats had dragged the talks to a standstill by refusing to advance a proposal of their own. ``We'll let the American people judge for themselves on this issue,'' White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said, shortly after Bush held a budget strategy session with 150 congressional Republicans. ``I'll just explain to my people, objectively, that we produced a plan pursuant to an agreement, we were ready to put it on the table, but the Democrats didn't,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee. Democrats countered that with the two parties trying to develop a schedule for reaching a deal in September, partisanship would not help. ``If they launch a full-scale partisan attack, they're risking a long-term agreement for a very short-term political gain,'' said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. ``This problem is much too serious to see who can make some clever accusation,'' said Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. The talks have barely budged during their 12 weeks, even as the Oct. 1 start of the 1991 fiscal year has drawn closer. The budget deficit for 1991 is projected at $169 billion, not including the cost of rescuing the nation's savings and loan industry. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law will impose devastating spending cuts of more than $100 billion in October unless a budget deal is reached. But the bargaining ground to a halt after an administration proposal to save $54 billion was floated last week. Higher taxes on beer and wine and a limit on the deductions allowed for state and local income taxes were mentioned as revenue sources. Angry Republicans have demanded that Democrats produce a plan of their own. Unless a plan is produced, Bush promised to veto spending bills he considered too expensive, and leave the Gramm-Rudman cuts intact. But Democrats have countered that with recess approaching, a package announced now would simply draw criticism for a month and prove of little value. ``The argument about laying down a plan right now frankly is more of an argument that says, `We'd like to have Democrats bleed a little bit because we bled,''' said Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee. Negotiators said that when bargaining resumes in September, they may seek a secluded retreat where they can do their work uninterrupted. Bentsen said a plantation on Maryland's Eastern Shore is a possibility. Participants said White House budget director Richard Darman wants the talks to proceed at Camp David, the presidential retreat in western Maryland. But Democrats fear Camp David would be too small to accommodate staff aides.

DOC.HEAD: Accord Reached on Access to Japanese Telecommunications Market
DOC.TEXT: A new U.S.-Japanese agreement resolves a contentious trade dispute over barriers that have blocked American and other foreign companies from the lucrative Japanese telecommunications market. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills announced the accord late Wednesday, hailing it as ``an important step towards giving U.S. firms in Japan access comparable to the access Japanese firms enjoy in the United States.'' The settlement ended four months of bargaining over U.S. demands for greater access to the Japanese market. Negotiators had been holding marathon talks in Tokyo over the past two weeks trying to meet a Wednesday deadline. Had the discussions failed to resolve the dispute, the United States could have retaliated by imposing higher tariffs on Japanese products. While the exact language of the agreement was still being reviewed by both sides, U.S. officials expressed satisfaction that their major demands had been met. Hills said the Japanese had agreed to remove barriers blocking U.S. companies from offering telephone services, such as voice mail and electronic banking. The agreement also removed barriers preventing the sale directly to customers of a type of telephone device known as network channel terminating equipment. This device allows signals from business equipment such as computers to be transmitted over telephone lines. The potential Japanese market in the two areas was estimated to be more than $3 billion annually. U.S. companies hope to gain a significant portion of the market because of their wide lead in many telecommunications fields. ``We are significantly ahead of the Japanese in experience and efficiency in providing these services. Given the significant lowering of bureaucratic obstacles, we are going to do pretty well,'' said one U.S. trade official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Both sides were negotiating under the Aug. 1 deadline set last March 30 for resolving the dispute. Without an agreement, Hills was authorized to begin a process that could have resulted in economic retaliation against Japanese products sold in this country equal to the amount of estimated lost sales facing American firms. Telecommunications has been a major source of trade tension between the United States and Japan. The 1988 U.S. trade act requires an annual review of all trade agreements in this area and allows for retaliation if the United States finds the Japanese are not living up to prior agreements. Last year, the United States threatened to impose tariffs on Japanese imports unless the Tokyo government changed regulations affecting the use of cellular telephones and some radio services offered by Motorola Inc. The agreement on telecommunications equipment is the latest in a series of deals struck between the two nations in an effort to lower trade tensions. Earlier this year, the Japanese agreed to expand market access for U.S. and other foreign companies in the areas of timber products, satellites and super computers. In addition, the two nations reached agreement on a broad-ranging accord aimed at attacking structural barriers in both countries that have been targeted as a primary reason for the $49 billion trade deficit the United States ran up with Japan in 1989. That represented nearly half the total U.S. shortfall of $109.4 billion for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Car-Crazy California Learns to Ride the Train
DOC.TEXT: Commuters in the land where the automobile reigns supreme are making like veteran straphangers and taking Los Angeles' new rail system to work. OK, not many are doing it, but officials say it's a start. After an 18-day introductory period during which the ride was free, the new 22-mile Blue Line began charging the $1.10 fare Wednesday. Ridership plummeted by more half, to about 11,000, but Rapid Transit District spokesman Ken Echard said that was anticipated. Many passengers said they had given up the workday drive for good and adapting to the lifestyle of straphangers in cities with established rail systems. Some clamped on stereo headphones. Others buried their heads in newspapers, did paperwork or snoozed. Many remarked on the absence of freeway driving tension. ``I feel so much less stress when I get to work and when I get home,'' said Connie Wilcken, 40, of Long Beach. The two-car trains leave her a few blocks from her job at a medical clinic near downtown, and she walks the rest of the way. No one has said one train line will relieve the region's highway congestion, but morning riders Wednesday rushed past motorists on the Long Beach Freeway. A one-car spinout had jammed traffic by 6:30 a.m. on the downtown-bound lanes, which run almost parellel to the Blue Line. The rail line linking downtown with Long Beach opened July 14, the first light rail transit in Los Angeles County in nearly 30 years. The system is aimed at easing car-crazy Southern California's dependence on automobiles. The line cost $877 million and is part of a 150-mile, $10 billion rail grid planned for completion next century. Three miles of the Blue Line are unfinished. The 55-minute ride proved so popular the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission, the system's operators, postponed the fare until Wednesday. An estimated 670,000 riders took advantage of the 18-day offer. Boardings Wednesday were down from the 33,000 riders who took the trains for free the day before. Officials expect daily usage to climb to 12,000 next year. Transit workers at the system's 22 stations showed riders how to operate machines that dispense tickets, transfers and change. Ticket-buying is on the honor system; fare beaters face a possible $250 fine starting this weekend. Sheriff's deputies are responsible for security on the line, which passes some of the area's toughest gang territory. Passengers Wednesday dutifully held aloft their rectangular ducats, like a class showing ``all present.'' ``There shouldn't be any confusion,'' said Sheriff's Sgt. Lynne Hughes at the Blue Line command center. ``For the next couple of days, we are warning people.'' Dawn Lacy of Anaheim and Jeni Buys of Mission Viejo, 19-year-old students at the downtown Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising, said each saves about $190 a month by taking the Blue Line. Before, they paid $12 for a round trip on Amtrak between Anaheim and Union Station in Los Angeles. Now they drive to Long Beach, park for free and buy a fare and transfer for a total of $1.35 per person. ``Now I can tell my kids I did all this to get to school,'' said Miss Buys. ``It's also been pretty reliable,'' said Miss Lacy. ``The train comes by every 10 or 15 minutes.'' Five accidents have been reported since the system opened, the most serious on Monday when a teen-ager playing ``chicken'' lost some of his toes. Hughes said in the five days ending Wendesday deputies made 20 arrests, mostly for vandalism and trespassing. There have been no reports of violent crime.

DOC.HEAD: Neil Bush, Regulators Still Disagree on Key Points of S&L Case
With PM-S&L Bailout
DOC.TEXT: Neil Bush, accused of conflict of interest as a savings and loan director, continues to dispute key points raised by regulators in the case. The president's son was a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver-based thrift that failed in December 1988 at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. In two documents released Wednesday by the Office of Thrift Supervision, Bush and the regulators said they disagreed on a number of significant points. The key point of contention is whether Bush adequately disclosed to Silverado his business relationships with Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters, two big borrowers from the thrift. On Monday, the OTS released a document setting out the areas of agreement between Bush and the regulators. All of the documents contain information that was previously made public. They have been submitted to Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson as part of the proceeding in the Bush case. Bush has been ordered to appear at a public hearing on Sept. 25 in Denver before Davidson, who will then make a recommendation to OTS Director Timothy Ryan. In addition to the OTS case, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is considering filing a negligence lawsuit against Bush and other Silverado directors. Bush's attorneys and the OTS each submitted one of the new documents, called statements of contested facts. In his seven-page paper, Bush contended that before he joined the Silverado board, he disclosed his relationships with Good and Walters to former Silverado chairman Michael Wise, other Silverado managers, the board of directors and the thrift's attorneys. Good and Walters invested millions of dollars in Bush's oil partnership, JNB Exploration Co., which drilled several dry holes in Wyoming over two years and failed to become profitable. As a director of Silverado, Bush voted to approve some loans to Good and Walters but did not vote on others. Bush also asserted in his document that he made no agreement to abstain from votes involving loans to Good or Walters. In its nine-page submission, the OTS said ``there is no evidence'' that a letter prepared by Wise about Bush's business dealings with the two men was actually sent. The letter was addressed to Silverado's preferred shareholders and was accompanied by a cover memo to the directors, the OTS noted. The document alleged that Bush breached his duty to Silverado shareholders when he voted to approve certain loans to Good and Walters. Five of those loans resulted in a combined loss to Silverado of at least $46 million, the OTS said. ``Generally accepted standards of prudent operation require the disclosure of a thrift director's relationships with major customers of the institution when further transactions are under consideration,'' the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Urges Inspections After Finding No Bomb in Plane Explosion
DOC.TEXT: A federal board is calling for immediate inspection of all Boeing 737s and several other airliners after investigators determined that a mechanical fault, not a bomb, likely destroyed a Philippine jet. Philippine authorities had said they suspected a bomb in the May 11 explosion and fire that killed eight people as the Philippines Air Lines 737 was taxiing for takeoff on a domestic flight from Manila. But the National Transportation Safety Board, which has assisted in the Philippine government's inquiry, said Wednesday that investigators found evidence of a possibly defective switch inside the jetliner's center fuel tank and damaged wiring leading to the switch. ``The investigation has found no evidence of a bomb, an incendiary device or sabotage,'' NTSB Chairman James Kolstad said in a letter to Federal Aviation Administration chief James Busey. The safety board has no power to issue orders for emergency inspections of airliners, but the FAA does. Foreign airlines generally follow FAA orders involving U.S.-built planes. The four-member board urged Busey to issue ``airworthiness directives'' calling for inspection of float switch wiring in all Boeing 737s and in all planes among other airliner types where modifications have been made that might have caused damage to wires leading to switches in the fuel tanks. Boeing Co. documents show that nearly 1,900 of its 737s are in use worldwide. The number of other airliners that could be affected was not immediately clear. The FAA already has advised Philippine Air Lines to inspect its remaining two 737s for possible wiring damage during installation of lights that shine on each plane's tail to illuminate its logo, Kolstad said. But he said there is evidence of other wire damage in the plane that may have occurred ``at the factory.'' ``The safety board does not believe that this action is adequate because it does not address the problem of faulty float switches,'' Kolstad added. Although Kolstad said investigators have not determined exactly what triggered the explosion, he said: ``It is possible that the combination of a faulty float switch and damaged wires providing a continuous power supply to the float switch may have caused an electrical arc or overheating of the switch, leading to the ignition of the center fuel tank vapor.'' The board chairman said laboratory examination of the switch from the Philippine jet indicated defects that show ``it is possible that the switch did not pass inspection when originally assembled.'' The manufacturer, Revere Aerospace, changed its method of building the switches three years ago, but all 850 switches stocked by Boeing were made before the change, Kolstad said in the letter. The board questioned Boeing's procedures for inspecting the switches and said a testing technique should be developed that would ensure that the switches ``are free from defect that could cause an explosion or fire.'' Boeing spokesman Tom Cole said the airplane manufacturer has been participating in the investigation. He said it probably already has sent out a service letter to other 737 users on implications of the Philippine explosion. Cole said, however, he knew of no recommendations Boeing had made for inspections or alterations. ``We are cooperating fully in the investigation, and we are advising our customers of whatever we learn,'' he said. Safety board member Jim Burnett, in a comment attached to Kolstad's letter, said he preferred an even broader inspection affecting any airliner with a Revere Aerospace switch of the type used in the Philippine jet. Burnett also called for an order that all such switches be tested and replaced if found defective.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Campaign Finance, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the highlights of the campaign finance reform bill approved by the Senate.

Voluntary ceilings would be set for Senate campaigns, with the total for both primary and general elections ranging from $1.9 million in the smallest states to $9.5 million in the largest, California. However, $243,000 of that amount in the smallest state up to $1,125,000 in California would have to come from in-state contributions of $100 or less.

Because the Supreme Court has ruled that mandated spending ceilings would violate First Amendment rights of free speech, the bill offers incentives for voluntary compliance. Complying candidates would be provided a total of $20 million in government vouchers to help them pay for TV advertising, financed through a voluntary checkoff on individual income tax returns. Candidates would qualify for additional public financing if their opponents exceed the caps.

Complying candidates would get a 75 percent discount on first-class mail rates for the campaign material up to 5 percent of the spending ceiling. Incumbent senators and House members would be prohibited from using their franking privileges to make mass mailings at government expense in the calendar years they are up for re-election.

Corporate, union and trade association political action committees would be banned from making contributions in federal elections. To deal with possible evasion, contributions from executives of the same employer would be limited to a total of $5,000 per candidate. If the PAC ban is declared unconstitutional, the maximum allowable PAC contribution to a single candidate would be cut from $10,000 to $2,000 for both primary and general elections. Total PAC contributions in that event would be limited to $375,000 for candidates in the smallest state up to $825,000 in California.
Senators would be prohibited from accepting outside speaking fees after Jan. 1, 1990. Currently, they can keep up to slightly more than $27,000 in honoraria.

Broadcasters would have to make their best advertising slots available to candidates 45 days before a primary and 60 days before the general election at the lowest rates they charge for those periods.

The current $25,000 limit on an individual's contributions to all political activities would be raised to $30,000, but all of the additional money could go only to state party organizations. Individual contributions to a single candidate would remain limited to $2,000 for both primary and general elections. Contributions to a single candidate from an out-of-state donor would be limited to $250.
Candidates could spend no more than $250,000 of their on money on their campaigns. They would be prohibited from paying off campaign loans with funds raised after an election.

Money contributed to state party organizations for voter registration and turnout efforts and not now reportable to the Federal Election Commission would have to be raised through accounts subject to disclosure. Spending by state parties on those activities would be limited to 30 cents per voter, ranging from $101,700 in Wyoming to $6.4 million in California. State parties could spend an additional 4 cents per voter in presidential elections.

DOC.HEAD: Business and Civil Rights Lobbyists Clash as Job Bias Vote Nears
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Vote scheduled for afternoon EDT, exact time uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Business and civil rights forces vied in last-minute lobbying as the House neared a vote on legislation designed to combat job discrimination but which critics claim will create hiring quotas. ``There has been a mounting lobbying effort,'' Rep. Henry J. Hyde, R-Ill., said Wednesday night. ``Anybody with any interest at all in this has been on the (Capitol) Hill _ the employer groups, the civil rights community.'' The House planned to vote this afternoon on the bill, which is similar to legislation already approved by the Senate. It would effectively overturn five Supreme Court decisions last year on job discrimination and was advancing in defiance of administration threats of a presidential veto. Lawmakers expected the major showdown to come over an amendment sponsored by Rep. John LaFalce, D-N.Y., that would eliminate a provision that critics say would lead to hiring quotas and cap court damages at $100,000. The administration and business groups have been pushing for the amendment, while civil rights forces say it would wreck the bill. Major provisions of the bill range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to barriers against reopening court-approved fair-hiring agreements. The most controversy centers on provisions that would make it easier to win hiring discrimination cases by showing statistical evidence of bias. The administration says those features are so skewed against employers that companies would adopt hiring quotas out of fear that they otherwise would be bombarded with discrimination suits. This week brought more intense debate over the unlimited damages that could be awarded to victims of intentional discrimination under the bill. The LaFalce plan provided for a cap on damages of $100,000 for each complaint. But they would be awarded only if no back pay was ordered as a result of the complaint. Administration officials and other critics said a cap was one of the features needed to prevent the bill from becoming ``a lawyers' bonanza.'' ``It will revitalize the Trial Lawyers Association and terrorize employers into hiring by the numbers,'' Hyde said of the bill as written. But sponsors said it would be unfair to women, religious minorities and the disabled because unlimited damages already are allowed for racial and ethnic discrimination. ``It would say to the world that America considers women second-class citizens, not deserving of the same rights as blacks and Hispanics,'' said Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif. Lobbyists from both sides crisscrossed Capitol Hill throughout the week as the House vote neared. Businesses flew in scores of executives on Tuesday to meet with home-state congressmen and urge a vote against the bill or at least in favor of amendments to temper its provisions. The executives set up an informal headquarters and clearinghouse for information at the Capitol Hill Club, adjacent to Republican National Committee headquarters, said lobbyists who asked not to be identified. Spearheading the lobbying on the other side was the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, whose member organizations range from major unions to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Conference representatives held several bargaining sessions with administration officials in an effort to reach compromise on the issue after President Bush said he wanted to sign a bill to fight job discrimination but not one that would lead to hiring quotas. But the two sides have not been able to reach an accord. A business umbrella group called the Fair Employment Coalition has been coordinating lobbying against the provisions it contends would bring on hiring quotas and allow excessive damages. Its members are senior human resources vice presidents of 140 major corporations.

DOC.HEAD: House OKs Bill to Revamp Federal Housing Programs
DOC.TEXT: The House has approved $28 billion for a series of revamped housing programs by an overwhelming vote that could make moot a presidential veto threat. The vote Wednesday was 378-43. The bill includes most of the Bush administration's initiative for encouraging low-income housing tenants to purchase their homes, as well as provisions sought by congressional housing advocates to offer rental assistance, to help first-time home buyers and to encourage construction of new rental housing. House Republicans joined Democrats in supporting the bill, but key Republicans said they were doing so in hopes the bill would be changed when it goes to House and Senate conferees to work out differences in the two chambers' versions. Rep. Chalmers Wylie, R-Ohio, ranking Republican on the Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee, said President Bush and Jack Kemp, the secretary of housing and urban development, got 90 percent of their proposal to encourage public housing residents to purchase their homes in some cases. The Senate has already approved a more modest housing bill after reaching agreement with the Bush administration on key provisions. The White House threatened a veto because the House version disregards the administration's demand for changes in the Federal Housing Administration, including a requirement for a larger down payment on FHA-backed home mortgages. The Senate version includes the higher down payment requirements.

DOC.HEAD: Six Drown as Cargo Ship Buckles in Hurricane
DOC.TEXT: The crew of a cargo ship broken by 30-foot waves kicked up by Hurricane Bertha abandoned ship in churning, chilly seas because the vessel's lifeboats were too shabby to use, the Coast Guard said today. Six crew members of the freighter Corazon drowned after the ship's keel snapped about 350 miles off Cape Cod. Twenty-one others were rescued by commercial ships providing lifeboats and rafts, the Coast Guard said. Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Paul Milligan said the Corazon's own lifeboats were ``unserviceable.'' The Coast Guard is investigating the ship's lifeboats, said Quartermaster 1st Class Matthew Giltner. The crew abandoned the 593-foot Maltese-registered freighter in 90 mph winds early Wednesday, about 11 hours after reporting the ship was breaking up. Soviet, Hong Kong and Norwegian merchant ships steamed to the stricken vessel as U.S. military aircraft coordinated the rescue effort from above. ``We have accounted for everybody: 20 in good condition, one alive but injured, six deceased,'' Milligan said. Three bodies were recovered. The search for the other victims, all seen dead in the water, was halted late Wedneseday because of rough seas and bad weather. The hurricane, which was blamed for a Florida swimmer's death Tuesday, moved northeast today and weakened slightly after injuring six people in Nova Scotia with high seas on Wednesday. The Corazon was carrying about 25,000 tons of cement from Greece to New York, and the load probably contributed to its damage, said Coast Guard Lt. Rodney Gadsden. Rescue efforts did not go easily. At one point in the morning, the Soviet trawler Vympel snared a life raft carrying 12 crew members with its screw propeller and several people were dumped into the water. One survivor was pulled from the water nearly 12 hours after abandoning ship. He was in good condition, said Petty Officer Gail Williams. The nature of the hurt sailor's injuries was not immediately known, officials said. The survivors were put aboard a Soviet merchant ship that was headed for Portland, Maine, and could arrive by Friday. After the crew abandoned ship, the Corazon's bow was submerged but its stern stood clear of the water, the Coast Guard said. The crew included Greek, Filipino, Polish and Maldivian sailors, said Charles Aitcheson, president of Asca Marine Inc., the ship's New York agent. The Corazon was built in Japan in 1972 and previously was operated under the Philippine flag as the Dona Corazon II, Aitcheson said. He said the owner is Good Faith Shipping of Piraeus, Greece.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Wage Psychological Warfare Against Pesky Birds
LaserPhoto CX3
DOC.TEXT: Health officials are employing psychological warfare in a nearly decade-long battle against thousands of noisy starlings that descend in dense flocks each summer in certain elm-lined neighborhoods. The birds keep people awake, coat cars in messy droppings and make Bob Mathis' life miserable each summer. Mathis, the village's environmental health supervisor, has tried everything over the years from wind machines to huge balloons painted with ``terror eyes'' to resemble owls. He had limited success until he hit on a promising combination two or three years ago of high-intensity search lights and a taped starling distress call that fills the evening air with screeching to scare away the birds. ``We use a physical assault and psychological warfare,'' he said. ``The lights unsettle their environment and the starling distress call is an eerie sound, like a bird being strangled.'' For seven years or more in the warmer months, the birds in flocks of 3,000 to 5,000 seem to favor the cathedral-arch canopies of elms on two usually quiet blocks in this Chicago suburb. The birds feast on beetles and caterpillars by day and head for the trees at dusk for their evening shut-eye. Residents call the kids inside and park their cars down the block, away from the splatter of bird droppings. ``It's a real mess here,'' one resident, Ken Radnitzer, said Wednesday night, during one of Mathis' regular trips to the neighborhood with the lights and distress call. ``It's a health hazard,'' said another, Kathleen Dawson. ``The droppings get so bad that if you're out in the evening and your kid is in bare feet you're forever running after him. Or in the back yard, the droppings get on the toys.'' John Jones said he doesn't need an alarm clock in the summer. ``At 4, 5, 6 o'clock in the morning the birds start up,'' he said. ``They'll take care of waking you up.'' When the village first went after the birds, it suspended balloons 6 feet around above trees. The balloons had reflective ``terror eyes'' stuck on, but the balloons blew away in wind storms and the approach was abandoned. Wind machines were tried with little success. Ultimately, Mathis, who doesn't want to kill the birds or tamper with the trees, settled on the lights and taped screeches. The method chases the birds off the blocks under siege, but they come back eventually or bother some other block. But Mathis isn't ready to give up on the technique. ``You just have to be persistent,'' he said. ``It's a question of who can last the longest and the Health Department so far is keeping up with the birds.'' Starlings, native to Europe, were first released in New York's Central Park in 1890. Two earlier attempts to introduce the birds to North America failed, but this one succeeded in a big way. Like the settlers before them, the starlings headed west and reached the Pacific in 60 years. Now they occupy nearly every nook and cranny of North America, numbering an estimated 200 million.

DOC.HEAD: Plan Calls For Three Mile Island Customers To Pay Until 2014
DOC.TEXT: Three Mile Island's Unit 2 nuclear reactor only functioned for four months, but customers would be paying for the now-crippled unit until the year 2014 under a plan proposed by the plant's owners. In a report filed with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the owners' representative said they intended to seek permission from state utility regulators to charge ratepayers $195.6 million to dispose of Unit 2. The money would be collected over the next 24 years. The unit operated only about four months before it was permanently disabled in the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident on March 31, 1979. Its twin, Unit 1, was unharmed and was given permission to resume operations in 1985. The owners hope to operate the healthy unit until 2014. The $195.6 million is about $70 million more than the usual cost of decommissioning a comparable reactor that did not suffer an accident. It is standard practice for utilities to ask ratepayers to fund decommissioning, the formal term for mothballing or dismantling a plant at the end of its energy-producing life. But Three Mile Island poses ``a more difficult question,'' Pennsylvania Consumer Advocate Irwin Popowsky said.
DOC.HEAD: Does The Government Owe You if Policies Cost You Your Job?
DOC.TEXT: If you lose your job because the federal government wants to protect the spotted owl or cut defense spending, does the government have any special obligation to you? That is the question generating increasing debate on Capitol Hill. With the fall election approaching, supporters of clean air, protected forests and reduced defense spending are displaying a heightened awareness that their actions have an economic impact. Lawmakers debated legislation Wednesday that is designed to provide extra support to loggers who lose their jobs because of protection of the spotted owl, soldiers and defense factory workers victimized by defense cuts, and coal miners laid off because of tougher air pollution laws and a corresponding decline in coal burning. The five-year, $5 billion program is the brainchild of Reps. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., and Pete Stark, D-Calif., whose districts are among the scores that could be heavily impacted by cuts in defense spending. Not surprisingly, Democrats from timber and coal mining states also signed on. The Downey-Stark proposal would provide extra unemployment and health benefits to about 200,000 workers _ far fewer, Downey noted, than the number expected to be displaced.
DOC.HEAD: Washington Bank Placed Under Federal Conservatorship
DOC.TEXT: The National Bank of Washington has been placed under federal conservatorship. NBW on Wednesday became the second financial institution in the Washington region to be seized in two days.
