On Tuesday, federal officials announced the takeover by the Resolution Trust Corporation of United Savings Bank in Vienna, Va. ``In order to keep the confidence in the bank's customers, and keep the bank continuing to operate we took the action to appoint a conservator,'' said Dean DeBuck, spokesman for the federal Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. Earlier on Wednesday, the Washington Bancorp filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code, officials said. At that time, indications were that NBW's $1.6 billion assets would be liquidated, but federal officials only have the power to take such action. ``We did not want the bankruptcy filing to make people run to the bank to withdraw the money,'' said DeBuck, adding that all deposits remain insured to the $100,000 limit and offices remain open daily.
DOC.HEAD: So Far, 1990 An Average Year for Earthquakes
DOC.TEXT: So far, 1990 is just an average year for earthquakes, although the Iranian quake in June was the deadliest in 14 years. The U.S. Geological Survey said Wednesday the death toll in Iran, estimated at 50,000 or more, is the highest since a 1976 quake in China killed more than 250,000 people. Overall, there were 34 significant quakes in the first six months of 1990. That would be close to normal, since there are, on average, 60 significant quakes in a typical year, the agency said. A significant quake is defined as one reaching 6.5 or higher on the Richter scale or a lesser temblor causing significant casualties or damage. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released in an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one whole number, say from 5.5 to 6.5, indicates a tenfold increase in ground motion. The quake that struck Iran measured 7.7 on the scale, according to Waverly Person, chief of the agency's National Earthquake Information Service in Golden, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Invades Kuwait, Says Kuwaiti Gov't Has Been Overthrown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with emir's palace taken, country being ravaged, American Embassy surrounded, British Embassy shelled. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Tank-led Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait before dawn Thursday, seizing the ruler's palace and other government buildings, Kuwaiti officials reported., The Iraqi government of President Saddam Hussein said the Kuwaiti government had been overthrown. The invasion comes nearly two weeks after Iraq massed troops on Kuwait's border in a dispute over an oilfield and Kuwait's violation of OPEC oil production quotas, which had kept down the price of crude. ``The Iraqis have occupied all of Kuwait!'' one Kuwaiti official shouted in a telephone interview. ``They have seized all administrative buildings, including the information ministry which houses the (state-run) radio and television stations,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Diplomats said about 350 Iraqi tanks wheeled into the capital a few hours after crossing the border 40 miles away before dawn. The invaders, whose forces far outnumber those of smaller Kuwait, were led by the elite Republican Guard that did the brunt of the fighting in the 1980-88 war with Iran. The troops set up roadblocks at major intersections in the capital. The invaders surrounded the palace of the ruler of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the official said. Residents in the palace's vicinity said it was seized after two hours of heavy artillery barrages. The whereabouts of the emir, whose family has ruled the city-state for almost 250 years, was not immediately known. The bombardment of ports and airports was vicious, eyewitnesses said. Thousands of residents attempted to flee south toward Saudi Arabia in their cars. Kuwait's official radio broadcast a desperate plea for help from other Arab nations. The Kuwaiti Embassy in Washington reported only that there were many casualties in the fighting, which follows a flareup in a protracted dispute over a border oil field, but gave no numbers early Thursday. Residents said there were about 50 tanks around the emir's palace and the neighboring U.S. Embassy. The embassy did no answer its telephones. The British Embassy was hit by shellfire and the Sheraton and Hilton hotels evacuated their clientele, sources said. The air space over Kuwait was closed, with airliners turned away. The Bush administration demanded immediate withdrawal of the Iraqi forces and added that it was ``reviewing all options in its response to the Iraqi aggression.'' U.S. warships have been on ``short-term'' alert 600 miles southeast of the Iraq-Kuwait border since July 24 because of the tensions in the oil-rich Persian Gulf region, scene of heavy fighting in the Iran-Iraq war. The White House said it had no reports of harm to Americans. The United States has extensive business ties to Kuwait, and the U.S. community in the nation _ slightly smaller than New Jersey _ is sizeable, in the thousands. The White House denounced the incursion, issuing a statement that said, ``The United States strongly condemns the Iraqi military invasion of Kuwait ... ``We have conveyed this message to the Iraqi ambassador in Washington and to the Iraqi government through our embassy in Baghdad. ``We deplore this blatant use of military aggression in violation of the U.N. charter.'' In New York, U.N. officials said the Security Council was to begin an emergency meeting early Thursday. Reaction was swift elsewhere. The British government said the ``armed incursion is clearly a grave threat to peace and stability in the area and of immediate concern to the international community as a whole.'' The Iraqi action was expected to dominate talks between President Bush and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher when they meet later Thursday in Aspen, Colo. Iraqi officials on Wednesday had abruptly walked out on talks in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, complaining that the Kuwaiti representatives were not negotiating seriously. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt had intervened beginning July 25 to set up the talks in a bid to cool tensions between the two OPEC members. In Baghdad, Saddam's government announced Thursday that the Kuwaiti government had been toppled. Kuwait radio went off the air briefly, but came back on different wavelenghs with martial music and Kuwaiti patriotic songs. Saddam's ruling council issued a statement from Baghdad saying an interim government had been established in Kuwait but the claim could not be immediately and independently confirmed. ``Iraq has responded to the request from interim government of free Kuwait and decided to cooperate with it,'' the Iraqi statement said. It said the troops _ no numbers were given _ were in Kuwait to defend the revolution and the Kuwaiti people. There was no further identification of the revolutionary government. Iraq warned too that any foreign troops trying to interfere with its actions would be attacked. More than 60 percent of the country's 1.8 million residents are foreigners. Kuwaiti forces had engaged the Iraqi invaders with heavy artillery in a failed attempt to repulse them, government officials contacted by telephone earlier Thursday said. Iraqi, which is the size of California, has an estimated 1 million troops among its 17 million populace, compared to 20,300 members of the Kuwait armed forces. In Baghdad, the official radio interspersed martial music with songs with slogans like, ``Greetings to the Revolution in Kuwait.'' The invasion followed massive troop movements to the south on Wednesday. In Kuwait early Thursday, the rattle of automatic guns sounded and explosions in rapid succession shook local residents from their sleep and the Kuwaiti Cabinet quickly assembled. Residents in downtown Kuwait reported formations of French-made Mirage jet fighters of the Kuwaiti air force taking to the skies in the direction of the border region. The streets were empty; some people on rooftops of their houses reported hearing gunblasts growing in intensity and speed. Moments later army tanks and armored personnel carriers were moving in the direction of the Royal Palace, apparently to reinforce the guards. Kuwait is a former British protectorate that gained independence in 1961. Its residents are among the wealthiest in the world because of the country's vast oil reserves. In Tokyo, the dollar moved sharply higher along with oil prices during morning trading Thursday on news of Iraq's invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Father Gets Life for Driving Car into River, Killing 4
DOC.TEXT: A father convicted of murdering his four children by driving the family station wagon into a river drew a sentence of life in prison from a judge who second-guessed his own handling of the case. Lawrence DeLisle, 29, had claimed a leg cramp and a faulty accelerator caused him to speed down a dead-end street and crash through a barricade into the Detroit River a year ago. Circuit Judge Robert Colombo Jr. on Wednesday imposed the mandatory sentence of life in prison on each of four murder counts and one count of attempted murder. The terms will be served concurrently. In imposing sentence, the judge said DeLisle intentionally drove the car into the water but may not have been guilty of first-degree murder and might have benefited had the trial been moved out of town, away from heavy publicity. The judge had denied a defense request for a change of venue. Killed when the car sank in 27 feet of water were DeLisle's children, Bryan, 8; Melissa, 4; Kathryn, 2, and Emily, 8 months. Passing boaters rescued DeLisle and his wife, Suzanne. DeLisle was convicted on June 21. ``A father's job is to protect his children, and I failed,'' he told the jduge Wednesday. ``I panicked. I froze. That is my guilt, not murder.'' Prosecutors said DeLisle was bent on suicide to free himself of family responsibilities. Witnesses testified he had complained his family was a financial burden and several years ago left the house with a candle burning by a leaky gas dryer in an alleged attempt to wipe the family out. Mrs. DeLisle said the deaths were an accident, and she affirmed her love for her husband. ``The police weren't there. I was,'' she said. ``I know that one of the reasons I have made it this far is because my husband is innocent. ... We will be together again.'' Trial evidence proved DeLisle's act was premeditated, Colombo said, but added, ``I don't know if the defendant is guilty of the crimes of which he was convicted.'' The jury could have convicted DeLisle of lesser charges including second-degree murder, negligent homicide or involuntary manslaughter. The judge also said the jury ``may have been subconsciously influenced by what they already knew about the case through the media.'' Defense attorney Frank Eaman said he will seek a new trial

DOC.HEAD: Relationship With Woman Led to Archbishop's Resignation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Church news conference scheduled for 2:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Atlanta's Roman Catholic archbishop resigned last month for fear a two-year relationship with a woman half his age would become public, his temporary successor says. Eugene A. Marino, the nation's first black archbishop, had cited health reasons and the need for ``spiritual renewal, psychological therapy and medical supervision'' when he resigned July 10. He had relinquished his duties in May because of stress and a near heart attack. But on Wednesday, Bishop James P. Lyke said Marino asked him to confirm the relationship with a 26-year-old lay minister after a report earlier in the day by WAGA-TV. The TV station said that Marino, 56, was supporting Vicki R. Long with $1,500-a-month payments and helping her buy a house. It said a flight insurance policy taken by Marino for a trip to Mexico listed Ms. Long as his beneficiary. Neither the TV station nor Lyke said if the relationship was sexual. Lyke said the archbishop resigned ``because I think he probably realized that this was not going to be something that was going to stay out of the public eye. My sense is that he concluded that he could not function with that kind of possible disclosure over his head.'' Ms. Long, who filed a $2.3 million paternity suit in 1987 against a priest she alleged fathered her child, refused to comment on the allegations involving Marino. Church officials refused to say where Marino could be located. The Rev. Peter Dora of the Atlanta Archdiocese said church officials would hold a news conference this afternoon. Ms. Long charged that the Rev. Donal Keohane of Columbus, Ga., fathered her daughter, who was born in 1986. The church is paying child support but denies Keohane fathered the child. Blood tests concluded he was not the father. Church faithful in Atlanta reacted with disbelief. ``This is a bombshell an I hate very much to hear this story,'' said Hugh Spalding Jr. Katherine Woodyard, former director of the archdiocesan Commission for Black Catholic Concern, said, ``As far as I know he's sick. That's what they told us and that's what I believe.'' Marino was ordained in 1962 and consecrated as a bishop in 1974. He had been the archbishop of Atlanta since May 1988, coming from Washington, where he was auxiliary bishop to Cardinal James Hickey. The pope appointed Lyke, auxiliary bishop of Cleveland, to run the archdiocese until a new archbishop is appointed. The archdiocese covers 69 northern Georgia counties with more than 150,000 Roman Catholics.

DOC.HEAD: Parents, Feminist Group Seek to Overturn Parental Consent Laws
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs last graf to qualify that in some listed states the laws require parental notification, although not necessarily parental consent
DOC.TEXT: The parents of a young woman who died from a back-alley abortion are joining forces with a national women's rights group to overturn state laws requiring minors to get parental consent for abortions. Karen and Bill Bell of Indianapolis appeared Wednesday with the Feminist Majority at a news conference announcing the ``Becky Bell Campaign,'' which the group plans to take to high schools and college campuses around the country. The Bell's 17-year-old daughter, Becky, died in 1988 from a massive infection after receiving an abortion from an unqualified practitioner. The Bells said they had a good relationship with their daughter and had openly discussed sex and birth control. They said that although they had never talked about abortion with Becky, they would have left the decision up to her. But her father said Becky confided to a friend: ``I can't tell Mom and Dad, I love them too much.'' ``The parental consent law sounds wonderful,'' Mrs. Bell said. ``What parent wouldn't want to know? I would. I'd say, `My girl will tell me because she tells me everything.' Becky told me every single thing she did _ until she fell in love.'' Becky's story is the subject of a half-hour video, ``Abortion Denied: Shattering Young Women's Lives,'' that the Feminist Majority plans to take to schools throughout the country. ``This is one of the toughest areas for us in public opinion. this is one of the reasons we decided to launch this major campaign,'' said Eleanor Smeal, president of the Feminist Majority. ``A lot of people just knee-jerk think, `Well, sure parents should be involved.' They do not realize what mandatory, intrusive, compulsory laws do to hurt women and their families.'' In June, the Supreme Court upheld laws in Ohio and Minnesota requiring a minor to obtain parental consent for an abortion. Fourteen states currently enforce such laws. Indiana allows minors to get a judge's permission to waive the parental consent restrictions. But the Bells said their daughter had heard that the only sitting judge in Indianapolis was opposed to abortion and granted few waivers. In the video, several young women who sought judicial waivers were interviewed. They described the process as intimidating. ``Everyone knows what you're sitting there for,'' said one young woman. In some states it takes up to 22 days for a waiver to be granted. The campaign hopes to recruit as many as 1 million young people from college campuses and high schools to join ``Becky Bell Brigades.'' ``We will be asking young people to help us with voter registration drives, with petition campaigns, with going door-to-door,'' said Smeal. Oregon, Massachusetts and Texas have been targeted as key states where parental consent legislation is pending. The states that currently enforce parental consent or notification laws are: Alabama, Arkansas, Indiana, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, North Dakota, Ohio, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Utah, West Virginia, Wyoming.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I will start right from the beginning by telling you that Mr. Barry used cocaine'' _ R. Kenneth Mundy, attorney for Marion Barry, during closing arguments in the Washington mayor's drug and perjury trial.

``Everybody's wondering how in the hell they're going to pay their mortgages on their boats and their businesses'' _ Walter Jakubas, a Texas marina owner, reacting to a state ban on fishing in seafood-rich Galveston Bay because of a 500,000-gallon oil spill.

``I think the first thing we're going to do is go out and have a good meal, and then let daddy have a little bourbon and branch water _ which he hasn't had in 5{ years'' _ Martha Moran, whose father, 81-year-old Roswell Gilbert, was granted release from a Florida prison for the 1985 ``mercy killing'' of his ailing wife.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader's Wife Convicted in Ritual Slayings
DOC.TEXT: A woman described as the cool, calculating mother figure of a cult run by her husband could draw a life sentence for her part in the ritual slaying of a family of five. Alice Lundgren, 39, was found guilty Wednesday of kidnapping, complicity and conspiracy to commit aggravated murder. She was the first to be convicted in the case. Eight people await trial, including her husband, Jeffrey Lundgren, and their 19-year-old son, Damon. Defense attorney Joseph Gibson said he will appeal. No sentencing date was set. Lundgren was defrocked in 1988 as a lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints for inappropriate conduct. He formed a splinter sect whose members lived commune-style with the Lundgrens on a farm. Mrs. Lundgren was among 13 cult members arrested last January in the 1989 shootings of Dennis and Cheryl Avery and their three daughters. Their bodies were found buried under a barn at the farm in Kirtland, about 30 miles from Cleveland. All five were bound with duct tape, gagged and shot, then dumped in a common grave. Mrs. Lundgren testified she was not at the farm during the killings and was told about the slayings afterward. But three of four cult members who have pleaded guilty in the case testified Mrs. Lundgren had known her husband had targeted the Averys for death as a spirit-cleansing ritual in hope of witnessing the return of Christ. Prosecutors described Mrs. Lundgren as the even-headed mother figure in the group. Cult member Deborah Olivarez testified Mrs. Lundgren portrayed her husband to others as a prophet who must be obeyed. She testified Mrs. Lundgren taught female cult members to be ``carnal, sensual and devilish'' and helped plan the Avery slayings. Lundgren, 40, faces trial Aug. 13 on charges of aggravated murder and kidnapping. If convicted, he could get the death penalty.

DOC.HEAD: Shark Hunt Worries Lifeguards, Surfers; Prompts Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing scheduled for 4 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: After the free lunch is over, will the sharks know it's time to go home? The $80,000 Columbia River-Pacific Ocean Shark Tournament, featuring a top prize of $35,000, prompted a lawsuit Wednesday from a surf shop manager who says it's too risky to lure the ocean predators into areas frequented by beachgoers. Competitors plan to chum, or toss ground fish and blood into the water, to attract sharks, said Ron Miller, a charter boat operator and tournament organizer. ``Who will tell the sharks that have been lured in from many, many miles away that it's time to go home now?'' Seaside resident Susanna Hendrix wrote in a protest letter to various state agencies. Steve McKenzie, manager of the Cleanline Surf Shop in Seaside, said in the lawsuit slated for a hearing today that the hunt, which is expected to draw 200 charter boats this weekend, jeopardizes public safety. ``The lifeguards say the possibility of a shark attack on the beach in Seaside is very real,'' McKenzie said. Aside from the safety issue, McKenzie said the tournament off Oregon's northern coast should be stopped because it is inhumane. ``The idea of attracting sharks by throwing animal blood into the water and then pulling them on board, clubbing them to death, holding them, weighing them and then throwing them in the landfill _ that's offensive,'' he said. ``It is killing for the sake of killing.'' Miller of Long Beach, Wash., said the danger of shark attacks was remote because the tournament will take place up to five miles offshore. ``There are literally millions of sharks out there,'' Miller said. ``As far as shark tournaments, they are held on the East Coast all the time and there has never been any kind of injury attributed to a tournament. ``If anything, this tournament will elevate the status of the shark to a more prized food fish and a more prized sport fish,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Soars, Tokyo Stocks Plunge After Iraq Invades Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The dollar soared against the Japanese yen today following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, while shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged. The dollar ended the day at 148.90 yen, up 2.25 yen from Wednesday's 146.65-yen close. It opened at 147.13 yen and ranged between 146.50 yen and 149.00 yen. Currency dealers said news late in the morning that Iraqi troops had crossed the border into Kuwait set off sharp dollar buying. ``The dollar was bought briskly and quickly when the news came'' of the Iraqi troop movement, said Masakazu Kimura, a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. The dollar tends to rise in times of world unrest because it is regarded as a safe haven. About $18.56 billion changed hands in spot trading, up from Wednesday's $13.55 billion. The invasion came after negotiations between Iraq and Kuwait collapsed Wednesday in their dispute over oil, borders and money. Bank of Tokyo trader Masafumi Koyama said fears of higher oil prices and uncertainties over the Iraq-Kuwait dispute accelerated the dollar buying in the afternoon. ``Investors generally tend to overreact to any news from the Middle East, but now they are waiting to see the reaction from the European and U.S. markets after we close,'' Koyama said. He said the Iraq-Kuwait situation had reversed the dollar's recent downtrend, in which the U.S. currency lost 4.1 yen in Tokyo between Monday and Wednesday. ``The dollar will quickly surpass the 151-yen line if participants remain uncertain about the situation,'' Koyama added. Strife in the Middle East also drove up bids for crude oil, as Tokyo traders reported the marker price for North Sea oil, Brent crude, was bid up to $21.30 a barrel, about 30 to 40 cents higher than in New York late Wednesday. No sellers were reported, however. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 592.81 points, or 1.92 percent, ending the day at 30,245.18. The index, which lost 197.67 points on Wednesday, dropped more than 700 points by mid-afternoon as panicked participants dumped issues after reports of the Iraqi action, traders said. Yoshio Ogawa, chief trader at Nikko Securities Co., said arbitrage selling of spot issues to take profits from price gaps between the spot and future markets, as well as the plunge in yen and bond prices, prompted the index's afternoon dive. Although the Nikkei reduced its losses toward the end of the afternoon session as participants calmed down and began picking up underpriced issues, Ogawa said the Nikkei was likely to continue to suffer from uncertainties linked to the dispute between the two Middle East nations. Trading was thin with volume on the first section estimated at 400 million shares, down from Wednesday's 430 million. In bond dealing, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 7.615 percent, up from Wednesday's 7.480 percent close. Their price ended the day at 85.11 points, down from 85.72 points Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Women, Blacks in Hollywood Looking for Different Picture Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Timothy Blake, chairwoman, in 5th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Almost every movie at the neighborhood theater these days stars a white male, and women and blacks say they're ready for a different picture show. Blacks and women gathered Wednesday at separate conclaves to discuss how they are underemployed, underpaid and overlooked in the film and TV industry. In a panel discussion launching the 15th convention of the National Association of Black Journalists, Hollywood insiders said blacks get meager jobs in front of and behind the camera. Earlier Wednesday, the Screen Actors Guild released a study showing that actresses earn half as much as actors and that their prominence in Hollywood has declined over the last three years. ``Feature films are the exclusive domain of men as this summer's movies illustrate,'' said Timothy Blake, national chairwoman of SAG's women's committee. She was referring to ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder,'' ``Dick Tracy,'' ``Total Recall,'' ``Days of Thunder'' and other blockbusters. At the journalists' convention, panel moderator Barbara Rogers said blacks purchase more than 25 percent of all movie tickets. Eddie Murphy's films have grossed more than $1 billion, but blacks have little say in key creative decisions within the industry, she said. ``I feel sometimes very alone,'' said Dennis Johnson, who is black and the vice president of original programs for cable's Showtime and The Movie Channel. ``Our business has made a regression.'' Others called for blacks to take an active leadership role. ``We have to begin to give ourselves an economic base from which our community can draw,'' said Keenan Ivory Wayans, producer and star of the acclaimed TV series ``In Living Color.'' Other panelists said black critics, TV viewers and moviegoers need to support works produced by or geared to blacks. The SAG study found that men were given more than twice as many roles as women in 1989 movies, and men received 65 percent of all parts in television programs during the year. The statistics were presented by Meryl Streep to launch SAG's first National Women's Conference. She called the report tragic and stunning. If the Hollywood employment trend continues, Miss Streep said, ``by the year 2000, we will have 13 percent of roles ... and in 20 years we will be eliminated from the movies.'' Miss Streep said a growing number of movie roles going to women cast them as prostitutes, rape victims and needy companions to domineering men. She said the perception that women don't go to movies and therefore don't need films aimed at them is flawed. Miss Streep said women are staying home precisely because there aren't films catering to their interests and tastes. Mike Medavoy, chairman of Tri-Star Pictures, said movie companies are just trying to produce popular fare. ``I don't think the studios determine what people's tastes are,'' he said. ``The tastes dictate what gets done.'' Three years ago, according to the SAG report, actresses claimed a third of all film roles. In 1989, they took 29 percent of all movie parts. Also in 1989, 41 percent of all film roles were for male supporting actors and female leading roles made up only 14 percent of the total. Jeffrey Katzenberg, chairman of Walt Disney Studios, said employment for women at Disney is fairer than the study suggests. ``We're trying as hard as we can,'' Katzenberg said. ``We're putting them to work.''

DOC.HEAD: McMartin Pre-School Criminal Case is Over, Civil Cases Remain
DOC.TEXT: The book is closed on the criminal end of the McMartin Pre-School molestation case, but the civil claims are just beginning. A jury hearing Raymond Buckey's retrial on eight child molestation charges deadlocked last week. On Wednesday, Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg accepted a prosecution request to close the case without a third trial. ``The case of the People vs. Raymond Buckey is hereby dismissed and the defendant is discharged,'' Weisberg said. ``That completes this case.'' Buckey promptly announced he was filing a lawsuit in state court alleging malicious prosecution, conspiracy, defamation and civil rights violations. His mother filed a similar lawsuit in federal court in January. ``My family has nothing left,'' Buckey said. ``Do we just walk out of the criminal system and they're not even going to say they're sorry?'' Lawyer Scott Bernstein, who did not represent Buckey in the criminal trial, said he will seek millions of dollars in compensation for Buckey. Buckey, 32, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were acquitted in January of 52 charges of molesting children at their now-closed preschool in Manhattan Beach. But the jury deadlocked on several other charges against him. That first trial took nearly three years and cost Los Angeles County more than $13.5 million, making it the longest and costliest criminal trial in U.S. history. Named as defendants in Buckey's lawsuit were the county, Manhattan Beach, former District Attorney Robert Philibosian, Children's Institute International and social worker Kee MacFarlane, KABC-TV and television newsman Wayne Satz. Satz broke the story and was romantically linked with Ms. MacFarlane, lead therapist at the institute where workers used play-acting techniques and anatomically correct dolls to interview children about alleged molestation.

DOC.HEAD: Two Countries Produce 20 Percent of OPEC Oil, 5 Percent Of U.S. Consumption
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq and Kuwait produce one-fifth of the total oil produced by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, and their oil accounts for an estimated 5 percent of daily U.S. consumption. Iraq is one of the major producers of the 13-member oil cartel, with a daily OPEC production quota of 3.14 million barrels. That equal's Iran quota and is second only to Saudi Arabia's quota of 5.1 million barrels. Kuwait's quota is 1.5 million barrels per day out of an estimated production capacity of 2.2 million to 2.5 million barrels per day. The United States buys about 200,000 barrels of oil daily from Kuwait and 500,000-600,000 barrels from Iraq. In the first six months of this year the United States imported 49.9 percent of its oil. It produced 7.3 million barrels a day, the lowest level in 29 years according to the American Petroleum Institute. In the first half of 1990, OPEC produced about 23.5 million barrels of crude oil per day, according to the Nicosia-based industry newsletter the Middle East Economic Survey. World production outside the Soviet Union and its former satellites was about 52 million barrels daily. Kuwait is the only OPEC member to have developed an integrated international system covering both production and distribution of oil. The latter is done through a network of gas stations in Europe and elsewhere in partnership with leading oil companies. Kuwait's huge oil reserves are backed by one of the largest financial reserves in the world. Kuwait has more than $100 billion in surplus petrodollars, mostly invested in the United States, Britain, West Germany, France and other industrialized countries.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Want to Launch Rockets from Florida
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union wants to launch unmanned rockets from Florida under a policy awaiting President Bush's approval. Bush is expected to act soon on guidelines, which would allow foreign countries to send up rockets from the United States. The Soviets are interested in launching Proton rockets from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, next to NASA's Kennedy Space Center. The center is much nearer the equator than the Soviets' launch site, making it easier to put satellites into the most commonly used orbit, above the equator. The Soviets won't make a formal request until the guidelines are final, said William Wirin, executive vice president of Space Commerce Corp., a Houston company that markets Soviet rockets outside the Soviet Union. Space Commerce recently relayed an informal request to the Spaceport Florida Authority, a state agency formed last year to support U.S. commercial space ventures. American launch companies fear their businesses will be jeopardized if American commercial payloads such as satellites are allowed to ride on Soviet rockets. ``This is not something we consider our mission by any means,'' said Ed Ellegood, the spaceport authority's operations manager. He said officials will not discuss the Soviet proposal until a formal request is made. The Soviet Union also is considering launch sites in Australia and Brazil.

DOC.HEAD: Skies Clear Over Most of the Nation
DOC.TEXT: Skies were hazy in the South but clear over the rest of the nation early today. Thunderstorms were expected again in Texas, where heavy rains caused flooding Wednesday and shut down some highways. Another day of thunderstorms was predicted for several other Southern states, including Louisiana, Mississippi, Georgia, South Carolina and Florida. Thunderstorms also were expected in Minnesota and Wisconsin. Continued sunny, pleasant weather was expected in the Northeast, while a mixture of sun and clouds was forecast for the Midwest. The East and Midwest were expected to have highs in the 80s, and the South in the 90s. Sunny, hot weather was predicted for most of the West, with thunderstorms possible in Nevada and Wyoming. Temperatures in Southern California and Arizona were expected to climb into the 100s. The high temperature for the nation Wednesday was 113 degrees at Lake Havasu City, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Small, Fabulously Rich, Envied by Neighbors
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait is a small kingdom whose fabulous riches have sometimes made it the envy of the much-larger neighbors that surround it. Baghdad has long claimed that the 6,880-square-mile Kuwait is part of Iraq, although Kuwait has been ruled by the Al-Sabah family as an emirate since 1756. Kuwait's relatively free-wheeling newspapers are read throughout the Arab world, and Kuwait has long been a major donor of economic aid to poorer countries inside and outside the Arab world. Recently, pro-democracy activists mounted a campaign for restoration of the country's parliament, which had been suspended in 1986 after fierce attacks on the government by opposition deputies. The emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, later introduced an interim National Council with 50 elected members and 25 appointed, charged with paving the way for restoration of a full parliament. Kuwait's oil tanker fleet was a frequent target of Iranian attacks during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, and Iranian missiles were sent into Kuwait at the height of the hostilities. Shiite Moslem terrorists, backed by Iran, launched repeated attacks in Kuwait during the war, including the successful bombings of the French and American embassies and an abortive attempt to kill the emir. The Kuwaitis are an ancient seafaring people. But more than half the population of 1.8 million are foreigners, mainly Arab, including 300,000 Palestinians. Most Kuwaitis are Sunni Moslem, but 30 percent adhere to the rival Shiite sect. Shiites of Iranian descent number nearly 150,000. The Al-Sabah clan has ruled Kuwait as an emirate since they settled there in the 18th century after trekking from the Arabian hinterland. Kuwait lives on its oil. Revenue reached $30 billion in 1983 but has been declining since because of a drop in oil prices and production curbs. Kuwait currently produces about 1.5 million barrels of oil a day and has reserves of 89.7 billion barrels, 12.8 percent of world reserves and enough to last for more than 250 years. Little grows in the desert climate, so the emirate has to import nearly all its food. The Mongols, Arab caliphs and Ottomans were by turn overlords of the bleak and largely unpopulated land until 1899, when the British became the dominant power in the region. Kuwait gained its independence in 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Redistricting Plan Rejected in Los Angeles County
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing expected to begin in the afternoon EDT. Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: A judge who ruled Los Angeles County's Board of Supervisors had illegally drawn its districts to keep Hispanics from getting elected rejected as nonsensical a plan offered by the board to solve the problem. U.S. District Judge David Kenyon on Wednesday called for a new plan, raising the prospect of a radical shift in the county's balance of power. Kenyon said the remedy offered by the board was a ``nonsensical distortion of existing supervisorial districts, a calloused interpretation of the Voting Rights Act, and is insensitive to the needs of Hispanic and black residents.'' The judge set a hearing for today to consider alternative plans from civil rights groups and the U.S. Justice Department. Civil rights groups and the department had sued in 1988, accusing the supervisors of deliberately spreading the Hispanic population across several districts when they changed voting boundaries after the 1980 census. Though Hispanics make up about 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million residents, the five-member board has not had an elected Hispanic member in 115 years. On June 7, Kenyon ruled against the supervisors, concluding they violated the Voting Rights Act. The board's conservatives responded by drafting a plan that created a Hispanic majority in one liberal board member's district while also preserving the board's conservative majority. It was this plan Kenyon rejected Wednesday. The next redistricting plans, to be submitted by the American Civil Liberties Union, the government and a Mexican-American group, could greatly increase Hispanic political clout and overturn the conservative majority. That could have profound implications for funding in such areas as health and social services. Conservative Supervisor Mike Antonovich denounced the judge's decision and said he will appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Surge on Middle East Turmoil
DOC.TEXT: The dollar soared against the Japanese yen and gained strongly against other key currencies in European trading today after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Gold prices leaped more than $8. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 148.90 yen, up 2.25 from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 150.25 yen. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday: _1.6105 West German marks, up from 1.5920 _1.3730 Swiss francs, up from 1.3555 _5.3970 French francs, up from 5.3355 _1.8170 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7935 _1,178.75 Italian lire, up from 1,164.75 _1.1533 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1530 In London, one British pound cost $1.8395 late today, down from Wednesday's late $1.8550. The dollar had dropped more than 4 yen in Tokyo trading between Monday and Wednesday, but the Iraqi invasion reversed market sentiment. ``The dollar was bought briskly and quickly'' following news of the invasion, said Masakazu Kimura, a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. Bank of Tokyo trader Masafumi Koyama said fears of higher oil prices and uncertainties over the Iraq-Kuwait dispute accelerated the dollar buying in the afternoon. ``Investors generally tend to overreact to any news from the Middle East, but now they are waiting to see the reaction from the European and U.S. markets after we close,'' Koyama said. The dollar also finished in Europe at 147.20 yen, up from the Tokyo close of 146.65 yen. That brought the dollar back to the level at the start of Tokyo trading Wednesday morning. In London, gold was quoted at a late price of $382.60 bid per ounce this morning, up from $374.30 a troy ounce late Wednesday. In Zurich, where markets were closed for a holiday on Wednesday, gold was quoted at $382.00. Gold in Hong Kong rose $7.93 an ounce on Thursday, to close at $379.39. Silver bullion traded in London at a bid price of $4.95 a troy ounce, from $4.85.

DOC.HEAD: Reunion of Two Pioneer Families Likely to Draw 600 Descendants
DOC.TEXT: Two prairie pioneer clans are inviting one and all to their first joint reunion, where activities include a watermelon-seed spitting contest, men's hammer throw and women's skillet toss. More than 600 descendants of frontier homesteaders William O. Coe and John Henry Russell are expected to gather from Aug. 10-12 for the reunion celebrating family bonds that began before the turn of the century. Offspring of the two men who established farms in Nebraska and Kansas chose to celebrate in Orleans, a town of 1,109 about 10 miles from the state line. In 1872, Coe and his wife, Emily, were the first homesteaders in Harlan County's Washington Township. They lived in a sod house not far from Orleans. In 1887, Russell and his wife, Margaret, homesteaded near Woodruff, Kan., south of Orleans across the state line. Third-generation Jerold Russell said his father married a Coe and as a boy he had more than 70 first cousins. Tracing relations through the years can get complicated, he said ``All I know is a whole bunch of Russells married a whole bunch of Coes,'' said Virgil Russell. Tours of the original homesteads are planned along with a watermelon-seed spitting contest and water-balloon toss. There also will be sack races and a haystack scramble. A flea market, a ladies' skillet toss and men's hammer throw are scheduled, along with a barbershop quartet concert and a street dance featuring the Wright Boys, more Russell cousins.

DOC.SECOND: Lawyers: Independent Autopsy Showed Teen's Hands Were Raised When
DOC.TEXT: Shot

Medical evidence showing that a teen-ager fatally shot in the back by police had his hands raised in surrender when the officer opened fire prompted the state's top prosecutor to reopen the case, lawyers said. Police said Phillip Pannell, 16, had a gun and was reaching for it when Officer Gary Spath shot him in April. A discredited coroner's report supported the story told by Spath and partner, Officer Wayne Blanco. DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraq Invades Kuwait Two Weeks After Threatening Attack In Oil Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. freezing assets, U.N. condemnation. Picks up 13th pvs, `Secretary of ...' Breaks into two takes. ^LaserPhotos NY4,5,6,8
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's powerful army overran this small oil-rich kingdom before dawn today and tank-led troops quickly seized the ruler's palace and other government buildings, Kuwaiti officials said. Iraq said it had come to the aid of ``revolutionary youth in Kuwait'' who had toppled the government and set up a new administration. The Kuwaiti ruler, whose palace was bombed by Iraqi jet fighters, reportedly fled to neighboring Saudi Arabia. Casualties in the blitz were reported heavy and the shelling fierce, but no figures were immediately available. The invasion came hours after Iraq abruptly broke off talks on a disputed border oil field. Iraq also was demanding billions of dollars for oil Kuwait pumped out of the field and the writeoff of billions in loans. ``The Iraqis have occupied all of Kuwait!'' a Kuwaiti official shouted in a telephone interview from Kuwait city just hours after thousands of Iraqi troops and hundreds of tanks stormed across the border 75 miles away. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Iraqi forces ``seized all administrative buildings, including the Information Ministry which houses the (state-run) radio and television stations.'' The Iraqi invasion was the first time in modern history that an Arab nation has moved troops over the border of another Arab state to take control. Saddam, Iraq's totalitarian leader, has long harbored ambitions to lead the Arab world and has committed his country's vast oil wealth to building an arsenal that could achieve that end. The palace of the country's ruler, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, was seized after two hours of heavy artillery and jet fighter attacks. Diplomatic sources in Saudi Arabia said the emir and his brother fled to Saudi Arabia early today. The sources would not say how the two got there. The Al-Sabah family has ruled Kuwait for nearly 250 years. Witnesses said the bombardment of ports and airports was vicious. Thousands of residents attempted to flee south toward Saudi Arabia in their cars. In Washington, the Bush administration condemned the invasion and froze all Iraq property in the United States and other areas under U.S. control. It also froze Kuwait property under U.S. jurisdiction to keep Iraq from seizing it. In New York, the U.N. Security Council swiftly condemned the invasion and demanded an unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops. Iraqi first threatened military action against its former ally Kuwait two weeks ago, and six U.S. warships began conducting exercises 600 miles to the southeast in the Persian Gulf on July 24. CNN reported without attribution that a battle group led by the carrier USS Independence was en route to the Persian Gulf from the Indian Ocean. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in Siberia for talks with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, asked the Soviet foreign minister to immediately cease Soviet arms deliveries to Iraq. Baker then flew to Mongolia, and U.S. officials said privately that he would cut short his visit there. Iraqi troops set up roadblocks at major intersections in the capital and on the main thoroughfare, Fahd Salem Street, where they were seen forcing drivers out of their cars and ripping phones out of the vehicles. Cars that did not stop were shot at. More than 60 percent of the country's 1.8 million residents are foreigners. Diplomats said about 350 Iraqi tanks wheeled into the Kuwaiti capital a few hours after crossing the border 40 miles away. The Kuwaiti Embassy in Washington said casualties were high but gave no numbers. Residents said about 50 tanks were around the emir's palace and the neighboring U.S. Embassy. The embassy did no answer its telephones. The White House said it had no reports of harm to the estimated 3,800 Americans in Kuwait.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Invasion Latest Adventure of Iraqi Strongman
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is the latest thrust for ambitious President Saddam Hussein. Saddam earlier this year threatened to destroy half of Israel with internationally outlawed chemical weapons if Israel tried to attack any Iraqi military facilities. Western nations are nervous about Iraq's military posturing. Police have arrested several people in Britain on charges they were trying to smuggle nuclear-bomb triggers to Baghdad. Police in Britain and other European countries also intercepted shipments that they said were parts of a gigantic gun capable of firing chemical or nuclear shells into Israel, 250 miles west of the Iraqi border. Seeking to don the Arab nationalist mantle of the late Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser, Saddam has acquired a reputation for ruthlessness. Obsessed about security, he ordered the March 15 execution of Iranian-born, London-based journalist Farzad Bazoft, who had tried to gather information about a huge explosion at a military-industrial complex. Iraq has the second-largest known oil reserves in the world after Saudi Arabia _ more than 100 billion barrels. Using oil revenue and his absolute power, Saddam initiated ambitious social, educational and economic development programs in the 1970s. His eight-year war with Iran left him with the Arab world's most formidable and battle-trained army, but his nation was also saddled with about $70 billion in war debts _ of which $10 billion to $20 billion was owed to Kuwait. Saddam had demanded that Kuwait write off that debt. Saddam launched an economic reconstruction drive after the August 1988 cease-fire with Iran but was constantly strapped for cash. He turned his attention to Kuwait, whose roaring oil production was helping glut the market and drive prices down, cutting Saddam's precious revenues. Iraq claimed Kuwait was stealing oil from a border oil field and demanded Kuwait's Bubiyan Island, which is opposite Iraq's only outlets to the sea. Baghdad has even claimed for years that Kuwait is part of Iraq. A majority of Iraq's 16 million people are Shiite Moslems, the same branch of Islam as most Iranians who the Iraqis were at war with between 1980 and 1988. But Iraq is ruled by Sunni Moslems. There are small Christian communities and an enclave in the north where most of the country's rebellious 3.5 million Kurds live. Captured by Britain in 1916, Iraq became independent in 1932. A military coup in 1958 ended the monarchy. Saddam came to power in 1979 and gradually tightened the grip of his ruling Baath Socialist Party.

DOC.HEAD: KUWAIT: in Kuwait.
DOC.TEXT: The British Embassy was hit by shellfire and the Sheraton and Hilton hotels evacuated their clientele, sources said. Swiss charge d'affaires Franco Bessoni said on French radio that the palace was taken after bombardment by Iraqi MiG jet fighters. ``You can see black smoke over there .... No one dares to go out. You can hear gunfire. The entire foreign community is staying indoors,'' he said. ``It's chaos, military jets are flying over all the time, Kathy McGregor, a Canadian, said by telephone at about midday. She said she could still hear artillery fire. The air space over Kuwait was closed, with airliners turned away. Iraq also sealed its own borders and airspace. Iraq said in a statement that it had ``responded to the request from interim government of free Kuwait and decided to cooperate with it.'' It said its troops _ no numbers were given _ were in Kuwait to defend the revolution and the Kuwaiti people. There was no further identification of the revolutionary government. Saddam's ruling council also warned that any foreign troops trying to interfere with its actions would be attacked. Kuwaiti forces had engaged the Iraqi invaders with heavy artillery in their failed attempt to repulse them, Kuwaiti officials said earlier. The invaders were led by the elite Republican Guard that did the brunt of the fighting in the 1980-88 war with Iran. Iraq has an estimated 1 million troops _ including reservists _ among its 16 million people, compared to 20,300 troops in Kuwait. Iraqi radio said 15 army divisions were being recalled and ordered all men born between 1960 and 1966 to report to the army within three days. Today's fighting quickly sent oil prices surging in international markets. The price of North Sea Brent crude for September delivery was quoted early today at $22.30 a barrel against Wednesday's London close of $20.40. Iraq, the world's second-largest oil producer, had demanded higher oil prices at last month's OPEC oil cartel meeting in Geneva. Saddam had threatened military action against Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates for exceeding their cartel production quotas and driving crude prices down. OPEC agreed to cut output to boost prices. The invasion came a day after talks between Kuwait and Iraq collapsed in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia. Kuwait had apparently refused to bend to Iraqi demands. The crisis began July 17 when Saddam accused Kuwait of trying to wreck the debt-ridden Iraqi economy with oil overproduction and began massing troops on Kuwait's border. He also accused Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion in oil drilled from the border oil field, Rumailah. Iraq also demanded the Kuwaiti island of Bubiyan, which is opposite Iraq's only outlets to the Persian Gulf. Iraq, which reportedly massed about 100,000 troops at the border on Wednesday, has been engaged in a major defense buildup since Saddam came to power in 1979. But the Iran-Iraq war left it with a foreign debt of about $70 billion. Iraq borrowed $10 billion to $20 billion from Kuwait wants that debt forgiven. In Kuwait early today, the rattle of automatic guns sounded and explosions in rapid succession shook residents from their sleep and the Kuwaiti Cabinet quickly assembled. The Cabinet was holed up at the headquarters of the Supreme Defense Council with telephone and telex links cut off, said official sources. Kuwaiti radio briefly stopped broadcasting, then went back on the air on a different wavelength. A speaker believed to be Crown Prince and Prime Minister Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah appealed for Arab support. ``Oh Arabs, Kuwait's blood and honor is being violated, rush to its rescue ... the children, the women, the old men of Kuwait are calling on you,'' the speaker said. Kuwait, nearly the size of New Jersey, is a former British protectorate that gained independence in 1961. Its residents are among the wealthiest in the world because of the country's vast oil reserves.

DOC.HEAD: Hotel Executives Sweep San Francisco Streets
DOC.TEXT: Hotel executives traded beepers and briefcases for blue jeans, gloves and orange safety vests before sweeping the streets of San Francisco as part of a civic drive to spruce up the city. More than 20 Hyatt executive volunteers got down and dirty Wednesday in the attack on some of the 41,000 tons of curbside garbage that piles up each year. ``It's not glamorous, but it's kind of fun,'' said Greg Cornwell, a human resources director for the Park Hyatt. The managers and executives from the hotel chain are part of a drive known as Beautification and Urban Design, or BUD. ``It's really not that bad,'' said employment manager Stephnie Flores, 24, who admitted not everyone wanted to volunteer. ``You have gloves on and they give you brooms with really long handles so you're not getting right down into the garbage.'' Before beginning the dirty work, the group sipped tea, drank coffee from three silver urns, and ate muffins and sweet rolls. ``I believe in the community and I think this could be the cleanest city in the world,'' said Abdul Suleman, a Hyatt regional vice president working after a 27-hour flight from Pakistan. ``I'm tired and to tell you the truth I don't think I'm going to be out here every Wednesday,'' said Suleman. ``But if this is successful we want to continue the program next year with all employees.'' Public Works chief Richard Evans said his agency needs help from civic leaders and residents because his staff can't keep up with the garbage. ``We've gone from cleaning up 10,000 tons of garbage in 1976 to 41,000 tons last year. We need help,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: American Peace Corps Vvolunteer Rreportedly Rreleased
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. ambassador welcoming Swanson's release, saying he safe and unharmed. Pickup 6th, `Swanson was...'
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels released an American Peace Corps volunteer today after holding him for 50 days on the central Philippine island of Negros, a provincial governor said. Earlier in the day, the New People's Army freed a Japanese aid worker who had been held since May 29. Timothy Swanson, 26, of Cheyenne, Wyo., was handed over to a Red Cross team in a rural area more than 25 miles east of Bacolod, said Daniel Lacson, governor of Negros Occidental province. The Red Cross was to turn Swanson over to a ``freedom committee'' of local lawyers, officials and clerics who negotiated his release. Lacson said he had been notified of Swanson's release by radio. A large group of journalists accompanied the committee to the release point, but were unable to report back because of primitive communications. In Manila, the U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt said he welcomed Swanson's release and thanked efforts of Lacson and others who helped negotiate the volunteer's release. ``The Embassy is releived that he is safe, unharmed, and apparently in good health,'' the embassy said in a statement. Swanson was abducted June 13 from his home in the Negros mountain village of Patag, about 320 miles southeast of Manila. The United States suspended all Peace Corps operations in the Philippines on June 27 and sent volunteers home because of alleged reports that the rebels planned to target them. U.S. officials said they were unaware of Swanson's kidnapping when the order was issued and learned of it June 30 when they tried to contact him. Swanson's Filipino wife said rebels had warned her not to report the abduction. Earlier today, the rebels freed Fumio Mizuno, 36, of the Organization of Industrial, Spiritual and Cultural Advancement. Mizuno appeared in good health although he complained of fatigue. The New People's Army, the military wing of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines, has been waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Police Veterans Sentenced in Motorist's Robbery
DOC.TEXT: Two police officers were sentenced to up to 10 years in prison after being convicted of stopping a teen-ager's car and robbing him of $85. Officers Nathaniel Bell, 35, and Douglas Hankins, 32, called Nathaniel Marshall a liar before they were sentenced Tuesday on armed robbery charges. ``I've been an officer since June 1977 and this is the job I love,'' Bell told Recorder's Court Judge James Chylinski. ``I did not _ or my partner, either _ ever come into contact with Mr. Marshall.'' Marshall ``has been lying since day one,'' added Hankins, a 12-year veteran named in 1988 as his section's Officer of the Year by the Detroit Police Officers Association. Marshall, 18, testified that Bell and Hankins stopped his car in February 1989 on Detroit's northwest side. The plainclothes officers identified themselves as Detroit police, then brandished guns and took his wallet and the $85 in it, Marshall told the jury. Bell received a one- to 10-year sentence, and Hankins received a 1{- to 10-year sentence on the armed robbery convictions. Bell also was convicted of using a firearm to commit a felony and received a mandatory two-year prison term.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Sees Iraqi Invasion As Proof of Saddam's Danger
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with defense minister comment, Cabinet to discuss invasion, official comenting on conditions under which Israel would respond. Pickup 3rd graf, `Saddam had...' TRIMS thereafter.
DOC.TEXT: The defense minister said today that Israel is ready to respond to any armed threat from Iraq, and that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait shows that its president, Saddam Hussein, poses a threat to the entire world. The minister, Moshe Arens, told NBC television that Saddam's action was reminiscent of Nazi Germany's aggression in the 1930s. Iraq's forces overran its small oil-rich neighbor in a lightning strike before dawn today. ``Iraq will be looking around for other targets,'' Arens said, adding that Saddam ``represents a threat to the entire world, not just Israel.'' He told ABC television in a separate interview that Israel would step in ``only if Iraq takes aggressive action against Israel.'' But an Israeli government official who briefed reporters on the basis of anonymity said Iraq was aware there were ``red lines'' that could not be crossed without bringing an Israeli response. Asked if that included Iraqi entry into Jordan or Syria, the official said such a move would require ``very strong consideration'' by Israel. The Israeli Cabinet was to discuss the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait today. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's spokesman said the invasion bears out Israel's warnings that Saddam poses a genuine threat. ``We need to call on the international arena to open their eyes and see what is happening and to understand we need to take Saddam Hussein seriously, that he threatens and then carries out,'' the spokesman, Avi Pazner, told Israel radio. Saddam had threatened military action against Kuwait for its overproduction of oil, which has reduced prices for Iraq's oil. After threats, demands and abortive peace talks, Iraqi troops invaded. Pazner noted that Iraq is heavily armed from its eight-year war with Iran, which ended in 1988. ``Iraq has also proven that it doesn't hesitate to use this against its immediate neighbors and this policy of Saddam Hussein is what endangers the region's security,'' Pazner said. He said the Iraqi attack made clear ``that if there is a danger to the stability in the Middle East it is not our conflict with the Palestinians.'' Yossi Olmert, director of the Government Press Office, said Iraq's invasion of Kuwait proved Israel was right in taking seriously Saddam's repeated threats to attack Israel with chemical weapons if it attacked any Iraqi facilities. ``There was a period a few weeks ago when his threats were only directed toward us and people outside Israel didn't take him seriously,'' Olmert said. Yitzhak Rabin, a former defense minister, also said the Iraqi attack shows that the easing of U.S.-Soviet tensions has increased rather than lessened the danger of war in the Middle East. ``Glasnost has not arrived in the Middle East. Arms are still flowing into the Middle East from all places,'' Rabin said on Army radio.

DOC.HEAD: Testimony: Coe Had Pitiful Childhood, Faces Threats in Jail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents in 10th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of murder after plunging his stepson into a toilet should be spared the death penalty because he's had a pitiful life, his parents told the jury that's considering his sentence today. Thomas Coe, 23, was born with painful kidney and hip defects, wore a catheter until he was 5, was hospitalized more than 30 times and walked with a limp, jurors learned Wednesday. Coe's mother, Mary Coe Anders, said she had to pay other children to play with him. His father, Don, told jurors he ignored the boy he claimed was the result of an affair the mother had. That doesn't excuse Coe for killing 2-year-old Bradley McGee last July, lawyer Robert Norgard said. But it shows he ``suffered ramifications on into adulthood'' and helps explain why Coe shouldn't get the electric chair, he said. The jury, which found Coe guilty of first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse on Monday, can recommend that Circuit Judge Randall McDonald give him death or life in prison without parole for 25 years. Even in prison, Coe could face an uncertain future. Lt. Mike Pol, a shift commander at the Polk County Jail, said inmates have threatened to kill Coe ever since his arrest on July 29, 1989. Word of Coe's offense reached the jail as soon as he was booked, and inmates hung upside-down pictures of Coe on the wall, with a toilet underneath. Coe has been held in an isolation cell for protection and several times has been placed on suicide watch. Even in isolation, inmates at the jail have managed to put glass and steel wool in Coe's food, Pol said. Once, when Coe was going to see the doctor, inmates threw lye, urine and feces on him. Coe had used urine and feces to punish his stepson, according to trial testimony. As a child, Coe's physical problems were compounded by his parents' divorce. Family and friends told the jury he was suicidal by age 18 and felt inadequate and out of place with peers. The state called one witness during the penalty phase of the trial, an assistant medical examiner, who said Bradley could feel pain when he was repeatedly plunged headfirst into the toilet for soiling his pants. The boy's head struck the bottom of the bowl and he later died of head injuries. Coe's wife, Sheryl McGee Coe, 21, pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse in her son's death and is serving a 30-year prison term.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Warships On Watch
With PM-US-Iraq-Kuwait
Pentagon Source Says U.S. Aircraft Carrier Heading Toward Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The aircraft carrier USS Independence is steaming toward the Persian Gulf to beef up the U.S. presence in the troubled region in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Pentagon sources said today. The carrier, escorted by its six-ship battle group, has been in the Indian Ocean as part of a regularly scheduled deployment. The Pentagon source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Independence would not enter the Persian Gulf. The move comes as President Bush, meeting this morning with Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and other top aides at the White House, condemned the Iraqi invasion as ``naked aggression.'' The president called for the unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces. Speaking with reporters before a meeting of his top national security advisers, Bush said he would ``take whatever steps necessary to defend longstanding vital interests in the Gulf.'' Asked if that included military force, he said, ``We're not discussing intervention,'' while acknowledging, ``I would not discuss any military options'' publicly. Lights burned throughout the night at the Pentagon. Top military commanders and Cheney aides _ including Undersecretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz _ worked all night on Bush's speech on defense issues and trying to respond to the crisis in the Gulf. U.S. carriers traditionally have stayed out of the battle-scarred waterway, not only because of their size, but also to prevent them from becoming targets. However, the presence of the Forrestal-class carrier, bristling with attack aircraft and missiles, offers a potent symbol of U.S. military power. The ship's escort craft include two cruisers _ including one of the Aegis class _ a guided missile destroyer, two frigates and one ammunition ship. The carrier and its support group are prepared to bolster the U.S. naval forces in the Gulf, an eight-ship group led by the USS LaSalle. The LaSalle is a converted amphibious transport dock ship that still has amphibious assault capabilities. Additional command headquarters and communications gear were added to the ship to serve as a command platform for the U.S. commander of Middle East forces. It's accompanied by a cruiser, one destroyer and five frigates. Two of those ships recently entered the Gulf to relieve two of the six ships that have been stationed there, the Pentagon said.

DOC.HEAD: On a `Free' Vote, Big Honoraria Takers Vote Against Taking Fees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 7, There is, to reflect Senate passage of overall campaign-finance bill in Senate
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Simpson of Wyoming accepted $90,600 in honoraria last year; Republican colleague David Durenberger of Minnesota took $62,185. Across the aisle, Democratic Sens. David Boren of Oklahoma and Don Riegle of Michigan each raked in more than $52,000. Yet the four were among 77 senators who voted Wednesday to ban outside speaking fees, lining up to partake in one of Capitol Hill's favorite events _ a free vote. Indeed, 56 of the 77 voting to ban honoraria accepted such payments last year _ to the tune of nearly $2 million. Several of the 56 have since stopped accepting honoraria. But for the rest who still do, Wednesday's vote most likely will not choke the flow of millions in speaking and appearance fees from special interests. Last year alone, senators accepted nearly $3 million in honoraria and kept $2.1 million for personal use, giving the rest to charity _ in most cases to keep within Senate limits on outside income. The vote Wednesday was significant, if only symbolically, because for the first time the Senate went on record against accepting special interest fees. Such honoraria have figured prominently in several recent ethics cases against lawmakers and were banned on the House side effective this year. But the provision, sponsored by Democratic Sen. Christopher Dodd of Connecticut, was attached to a campaign finance measure that is vehemently opposed by Republicans lawmakers and the Bush administration. The overall measure cleared the Senate late Wednesday night, but the House has yet to act on the issue and has major differences with the Senate. On top of that, President Bush is promising to veto the legislation if it carries the Senate-passed provisions. ``This bill clearly will not become law,'' Sen. Mitch McConnell of Kentucky told his colleagues after speaking to White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. Thus, in the words of Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, the amendment gave senators a chance to ``vote no and take the dough'' _ at least until the proposal is attached to legislation with a better chance of becoming law. But some publicly hailed the vote, hoping to keep the pressure on senators. ``It is just a matter of time before the Senate joins the rest of the federal government in banning private interest speaking fees for personal use,'' said Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer. Election Day is just three months away, and the proposal to ban honoraria was popular among senators facing voters this year _ even many who have handsomely supplemented their Senate salary in the past. Among those voting for the proposal who face re-election were Democratic Sens. Max Baucus of Montana, Joseph Biden of Delaware, David Boren of Oklahoma, Albert Gore of Tennessee, Howell Heflin of Alabama, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, Sam Nunn of Georgia, David Pryor of Arkansas and Paul Simon of Illinois. They accepted a combined total of $335,148 in honoraria last year. On the Republican side, five senators up for re-election this year who accepted at least $20,000 in honoraria in 1989 voted in favor of the ban _ Dan Coats of Indiana, William Cohen of Maine, Larry Pressler of South Dakota, Alan Simpson of Wyoming and Ted Stevens of Alaska. They accepted a combined $212,900 last year. Also voting in favor of the ban was GOP Sen. Pete Wilson, the Republican candidate for governor in California, who accepted $48,500 in 1989. Six Republican senators up for re-election this year, apparently undaunted by the potential use of their vote as a campaign issue, voted against the ban. The six _ Sens. McConnell of Kentucky, Mark Hatfield of Oregon, Phil Gramm of Texas, Pete Domenici of New Mexico, Thad Cochran of Mississippi and Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota _ collected a combined $212,815 in honoraria last year. The Dodd proposal also found favor among all six senators with cases pending before the Ethics Committee: Democrat Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, Alan Cranston of California, John Glenn of Ohio and Riegle, and Republicans John McCain of Arizona and Alfonse D'Amato of New York. Cranston, DeConcini and Glenn were among 21 senators who did not accept honoraria in 1989. Riegle, McCain and D'Amato accepted a combined $125,000 in honoraria last year, with McCain giving all $30,250 of his to charity.

DOC.HEAD: Bertha Downgraded to Tropical Storm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf, `Meanwhile...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with depression becoming a named tropical storm. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Ship Distress
DOC.TEXT: Bertha, downgraded from a hurricane to a tropical storm, continued to lose strength today, a day after its winds and rain broke apart a freighter off the U.S. coast. The National Hurricane Center in Miami said at 6 a.m. EDT today that Bertha was centered near Port Aux Basques on the southwest tip of Newfoundland, with tropical storm-force winds of at least 39 mph. Bertha dropped below hurricane strength late Wednesday. The crew of the cargo ship Corazon, broken by 30-foot waves spawned by Hurricane Bertha abandoned ship in churning, chilly seas, the Coast Guard said today. Six crew members of the freighter drowned after the ship's keel snapped about 350 miles off Cape Cod. Twenty-one others were rescued by commercial ships providing lifeboats and rafts, the Coast Guard said. Heavy rainfall warnings for Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and eastern New Brunswick were discontinued by the Canadian government. At least six people were injured Wednesday in Nova Scotia during the high seas, though the hurricane skirted the mainland. Earlier Wednesday, forecasters had predicted it would hit Nova Scotia with full force. Meanwhile, the Atlantic hurricane season's fourth tropical depression became its named tropical storm, Cesar. It formed off the coast of Africa and moved westward across the Atlantic Ocean, said Max Mayfield at the National Hurricane Center. At 9 a.m. EDT, Cesar was centered near latitude 16.7 north, longitude 35.1 west, or about 625 miles west of the westernmost Cape Verde islands. It was moving west-northwest near 16 mph with maximum sustained winds of near 40 mph, and some increase in strength is likely during the next day or two, said forecaster Miles Lawrence.

DOC.HEAD: Videotape Received By Relative of Couple Who Apparently Took Own Lives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to RECAST lead and move up ages of couple. SUBS 8th graf with 1 graf to delete ages.
DOC.TEXT: A couple in their 40s who described themselves on videotape as fearful of growing old calmly talked of suicide, mailed the tape to a relative and took their lives, police said. A horror-stricken Ronald Ridenour raced Wednesday to the Anaheim home of his 48-year-old brother, Douglas, and 45-year-old sister-in-law, Dana, after he viewed the videotape at his house in Santa Barbara. There, he found their bodies slumped on separate couches in the den, along with the bodies of their two cherished poodles, police Capt. Stan Kantor said. ``They decided they reached the age where they have gone as far as they are going to go,'' said Sgt. Chet Barry. ``They decided they wanted to make the decision as to when it all should end.'' The murder-suicide had taken place two days earlier, Barry said. Ridenour apparently shot his wife before turning the 12-gauge shotgun on himself, he said. The couple, who had been married 22 years, had no children. Ronald Ridenour received the videotape in the mail, along with a will, a receipt for cremation services and some personal effects, Barry said. ``He told me (last week) that I'd be receiving an important package in the mail,'' Ronald said Wednesday. ``As soon as I saw those papers, I knew what the videotape was.'' In the 15-minute videotape, Douglas and Dana described some recent successes in real estate and said they planned to go on a $50,000 spending spree. The couple then talked about their fears of growing old and of ending their lives, Barry said. ``They said they had a full life and are very happy with it,'' Barry said. ``But neither one had a desire to grow old, and they were going to take care of it. They didn't leave any doubt what they had in mind.'' In the tape, they asked Ronald to cremate their bodies and scatter the ashes in the ocean. They even prepaid for a funeral, police said. The couple apparently had planned the suicide for months because the tape had been made in April, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Five Arrested In Protest of Mule-Diving Act
DOC.TEXT: Five members of an animal rights group were arrested after they tried to stop a mule-diving act in eastern Maryland. But others from People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals intend to continue picketing the act, which is scheduled to continue through Saturday at the Cecil County Fair in Elkton. Wednesday's arrests failed to stop the act, billed as ``the world's only high-diving mules.'' The animals jump from an 18-foot platform into a 6-foot-deep pool. Tim Rivers, the act's manager and mules' owner, said the mules like the water and none has been injured since it began in 1957. Shouting ``stop the torture, stop the pain,'' three protesters tried to handcuff themselves to the ramp leading to the diving platform. Two others jumped into the pool. Cecil County sheriff's deputies and state police pulled them from the water, Jackson said. All five were charged with disorderly conduct and released after being given citations, said a spokesman for the county detention center. State police spokesman Chuck Jackson said about 12 demonstrators picketed outside the fairgrounds. The protest came after the group failed to persuade the fair to bar the act or have animal cruelty charges filed against Rivers. Rivers said he only picks mules for the act who like the water. ``I'm not an animal activist, but I am an animal lover,'' Rivers said. ``Animals are my life. For me to abuse my animals would be for me to abuse my living.'' People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, a Washington-based group that claims 325,000 members, contends that the animals hit the water at 30 mph and emerge dazed and gasping for air. It has fought Rivers in several other states, in demonstrations and through court challenges. The Cecil County Humane Society said it had no legal grounds to challenge the act, saying nothing in state law prohibits it. Jenny Woods, a spokewoman for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, said the group would continue to picket and hand out leaflets.

DOC.HEAD: `Twin Peaks' Leads Emmy Nominations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, ``The Simpsons ..., to CORRECT total number of show's nominations to five, sted three; picks up 4th graf: `ABC, which ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: ABC's quirky drama ``Twin Peaks,'' which astounded critics and confounded television viewers, captured a leading 14 nominations today for the 42nd Annual Primetime Emmy Awards. NBC's legal drama ``L.A. Law'' earned 13 nominations, and NBC's ``Cheers'' and CBS's ``Murphy Brown'' each received 12 nominations. ``The Simpsons,'' the irreverent animated program from cartoonist Matt Groening, had five nominations. The series got three nominations, including best animated program, and ``The Simpsons Christmas Special'' received two. ABC, which finished last among the three networks in nominations last year, tied for first with NBC with 95 nominations. CBS drew 73 selections and the Fox Broadcasting Co. earned 23, up from 12 a year ago. The selections were announced in a predawn ceremony at the Beverly Hilton Hotel by Dana Delany of ABC's ``China Beach'' and Louis Gossett Jr., both Emmy winners themselves. Director David Lynch's ``Twin Peaks'' was nominated for outstanding drama series and its star Kyle MacLachlan was nominated for best actor in a drama series for his performance as enigmatic, pie-loving FBI agent Dale Cooper. The series also collected a nomination for lead actress Piper Laurie, two nominations for writing, and one to Lynch for directing the acclaimed pilot episode. Other nominees for best drama series were ABC's ``China Beach,'' NBC's ``L.A. Law'' and ``Quantum Leap,'' and ABC's ``thirtysomething.'' ``Cheers,'' the Boston bar comedy, was nominated again for best comedy series, which it won last year. Also nominated were CBS' ``Designing Women,'' and ``Murphy Brown,'' NBC's ``The Golden Girls'' and ABC's ``The Wonder Years.'' ABC's ``The Kennedys of Massachusetts,'' with eight nominations, headed the list of nominees for best miniseries. Other nominees were NBC's ``Blind Faith,'' NBC's ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story,'' CBS' ``Family of Spies'' and ABC's ``Small Sacrifices.'' The CBS movie ``Caroline?'' drew six nominations, including best drama-comedy special. It will face ABC's ``The Final Days,'' CBS' ``The Incident'' and ``A Killing in a Small Town,'' and NBC's ``Murder in Mississippi.'' Despite actress Tracey Ullman's decision to end her inventive Fox variety series, it won a total of 13 nominations. ``The Tracey Ullman Show'' received nine nominations, and ``The Best of the Tracey Ullman Show'' was recognized four times. Other multiple nominees included ``thirtysomething'' with 11, the syndicated ``Star Trek: The Next Generation'' with nine and ``The Golden Girls'' with eight. ``Roseanne,'' the top-rated but increasingly controversial comedy series, earned just two nominations, including a best comedy actor selection for series co-star John Goodman. Series star Roseanne Barr was not nominated, but her exclusion had nothing to do with her shrilly mangled rendition of the national anthem at a San Diego Padres baseball game.
