Emmy balloting closed before her infamous performance. ``Roseanne'' and its leading performer also were overlooked in last year's nominations, even though the situation comedy was the nation's favorite. Also overlooked was ``The Cosby Show,'' which has been one of TV's most consistent hits but hasn't been an Emmy winner since 1986. Richard Mulligan, who won the Emmy for best comedy actor last year, was nominated again in the category for NBC's ``Empty Nest.'' He will face Goodman, Ted Danson of ``Cheers,'' Craig T. Nelson of ABC's ``Coach'' and child star Fred Savage of ABC's ``The Wonder Years.'' Their female counterparts in the comedy competition were Kirstie Alley for ``Cheers,'' Delta Burke for CBS's ``Designing Women,'' Betty White in ``The Golden Girls,'' Candice Bergen in ``Murphy Brown'' and Blair Brown for ``The Days & Nights of Molly Dodd,'' which is seen on cable's Lifetime network. For supporting performances in a comedy, the choices were Woody Harrelson and Kelsey Grammer for ``Cheers,'' Jerry Van Dyke in ``Coach,'' Charles Kimbrough for ``Murphy Brown'' and Alex Rocco in CBS' ``The Famous Teddy Z.'' Supporting comic actress were Rhea Perlman and Bebe Neuwirth in ``Cheers,'' Estelle Getty for ``The Golden Girls, '' Faith Ford from ``Murphy Brown'' and Julia Duffy in CBS' ``Newhart.'' Nominated for dramatic actor were Peter Falk for ABC's ``Columbo,'' Edward Woodward from CBS' ``The Equalizer,'' Robert Loggia in NBC's ``Mancuso FBI,'' Scott Bakula in ``Quantum Leap'' and MacLachlan from ``Twin Peaks.'' Dramatic actress choices were Dana Delaney in ``China Beach,'' Jill Eikenberry from ``L.A. Law,'' Angela Lansbury for CBS' ``Murder, She Wrote,'' Patricia Wettig of ``thirtysomething'' and Miss Laurie for ``Twin Peaks.'' ``L.A. Law'' collected three of the nominations for supporting dramatic actor, for Richard Dysart, Larry Drake and Jimmy Smits. Dean Stockwell was chosen from ``Quantum Leap'' and Timothy Busfield of ``thirtysomething,'' who's in a contract dispute with the show. Sherilyn Fenn, who plays Audrey Horne on ``Twin Peaks,'' was nominated for best supporting dramatic actress, as were Marg Helgenberger of ``China Beach,'' Melanie Mayron of ``thirtysomething'' and Diana Muldaur and Susan Ruttan of ``L.A. Law.'' Among the more notable nominations was one for the late Jim Henson, who created the Muppets. He was named for directing a variety or music program, ``The Song of the Cloud Forest,'' from ``The Jim Henson Hour.'' ``In Living Color,'' the daring black sketch comedy show, was nominated for best variety, music or comedy series. A total of 361 nominations were made. The Emmy winners will be selected Aug. 26-27 by directors, actors and writers. The awards ceremony will be broadcast live on Fox on Sept. 16 from the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. It will be the third consecutive Emmy broadcast for Fox, which has rights to the ceremony for two more years.

DOC.HEAD: All South Koreans Can Apply to Visit North, Seoul Says
DOC.TEXT: South Korea said today all citizens would be allowed to apply to visit Communist North Korea during a five-day period next month, provided the North guarantees their safe return. The announcement was the first time South Korea has offered to let all citizens apply to cross the border and visit the North. A 1985 exchange program was limited to about 100 people who were members of separated families. ``We hope...this would not only lead to the reunion of separated families, but also the sharing of the emotional excitment by embracing each other after 45 years of separation,'' Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul told reporters. All applicants accepted by the North would be allowed to cross the border Aug. 13-17, Hong said. That implied that even if the North chooses to allow only South Korean dissidents to visit, the South would allow them to go. Previously, the Seoul government's position has been that Koreans from ``all walks of life'' must be included in proposed travel exchanges. Hong said the government expected North Korea to guarantee the travelers' safe travel and return to South Korea by communicating on a government-to-government basis, not via a radio broadcast. North Korea frequently issues pronouncements concerning policy on North Korean radio broadcasts, monitored in Tokyo. The Seoul government's announcement follows a July 20 proclamation by South Korean President Roh Tae-woo calling for a five-day border opening to allow free and unrestricted travel between the hostile Koreas. The North had earlier proposed a more limited one-day border opening. North Korea effectively rejected Roh's proposal by listing a set of conditions unlikely to be met, including release of political prisoners, dismantling of border barriers and abolition of anti-Communist security laws. When the South proposed a meeting to discuss the preconditions, the North did not reply. By today's announcement and presentation of an application form, the government appears to be trying to put pressure on the North to accept a trial exchange. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist North and capitalist South in 1945 and the two nations fought a civil war in the early 1950s. The border between the Koreas is the most heavily fortified in the world with more than 1.5 million armed troops behind concrete bunkers and barbed wire on either side. There are no telephone, radio, television or travel exchanges.

DOC.HEAD: Secretary Of State Urges Soviets To Halt Arms Shipments To Iraq
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE that Baker to cut short visit, return to Washington Friday. Pickup 7th graf, `Graves, who...' TRIMS.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III condemned Iraq's attack on Kuwait today and said he had asked Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to immediately cease Soviet arms deliveries to Iraq. Baker spoke to reporters aboard a U.S. Air Force jet heading from a meeting with the Soviet foreign minister in the Siberian city of Irkutsk to Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia. Baker later said he would cut short his Mongolian visit and fly back to Washington on Friday, two days earlier than scheduled. The move came after he conferred with President Bush by telephone, the secretary told reporters. The secretary said he asked Shevardnadze to halt ``any military or arms deliveries that they might have in the pipeline to Iraq.'' Baker said Shevardnadze ``was not pleased to hear that Iraqi forces had moved into Kuwait,'' but the U.S. envoy declined to comment on whether the Soviet foreign minister agreed to stop arms deliveries. ``We condemn this. We want Iraq to withdraw,'' Baker told reporters. ``Intimidation is not the way to solve problems.'' Baker said he heard about the invasion just before he went into a final negotiating session with Shevardnadze this morning. The secretary was to leave for Washington Friday afternoon after meeting with Mongolian opposition members and hosting Mongolian government officials at a lunch. He had originally planned to take a private hunting and fishing trip in the Gobi Desert. Baker he also was keeping in touch with developments in Kuwait through Lt. Gen. Howard Graves of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, who is traveling with him. Graves, who was in touch with the Pentagon, said the United States was considering ``political, military or economic'' moves against Iraq. ``A decision is being made,'' said Graves, who is assistant to the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Baker told reporters at the start of a meeting with Mongolian President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat that he planned to complete the official portion of his visit, but it was not clear if the schedule would be accelerated because of the Persian Gulf developments. Baker, the highest-level American to visit in 46 years, expressed support for recent democratic reforms in this long-time Soviet satellite nation. ``We are very heartened by the peaceful emergence of democracy in Mongolia,'' he told reporters as he sat down for talks with Ochirbat.``We have expressed our desire to continue to support political and economic reforms in Mongolia.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Condemns Iraqi Invasion, Seeks Pullout, Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with British envoy's comment. Pickup 5th graf pvs, ``The United..''
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council today swiftly condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, demanding an unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops and calling for immediate negotiations between the countries. The Iraqi envoy said his country's troops would withdraw ``as soon as the situation is stable,'' perhaps within ``a few days or some weeks.'' The Security Council resolution was adopted 14-0 in an emergency session requested by the United States and Kuwait hours after today's pre-dawn invasion. Neither Kuwait nor Iraq is on the 15-member council. The representative of Yemen said he did not vote because he had not received instructions from his government. Britain's U.N. envoy, Crispin Tickell, condemned the invasion as an ``ugly moment in world affairs.'' Kuwait is a former British colony. ``The United States has made it clear that it will stand shoulder to shoulder with Kuwait in this time of crisis,'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering told the council. ``It is our understanding that the present aggression was completely unprovoked.'' Baghdad radio claimed Iraq had come to the aid of ``revolutionary youth in Kuwait'' whom it said had toppled the Kuwaiti government. Kuwait's ambassador to the United Nations, Mohammad Abulhasan, denied the invasion was in response to a call from help from a new government. ``The pretext to invade an independent, sovereign state is a false, flimsy pretext,'' he said. ``This kind of pretext, if it's not going to be deterred in a decisive manner and by this august assembly, all international relations will be threatened. No country at all will be safe after this.'' A statement read by Sabah Talat Kadrat, Iraq's deputy permanant representative said Iraq's forces would withdraw when what it referred to as the ``free Kuwaiti interim government'' requested it. The Iraqi statement was also reported by the Iraqi News Agency in Baghdad. The Security Council resolution said the council supports all efforts for negotiations between Iraq and Kuwait. It specifically endorsed mediation efforts by the Arab League, which met in emergency session in Cairo today. The Iraqi invasion posed ``a breach of international peace and security,'' the Security Council said. Kadrat said the events were related to an internal matter that was not the council's concern. ``The Iraqi government firmly believes and states that Iraq is pursuing no goal or objective and wishes only cordial relations with Kuwait,'' said Kadrat. ``Furthermore, it is the Kuwaitis themselves who will determine their own future and Iraqi forces will withdraw as soon as order has been restored.'' Members of the 15-member Security Council began gathering at the United Nations shortly after midnight. Diplomats held more than three hours of private consultations before convening the formal meeting. Kuwaiti spokesman Nasser Al-Sabeeh said before the formal meeting that Kuwait wants negotiations with Iraq to be mediated by the Arab League. ``But if it's necessary, then we would seek U.N. mediation,'' he said. Two weeks ago, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq threatened military action with Kuwait over its violation of OPEC oil production ceilings and a disputed border oil field. Saddam also has accused some Persian Gulf nations of conspiring with the United States and Israel to weaken Iraq's economy and undermine its military buildup. Today's resolution was sponsored by Canada, Colombia, Ivory Coast, Ethiopia, Finland, France, the United States, Britain and Malaysia. The 15 members of the Security Council are China, Yemen, Romania, the Soviet Union, Cuba, Canada, Colombia, Ivory Coast, Ethiopia, Finland, France, the United States, the United Kingdom, Malaysia and Zaire.

Here is the text of President Bush's executive order freezing control of Iraqi assets in the United States and prohibiting transactions with Iraq. By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and laws of the United States of America, including the International Emergency Economic Powers Act ..., the National Emergencies Act ... and section 301 of title 3 of the United States Code, I, George Bush, president of the United States of America, find that the policies and actions of the Government of Iraq constitute an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States and hereby declare a national emergency to deal with that threat. I hereby order: Section 1. All property and interests in property of the Government of Iraq, its agencies, instrumentalities and controlled entities and the Central Bank of Iraq that are in the United States, that hereafter come within the United States or that are or hereafter come within the possession or control of United States persons, including their overseas branches, are hereby blocked. Section 2. The following are prohibited, except to the extent provided in regulations which may hereafter be issued pursuant to this order: (a) The import into the United States of any goods or services of Iraqi origin, other than publications and other informational materials; (b) The export to Iraq of any goods, technology (including technical data or other information controlled for export pursuant to Section 5 of the Export Administration Act . . . or services from the United States, except publications and other informational materials, and donations of articles intended to relieve human suffering, such as food, clothing, medicine and medical supplies intended strictly for medical purposes. (c) Any transaction by a United States person relating to transportation to or from Iraq; the provision of transportation to or from the United States by any Iraqi person or any vessel or aircraft of Iraqi registration; or the sale in the United States by any person holding authority under the Federal Aviation Act of 1958, as amended . . . of any transportation by air which includes any stop in Iraq; (d) The purchase by any United States person of goods for export from Iraq to any country. (e) The performance by any United States person of any contract in support of an industrial or other commercial or governmental project in Iraq; (f) The grant or extension of credits or loans by any United States person to the Government of Iraq, its instrumentalities and controlled entities. (g) Any transaction by a United States person relating to travel by any United States citizen or permanent resident alien to Iraq, or to activities by any such person within Iraq, or travel for journalistic activity by persons regularly employed in such capacity by a news gathering organization; and (h) Any transaction by any United States person which evades or avoids, or has the purpose of evading or avoiding, any of the prohibitions set forth in this order. For purposes of this order, the term `United States person' means any United States citizen, permanent resident alien, juridical person organized under the laws of the United States, or any person in the United States.'' Section 3. This order is effective immediately. Section 4. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of State, is hereby authorized to take such actions, including the promulgation of rules and regulations, as may be necessary to carry out the purposes of this Order. Such actions may include prohibiting or regulating payments or transfers of any property or any transactions involving the transfer of anything of economic value by any United States person to the government of Iraq, its instrumentalities and controlled entities, or to any Iraqi national or entity owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, by Iraq or Iraqi nations. The secretary may redelegate any of these functions to other officers and agencies of the federal government. All agencies of the United States government are directed to take all appropriate measures within their authority to carry out the provisions of this Order, including the suspension or termination or licenses or other authorizations in effect as of the date of this Order. This Order shall be transmitted to the Congress and published in the Federal Register.

DOC.HEAD: Uzbekistan Agrees to Obey Gorbachev's Weapons Confiscation Order
DOC.TEXT: Uzbekistan's government announced steps today to implement a presidential order to seize weapons from illegally armed groups. The Uzbekistan Council of Ministers ordered city councils to collect illegal arms in their regions, Tass reported. The official Soviet news agency said 3,685 weapons were seized or handed in voluntarily before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's July 25 decree. Tass said 254 stolen guns were still missing. Gorbachev gave illegally armed groups throughout the Soviet Union 15 days to disband themselves and turn in their weapons, or risk having them confiscated by security forces. It was his latest attempt to reduce ethnic violence in the southern Caucasus and Central Asian republics that has killed more than 400 people in the last two years. The Armenian parliament has voted to ignore the decree, although Tass reported today that lawmakers said they would be willing to discuss their decision with Gorbachev who is vacationing in the Crimea. Armenian nationalists said earlier this week the decision would also extend to the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, a mostly Armenian enclave inside the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan. Georgia has also refused to implement the decree, at least until its parliament resumes work on Aug. 17. Azerbaijan's Interior Ministry published a commentary in today's local newspapers praising the decree for giving law enforcement agencies powers to restore order and neutralize extremists, the Interfax news agency reported. In the Armenian capital, Yerevan, 100 flamethrowers were seized after an attack on a military unit, Interfax said.

DOC.HEAD: `Mercy Killer' Released From Prison Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6 pvs. beginning `Before leaving ...' with 9 grafs to UPDATE with comments from Gilbert at press conference, new comments from his daughter. Picks up 7th graf pvs: `Gilbert was .. .' DELETES outdated last 2 grafs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Roswell Gilbert walked out of a Florida prison a free man today after serving 5{ years for the 1985 ``mercy killing'' of his ailing wife. The 81-year-old Gilbert, granted clemency by Gov. Bob Martinez and the Florida Cabinet because he suffers from heart and lung disease, was freed from the North Florida Reception Center at Lake Butler shortly after 9 a.m. Gilbert, who had breakfast earlier at the prison with his daughter, Martha Moran of Baltimore, smiled broadly as he left the jail, but he expressed remorse over the killing of his wife, who suffered from Alzheimer's disease. ``I shouldn't have killed my wife, now I know that,'' he said. ``I know the public at least understood what I did if they didn't approve of it.'' He called the slaying an ``act of desperation.'' ``That was an error I made,'' Gilbert said. ``That's not an excuse, but that's what it was. ... It's such a personal thing, it's difficult to explain to anybody.'' He called Alzheimer's ``a horror, an absolute horror,'' and said he believes euthanasia should be legalized for some cases. Mrs. Moran said she believes her mother would say: ``It's about time they let him out.'' Gilbert and his daughter planned to drive to the Fort Lauderdale area, where he will spend several days at an undisclosed location before returning to his condominium in Fort Lauderdale. Gilbert tried to light a cigarette just after entering the rental car, but his daughter and attorney Brad Stark objected. ``No this, no that,'' joked Gilbert. ``I'm free now.'' Gilbert, who lost nearly 40 pounds in prison, said he needed to begin rebuilding his health, but pledged not to give up smoking despite his lung problems. ``I'm a tough old rooster,'' he said. Gilbert was serving a 25-year prison term for murder in the 1985 shooting of his wife, Emily, who had Alzheimer's disease and osteoporosis. The case, depicted in the 1987 TV movie ``Mercy or Murder,'' focused national attention on the so-called ``mercy killing'' of an ailing loved one. Gilbert had said his wife begged him to end her misery. Prosecutors claimed the retired engineer killed the 73-year-old woman because she had become a burden to him. The inmate was examined in January and doctors said he suffered from heart and lung disease and was ``at high risk of death at any time.'' In Florida, clemency requires the approval of the governor and at least three of the six members of the independently elected Cabinet. The needed votes came quickly, with Comptroller Gerald Lewis, Education Commissioner Betty Castor and Attorney General Bob Butterworth signing the petition less than 90 minutes after Martinez announced plans to grant clemency. ``Mr. Gilbert's declining health, and the likelihood that his condition will continue to deteriorate if he remains in prison, leads me to the conclusion that he should be granted clemency,'' said Martinez, who previously opposed freeing Gilbert. ``I don't really condone the action that occurred some years ago, but you've got to mix that with some compassion.''

DOC.HEAD: Witness Says Businesses Denied Credit Because of Cleanup Fears
DOC.TEXT: Farmers, furniture refinishers and funeral homes are being denied credit because lenders fear being stuck with cleanup costs if pollution is found on the properties, the president of a small Ohio bank told Congress today. Businesses that use chemicals such as auto paint and embalming fluids and properties with underground storage tanks are considered undesirable loan risks because of recent court interpretations of the 10-year-old Superfund law, said R. Duane Lillibridge, president of Farmers Savings Bank, Northwood, Ohio. Farmland ``is considered highly suspect, and unfortunately we are being forced to wind down our loans in this critical sector of our economy,'' Lillibridge told the House transportation and hazardous materials subcommittee. ``If we are unable to obtain some relief ... Ohio bankers will soon be unable to look to real estate as collateral,'' he said in prepared testimony. The Superfund law gave the federal government the power to move in on heavily polluted properties, clean up the contamination and then force the property owners to pay for it. In May, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that a lender that forecloses on a polluted property could be held liable for cleanup costs under Superfund. The subcommitee's chairman, Rep. Thomas Luken, D-Ohio, said the court rulings on Superfund liability could have an ominous impact on the $500 billion taxpayer cost of the savings and loan bailout and ``inflate these astronomical figures even more.'' The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. submitted testimony estimating 270 properties in its possession may have Superfund problems, Luken said. ``All American taxpayers have an important stake in how these problems are resolved,'' said Luken, who supports a bill by Rep. John LaFale D-N.Y., to exempt lenders from Superfund liability when they foreclose on contaminated property. Rep. Frank Pallone, D-N.J., criticized the bill this week in a letter to fellow House members. ``The bill condones bad loans to polluting businesses and tells lenders that the government will clean up after them,'' he wrote. The Environmental Protection Agency submitted testimony announcing it intends to resolve the issue by issuing a rule ``expeditiously.'' EPA agrees that lender liability ``needs to be as certain and predictable as possible,'' testified James M. Strock, the agency's assistant administrator for enforcement.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Establishes Hotline
DOC.TEXT: The State Department has set up a hotline for people seeking information about the safety of American relatives and friends in Kuwait and Iraq. The number for the 24-hour hotline is: (202) 647-0900.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners in Kuwait Say They're Shocked By Sudden Iraqi Invasion
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreigners living in Kuwait said they watched from their windows or dived for cover when Iraq staged a lightning invasion of Kuwait today. Reached by telephone from Bahrain, the expatriates told of hearing gunfire, explosions, and jets and helicopters overhead as the Iraqi troops moved in before dawn. ``Unbelievable,'' said Catherine Baker, 37, of Illinois, who works for a British design firm in the small oil-rich nation. ``It doesn't seem real.'' There are about 4,000 Americans among the large expatriate community in Kuwait, where more than 60 percent of the 1.8 million residents are foreigners. Ms. Baker said she was shocked by the suddenness of the Iraqi strike, although Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had made threats against Kuwait in recent weeks. ``We were totally unprepared,'' she said. ``One feels like there should have been a bit of warning.'' U.S. officials monitoring the situation had no reports that U.S. citizens in Iraq had been harmed, White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said. Diplomats said the British Embassy was hit by shellfire and the Sheraton and Hilton hotels evacuated their clientele. Diplomatic sources in the Persian Gulf estimated that more than 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded in the invasion. Kathy McGregor, 32, a Canadian, said one explosion was close enough to shake her home. ``You know when you see a movie, when people dive for cover? We did it. The explosion blew inside the house, shaking it,'' she said. ``It's chaos, military jets are flying over all the time,'' Ms. McGregor said by telephone early today as she watched from her window. But in the afternoon, she said things had quieted down considerably. ``There is not much noise or gunfire. I feel better with more people around now,'' she said. Some expatriates said they did not want to leave despite the invasion. ``I think it will be over soon somehow,'' said Serge Sejournet, 30, an artist from Paris. ``I don't think I want to get out of Kuwait.'' Sejournet said the Iraqi soldiers on the street in front of his home in downtown Kuwait were ``very friendly with everyone, saying hello to all.'' Sejournet said he thought the United States would ``bring the situation under control.'' President Bush said the United States _ which has warships in the Persian Gulf area and more on the way, according to reports out of Washington _ would ``take whatever steps necessary'' to defend interests in the region. Asked if this included military force, Bush said: ``We're not discussing intervention.'' But he said he would not discuss military options publicly. Sejournet, Ms. Baker and other expatriates said they gathered together in homes of friends, listening to the fighting. Western diplomats said the invasion was too sudden to try to carry out any evacuation. For the time being, they simply advised foreign residents to keep a low profile until the situation was calmer. Anxious friends and relatives of those living in Kuwait found it difficult or impossible to get in touch with them. In Washington, a spokesman for AT&T said calls to Kuwait reached 2,000 every five minutes. The spokesman, Herb Linnen, said only some of the calls were getting through, and there were long delays because of the heavy volume. Linnen said the company itself had managed to get only one call through to its employees in Kuwait today and ascertained that the several dozen employees and their families were safe. AT&T employees in Kuwait include Americans, Canadians, British, Filipinos and one Sri Lankan who have been working on a project with the Kuwaiti government to improve communications, he said. The State Department, meanwhile, set up a 24-hour hotline for people seeking information about the safety of American relatives and friends in Kuwait and Iraq. The number is (202) 647-0900.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Adds Haiti To Latin American Trip This Month
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle added Haiti to his forthcoming Latin American trip today, announcing that he will visit Port au Prince on Aug. 9 on his way back to Washington. Quayle's agenda for the Aug. 6-10 trip already included Bolivia, Peru and Colombia. The vice president's press office said he would talk with Haitian President Ertha Pascal Trouillot and other officials about economic development, upcoming Haitian election and other topics.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Driver Gets Record 190-year Jail Term
DOC.TEXT: A bus driver has been sentenced to a record 190 years in prison for causing the deaths of 28 schoolchildren and 10 others in a 1989 accident, court officials said Thurdsay. The High Court on Wednesday found driver Sriyan Ananda guilty of homicide on all 38 counts of rash and negligent driving, said the officials who cannot be identified under standing regulations. The accident happened Jan. 17, 1989, when Ananda failed to stop at a rail crossing and drove into the path of a speeding train at Ahungala, 45 miles south of Colombo. Survivors said Ananda tried to cross the track despite screams of warnings by passengers. Ananda had claimed that the bus engine stalled on the track. Judge Wimal B. Dassanayake sentenced him to five years on each of the 38 counts with the terms to run consecutively. A senior police officer said it was the longest jail term ever given for a traffic offense. Ananda, a 48-year-old employee of the state-owned bus company, can appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian City Takes Down Lenin's Statue, Orders Marx's Removed
DOC.TEXT: The Ukrainian city of Chervonograd dismantled its monument to Vladimir Lenin and has ordered Karl Marx's monument be removed within three days, Tass reported Thursday. The orders were made during an emergency session of the city council on Wednesday, the official Soviet news agency said. It did not elaborate. Tass quoted the regional prosecutor in nearby Lvov as saying the council's orders were illegal and should be repealed. ``The council's decision violates the Ukrainian law on the protection and use of historical and cultural monuments,'' Leonid Izosimov told Tass. The western Ukrainian city of Ternopol has also outraged local Communists by ordering the dismantling or sale of monuments to Lenin, the Soviet founder, and Marx, the father of modern Communism. Moscow City Council voted earlier this year to remove a bust of Lenin from its chambers. Statues of Lenin have also been toppled or damaged in recent weeks in two dozen towns in southern Georgia and in Lithuania. Attempts were made to deface them in Azerbaijan and Armenia. Since President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985, statues, plaques and other memorials to disgraced Soviet leaders such as Josef Stalin and Leonid I. Brezhnev have been removed. Official criticism of Lenin, however, has been taboo, and for many he remains a figure of reverence and grandfatherly affection.

DOC.HEAD: Airplane Wreckage Found in Disputed Nagorno-Karabakh Region
DOC.TEXT: Wreckage from a small aircraft carrying passengers from Armenia was found early Thursday in the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, the Tass news agency reported. Poor weather and rough terrain prevented the civilian helicopter that spotted the debris from landing and determining the fate of 26 passengers and four crew members, Tass said. The Yakovlev-40 aircraft crashed in dense fog Wednesday, en route from the Armenian capital of Yerevan to Stepanakeri, capital of Nagorno-Karabakh, a mostly Armenian enclave inside the republic of Azerbaijan. The wreckage was sighted 12 miles from Stepanakeri, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Government To Issue Solidarity Coins
DOC.TEXT: The government is issuing commemorative coins to mark this month's 10th anniversary of the Solidarity trade union. The coins, which range in denomination from 10,000 zlotys to 200,000 zlotys, will be made of copper, silver, and gold, the National Bank of Poland announced Wednesday. Only the 10,000 zloty copper coin, worth slightly more than $1, will be issued for mass circulation. One dollar is worth 9,500 zlotys. Currently, the largest Polish coin is worth 20 zlotys, about 0.2 cents. Banknotes range from 10 zlotys to 200,000 zlotys. The coins, designed by Polish artist Bogdan Chmielewski, will bear a variety of symbols connected to the Solidarity trade union. One side of the 100,000 zloty silver coin, for example, is inscribed with the official Polish emblem, the crowned eagle, for the first time since 1939. The reverse side bears the date 1980-1990 and the Solidarity logo with a panorama of Gdansk, where the East bloc's first independent trade union was born during a wave of strikes in August 1980. It includes the monument erected in honor of shipyard workers killed there during riots in 1970. Sets can be purchased at the bank's branches or offices throughout Poland, or abroad through Ryan James, Ltd., a New York numismatics firm, for about $1,600, the bank said.

DOC.HEAD: Oops! Anyone Have a Dictionary?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jacque in 9th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: What was intended to be a simple gesture of international friendship has turned into a source of embarrassment for Missouri highway and economic development officials. The multilingual sign they erected outside St. Louis' Lambert Airport to welcome foreign visitors was botched, in three of seven languages. ``Their intentions were definitely good, and I can understand how these things happen, but they should have consulted a dictionary,'' said Antonio M. Molina of suburban University City. Molina said the Spanish welcome _ ``Bienvendos a Missouri'' _ should have read ``Bienvenidos a Missouri.'' Molina should know _ his father, the late Jose Molina, was the honorary vice consul from Spain, and his great-uncle, Jose Alvarez, held the post before him. The German and French salutations also were misspelled or grammatically incorrect. ``Wilkommen in Missouri'' should have read ``Willkommen in Missouri,'' according to James McLeod, professor of German at Washington University. The French version, ``Bienvenue a Missouri,'' should read ``Bienvenue en Missouri.'' ``The preposition is wrong. People arriving here from France would laugh at the sign,'' said Jacques Chicoineau, a retired professor of foreign languages at Webster University. The greetings in Japanese, Chinese and Korean were perfect, however. Oh yes, they also got the English greeting right. Jacque Dunn, director of public affairs for the state's department of economic development, said her office was reconfirming the translations. Dunn said the translations had been made with the help of the department's offices overseas.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Puts Navigation Satellite in Orbit
DOC.TEXT: A navigation satellite boosted into orbit by a Delta rocket Thursday is the latest in a series of spacecrafts capable of pinpointing the location of U.S. military units to within 50 feet. The unmanned rocket thundered into a clear sky at 1:39 a.m., trailing fire as it headed out over the Atlantic. The $65 million Navstar satellite separated from the booster on schedule about 25 minutes into the flight and settled into an orbit 10,898 miles high. The satellite is the eighth in a series of advanced Global Positioning System spacecraft that guide U.S. and allied warplanes, ships, submarines and troops. In some cases, it is accurate to within 10 feet. The Air Force plans to send up 16 more satellites by early 1993, three of them spares, under the $8.5 billion program. The first Navstar spacecraft was launched in February 1989. The 3,675-pound Navstar satellites, good in any kind of weather, keep track of the speed of military vehicles within a fraction of a mile per hour and the time within a millionth of a second. They contain an atomic clock with an error rate of one second every 300,000 years. Military personnel tune in the network's coded radio signals with receivers as small as a hand-held telephone. Boat and private aircraft operators also have access to the system. Seven earlier, less sophisticated navigational satellites still are functioning. The newer spacecrafts have a working lifetime of 7{ years. McDonnell Douglas of Huntington Beach, Calif., supplied the 128-foot Delta 2 rocket.

DOC.HEAD: Postman Helps With Special Delivery _ A Baby
DOC.TEXT: Letter carrier Bob Newkirk usually delivers the mail, but in this case it was a male _ a baby boy. Newkirk had just dropped off the mail at the Race Track Tavern on Wednesday afternoon when a boy ran up to him, seeking help with a special delivery. ``The little boy came up and said, `You have to help me, my sister's having a baby!''' Newkirk recalled. The boy told him he couldn't call an ambulance from his home because the telephone wasn't working. So Newkirk took the boy into the bar, gave him a quarter and told the bartender to call for help. Newkirk then sped to the home, where he found the 16-year-old mother in bed giving birth. The baby's head and shoulders were already out when he arrived. ``Her mother and father were there but they didn't seem to know what to do,'' Newkirk said, adding he learned emergency medical procedures as a soldier during the Vietnam War. After the birth, Newkirk said, he checked to see that the infant and his mother were OK, adding: ``If either of them had any problems we would've taken a quick trip in a post office truck.'' Said Newkirk: ``It was just a neat experience to be there. My wife and I are going to go see the baby and take them some stuff.'' Paramedics took mother and child to the hospital, where both were reported doing fine, a nursing supervisor said Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Died in Coup Attempt; Trinidad Will Prosecute Rebels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with government saying 30 people died during the coup attempt, no deals struck with rebels will be honored. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ A failed coup attempt by Moslem extremists and widespread looting that resulted left at least 30 people dead and 150 wounded in Trinidad, a government spokesman said today. The authorities expect to find more bodies in Parliament, where the prime minister and other government ministers were held hostage, and in a police station that was gutted by a car-bomb and fire, spokesman Gregory Shaw said. Previous reports had said about 20 people died in the coup attempt, which began Friday with a raid on Parliament and a government TV station. Shaw also confirmed for the first time that Prime Minister N.R. Robinson, after being shot in the leg, signed agreements to resign, turn over power to a caretaker government and grant amnesty to the rebels. ``All the agreements were signed under duress, all under gunpoint, all of which are completely invalid,'' Shaw told reporters at a news conference. Shaw said that the coup leader, Abu Bakr, and his band of 111 militants had dropped their demands before surrendering on Wednesday and releasing their remaining 46 hostages. A total of 55 hostages had been held. ``They caved in completely,'' he said. ``They surrendered unconditionally. Officials have said they will press charges against Bakr and those who joined him in the coup attempt. Shaw said soldiers expect to go into Parliament and the nearby police station on Friday to search for bodies and unexploded bombs. Soldiers standing outside the buildings said they were waiting one day to go inside because of fears of time-delayed explosives. The security forces also evacuated 2,000 to 3,000 people from the vicinity of the government television station, where 29 hostages were held after the building was seized last Friday. That building also will be searched. Shaw said the dead included looters shot by the security forces, but he gave no breakdown. The capital was quiet this morning. People remained indoors, under a 6 p.m. to noon curfew that remained in effect. State radio said Leo des Vignes, a junior government minister taken hostage Friday and released a day later, died of a heart attack Wednesday in a hospital. He had been shot in the heel. Deputy Prime Minister Winston Dookeran said Wednesday that ``appropriate charges'' would be brought against the militants. Asked whether the charges would include murder and treason, Dookeran said it would be up to the judicial authorities to decide. Bakr, a former policeman who converted to Islam and considers himself a champion of the downtrodden, was under heavy guard along with the other 111 rebels at army headquarters in Chaguerames in northwest Trinidad. The freed hostages spent the night at Camp Ogden, another army base near the capital of Port-of-Spain, for medical exams and treatment. Bakr had demanded Robinson's ouster, accusing him of corruption and blaming him for widespread poverty in this once oil-rich Caribbean nation of 1.3 million people. The 63-year-old prime minister was freed Tuesday and hospitalized for treatment of a leg wound suffered in the attack as well as exhaustion and glaucoma. The defense chief, Col. Joe Theodore, said Bakr had agreed to surrender Tuesday night, four days after the siege began. ``I just think they were worn down,'' he said of the rebels. ``They just wanted out. They had come to the conclusion they had failed.'' The defense chief said the rebels had agreed to leave all their explosives and ammunition on the speaker's table in the Parliament building. Officials said the rebels had been armed with AK-47 assault rifles, vintage World War II rifles, pump-action shotguns, pistols and grenades. The coup attempt began Friday when armed rebels stormed the state television station and the Parliament building, taking top government officials and others captive. They also bombed and burned down the police station. The attack set off a wave of looting. Hundreds of people took to the streets, ransacking stores and warehouses and carrying away everything from food to television sets. Damage was estimated at $50 million and food and medicine were beginning to run short. It was the country's worst violence since a black power uprising in the early 1970s. Dookeran said a state of emergency, including the islandwide curfew, would remain in effect until the country gets back to normal.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Gives Bush Extra Authority To Pump Oil From Strategic Reserve
With PM-US-Iraq-Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The Senate today gave President Bush an extra month's authority to begin pumping oil from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve into the market should Iraq's invasion of Kuwait disrupt world oil supplies. On a voice vote, the Senate passed a temporary extension of the Energy Policy Conservation Act that established the 580-million-barrel rainy-day stockpile of unrefined crude oil in response to the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo. Without the extension, Bush's authority to start pumping oil from the reserve would have expired Aug. 15, while Congress is on vacation. ``The events in the Middle East today underscore once again the fragility of the economies of the Western world and the marginal supply of energy that fuels it,'' said Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho. The stockpile, located in salt caverns along the Louisiana-Texas coast, contains oil worth $20 billion. The administration and Congress have been battling for the past 18 months over whether to increase the stockpile's size to 1 billion barrels. Bush opposes the increase. ``The least we can do is to preserve the most important tool that we have constructed so far,'' McClure said. ``It is important ... to take this emergency action on a temporary extension while we try to resolve larger policy questions.'' The system could now replace 80 days of oil imports, according to the Senate Energy Committee. That cushion has fallen from 110 days in the middle 1980s because of growing U.S. dependence on foreign crude.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Begins Writing into Law Economic Sanctions Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with further quotes, action.
DOC.TEXT: The House Foreign Affairs Committee, endorsing President Bush's move for an economic embargo against Iraq, convened hastily today to begin writing the White House sanctions into law. The Senate, meanwhile, extended by a month the president's authority to begin pumping oil from the nation's 580-million-barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve into the market should the invasion disrupt world oil supplies. But some members of Congress criticized the administration, saying there had been ``a total misjudgment of the policies and goals'' of Iraqi President Haddam Hussein prior to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``We have no intention of doing anything but codifying the president's executive order,'' said House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla. ``We want to indicate through legislation that we are in full support of the president's action.'' The panel was seeking to rewrite legislation it approved a day earlier that would have cut off Iraq's $200 million a year in Export-Import Bank credits and tightened restrictions on U.S. exports which could have dual civilian and military uses. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said the chamber would pass the measure later in the day. ``It is a matter of gravest concern to the United States government,'' he said. Foley said it was too early to say what, if any, steps the nation should take militarily. ``Obviously, the United States has to keep all of its options open,'' he said. He refused to criticize Bush for opposing earlier sanctions against Iraq, saying it would be ``foolish'' to think they would have prevented the invasion. But Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., accused the Bush administration of a ``policy of appeasement'' prior to the invasion which had emboldened Saddam. ``There was a total misjudgment of the policies and goals of Saddam Hussein to the very moment his troops invaded a neighboring country,'' Lantos said. On a voice vote, the Senate passed a temporary extension of the Energy Policy Conservation Act that established the stockpile of unrefined crude oil in response to the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo. Bush's authority to begin pumping oil from the reserve located in salt caverns along the Louisiana-Texas coast would have expired August 15, while Congress is on vacation, without the extension. ``It's clear the president has responded boldly and comprehensively'' in severing exports and imports, and in freezing assets of Iraq and Kuwait in the United States, said Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y. He said it was important that Congress and the administration speak with one voice in condemning Iraq's action. Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., said: ``Many have been urging this administration to take Saddam Hussein much more seriously than they have.'' The author of the original sanctions bill, Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., said the Reagan administration had begun the policy when it ``tilted'' toward Iraq during its eight-year war with Iran and urged allies to provide military equipment to the Baghdad government, overlooking that regime's support for terrorism and its human rights violations. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said he would not rule out military action, perhaps in cooperation with other countries in the region, to deal with the threat from Iraq. ``You're dealing with a madman here,'' Dodd said of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``I'm not sure he's going to respond to sanctions.'' He said he believed that military moves will be necessary ``at some point'' because the invasion ``poses a significant and very real threat to the entire region.'' Dodd, like many others on Capitol Hill, compared Saddam to Hitler: ``There was another time in this century when we've watched the first actions of a madman and said, `sooner or later they'll be satisfied.' Well, I don't believe they will be.'' Added Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt.: ``You're talking about something that could totally unravel the whole Middle East. Talk about the analogy of the fuse being lit, it's being lit in Kuwait.''

DOC.HEAD: American Peace Corps Worker Released After 50 Days in Rebel Hands
DOC.TEXT: An American Peace Corps worker freed Thursday after being held 50 days by Communist rebels said he was tired, happy and eager to get home. Timothy Swanson, 26, of Cheyenne, Wyo., was handed over to a Red Cross team in a rural area on the central Philippine island of Negros, not far from where he was abducted on June 13. ``It's just great. It's just wonderful news,'' Swanson's father, Leonard Swanson, told radio station KRAE in Cheyenne after learning of his son's release. ``You feel like a whole big weight has been taken off,'' said his mother, Lynn Swanson. President Bush, who met briefly with Swanson's parents when he visited Cheyenne on July 20, called Thursday morning with his best wishes, they said. ``I'm tired, I'm very happy,'' Swanson told reporters after his release. ``They treated me well. I'm OK and I want to go home.'' U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt welcomed Swanson's release, saying the embassy is ``relieved that he is safe, unharmed, and apparently in good health.'' The United States ordered the evacuation of Peace Corps workers in the Philippines on June 27 because intelligence information indicated the Communist rebels might try to kill or kidnap them. By that time, Swanson was already in rebel hands, but his Filipino wife said she had been ordered by the rebels not to tell anyone. Swanson had been living and working in the remote mountain village of Patag, about 320 miles southeast of Manila. U.S. officials said they learned of Swanson's abduction on June 30 when they tried to contact him. U.S. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said Swanson probably would stay in Manila for a few days and then leave for the United States. Earlier Thursday, the New People's Army rebels freed Fumio Mizuno, a Japanese aid worker who had been held since May 29. Mizuno, of the Organization of Industrial, Spiritual and Cultural Advancement, appeared in good health. Rebels said they seized the two because their organizations were suspected of supporting the Philippine government's counter-insurgency campaign. Relief organizations have denied any such involvement. The New People's Army has been waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state. The incident caused some strain in U.S.-Philippine ties. When the pullout of Peace Corps workers was ordered, some Philippines officials complained that the action was too hasty and said they should have been consulted first. Then, after the abduction was disclosed, U.S. officials said it proved their intelligence information had been correct. In Cheyenne, Swanson's mother said she was planning to bake rhubarb pie and stock up on steaks to celebrate her son's homecoming. ``He'll be well-fed when he gets home, I can guarantee that,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President Announces Space Study Committee Members
DOC.TEXT: A former astronaut, two former congressmen and an ex-administrator of NASA are among 11 people named to a new federal commission to study the future of America's space program, Vice President Quayle's office announced Thursday. The panel, called the Advisory Committee on the Future of the U.S. Space Program, was organized by NASA and by the Space Council, which Quayle directs, after the space agency's recent problems with a flawed space telescope and with hydrogen leaks that grounded the shuttle fleet. The purpose of the committee, officials said, is to provide an independent evaluation of the civil space program, assess how the program is being operated by NASA and to make recommendations on future directions in space. Norman R. Augustine, the chairman and chief executive officer of Martin Marietta Corp., was named chairman of the committee last week. Committee members announced Thursday are: Laurel L. Wilkening, provost of the University of Washington, Seattle, and a former member of an earlier space commission. Edward C. Aldridge Jr., president of McDonnell Douglas Electronics Systems Corp., and a former secretary of the Air Force. Joseph P. Allen, former astronaut and president of Space Industries International Inc. D. James Baker, scientist and president of Join Oceanographic Institutions. Edward P. Boland, former congressman from Massachusetts. Daniel J. Fink, retired vice president of General Electric Co. Don Fuqua, former congressman from Florida and now president of the Aerospace Industries Association of America, an industry organization. Robert T. Herres, retired Air Force general and former commander of the U.S. Space Command. David T. Kerns, chairman of the Xerox Corp. Louis J. Lanzerotti, scientist and chairman of the space studies board of the National Research Council, an organization of the National Academy of Sciences. Thomas O. Paine, former NASA administrator and chairman of an earlier commission on space. Though the panel is to operate independently, it will submit its findings directly to NASA administrator Richard Truly and to Quayle. The committee is to make its report within four months.

DOC.HEAD: New York Congressman Indicted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with U.S. Attorney Announcing Indictment.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Floyd Flake was indicted today for conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion in the alleged embezzlement of funds from a federally subsidized senior citizens housing project run by his church. The indictment, announced by U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney, listed 17 counts against the New York Democrat and nine against his wife, described as the bookkeeper for the operation. In addition to his congressional duties, Flake is the pastor of the 156-year-old Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Queens. The church built and operates the 300-unit senior citizen facility. Maloney told a news conference that Flake stole about $75,000 in transportation funds from the Allen Senior Citizens Apartments from 1983 to 1987, and diverted another $66,000 in church funds to his own use from 1983 to 1988. The allegedly misappropriated money was not reported by Flake on federal income tax returns, Maloney said. ``The defendants' conduct deprived the senior citizens, whom they were pledged to protect, of the federal funds specifically designated for their care,'' Maloney said. The church built the 300-unit senior citizen facility with a $10 million grant from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. HUD also provides $100,000 a month in subsidies for operations, Maloney said. Flake, in a statement, said he had cooperated fully with the government in an 18-month investigation and expected to be acquitted. ``The prosecutor has decided to charge me, basically, with tax violations which he has attempted to bolster with allegations of misapplying a portion of the transportation expenses,'' Flake said. Flake said he and his wife, Margarett, were both innocent. ``Our abiding belief in God and in the American system of justice reassures us that, despite the awful price, justice will triumph and we will be vindicated at trial,'' Flake said. The charges included one count of conspiracy, two of HUD fraud and six of tax evasion against each of the two defendants. In addition, Flake is charged with another four counts of filing false tax returns and four of making false financial statements. If convicted on all 17 counts, Flake could be sentenced to a maximum of 87 years in prison and fined up to $3.95 million. His wife could face penalties of 55 years in prison and fines of up to $2.1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Zodiac Gunman Fails To Strike
DOC.TEXT: Scores of detectives and hundreds of police officers spread out across the city in anticipation of a fifth attack by the Zodiac killer this morning, but the astrology-obsessed gunman did not strike. The pre-dawn hours of this morning were considered a target night for the gunman, based on his pattern of striking on early Thursdays at 21-day intervals or multiples thereof. Today marked 42 days since the gunman's last attack, on a homeless man sleeping on a Central Park bench. It is also in the sign of Leo, believed to be the astrological sign of the gunman's next victim. The gunman has sent six letters to police and the media, threatening to kill 12 people, one for each astrological sign. Since March 8, he has shot four men, one of them fatally. In anticipation, police officials reactivated ``Operation Watchdog,'' flooding the streets with undercover officers, just as they did on July 12, when the gunman was also expected to strike, but didn't. The gunman's long silence has made it difficult for the 50 investigators assigned to the Zodiac task force to develop new leads. Detectives have followed as many as 2,900 calls to a 24-hour hotline without success. Investigators predicted that the next target night for the gunman would be Aug. 23, in the sign of Virgo.

DOC.HEAD: Barry's Lawyer Says Government Witnesses Were Facile Liars
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs with editing. ^By RICHARD KEIL
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry's lawyer described the mayor's accusers today as ``facile liars'' and ``little Lucifers'' as he urged that Barry be acquitted of all 14 criminal charges against him. The government's exhaustive investigation of Barry's drug use amounted to ``using a sledgehammer to kill a fly,'' defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy told the jury in closing arguments at the mayor's drug and perjury trial. The jurors' verdict should be ``not guilty,'' Mundy told the panel. If the government's witnesses, such as former model Rasheeda Moore and admitted cocaine dealer Charles Lewis, weren't ``devils, they were at least little Lucifers or small Satans,'' said Mundy. The witnesses were ``facile liars right here in your very presence,'' he added. Mundy said the mayor has occasionally used cocaine. But he said the government was not justified in pursuing Barry as vigorously as it did. On Wednesday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin in her closing argument called Barry a ``general in the war'' on drugs ``who was working with the other side.'' Retchin, summarizing six weeks of trial testimony, told the jury that Barry used drugs in ``every quadrant of this city for years'' and wrapped himself in a ``web of deception'' to cover it up. ``If Mr. Barry's drug use were so rampant, he could have been discovered in a more traditional way,'' Mundy said. ``The cure is many-fold worse than the ailment.'' ``The government in effect used a sledgehammer to kill a fly,'' Mundy said, describing the lengthy investigation of the mayor that culminated in Barry's Jan. 18 arrest in an undercover sting operation. Mundy lashed out at government witnesses who testified against Barry, contending they described the mayor using drugs only to save themselves from prosecution. ``How trustworthy, how believable and credible is the testimony of anyone under that kind of pressure?'' Mundy asked the jury. ``They are prosecuting him because he is the mayor.'' Mundy, who began his presentation Wednesday, was concluding his statement today, followed by a final argument by the prosecution. The jury then will receive its instructions from U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, and begin deliberations. The mayor has pleaded innocent to 10 counts of cocaine possession, three felony charges of lying to the grand jury and one count of conspiracy. Each perjury count carries a maximum five-year prison term. On Wednesday, Mundy said he was ``trying to gain the respect of the jury'' by acknowledging that the mayor has used cocaine. ``I will start right from the beginning by telling you that Mr. Barry used cocaine,'' he said. ``We do not intend to give you the imression for one moment that there was not occasional drug use by Mr. Barry.'' But the government adopted the philosophy of ``the ends justify the means'' to catch the mayor using drugs, Mundy argued. ``Everything that the government could amass against him was put forward.'' Retchin said a government sting operation at the Vista International Hotel was necessary to expose Barry's drug use. The mayor was arrested Jan. 18 after he was videotaped smoking FBI-supplied crack cocaine in a hotel bedroom. Mundy accused federal authorities of using the equivalent of an illegal war weapon to catch him using cocaine in the sting operation. ``The danger of mustard gas _ which was the sting at the Vista _ is that it cuts at the very fabric of our society,'' the defense attorney said. ``It might be Mr. Barry today, someone else tomorrow.'' Most of those who testified against Barry had no one to back up their stories and could not provide much detail, Mundy said. ``There was very rarely a situation where there is corroborating testimony about these things,'' he said. The three-term mayor denied he was involved with drugs in grand jury testimony and in public statements, but Retchin said the sting operation ``breaks the shield of secrecy.'' The evidence is ``overwhelming'' that Barry relied on a ``close group of friends'' to get him cocaine because they wanted city jobs, city contracts and the power that comes with knowing the mayor, the prosecutor said. She recounted testimony from 10 friends and associates of the mayor who said they saw Barry use cocaine about 200 times from 1983 through Jan. 18.

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Wants U.S. Military Intervention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 3rd graf pvs `Asked what ...' to UPDATE with comment from Iraqi ambassador. Picks up 4th graf pvs `Bush told ...' ^With PM-US-Iraq-Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's ambassador to the United States appealed today for direct U.S. military intervention to repulse the Iraqi forces he said are controlling his nation. ``We don't stand a chance if we don't get any aid from our friends,'' Ambassador Saud Nasser Al-Sabah told reporters at a press briefing at the embassy. Asked what type of help he wanted, the ambassador replied: ``I'm talking about military intervention. ... U.S. intervention at this stage is of paramount importance.'' Hours later, Iraq's ambassador, Mohamed Sadiq Al-Mashat, summoned reporters to his embassy where he said any foreign interference ``will only aggravate the situation.'' Despite Kuwait's protestations, Al-Mashat said the ``events currently occurring in Kuwait are an internal affair'' and that Iraq ``harbors no special objectives in Kuwait.'' Iraq, he said, ``is desirous of establishing relations of fraternity and good neighborliness with it.'' Standing in front of a life-sized picture of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Al-Mashat read a prepared statement but refused to answer questions. Bush told reporters at an early morning news conference at the White House that he was not considering taking military steps. ``The United States strongly condemns the Iraqi military invasion of Kuwait and calls for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of all the Iraqi forces,'' Bush said. Sources at the Pentagon said the aircraft carrier USS Independence was en route to the Persian Gulf to bolster U.S. forces there. However, the sources said the carrier would not enter the Gulf. Ambassador Al-Sabah, speaking in a somber tone, said that Kuwait was ``under occupation'' by a belligerent power. He said that he had talked within the last 30 minutes to members of the ruling family who he said were in good health and ``in a safe place to conduct the resistance that is taking place inside.'' Kuwait's ruler, Sheik Jaber Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah, is directing the resistance from Saudi Arabia, the ambassador said. He said all Kuwait government facilities, including the ministry buildings, had been occupied by the Iraqis, who are heading toward the southern part of the country, where the oil installations are located. Al-Sabah gave only sketchy details of the resistance and of the situation on the ground, but he said there were numerous casualties. He had no estimates and said the State Department had been told there were no Americans at risk. Al-Sabah said he was in touch with officials both at the State Department and at the White House and had relayed his requests for assistance to them. Administration officials were weighing the request but had not responded, he said. Kuwait, Al-Sabah said, would be willing to accept help from other countries. ``We are desperate for any help we can get,'' he said, describing it as a ``universal cry for help.'' Al-Sabah said bitterly that his government had been assured by other powers that Iraq would not follow through with its menacing threats of the last week. The United States was among those countries that reassured Kuwait, he said, noting that they had been proved wrong. The Arab nations are holding an emergency meeting in Cairo to discuss the situation.

DOC.HEAD: Weeklong Party Planned to Celebrate I-10 Completion
DOC.TEXT: A week of festivities beginning Friday will mark the opening of the final link of coast-to-coast Interstate 10, a one-mile segment through downtown Phoenix partly covered with a park. The official opening is set for Aug. 10, but the celebration begins a week earlier with what is billed as a freeway ``open house.'' That will include tours of ``the deck,'' a half-mile section that is depressed below surface level and covered with a deck that is being buried under a thick layer of soil for a park. It cost over $55 million to build the deck-tunnel, and lighting and other environmental features inside the tunnel cost $20 million. The festivities will include foot races, fireworks, parades, antique cars and a black-tie dinner, with music by the Phoenix Symphony, on the evening of Aug. 9. The 2,460-mile I-10 runs from Jacksonville, Fla., to Santa Monica, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Provisional Government Statement
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of a statement released by the Provisional Government of Free Kuwait, which Iraq claims took power in Kuwait before the Iraqi invasion. The statement was carried by the French service of the official Iraqi News Agency and translated by The Associated Press.

Since the dawn of independence the sons of Kuwait have aspired to freedom, to participation, with their Arab brothers, in the realization of the goals of the nation and the recuperation of usurped Arab rights, especially in Palestine. But the colonialists who had governed the country, plundered its riches and humiliated the people before independence either directly or through the intermediary of their agents _ certain members of the al-Sabah family _ handed the reins of power to that same clique after independence, letting them set up around their family an oligarchic, despotic and corrupt power. The fictitious institutions that this regime installed were not able to camouflage its reality, which the people divined right from the first minute. As the years went by, the people became more and more convinced that this clique was determined to pursue its monopolization of power and its plundering of the riches of the country by collaborating with a small number of mercenaries, relying principally on foreign forces. Falsification of elections, authoritarianism, persecution of patriotic personalities have always been characteristics of the regime of the al-Sabah family, and of its stability. The dissolution of the last Parliament, which put the despotism and the corruption of the regime under the limelight, is a proof of the violation by this regime of the constitution and of the terrorism to which it had recourse every time it was cornered by the patriots. This clique, which was in the service of foreigners before independence, remained so after independence. It attached our interests and our wealth to foreign interests and even to certain known Zionists. It stained the reputation of our people, putting hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign banks and in investments linked to Zionist circles. Some of them (in the al-Sabah family) were known for their intransigence and corruption, and were among the most faithful men of colonialism. They collaborated and coordinated with it, they intrigued and plotted in the vilest, basest manner, against the nation and its noble causes. Their last conspiracy was the one they hatched against Iraq, which assumed its responsibility to defend the eastern gateway of the Arab nation _ Kuwait and the countries of the Persian Gulf _ and suffered tremendous sacrifices to conserve their soil, honor and dignity. In this conspiracy with Zionist and colonialist aims, this al-Sabah family clique pulled off its mask, manifesting its hostility to Kuwait and the (Arab) nation, like a satellite in the pay of colonialism and Zionism. This is the reality of this clique that governed the country, this is why the patriotic forces _ which rejected despotism, injustice and corruption and resisted this regime attached to Zionist and colonialist circles _ decided, relying on God's will and the will of the people, to assume power and topple this despotic, satellite regime. We declare the destitution from power of (Emir) Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah and (Crown Prince) Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, as well as the dissolution of the National Assembly, and the formation of a free provisional government that will assume legislative and executive responsibilities during a transitional period, and will organize free, honest elections in order to elect an assembly that represents the people, which will decide on a political system and other fundamental questions of the country. The government finds that one of its primary obligations is to remedy the harm done by the deposed, corrupt government to our brothers in Iraq, which backed us under difficult circumstances. We consider the border issue with Iraq by appealing to the principles of fraternity and Arab national interests. Dear free citizens, on this day a new era begins, an era of serious action aimed at setting up the bases of freedom, democracy and justice, as well as true prosperity throughout society. Serious action is beginning to serve the objectives of the Arab nation and deal with its fundamental issues. The Provisional Government of Free Kuwait salutes you and calls on you to understand and sustain this uprising carried out by your free brothers. The Provisional Government of Free Kuwait undertakes to protect the rights, interests and security of foreigners living in Kuwait and calls on them to carry out all the decisions and instructions issued by the government. It will hit back vigorously against any attempt to destabilize the situation in Kuwait, or to carry out the plans of foreign forces. The Provisional Government of Free Kuwait confirms its allegiance to all treaties in accordance with its Arab, Islamic and world role, in particular the charter of the Arab League, the treaty on common defense and economic cooperation among Arab countries and the charter of the United Nations, as well as the charter of the Organization of the Islamic Conference and the Gulf Cooperation Council. The government confirms it will respect all accords concluded with other nations except any secret accords that are in contradiction with our sovereignty and our national, pan-Arab engagements, and following the principle of reciprocity. The government also confirms its attachment to all financial engagements vis-a-vis other countries and institutions, and this following the principle of reciprocity. It confirms it will carry out all reciprocal agreements and warns any foreign party not to interference in our internal affairs. Foreign forces allied with the expelled caste should know that the citizens of Kuwait, including Arabs residing in this country, will defend its soil, its dignity and its uprising to the last drop of their blood. They will never surrender to foreign attempts at intimidation and threats. In this framework the people of Kuwait and the Provisional Government of Free Kuwait will reject any cover that might be used to excite the ambitions of suspect forces wanting to intervene directly or indirectly, be it by their armies, their fleets or by any other means. These forces should know that Kuwait is part of the Arab nation and has at its side audacious, experienced brothers who are ready to defend Kuwait against any foreign aggression.

DOC.HEAD: Quotes on Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some quotes on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait:

``The Iraqi government firmly believes and states that Iraq is pursuing no goal or objective and wishes only cordial relations with Kuwait. Furthermore, it is the Kuwaitis themselves who will determine their own future and Iraqi forces will withdraw as soon as order has been restored.'' _ Sabah Talat Kadrat, Iraq's deputy permanent representative to the United Nations.

``The pretext to invade an independent, sovereign state is a false, flimsy pretext. This kind of pretext, if it's not going to be deterred in a decisive manner and by this august assembly, all international relations will be threatened. No country at all will be safe after this.'' _ Mohammad Abulhasan, Kuwait's ambassador to the United Nations.

``We remain committed to take whatever actions are necessary to defend our longstanding, vital interests in the (Persian) Gulf.'' _ President Bush, who said his advisers would ``consider all possible options available to us.''

DOC.HEAD: Supporters Predict Quick Passage of Radiation Bill
DOC.TEXT: Senate backers of legislation that would compensate victims of radiation exposure in the Western states predicted on Thursday that the bill will be passed quickly by the House and accepted by President Bush. By voice vote early Thursday, the Senate approved the bill to establish a $100 million, government-administered trust fund to assist hundreds of radiation victims. ``Those victims, whether a `downwinder' receiving radiation fallout from nuclear devices detonated in Nevada, or miners digging uranium, will now be eligible for compensation,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, the bill's sponsor. The White House initially had opposed the bill, and the Justice Department was concerned that claims would be handled by the U.S. Claims Court rather than the department. But Hatch told a news conference that ``as late as last night I was told they would not oppose this bill.'' Under the legislation, a person who was harmed while standing downwind of the government's atomic test site in Nevada in the 1950s and 1960s could receive a one-time damage award of $50,000. Damages would be for injury or death to the victim. A uranium miner who was unwittingly exposed to harmful doses of ionizing radiation from 1947 to 1971 would be entitled to a one-time damage award of $100,000. To qualify for damages, claimants must be residents of specified areas and have suffered certain types of cancer, including leukemia and lymphomas. Hatch and Sens. Alan Simpson, D-Wyo.; Harry Reid, D-Nev., and Pete Domenici, R-N.M., said it would be difficult for the White House to oppose the legislation. ``This is a bill that gallops through the place,'' said Simpson, the Senate Republican whip. He said the bill was ``compassionate, it provides an apology.'' ``The government has finally admitted negligence,'' Hatch said. ``We've fought through layers of red tape for years, through litigation, reversals and years of pain suffered by those people who lived through the horrors of a death they could not see: radiation.''

DOC.HEAD: Factory Orders Slump For Third Time This Year
DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods slumped in June for the third time this year, the government said Thursday. The report added to analysts' fears of a possible recession that were intensified by rising oil prices resulting from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``The economy is walking on a precipice and doesn't need something to come up and give it a shove,'' said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist with the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. Shortly after the Iraqi army pushed into neighboring Kuwait, oil prices soared amid fears the invasion would reduce the world's oil supply. At the same time, the Commerce Department reported a 1.5 percent drop in orders for both durable and non-durable factory goods, more evidence of economic weakness. ``We're in a precarious position, on the edge of a recession,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with the WEFA group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``With the problems in the Middle East and the threat of higher oil prices, that may be just enough to push us over.'' On the other hand, Chairman Michael Boskin of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers contended that a 25 percent hike in oil prices could be absorbed by the economy without halting its growth. ``Even if the higher price is enforced, our economy today is much better able to absorb modest price increases,'' Boskin told the congressional Joint Economic Committee. Iraq and Kuwait produce one-fifth of the total oil produced by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, and their oil accounts for an estimated 5 percent of daily U.S. consumption. In its report on factory orders, the Commerce Department said the decline was concentrated in durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years. They fell 2.8 percent to $125.1 billion after a 2.2 percent advance a month earlier. Non-durable orders were flat at $112.3 billion. Dederick noted that factory orders have bounced up and down throughout the first half of the year and, as a result, the manufacturing sector ``is really just spinning its wheels.'' Orders plummeted 5.5 percent in January _ the sharpest drop since a 7.0 percent decrease in December 1974. They then rose 1.8 percent in February and 4.0 percent in March before dropping 2.1 in April. Orders were up 2.2 percent in May. And as orders decline, industry tends to cut production and jobs. In fact, the Labor Department reported earlier the loss of 31,000 factory jobs in June. Because many factory items, particularly durable goods, are purchased through loans, the manufacturing sector has borne the brunt of high interest rates engineered by the Federal Reserve as its sought to slow the economy to dampen inflationary pressures. But even if the higher oil prices do not jolt the economy into recession, they will tend to drive up overall living costs and hamper the central bank's anti-inflation efforts. The factory orders report did contain at least one hopeful sign, a 0.6 percent gain, to $36.1 billion, in the key category of non-defense capital goods. This barometer of business investment plans had fallen 1.8 percent in May. Over half of the durables decline was in defense goods, which dropped 20.3 percent to $8.0 billion. Excluding defense, orders would have dropped 0.7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: border area.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet announcement about suspending arms sales came shortly after Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Siberia and asked him to immediately halt arms deliveries to Iraq. The two leaders were meeting to discuss Afghanistan and other issues. The Foreign Ministry issued a statement earlier today condemning the Iraqi attack and calling for an immediate withdrawal of all Iraqi troops, but the Tass report contained the first response to Baker's request. The brief Tass announcement said sales of arms and military hardware were being interrupted ``in connection with the invasion of Kuwait by Iraqi armed forces.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes $21 Billion Energy and Water Project Measure
DOC.TEXT: The Senate passed a spending bill Thursday that includes full funding for a huge atom smasher in Texas and nearly $3 billion for a new program to clean up nuclear contamination from weapons plants.
