The $20.8 billion spending measure also contains hundreds of millions for water projects in the home states of senators who put together the package. The measure, which increases spending over this year's level by $2.5 billion, must be reconciled with the version that the House passed in June. The Senate version _ almost exactly the same as the House total _ exceeds the administration request by nearly $600 million. It was passed by a voice vote. The bill contains $318 million in 1991 for the Texas-based Superconducting Super Collider project, the same amount requested by the administration and granted by the House. Current estimates put the final cost for the collider at nearly $9 billion when it is completed in 1998. The circular project would be 54 miles long and would be the world's largest atom smasher. An estimate three years ago put the cost at $4.4 billion. The 1991 appropriation includes construction funds. More than half the money in the Senate bill is set aside for defense-related nuclear projects. The bulk of that money goes to nuclear weapons research and production, including $107 million for Star Wars. The defense component also includes $2.7 billion to clean up contamination at the nation's nuclear defense plants. The amount is $318 million more than the administration requested and $34 million less than what the House voted to spend. Estimates put the ultimate cleanup cost at $50 billion to $200 billion over the next two decades. The Senate bill also calls for spending more than half a billion dollars on civilian nuclear waste management, only slightly exceeding the administration request. The bill contains $5 billion worth of water projects, including $63 million more than the administration requested for Louisiana alone. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., is chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that put together the bill.

DOC.HEAD: Advocacy Group Blasts Proposal to Cut Medicare
DOC.TEXT: An advocacy group for the elderly on Thursday said Medicare cuts under consideration by federal budget negotiators would hit the nation's sickest and poorest senior citizens the hardest. Families USA, a non-profit advocacy group, called the proposal to raise Medicare premiums and deductibles ``a wolf in sheep's clothing'' that was being advanced because it was politically more acceptable than cutting Social Security cost-of-living adjustments. The group analyzed three proposals to reduce spending on senior citizens that are under consideration by budget negotiators for the Bush administration and Congress. The 12-week-old budget talks are aimed at producing a deficit-reduction package. One plan under consideration would increase the Medicare deductible on payments to physicians from $75 to $150, and raise monthly premium rates. Phyllis Torda, health policy director for Families USA, said the Medicare cutbacks would cost elderly beneficiaries 20 percent more in 1995 than a one-year freeze in Social Security COLAs, but would be less risky politically. ``Raising the cost of Medicare is nothing more than a Social Security COLA cut in disguise,'' she said. A third option under consideration would increase taxes on Social Security income for senior citizens with annual incomes of $40,000 or more. Families USA said this plan was the fairest of the three proposals. Torda said the release of the group's report was timed to coincide with the August congressional recess. ``We think that while Congress is in recess, work will be going on on the package,'' said Torda. ``Now is the time to influence the shape of that package.''

DOC.HEAD: Escapee, Former Delta Force Soldier, Captured After Tip
DOC.TEXT: An Army commando who escaped police custody while being taken to court in a rape case was recaptured early today, authorities said. Master Sgt. Marshall L. Brown, who faces life in prison if convicted on charges he raped two Cranston women last year, was captured by police in a stolen car in an East Providence parking lot. He was unarmed. Brown, 37, has been a Green Beret, a Ranger and, most recently a member of the Delta Force, the secret anti-terrorist group. He took part in the failed raid to free U.S. hostages from Iran. Brown escaped Monday after freeing himself from handcuffs while being taken from a jail to the courthouse for a hearing on the rape charges. Attorney General James O'Neil said Brown would be arraigned today on escape and auto theft charges. Officials said state police had received a tip from a confidential source that Brown could be found in the parking lot. ``Two of our undercover detectives were parked in the parking lot and observed Brown hiding in bushes,'' said state police Lt. Brian Andrews. ``He came out of the bushes, crept very slowly along the ground and got in what turned out to be a stolen car.'' State police detectives grabbed him before he could leave the parking lot, Andrews said. Even if Brown had been armed, Andrews said, ``We hit that car so fast he didn't even have time to reach for a gun.'' Brown, of Spring Lake, N.C., was attending a nine-week course at the Naval Education and Training Center in Newport when Cranston police arrested him on June 11, 1989. He also has been charged with two rapes in North Carolina, where he was a member of the Army Special Forces stationed at Fort Bragg.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Quick International Criticism Of Iraq For Invasion Of Kuwait
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Soviets halting arms sales, France freezing assets. Pickup 4th pvs, `The Arab...;' Insert graf after 12th, `In London...' to ADD Swiss govt reaction. SUB 15th graf pvs, `France, the...' with details from statement. Pickup 16th pvs, `The 12...
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, Iraq's main arms supplier, said today it will suspend weapons sales to Baghdad, and the United States blocked most Iraqi imports as part of a worldwide condemnation of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. President Bush signed orders freezing Iraqi assets and Kuwaiti assets to prevent Iraq from seizing them. France quickly did the same, while Britain froze Kuwaiti assets. In Moscow, the Tass news agency quoted th Foreign Ministry as saying Soviet arms sales to Iraq were being suspended. Secretary of State James A. Baker III had requested this today, after Iraqi troops crossed into Kuwait. The Arab League Council met in emergency session in Cairo but issued no immediate statement. At the meeting, Lebanese Premier Salim Hoss urged the League to condemn the invasion. Iraq overran Kuwait after talks broke down Wednesday on a dispute over an oil-rich border area. The U.N. Security Council met in emergency session and voted 14-0 to condemn the attack. It demanded the unconditional withdrawal of the Iraqi troops. Kuwait's U.S. ambassador, Sheik Saud Nasir al-Sabah, appealed for military help from the United States and urged the Arab League to dispatch a peacekeeping force. But the Arab League's U.S. ambassador, Clovis Maksoud, urged world powers to abstain from intervening. Jordan's official news agency said King Hussein also hoped to prevent foreign intervention. ``We're not discussing intervention,'' President Bush told reporters in Washington but added that he would not discuss military options in public. A Pentagon source said a U.S. naval battle group was diverted toward the gulf from the Arabian Ocean. Bush signed orders freezing all Iraqi property in the United States and blocking almost all imports from the oil-rich Middle Eastern country, including its most important revenue source _ oil. He also froze Kuwaiti property under U.S. jurisdiction to keep Iraq from seizing it. In London, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Britain was doing the same. Kuwait is estimated to have $100 billion in foreign investments, including stakes of about 10 percent in British Petroleum and Britain's Midland Bank. The Swiss government told the nation's banks to increase vigilance over Kuwaiti assets to prevent their seizure by Iraq. In Moscow, Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Belonogov called in the Iraqi ambassador and expressed hope his country would comply with the U.N. resolution, the Tass news agency said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said, ``The sovereignty, national independence and territorial integrity of the state of Kuwait must be fully restored and safeguarded,'' according to Tass. France, Iraq's No. 2 arms supplier, issued a ``total and unreserved condemnation of the intervention of Iraqi troops in Kuwait,'' and demanded an immediate withdrawal. The government halted international capital transactions ``of any nature'' involving Iraqi or Kuwaiti accounts, the prime minister's office said in a communique. The 12 European Community nations meeting in Brussels strongly condemned Iraq but did not immediately adopt economic sanctions or freeze Iraqi assets in the trade bloc. Also in Brussels, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization called the Iraqi military aggression a ``clear violation of the charter of the United Nations.'' Israel's defense minister, Moshe Arens, said Israel expected more aggressive actions from Iraq and was ready to meet any threat posed by the Arab nation. Avi Pazner, the spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said the invasion confirms Israel's warnings that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's threats should be taken seriously. Saddam had threatened military action against Kuwait for its overproduction of oil, which had driven down prices for Iraq's oil. China described Iraq and Kuwait as ``friends,'' and said there was ``no conflict of fundamental interests among Third World countries and that no one should resort to force of arms in resolving their disputes.'' Australia condemned ``any Iraqi violation of Kuwait's territorial intergrity.'' Japan, which gets more than 10 percent of oil from the two countries, called for the immediate withdrawal of Iraq's forces. Japan imports 99 percent of its oil needs and its economy has proved vulnerable to ``oil shocks'' emanating from Middle East conflicts. The Arab oil embargo after the 1973 Arab-Israeli War was a powerful though short-term setback to Japan's economic growth as oil prices skyrocketed, causing inflation and cutbacks in industrial production. West Germany demanded an ``immediate and unconditional'' withdrawal of the forces that stormed Kuwait's northern border before dawn today. Libya's Foreign Ministry issued a statement warning against foreign intervention, the official JANA news agency reported. ``Foreign intervention on the part of imperialist powers is something which we utterly reject because the Arabs are capable of resolving their problems on their own,'' the Libyan statement said. Norwegian Foreign Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik urged maximum international pressure to end the dispute. In Singapore, the Foreign Affairs Ministry said the invasion was ``a threat to the security of small states everywhere.'' Some members of the U.S. Congress criticized the administration for not acting earlier against Saddam. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., accused the Bush administration of a ``policy of appeasement'' prior to the invasion and said this had emboldened Saddam. Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., said the Reagan administration began the policy when it ``tilted'' toward Iraq during its eight-year war with Iran and urged allies to provide military equipment to the Baghdad government.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Will Return to Philippines When Safety Is Assured
DOC.TEXT: Peace Corps volunteers will return to the Philippines when their safety can be assured, the corps director said after the release Thursday of a corpsman detained for 50 days by Filipino communist guerrillas. Timothy Swanson, a 26-year-old volunteer from Cheyenne, Wyo., was released by New People's Army insurgents and he appeared to be physically unharmed, said corps director Paul Coverdell. The program's suspension June 27 was not intended to be permanent, and ``I think there are valid reasons for us to begin discussions to find a way volunteers can return to that country in safety,'' Coverdell said. However, he said, ``Until we can verify that safety, they cannot return.'' He did not list specific conditions. U.S. officials suspended the Philippines program after learning that the New People's Army had targeted volunteers for attack. Manila headquarters did not learn Swanson had been abducted from his home in Negros province on June 13 until it summoned participants to return to America two weeks later. The reason for the kidnapping remains unknown, Coverdell said. The Peace Corps began Philippine operations 30 years ago. Until it abducted Swanson, the New People's Army left all foreign volunteers alone, Coverdell said. Their release of Swanson and of Fumio Mizuno, a detained member of a Japanese service organization, may suggest that they have reverted to the earlier hands-off policy, he said, but ``it is too early to know as yet.'' Meanwhile, more time will be needed to activate a Peace Corps program planned for China but canceled after the June 1989 crackdown on the pro-democracy movement, Coverdell said. Discussions have resumed with the Chinese government, but funds for the program were diverted to other uses when the plans were canceled, he said. The first Peace Corps volunteers will go to Mongolia next year under an agreement signed by Secretary of State James Baker III in Ulan Bator, Coverdell said.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Filed in Bid to Stop Parental Consent Initiative
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to add comment from anti-abortion group, note person who filed suit is a state Senate candidate. Picks up 4th graf pvs., `The lawsuit ...'; Deletes outdated last graf.
DOC.TEXT: A suit filed today seeks to stop the Legislature from considering a proposed measure that would require unmarried girls 17 and younger to get a parent's consent for an abortion. The suit filed by Zolton Ferency, a state Senate candidate, maintained that the proposal is unconstitutional and asks that the Board of State Canvassers be prohibited from sending the initiative to the Legislature. ``I'm saying the right to keep your body healthy, the right to seek medical care when you need it, is a fundamental right nobody can interfere with,'' Ferency said. But Barbara Listing, president of Right to Life of Michigan, said the legal challenge is premature since the measure has not been acted on. She said Ferency, one of two Democrats running for a vacant state Senate seat in next Tuesday's primary, filed the suit to help his campaign. ``It's a rather frivolous suit and a publicity stunt right before a contested primary in which he's a candidate,'' she said. The lawsuit, filed in Ingham County Circuit Court, targets a measure being pushed by the Right to Life of Michigan group, which gathered more than 333,000 signatures on petitions to put the proposal before the Legislature. If the Board of State Canvassers certifies the petitions, the Legislature will have 40 days to pass the measure or it will go before voters in the 1992 general election. Gov. James Blanchard, who vetoed a similar measure earlier this year, is barred by the state constitution from doing so to initiated bills. Ferency's suit relies on a section of the Michigan Constitution that says the people's power to initiate legislation covers only laws that are constitutional. Ferency argued that the bill is unconstitutional because it treats unmarried minors differently from married minors and interferes with the right to seek medical care. It also unconstitutionally violates the due process rights of doctors by punishing them for performing a legal medical procedure and interferes with a contract between a doctor and a patient for medical care by requiring a third party's consent, Ferency's suit argued.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviet Union Suspends Arms Sales to Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to update with Baker planning to fly to Moscow to issue joint statement with Shevardnadze. Pickup 7th pvs, `President Bush...
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, Iraq's main arms supplier, decided today to suspend weapons sales to Iraq in response to Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait, the official Tass news agency said. At the same time, the United States said Secretary of State James A. Baker III would travel to Moscow on Friday to issue a joint superpower statement on the invasion, which Washington and the Soviet Union both condemned. The Soviet announcement about arms sales came several hours after the Soviet Union demanded that Iraq withdraw its troops from Kuwait. Iraq's forces overran Kuwait after talks broke down Wednesday on a dispute over an oil-rich border area. Earlier today, Baker met with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Siberia and asked him to halt arms deliveries to Iraq. The two leaders were in the Siberian city of Irkutsk to discuss Afghanistan and other issues. After Tass reported the suspension of arms sales, the State Department announced that Baker had changed his travel plans and would fly to Moscow on Friday to issue the joint statement with Shevardnadze on the Iraqi invasion. The fact that the Soviet Union and the United States both moved together against Iraq shows how their relationship has improved and how both seem less prepared to take opposite sides in regional conflicts. The Soviet Foreign Ministry issued a statement this morning condemning the Iraqi attack and calling for an immediate withdrawal of all Iraqi troops, but the brief Tass report tonight contained the first response to Baker's request. Tass, which was quoting a second Foreign Ministry statement, said sales of arms and military hardware were being interrupted ``in connection with the invasion of Kuwait by Iraqi armed forces.'' It was the latest in a series of quick responses by governments that have condemned the Iraqi invasion, which toppled the Kuwaiti government and put a provisional government in its place. President Bush, who condemned the invasions as ``naked aggression,'' signed orders freezing Iraqi assets and Kuwaiti assets to prevent Iraq from seizing them. France quickly did the same, while Britain froze Kuwaiti assets. Baker spoke to reporters aboard a U.S. Air Force jet en route from the Siberian city of Irkutsk to Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia, where he met with that country's leaders on an official visit. The secretary said he asked Shevardnadze to halt ``any military or arms deliveries that they might have in the pipeline to Iraq.'' Baker said Shevardnadze ``was not pleased to hear that Iraqi forces had moved into Kuwait.'' Baker said he had heard about the invasion just before he went into a final negotiating session with Shevardnadze this morning. Shevardnadze told reporters on his return to Moscow from Irkutsk that every measure should be taken to end the Iraqi-Kuwait conflict, Tass said. He said he would be consulting with his advisers and the Soviet Union would take all necessary measures that are possible.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Ant Plague Worsening in South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS bushels to tons in second item, graf 8.
DOC.TEXT: Killer bees, humbug! It's the ornery red, imported fire ant that is threatening life and limb in the South these days. And the situation keeps getting worse, says the Agriculture Department. In 1957, fire ants occupied about 27 million acres. By 1985 their domain was 230 million acres, stretching from Texas to Virginia and Puerto Rico. Regina Wiggen of the department's Agricultural Research Service said people throughout the South ``have grudgingly surrendered ground'' to fire ants since the pests were first seen in the United States near Mobile, Ala., in 1918. Wiggen, associate editor of the agency's Agricultural Research magazine, wrote that fire ants are a threat to humans and livestock. They also destroy or disfigure the landscape with their mounds. ``In the ants' wake, playground and picnic areas lie abandoned, parks disfigured, golf courses churned up and cemeteries damaged,'' she said. ``No one who is hypersensitive to stinging insects should risk being stung.'' All of this is old stuff to millions of Southerners who have learned to look carefully where they sit or lie in the great outdoors. But the ants may be getting antsy about moving on. For years, Wiggen said, scientists believed the ants have a limited tolerance of cold weather. In their native Argentina, they don't range south of 38 degrees latitude, which is comparable to the pests' northernmost range in the United States. But lately there has been concern that the imported red fire ant has been mingling with black varieties, which might produce a cold-tolerant fire ant. Isolated colonies have been spotted in Arizona and California. The December 1989 issue of Nursery Digest warned that once established in California, fire ants probably will spread to much of the western seaboard. The USDA for many years worked with states to fight fire ants with chemicals and poisoned bait. Wiggen said that between 1957 and 1977, millions of acres were treated with the insecticide Mirex, but ``without enduring avail.'' Now, she said, ``We know that widespread application of toxic chemicals may put the environment at more risk than the ants.'' The magazine's cover story by Jessica Morrison Silva tells about the life cycle of fire ants, how they threaten homeowners, public lands and farming areas. The colony is based on a queen, which has a rather bizarre sex life. ``After a virgin queen mates in midair, she descends to the ground,'' Silva said. ``No longer needing wings, she now chews or breaks them off. The remaining wing muscles are used as a nutritional source for her in establishing the new colony and in egg production.'' Parasites and other natural weapons are being examined as possible methods of curbing the pests. Scientists are seeking a complex of fire ant disease and natural pests that will do the job. Meanwhile, Africanized bees _ the so-called ``killer bees'' of Hollywood fame _ are still moving north and may cross the U.S.-Mexico border any time now, say USDA officials. While these aggressive bee can be threatening, they still only sting from one end. The fire ant, according to USDA entomologists, grabs you with its jaws and socks it to you with its tail stinger. Both the bite and sting are painful.

The Agriculture Department says China has bought an additional 247,900 metric tons of U.S. wheat under a price subsidy program. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Wednesday that two private exporting companies made the deals under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for December, he said. The sales were part of 2 million tons authorized China under EEP on May 2. Previous allocations had been exhausted except for 5,050 tons. Dickerson said China has about 760,000 tons remaining in its current allocation. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The latest sales would be about 9.1 million bushels. At current prices estimated by USDA at around $2.62 per bushel, the wheat would have a farm value of around $24 million. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $20.40 per ton, or about 56 cents per bushel. The subsidized sales were handled by Continental Grain Co., 207,900 tons; and Cargill Inc., 40,000 tons. With the latest sales, China has bought about 2.2 million tons of U.S. wheat for delivery in the 1990-91 wheat marketing year that began June 1, compared with 5.6 million tons in 1989-90.

Rural development councils will be started this summer in eight states as a forerunner of a nationwide project to boost development in rural America, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced. The councils will be started in Kansas, Maine, Mississippi, Oregon, South Carolina, South Dakota, Texas and Washington, he said Wednesday. Existing resources will be used to form the councils, which will have full-time coordinators, Yeutter said. A goal will be to form state-level partnerships between federal and state governments and the private sector. ``The participants will create a long-term strategy for applying federal rural development resources and will carry out joint actions to implement the strategy,'' Yeutter said. Councils will be made up of federal officials representing various departments and agencies that have significant rural development roles. Such agencies would include the Extension Service and the Farmers Home Administration, for example.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Madonna's chief bodyguard apologized for roughing up a newspaper photographer who tried to snap the pop star jogging along a busy street. Security guard Marcus Johnson went to El Periodico de Cataluna's newsroom Wednesday to apologize to the photographer, Juan Valganon, the newspaper reported Thursday. Valganon was bruised in Tuesday's altercation. Madonna's ``Blond Ambition'' tour included three concerts in Spain. Meanwhile Thursday in Italy, the Vatican newspaper criticized the country's state-run television network for broadcasting Madonna's Barcelona concert. In a commentary, L'Osservatore Romano said the live broadcast of Wednesday night's concert violated ``good sense, good taste and decency.'' More than 50,000 people attended the show.

The Rolling Stones will play in Prague for the first time as part of festivities marking the country's freedom from communism. President Vaclav Havel, who led last winter's anti-communist revolution, is a fan and wants to meet Mick Jagger and other members of the band, an aide said Thursday. The concert is scheduled for Aug. 18, the last stop on the Stones' ``Urban Jungle'' tour. The Stones will perform three days before the anniversary of the 1968 Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia. The concert was scheduled then so ``it could be a great celebration of freedom and the defeat of evil powers,'' said Jiri Ruzek, the show's Czech promoter.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The following item embargoed until 4 p.m. EDT Thursday
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles gave the Queen Mother a special 90th birthday present Thursday, a concert of specially commissioned music. The concert by the English Chamber Orchestra, and a recording to be released by EMI, benefit the prince's charity, The Prince's Trust. The trust helps disadvantaged young people. Charles commissioned one of the works by composer Patrick Doyle especially for his grandmother. The piece has a series of Scottish verses set to music and was sung by Scottish soprano Marie McLaughlin. Besides the guest of honor, the Prince invited his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, his wife, Princess Diana, and about 300 others. The Queen Mother turns 90 on Saturday.

A philanthropist has given $1.4 million to Connecticut College to create a professorship honoring Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel. The endowment creating the Elie Wiesel Chair in Judaic Studies is the largest gift in the private college's 79-year history, school officials said Thursday. The money was donated by Jo Ann Hess Myers, a 1967 graduate of the school, who runs a private day school in Birmingham, Ala. She also directs the Fig Tree Foundation, a private philanthropy. Wiesel, a survivor of a Nazi death camp, has crusaded for human rights throughout the world. He has written more than 30 books and is the founder of the Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity. He won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986. The college has formed a search committee to fill the post with a Judaic scholar, who is to develop a program including philosophy, government, history, sociology and religion.

A $20,000 donation from talk show host Oprah Winfrey will help open a new shelter for battered women. The B. Robert Lewis House, a private agency headquartered in Eagan, will open its second shelter in an abandoned convent, said director Mary Ajax. The convent is being leased for 20 cents a year from church officials who wished to remain anonymous, she said. The windfall came last November when Winfrey held a benefit performance in Minneapolis and offered to give half of the proceeds to the shelter. Ajax said the donation was so large it took several months for the shelter to find other sources to match it.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Calls for Iraqi Pullout
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan, heavily dependent on Persian Gulf oil, said Thursday it was greatly concerned by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and urged Iraq to withdraw its troops. Japan imports 99 percent of its oil and its economy has proved vulnerable to ``oil shocks'' sparked by Middle East conflicts. Iraq's predawn invasion of Kuwait drove down the Japanese yen and sent shares plunging on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Kuwait and Iraq, between them, supply 11.2 percent of Japan's oil needs. Japan ``deeply regrets'' the invasion and ``is watching the worsening situation with great concern,'' chief government spokesman Misoji Sakamoto said. He said Japan ``requests the immediate retreat of the Iraqi forces'' and expressed hope the issues between the two Persian Gulf neighbors could be settled without more force. The Arab oil embargo after the 1973 Arab-Israeli war was a powerful though short-term setback to Japan's economic growth. Oil prices skyrocketed, causing inflation and cutbacks in industrial production. In the first quarter of 1990, Iraq supplied Japan with about 260,000 barrels of oil a day, or 6.2 percent of its needs, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said. During the same period, Kuwait was the source of 210,000 barrels a day, or 5.0 percent of Japan's needs, it said. Trading in crude oil was chaotic in Far Eastern markets Thursday. Bid prices climbed sharply. As of the end of June, Japan had 142 days worth of oil in reserve, an official at the trade ministry said. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, predicted oil prices would fluctuate in the short term but said it was too early to say what long-term effect there might be on Japan's oil imports. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the widely quoted Nikkei index of 225 selected issues closed down 592.81 points at 30,245.18, a drop of 1.92 percent for the day. The dollar closed up 2.25 yen at 148.90 yen in Tokyo after trading in a wide range. Earlier this week the dollar had gone into a decline based on interest-rate concerns, but it moved sharply up on news of the Middle East fighting. Earlier this year, Iraqi Oil Minister Issam al-Chalabi visited Tokyo seeking increased oil sales to Japan. He said Japanese companies had expressed interest in helping to develop oil fields, with expenses to be repaid in oil from the fields.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea to Procede With Five-Day Border Opening
DOC.TEXT: South Korea said Thursday it would procede with a five-day border opening in mid-August and that all citizens will be allowed to visit Communist North Korea if the North guarantees their safe return. Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul announced details of the Aug. 13-17 border opening and urged North Korea to support the historic project, designed to promote unification of the divided peninsula. North Korea said it would send a delegation across the border during the five-day period to ``console'' several prominent South Korean dissidents jailed for allegedly promoting national unification. South Korean security laws ban private contacts between South Korean citizens and North Korea, which Seoul considers an enemy country. In a nationally televised news conference, Hong said any of South Korea's 42 million citizens may apply to visit the North and any applicants accepted and guaranteed by Pyongyang authorities would be allowed to cross the border. This was the first time South Korea has said it would allow all citizens, including dissidents, to visit Communist North Korea. ``We hope ... this would not only lead to the reunion of separated families, but also the sharing of the emotional excitement by embracing each other after 45 years of separation,'' Hong told a news conference. The minister said, however, South Korean dissidents would not be allowed to to attend a North Korean-sponsored unification rally at the border village of Panmunjom Aug. 15 unless they are joined by ``representatives of all walks of life.'' North Korea has said it will welcome only dissidents from the South at the rally. In a report, monitored in Tokyo Thursday, North Korea said that on Aug. 15 it would send a delegation to visit a jailed South Korean radical student and other dissidents. ``Our consolatory team is going to meet and console not only Im Su-gyong but also father Moon Gyu-hyon ... and at the same time, Rev. Moon Ik-hwan and his family,'' according to the North's official Korean Central News Agency. Ms. Im, a 22-year-old sophomore in Seoul, was sentenced to five years in prison for making an illegal trip to North Korea last year. She said she went to the North to promote unification. Moon Gyu-hyon, a 41-year-old Catholic priest, and Moon Ik-hwan, a 72-year-old protestant minister, also received long prison terms for violating national security laws. The two Moons are unrelated. There was no immediate South Korean response to the North Korean move. The Seoul announcement Thursday was a followed a July 20 proclamation by President Roh Tae-woo calling for a five-day border opening to allow free and unrestricted travel between the hostile Koreas. North Korea effectively rejected Roh's proposal by listing a set of preconditions unlikely to be met, including releasing political prisoners and dismantling border walls that South Korea claims do not exist. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist North and capitalist South in 1945 and the two nations fought a war in the early 1950s. Despite sporadic dialogue aimed at reducing tensions, they remain archenemies. The border between the Koreas is the most heavily fortified in the world, with more than 1.5 million armed troops behind concrete bunkers and barbed wire on either side. There are no telephone, radio, television or travel exchanges.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say They Have 40,000 Tons of Chemical Weapons Stored
DOC.TEXT: The commander of Soviet chemical forces says the Soviets have a stockpile of 40,000 tons of chemical weapons, about 10,000 tons less than previous independent estimates. Meanwhile, France on Thursday proposed a high-level meeting in January to chart the path to speedy agreement to ban the use, production and stockpiling of chemical weapons the world over. The Soviet official, Stanislav Petrov, told the Communist Party newspaper Pravda that all Soviet chemical weapons are stored on Soviet territory. There have long been rumors that the Soviets have chemical-weapons depots in Eastern Europe. Petrov confirmed to Pravda there are no facilities in the Soviet Union to destroy the chemical weapons, despite a superpower agreement to eliminate 80 percent of them immediately. A weapons-destruction plant was built at Chapayevsk, 550 miles southwest of Moscow, but was closed last summer after local residents complained it would add to already high pollution levels. Petrov told Pravda the Chapayevsk site would become a training center for workers who destroy chemical weapons. The Supreme Soviet legislature was asked to find a safe site to build a replacement plant, but so far no lawmaker has volunteered a district in which to place it. Petrov said he would like to build two destruction facilities in sparsely populated areas. Independent sources had previously estimated the Soviet Union had 40,000 tons of chemical weapons compared with 30,000 tons in the United States. The French call for high-level talks on chemical weapons came at the 40-nation Geneva Conference on Disarmament. France's chief delegate Pierre Morel said despite earlier headway, talks on a chemical weapons treaty had bogged down. Morel proposed that January's meeting be held at the ministerial level to speed the treaty process.

DOC.HEAD: A Comparison of the Military Forces of Iraq and Kuwait
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a comparison of the military forces of Iraq and Kuwait:

The numbers of Iraqi servicemen and weapons dwarf those of Kuwait. Iraq has been engaged in a major defense buildup since President Saddam Hussein came to power in 1979. Its combined military forces are estimated at 1 million, with roughly half as active reservists. The army encompasses five armored, two mechanized and 42 infantry divisions with 20 special forces brigades. Equipment includes 3,500 Soviet tanks, 1,500 Chinese tanks, and 100 PT-76 light tanks according to figures from the 1989-90 Military Balance. The air force has about 500 combat aircraft. The planes are in large part Soviet-designed, including 30 Su-7s, 50 Su-20s, and 30 Su-25s. There are 25 MiG-25s, 18 MiG-29s and 90 MiG-23s interceptors and fighter-bombers. Additionally, there are 40 Chinese made J-6's, 80 J-7s, as well as 64 Mirage F-IEQ5s with Exocet. Military service of up to two years is compulsory for all men at 18 years of age. On Tuesday, as Iraqi and Kuwaiti envoys met to discuss their border and oil dispute, diplomats said Iraq had massed 100,000 troops on Kuwait's border. That was more than triple the number estimated earlier. The reported Iraqi troop buildup included hundreds of tanks and armored personnel carriers.

Kuwait has a total of about 20,300 troops in its military. It maintains a small but well-equipped army with two armored brigades, a mechanized infantry brigade, one artillery brigade and a surface-to-surface missile battalion. Its air force, initially a small combat force, has grown to include two squadrons with 20 Mirage F1-CK fighters, 4 F-1BKs and 24 A-4KU Skyhawk attack aircraft. For most Kuwaitis, military service is compulsory for 24 months.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraq Invades Kuwait; U.S. Responds With Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 12th, `A Pentagon...' to UPDATE with Baker to fly to Moscow for joint statement, sub 20th, `Egypt's Middle...' to UPDATE with diplomats confirming death. Pickup 1st graf of a0571, `Kuwait radio...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,5,6,8; LaserGraphics
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's powerful army invaded this small oil-rich kingdom early today. Tank-led troops quickly seized the ruler's palace and government buildings, and the emir fled to Saudi Arabia, Kuwaiti officials said. Kuwait's U.S. ambassador said the Iraqis occupied all government buildings in the capital and were moving south toward the country's oil facilities. He appealed for U.S. military intervention. A Pentagon source said U.S. Navy ships were diverted to the region, but President Bush said the subject of intervention was not being discussed. ``The Iraqis have occupied all of Kuwait!'' a Kuwaiti government official shouted in a telephone interview. Diplomatic sources in the Persian Gulf estimated that more than 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded. The Iraqi government of President Saddam Hussein claimed it invaded at the request of revolutionaries who had already staged a coup and established ``The Provisional Government of Free Kuwait.'' Kuwait and U.N. diplomats labeled the coup report a farce. The assault followed two weeks of tension between Kuwait and Iraq, caused by Iraqi accusations that Kuwait stole oil from a disputed border area. Saddam also accused Kuwait of exceeding OPEC production quotas, thus driving down the price of oil, a major Iraqi revenue source. The attack had wide-ranging ramifications: _Oil prices soared $3 a barrel in early trading because of fears the invasion would disrupt supplies. Prices were about $2 higher later. _President Bush signed orders freezing Iraqi assets in the United States and blocking most Iraqi imports, including oil. Oil accounts for 97 percent of Iraqi imports to the United States and makes up about 3.5 percent of U.S. oil consumption. Bush also froze Kuwaiti assets to prevent Iraq from seizing them. _The Soviet Union, Iraq's main arms supplier, halted weapons sales. _The U.N. Security Council voted 14-0 to denounce the invasion and demanded immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops. _A Pentagon source said the aircraft carrier USS Independence, escorted by a six-ship battle group, was diverted from the Indian Ocean toward the gulf, where other U.S. ships were already patrolling. _Secretary of State James A. Baker III planned to fly to Moscow to issue a rare joint statement Friday with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze about the invasion. The plan, which was announced in Washington, illustrates the dramatic improvement in relations between the superpowers, who once routinely lined up on opposite sides of most regional disputes. Kuwait's U.S. ambassador, Sheik Saud Nasir al-Sabah, told reporters in Washington: ``We are desperate for any help we can get.'' He appealed specifically for American intervention. In recent days, diplomats said Iraq had massed more than 100,000 troops at the border. Kuwait's entire armed forces has 20,300 soldiers. Bush said the United States would ``take whatever steps necessary'' to defend interests in the gulf. Asked if this included military force, Bush said: ``We're not discussing intervention.'' But he said he would not discuss military options publicly. It was the first time in modern history an Arab nation had invaded another and taken over its government. Kuwait's army was no match for Iraq, battle-hardened after eight years of war with Iran. Iraq has emerged as the Arab world's strongest and most militant military power, and Saddam has a vast arsenal of chemical and conventional weapons. Diplomats said about 350 Iraqi tanks wheeled into the capital a few hours after crossing the border 40 miles away at dawn. Witnesses said the bombardment of ports and military airports by artillery and the air force was vicious. The invaders surrounded the palace of Kuwait's ruler, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. Residents said the palace was seized after about two hours of heavy artillery barrages. Diplomats said Sheik Fahd al-Ahmed al-Sabah, one of the emir's brothers, was killed while trying to defend the palace. There were about 50 tanks around the palace and the neighboring American Embassy, residents said. The al-Sabah family has ruled the city-state for almost 250 years. The Kuwaiti ambassador said the leaders were safe in Saudi Arabia. Operating from an unknown location, al-Ahmed's government responded to the formation of the provisional government by stating: ``Kuwait is Kuwait to its people, let by the emir, Sheik Jaber, and his Crown Prince Sheik Saad. God preserve them from all harm.'' For its part, the provisional government announced through Baghdad's official Iraqi News Agency that it was dissolving parliament and would hold ``free and honest elections'' at a future date. The Iraqi forces were led by the elite Republican Guard, which did the brunt of fighting in the Iran-Iraq war. Troops set up roadblocks at major intersections and shot at cars that did not stop. Baghdad television said Iraq qould withdraw its forces within days or weeks, depending on how quickly the situation stabilized. Kuwait's land and sea borders were closed, as was the airport. Diplomats said the invasion was too swift to arrange the evacuation of nationals, and foreigners were asked to keep a low profile. There are about 4,000 Americans among the large expatriate community in Kuwait, where more than 60 percent of the 1.8 million residents are foreigners. U.S. officials monitoring the situation had no reports of harm to U.S. citizens in Iraq, White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said. Foreigners reached by telephone said they watched from their windows or dived for cover as the invasion began. ``We were totally unprepared,'' said Catherine Baker of Illinois. ``One feels like there should have been a bit of warning.'' The British Embassy was hit by shell-fire and the Sheraton and Hilton hotels evacuated their clientele, the diplomats said. The invasion came hours after Iraq broke off talks intended to mend its differences with Kuwait. Iraqi first threatened military action against its former ally Kuwait two weeks ago. Washington declared its support for Kuwait from the start. During the Iran-Iraq war, American ships protected U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tankers from attacks in the gulf.
DOC.HEAD: Kuwait radio, 1st graf, a0571
Galveston Bay Closed to Fishing; Oil-Eating Bacteria Approved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs., `Cleanup crews ...' with 1 graf with governor saying oil-eating microbes not necessary; SUBS 6th graf pvs. `The spill ...' with 3 grafs saying Coast Guard taking over cleanup; SUBS grafs 16-17 pvs. beginning `State officials ...' with 5 grafs on dispute over microbes.
DOC.TEXT: Fishing was banned in seafood-rich Galveston Bay because of a 500,000-gallon oil spill, and crews trying to raise a submerged barge closed the Houston Ship Channel again today. Cleanup crews, meanwhile, got the go-ahead from the federal government to use oil-eating bacteria on the 17-mile slick, but Gov. Bill Clements said after flying over the area today that he does not think the microbes will be effective. ``It's as much a precautionary measure as anything else,'' Neil Travis, chief of the Texas Health Department's consumer health protection bureau, said Wednesday in announcing the open-ended ban on commercial and private fishing. The move was a blow to the seafood industry, and some business owners threatened to sue to recoup their losses. The bay is one of the state's richest fishing grounds, generating revenue estimated at more than $338 million a year. ``Everybody's wondering how in the hell they're going to pay their mortgages on their boats and their businesses,'' said Walter Jakubas, owner of Captain Wally's Marina in San Leon. The spill occurred Saturday when a Greek tanker collided with two oil barges in the Houston Ship Channel. The tanker did not lose any of its cargo of jet fuel. But one Apex Towing Co. barge sank and the other was damaged. The Coast Guard said today it is taking charge of cleanup operations. ``We took over the cleanup. We call the shots now and we pay the bills,'' said Chief Warrant Officer Rick Meidt. But, he said, the Coast Guard will bill the towing company for the cleanup costs. Coast Guard Petty Officer Glenn Rosenholm said divers have found a crack between two cargo tanks on the barge and numerous holes, including one 7-foot gash in the stern. Some 10,000 gallons of oil was found still aboard the barge in one of the tanks. Rosenholm said divers put a sling under the barge in front of the crack to try to raise it enough to move it out of the ship channel. Gov. Bill Clements met with Coast Guard Rear Adm. Jim Loy early today before flying over the accident site. Clements, who has declared a state emergency for the area, planned to visit Eagle Point, a peninsula that was doused with oil and is being used as a command post for cleanup crews. Rosenholm said the Coast Guard estimates about 50,000 gallons of oil remained on the water throughout Galveston Bay today. ``That does not include oil contained in the booms, or picked up by skimmers,'' he said. ``That's just what remains free-floating.'' More than 50,000 gallons of oil had been skimmed from the bay by Wednesday and other oil has been trapped in booms surrounding the spill area and sweeps used to deflect oil from sensitive marshland areas. Meanwhile, officials from the Coast Guard and the National Transportation Safety Board resumed a hearing today into the cause of the accident. On Wednesday, officials heard testimony from the captain and helmsman aboard the Shinoussa, who blamed a Houston Ship Channel pilot for directing them into the path of the barges. The pilot, however, claimed the helmsman turned the wrong way. State officials had hoped to begin deploying some 800 pounds of oil-eating microbes in some areas of the bay later today. But Clements, who declared the bay an emergency area Wednesday, said he didn't think bioremediation would be effective on the 17-mile oil slick because it has broken up. ``It is so fragmented out there. There's no concentration of the kind of slick that you would address it to,'' Clements said. Blanton Moore, a representative of the Texas General Land Office, disagreed. He said the microbes could be used on the remaining sheen. ``It has no negative effects and can only help the bay,'' he said of the process. The naturally occurring microbes reduce the oil to a fatty substance that sinks and is eaten by fish. When the oil is gone, the microbes die. Earlier this summer, the oil-eaters underwent their first open-sea test on a small section of the 3.9-million-gallon Mega Borg oil spill. State officials said the microbes gobbled up the oil and caused no harm to the environment. Travis of the state Health Department said the fishing ban was imposed because shrimpers were spotted fishing in oil-tainted areas and because oil was found on some shrimp caught in the bay. The ban prohibits the taking of any aquatic organisms, including fish, crabs, oysters and shrimp. ``We're at a point of extreme frustration,'' said Clifford Hillman, owner of Hillman Shrimp and Oyster Co. in San Leon. ``Are the effects of this two weeks, two years or twenty years?'' Larry McKinney, director of resource protection at the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, said oil settling on the bottom could kill small marine life _ a crucial link in the food chain _ and reduce the number of shrimp, oysters, crabs and other wildlife. ``If it's on the surface, at least you have the chance of cleaning it up. If it gets to the bottom, there's nothing you can do, you're stuck with it,'' McKinney said. ``That's when you get the long-term impact. If it gets in the sediment, it can be very toxic over a long period of time _ up to five years.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait's Ruling Dynasty Brought Low By Iraqi Invasion
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For 234 years, the al-Sabah family ruled Kuwait. But on Thursday, the once-proud dynasty was shattered by a lighting invasion by Iraq. At least one member of the royal family was reported to have been killed, and the emir himself, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, and his crown prince, Sheik Saad Abdullah al-Sabah, fled to neighboring Saudi Arabia. ``This is a black Thursday in the annals of not only the al-Sabah dynasty but also Arab solidarity,'' one Kuwaiti government official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Egypt's Middle East News Agency quoted witnesses as saying Sheik Fahd al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the emir's brother, was gunned down as he tried to defend the emir's palace. Persian Gulf diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, later confirmed he was dead. Members of the al-Sabah family, like other royal families in the rest of the Gulf region, fill many key posts in the government, army, police and private sector. They number more than 1,000. Oil has given Kuwait one of the highest per capita incomes in the world _ about $20,000. But this has not meant peace for the tiny Persian Gulf country of 1.8 million people. The 64-year-old emir, Sheik Jaber, has come in for much of the turbulence. When his country gained independence from Britain in 1961, he was named minister of finance and economy _ just as Iraq was claiming sovereignty. Britain had to bring in troops to get the Iraqis to back off. By the time he moved up the ranks to prime minister, crown prince and finally emir late 1977, Kuwait was a country in the throes of a parliamentary crisis. By 1980, Parliament was restored and Kuwait was an Arab pioneer of Western-style democracy. But soon the Iraq-Iran war broke out. Kuwait was a leading supporter of Iraq, bearing $15 billion of Baghdad's war costs. From 1980 to 1988, Kuwait was caught in between the fighting of two neighboring powers, Iraq and Iran, hearing the sound of gunfire from the front only 90 miles away. Iran, dedicated to spreading its Islamic revolution and angry at Kuwait for supporting Iraq, attacked Kuwaiti shipping lanes and oil facilities. The United States later protected reflagged Kuwaiti tankers in the gulf. Kuwaitis also believe Iran was behind a spate of terrorism that began with the 1983 car bombings of U.S. and French embassies. Seventeen pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem terrorists were convicted for those attacks, and demands for their release were hammered home with more attacks. Bombs were planted in downtown locations, at oil installations and at seafront cafes. In May 1985, there was a car-bomb attack on Sheik Jaber's life, but he escaped with minor injuries. With the end of the war, the emir hoped Baghdad would settle its longstanding border dispuate with Kuwait. But it never did.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Isolates Iraq; Kuwait Seeks US Intervention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with Soviet action, Bush's extended order, House vote; specifies that only donated food exempt from embargo; Picks up graf 14 pvs `The State...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait as ``naked aggression,'' froze control of Iraqi assets in the United States and blocked almost all imports from the oil-rich Middle Eastern country. Bush demanded that Iraq withdraw its troops but said military intervention was not under discussion. Nonetheless, the Pentagon ordered the aircraft carrier USS Independence and a six-ship battle group toward the strife-torn Persian Gulf. With Kuwait's royal family in exile, the kingdom's ambassador to Washington pleaded for help. ``We don't have a chance if we don't get any aid from our friends,'' Saud Nasir al-Sabah told reporters. ``U.S. intervention at this stage is of paramount importance.'' The chief U.S. military presence in the Gulf is the eight-ship Joint Task Force Middle East, led by the command ship USS LaSalle. Battle-ready Marines are stationed on the super-secret Diego Garcia base in the Indian Ocean, but moving their equipment would require at least 10 days, a military source said. The Bush administration rejected as ``a patent fraud'' the Iraqi claim that the invasion came at the behest of an interim Kuwaiti government. ``We just can't accept that kind of explanation,'' said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. After pleas from U.S. officials, the Soviet Union said it would cut off arms shipments to Iraq. U.S. and Soviet officials scheduled a joint declaration on the war for Friday in Moscow. Bush's condemnation of the invasion won general endorsement in Congress. The House quickly passed a bill, 416-0, embodying and toughening Bush's economic sanctions. The only criticism of the president came from lawmakers who said he should have acted earlier. Bush said he had not been taken totally by surprise by the invasion. ``We had good intelligence and our intelligence has had me concerned for some time now,'' he said. Government officials who would not be identified by name said the United States was told of the invasion at 8:30 p.m. Washington time Wednesday, about 3{ hours after it began. Bush's early morning order cut off virtually all commerce between the United States and Iraq. The only exceptions were publications and shipments to Iraq of donated food, clothing and medical supplies. Later in the day he issued a memorandum to agency heads barring any financial assistance, loan guaratnees or export license to Iraq. Iraq and Kuwait together supply less than 10 percent of U.S. oil imports, according to U.S. industry officials. However, the instability is certain to affect domestic oil prices. Bush summoned reporters before an early morning meeting with his top national security advisers and said he was viewing the Middle East tumult ``with utmost gravity.'' ``We remain committed to take whatever actions are necessary to defend our longstanding, vital interests in the (Persian) Gulf,'' Bush said, adding that his advisers would ``consider all possible options available to us.'' Lt. Gen. Howard Graves of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, traveling in Mongolia with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, said the United States was considering ``political, military or economic'' moves against Iraq. Pentagon sources identified one option as assisting evacuation of 3,000 Americans from Kuwait. Bush said he would cut short a trip to Aspen, Colo., for a visit with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and return to Washington Thursday night. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney decided not to go to Aspen to remain in Washington, and Baker headed for Moscow for a joint announcement with the Soviets. The State Department said at midday that all 270 U.S. Embassy personnel in Kuwait were safe and that the embassy grounds had not been penetrated during the fighting. The department acknowledged that one option under consideration was withdrawal of the U.S. ambassador from Iraq, but added that Ambassador April Glaspie had left the country for vacation before the invasion _ an indication the United States did not take seriously Iraq's threatening buildup along the Kuwaiti border. In Congress, there was widespread condemnation of the invasion and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said the House would vote to impose sanctions against Iraq. The House Foreign Affairs Committee met in special session to write Bush's executive order into law. Foley declined to criticize Bush for resisting earlier sanctions against Iraq. But Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said if Bush had acted earlier, after Iraq had used gas against some of its own citizens during the war with Iran, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``may have gotten the message that his lawlessness would not be tolerated.'' Ambassador Saud Nasir al-Sabah of Kuwait told reporters here: ``We are desperate for any help we can get.'' Experts said Bush harbored few easy military options to bolster his condemnation of the Iraqi invasion. ``We're not discussing intervention,'' Bush said, but acknowledged, ``I would not discuss it (publicly) if I were.'' In announcing his economic sanctions against Iraq, Bush expressed concern about how the invasion would affect U.S. oil supplies. The United States imports about half its oil. The boycott against Iraq is certain to affect domestic oil prices. According to a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee, the United States imports more than $3 billion in goods annually from Iraq; 97 percent of the total is oil. The executive order also froze Kuwait property under U.S. jurisdiction _ a move intended to keep Iraq from seizing it. Bush urged other nations to take similar measures and called on Moscow to suspend arms shipments to Baghdad. The State Department advised Americans to postpone travel to Kuwait. Bush said his advisers would explore a range of options including a request for unspecified action by the United Nations. ``The United States strongly condemns the Iraqi military invasion of Kuwait and calls for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of all the Iraqi forces,'' Bush said. ``There is no place for this sort of naked aggression in today's world.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. and chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, told NBC News that he doesn't believe the United States has a military option at the moment, ``nor do we have a treaty obligation.'' ``I believe that our primary recourse should be very intensive diplomatic activity,'' he said. ``We ought to put the burden on the nations in that region to bring to bear all the diplomatic and economic power.'' William J. Crowe, retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, described the level of danger in the Middle East as ``very high.'' He told ABC the U.S. military could not play a significant role unless invited by Saudi Arabia and given access to Saudi military facilities. Even before the invasion, Congress had been pressuring Bush to impose new sanctions on Iraq over its belligerent moves toward Mideast neighbors. Iraq had moved about 100,000 troops to its border with Kuwait after claiming that Kuwait's production of oil beyond quotas of the OPEC cartel had depressed the world price, thus diminishing Iraq's revenue, and that Kuwait had been stealing oil from a field that straddles the border. Iraqi officials on Wednesday walked out on talks in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, aimed at resolving the 2-week-old crisis and complained that Kuwait was not negotiating seriously.

DOC.HEAD: Dawn Wake-Up Calls for Emmy Nominees Bring Good News, Bad News
With AM-Emmy Nominations, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: John Goodman's mother woke him up Thursday to tell him of his Emmy nomination, Angela Lansbury was whispered the news by her husband and Dana Delany thought a bagel and coffee was in order. The pre-dawn announcement in the West Coast caught some stars asleep, others on the road or finishing movies. One actress was speechless after what she perceived as a snub by the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. Miss Lansbury, who has never won an Emmy despite numerous nominations for ``Murder, She Wrote,'' was with her hairdresser when she learned of the nomination from her husband, Peter Shaw. He leaned over and whispered the news. ``I'm surprised and delighted. It's wonderful to know you're still up there and your performance is intact,'' Miss Lansbury said. Leading the Emmys list with 14 nominations was the nighttime soap series ``Twin Peaks,'' which revolves around junk food and murder in a Pacific Northwest lumber town. Co-executive producer Mark Frost was elated. ``I guess I feel like the quality of life in Twin Peaks got a little better today,'' Frost said. ``I guess our chances of surviving are a little bit better.'' ``Empty Nest'' star Richard Mulligan, a two-time Emmy winner, was at home studying a script and eating strawberries when the telephone rang with the news of his latest nomination. ``To be recognized by your peers is great,'' he said. Roseanne Barr was missing from the nominations list for a second year as she expected, but her show ``Roseanne'' got two nominations. Earlier this week, she told interviewer Sally Jessy Raphael she had felt ``snubbed.'' ``It really hurt my feelings,'' she said, adding she felt the ``same thing'' would happen this year. She reacted Thursday through her publicist: ``Miss Barr is resting her voice and is unavailable for comment,'' said Chris Hamblin. ``I think Roseanne and her show are the best things on television,'' said Miss Barr's husband-producer, Tom Arnold, from the couple's Malibu home. ``It always takes the industry a few years to catch up with anything ground-breaking.'' ``Roseanne'' co-star John Goodman's mother was watching the nominations announcement on TV in St. Louis when she heard her son's name called. She phoned him in Los Angeles and woke him up. ``I'm extremely happy. I did not get into this business to win awards but if somebody nominates me I'll take it,'' said Goodman, who was completing his latest movie ``Barton Fink'' before returning to the ``Roseanne'' set Monday. Estelle Getty and Betty White were nominated in different categories for their roles on ``The Golden Girls,'' but co-stars Rue McClanahan and Bea Arthur weren't on the list. ``It's always a thrill to be nominated and I'm very grateful to the academy, but it amazes me how anyone can pick and choose because it is so strongly an ensemble company,'' said Miss Getty. Melanie Mayron, nominated again for her role on ``thirtysomething,'' was asleep when the telephone rang with the news from the show's producer. She won the Emmy for supporting actress in a drama series in 1989. ``You never get tired of being nominated _ a virgin every time,'' Miss Mayron said. ``I'm ecstatic. I felt like this last season I did some of the best work of my career.'' ``China Beach'' star Dana Delany, who won the dramatic series Emmy last year, was nominated again for her role as nurse Colleen McMurphy. Miss Delany was participating in the news conference announcing nominations with actor Lou Gossett. When Gossett began reading the lead actress in a drama series category, Miss Delany thought she wasn't nominated because they had been going in alphabetical order. ``I was thinking, `Well, that's not it this year. It's not in the cards,''' Miss Delany said. Then, Gossett read her name. ``I think they did that just to get me,'' she said. ``It's almost scarier this year because I know I have a chance,'' she said. ``I think I'll go out and celebrate maybe with a bagel and a cup of coffee.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Envoy Pleads for Help; Iraqis Defend Invasion
With AM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The mood at the embassies of two warring Middle East nations was a study in contrasts Thursday, as Kuwait's ambassador pleaded for outside assistance and the Iraqi envoy defiantly defended his country's invasion of Kuwait. ``We don't stand a chance if we don't get any aid from our friends,'' a somber Saud Nasser Al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti ambassador, told reporters in an ornate chamber of his embassy. Al-Sabah, a member of Kuwait's ruling family, asked the United States to intervene militarily to help his oil-rich emirate repulse Iraqi troops who invaded on Wednesday. As Al-Sabah spoke of deaths in Kuwait and the country's efforts to resist, a member of the staff wiped tears from his eyes and muffled a sob. ``We are desperate for any help we can get,'' he said, describing his plea as a ``universal cry for help.'' Al-Sabah said Kuwait's leader is directing the resistance from Saudi Arabia, but that his country is ``under occupation'' by Iraqi forces. Hours later, Iraqi ambassador Mohamed Sadiq Al-Mashat summoned reporters to his embassy, where he said any foreign interference ``will only aggravate the situation.'' Surrounded by aides, Al-Mashat stood in front of a life-size picture of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The ambassador disregarded two power failures that occurred during his remarks. Contradicting Kuwaiti claims to the contrary, the Iraqi envoy insisted that the ``interim free government'' installed after the invasion ``has asked the Iraqi government to extend assistance for the maintenance of law and order.'' Al-Mashat said Iraqi forces ``will be withdrawn as soon as the situation is settled down and as soon as the free government of Kuwait has so wished.'' He refused to answer questions, choosing instead to read a five-paragraph statement. Both ambassadors said they had been in contact with Bush administration officials but neither shed any light on the U.S. response. Bush condemned the invasion but said he was not considering military intervention. Defense Department sources said the aircraft carrier Independence was en route toward the Persian Gulf from the Indian Ocean to bolster U.S. forces in the Middle East, but would not actually enter gulf waters.

DOC.HEAD: Repentant Roswell Gilbert Freed for Wife's `Mercy Killing'
LaserPhotos XSTA1-2
DOC.TEXT: A frail, repentant Roswell Gilbert regained his freedom Thursday after spending more than 5 years in prison for the 1985 ``mercy killing'' of his ailing wife. The 81-year-old Gilbert acknowledged publicly for the first time that he was wrong to kill his wife of 51 years, who suffered from Alzheimer's disease and osteoporosis. ``I shouldn't have killed my wife, now I know that,'' said Gilbert, whose case focused national attention on the killing of an ailing loved one. ``It's difficult to explain to anyone who hasn't been through this trauma, a mental trauma really,'' said Gilbert. He said his wife's illness ``created just a complete state of desperation in my mind ... it's a lousy excuse, but that's what it was.'' Gilbert shot his wife, Emily, twice with a 9mm Luger in March 1985 in their Fort Lauderdale apartment. He was serving a mandatory minimum prison term of 25 years on a murder conviction when he was granted clemency on humanitarian grounds Wednesday by Gov. Bob Martinez and the Florida Cabinet. Gilbert, who suffers from heart and lung disease, wants to regain some of the 40 pounds he lost in prison and ``recoup my health.'' He chuckled at reports that his death may be imminent. ``I'm a tough old rooster ... don't believe it,'' said Gilbert, who said he would probably ignore his daughter's pleas to stop smoking. ``Daddy has very bad emphysema and one of the main things I'm going to do is really insist he quit smoking,'' said daughter Martha ``Skipper'' Moran, the Gilberts' only child. The retired engineer was examined in January and a medical report showed he suffered from heart and lung disease and was considered ``at high risk of death at any time,'' because of his age and physical condition. Gilbert, who left the North Florida Reception Center with a handful of possessions in a small brown paper bag, described prison as a ``human zoo.'' ``It's been plain awful for a freedom-loving person like myself,'' he said. Besides a hamburger, a shot of bourbon and a nice soft bed, Gilbert said he was looking forward to seeing his three grown grandchildren soon. ``I haven't had a good look at them for a long time,'' he said. He left the prison for a friend's home in an undisclosed location. His daughter said she expected him to resettle in Fort Lauderdale. The lawyer who prosecuted Gilbert at the murder trial, Kelly Hancock, said he was relieved that the state decided to free Gilbert. ``His health is deteriorated, and I think his release puts to an end a very, very tragic case _ a case that made us all more aware of the problems of the sick and the elderly have,'' said Hancock, who's now in private practice and publicly sought Gilbert's release in recent weeks. Actor Robert Young, who portrayed Gilbert in a 1987 television movie, ``Mercy or Murder?,'' also said he was elated with the news of Gilbert's clemency. ``That's sensational,'' said the 83-year-old Young, best known for his roles in the TV series ``Father Knows Best,'' and ``Marcus Welby, M.D.'' Although the two men never met, Young said he spoke with Gilbert many times by telephone. ``We had wonderful chats,'' said Young. ``There was no self-pity in him at all. It was a remarkable experience for me to play the role and get to know the man.'' Mrs. Moran, who lives in Baltimore, said she believes her mother would say: ``It's about time they let him out.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Want to Allow Abortions at Military Hospitals
With AM-Military Spending
DOC.TEXT: Two Democratic senators opened a new skirmish in the war over abortion Thursday, saying they want to reverse a regulation that bans abortions in military hospitals. Sens. Tim Wirth of Colorado and John Glenn of Ohio planned to try to add the amendment to reverse the 2-year-old rule to the Defense Department authorization bill for fiscal 1991. The bill is being debated in the Senate. They said the rule, banning abortions except when the life of the mother is endangered, has caused tragic hardship for some U.S. service personnel and their families. ``Why should a whole group of Americans, who happen to be in service, be treated like second-class citizens?'' Wirth asked. The amendment, he said, was triggered by the story of Charles and Kaoru Zwierzynski, who appeared with the senators at a news conference. The couple went to a Japanese hospital last year when a Navy hospital said it couldn't perform an abortion _ despite a diagnosis that the fetus was severely deformed. ``We really went through hell,'' Mrs. Zwierzynski said. ``It was the worst thing that has happened in my life.'' Zwierzynski is a petty officer on the USS Midway, which was in Japan. Mrs. Zwierzynski's fetus had major organs forming outside its body and a malformed heart. Physicians, including one at the U.S. military hospital, said the fetus had no chance of survival and recommended an abortion. Because the military hospital was banned from abortions, the couple went to a Japanese doctor and used their savings to pay $2,400 for an abortion. It was Mrs. Zwierzynski's first pregnancy. The amendment would require that U.S. military personnel and their dependents who are stationed outside the United States be able to obtain any reproductive health service in military hospitals. Abortions, for which federal funds are not permitted to be used, would have to be paid for by the individual. The prohibition was imposed in 1988 by the Reagan administration and was left in force by the Bush administration. The amendment is being sought by abortion-rights groups, including Planned Parenthood Federation. Doug Johnson, legislative director for the National Right to Life Committee, said opponents would try to block the amendment and were focusing their efforts on trying to deny supporters the 60 votes they need to cut off opponents' debate. ``We think every baby, even those with severe handicaps, ought to be allowed their allotted lifespan,'' Johnson said. Rep. Les AuCoin, D-Ore., an abortion-rights leader in the House, said he would try to offer a similar amendment when the defense bill comes to the House floor in September. He said his amendment would provide a new test for the strength of abortion-rights forces, which last year won passage of exemptions in the ban on federally funded abortions to cover cases of rape and incest, but were unable to override President Bush's veto of the measure.

DOC.HEAD: One-Fourth of Infants Born to Single Mothers; For Blacks, 62 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 5 p.m. EDT _ time set by source
DOC.TEXT: More than six out of 10 black infants in the United States are born to unmarried mothers, indicating a risk for health problems, federal health officials said Thursday. Among all races, 24 percent of infants were born to unmarried women in 1987, the latest year for which statistics are available. That's up sixfold from 1950, the national Centers for Disease Control said in reporting the findings. The disproportionate percentage of black infants born to unmarried mothers _ 62 percent, compared to 17 percent of white infants _ represents an escalating trend. In 1983, 59 percent of black births were to single mothers, compared to 13 percent of white births, the CDC said. ``These figures are alarming,'' said Evelyn Lowery, president of SCLC Women, a family-issues arm of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. ``The problems are not getting better; they're getting worse.'' The Atlanta-based CDC, in its weekly report, said single motherhood is a signal of possible health problems for the child, not a direct cause. ``Marital status confers neither risk nor protection to the infant,'' the CDC said. ``Rather, the principal benefits of marriage to infant survival are economic and social support.'' U.S. infant mortality rates are higher for infants born to unmarried mothers than for children of marriage, for both whites and blacks, the CDC said, citing new analysis of 1983 statistics. For whites, the infant mortality rate was 13.1 per 1,000 children of unmarried mothers, compared to 7.8 for children of married mothers. For blacks, the non-marriage infant mortality rate was 19.6, compared to 14.6 for children of married women. ``Our effort at teen pregnancy education has got to continue,'' said Mrs. Lowery, the wife of SCLC President Joseph Lowery. ``Many of these young people are (themselves) from single parent homes.'' Young black women have been especially affected by cutbacks in educational aid and in work programs, and ``this impacts _ as well as the economy _ the teen-age pregnancy problem,'' she said. ``They're out there on the loose.'' The ``benefits of marriage'' may not be there for babies born to teen-agers, even if the mothers are married, the CDC said. Mortality rates for infants of married mothers under 18 tend to be even worse than for unmarried mothers under 18, probably because of a ``severe lack of economic and social support'' in struggling teen marriages, the CDC said. ``Married teen-agers are ... more likely to establish independent households, thereby estranging themselves from financial and child-care support from relatives,'' the agency said. But in general, unmarried mothers often are poor, and ``adverse pregnancy outcomes are correlated with poverty conditions,'' the CDC said. The Census Bureau has reported that 36 percent of black families with a child under 18 are classified as living in poverty, compared to 12 percent of similar white families.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday called for Iraq to withdraw its invading armies from Kuwait, and said he would not rule out direct U.S. military intervention in the conflict. Bush denounced Iraq's move as ``naked aggression,'' and said he wants to see ``the restoration of the Kuwaiti leaders to their rightful place.'' The president spoke at a news conference with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher near Aspen, Colo., several hours after he signed an order freezing control of Iraqi assets in the United States and blocking almost all imports from the oil-rich Middle Eastern country. Thatcher called on Iraq to heed the United Nations Security Council's call for a withdrawal. ``We need a collective and effective will of the nations belonging to the U.N.'' to resolve the conflict, she said. Speaking of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Thatcher said, ``We find his behavior intolerable.'' Bush said he had talked by telephone during the day with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and other Arab leaders, and said he was encouraged by their efforts to find an ``Arab answer'' to the problem. He also noted approvingly that the Soviets had cut off military supplies to Iraq, and that Secretary of State James A. Baker III would stop in Moscow on his way back to the United States from Asia. ``He would not be stopping in Moscow unless there would be a good degree of cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States,'' he said. Asked about a plea from Kuwait's ambassador for military assistance, the president said it would be inappropriate to discuss options. He added, ``We're not ruling any options in but we're not ruling any options out.'' Bush's reply was a slight departure from his answer to a similar question a few hours earlier in Washington. Then, he said he was ``not discussing'' military steps. In Washington, American officials said it would be difficult for the United States to mount an effective military response anytime soon. Bush was asked about reports that Americans working in Kuwait were being rounded up by Iraqi forces. ``I don't have anything on that right now. Secondly, it would affect us in a very dramatic way because I view a fundamental responsibility of my presidency is protecting American citizens. If they're put into harm's way I have certain responsibilities,'' Bush said. Ms. Thatcher denounced the invasion, and said it would be ``totally unacceptable if it were allowed to endure. There would be many other small countries that would never feel safe.'' The two leaders met near Aspen, Colorado. The meeting had been scheduled to discuss the changing face of Europe and western security needs in the post-Cold War ear, but it undoubtedly turned as well to Iraq's overnight invasion of its Middle Eastern neighbor. The president was flying back to Washington later in the day, rather than spend the night in Colorado as originally planned.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Suspends Arms Sales to Iraq; U.S.- Soviets to Issue Joint Statement
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin suspended arms sales to Iraq Thursday and Secretary of State James A. Baker III said he would join Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Moscow to condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. A joint statement from the United States and the Soviet Union demanding Iraq's immediate withdrawal from Kuwait _ combined with their sanctions _ would mark highly unusual superpower cooperation toward stopping a war.
