The Soviet Union is Iraq's major supplier of weapons. The official Soviet news agency Tass announced the Soviet decision to suspend arms sales to Iraq, whose million-man army overran Kuwait, which has a force estimated at 20,000. Almost all of Iraq's 5,500 tanks, most of its 500 warplanes, most missiles, and much of its artillery are Soviet, said Hans Binnerndijk of the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies. Iraq also has about 100 French Mirage jets, Binnendijk said. Soviet television showed Soviet warplanes _ apparently MiG-29s, MiG-25s and Sukhoi fighters _ flying over the desert city of Kuwait. It showed Soviet-built tanks driving across sand and Iraqi soldiers holding Soviet-designed Kalashnikov automatic rifles. The film clip also showed blurred shots of damaged buildings. The announcer did not say, however, if the film was shot Thursday. On Friday, Baker is expected to arrive in Moscow, where he will sign the joint statement with Shevardnadze, according to State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. Baker on Thursday arrived in the Mongolian capital, Ulan Bator, the last stop on a four-nation Asian tour. He traveled there from the Siberian city of Irkutsk, where Shevardnadze and Baker were meeting when they learned of the Iraqi attack. As he flew from Irkutsk to Mongolia Thursday afternoon, Baker told reporters he had asked Shevardnadze to halt ``any military or arms deliveries that they might have in the pipeline to Iraq.'' In Washington, President Bush immediately froze control of Iraqi assets in the United States and blocked almost all imports from the oil-rich Middle Eastern country. Baker had said Shevardnadze ``was not pleased to hear that Iraqi forces had moved into Kuwait.'' The Soviet Foreign Ministry in Moscow condemned the Iraqi attack and urged an immediate withdrawal of all Iraqi troops from Kuwait. Upon his return to Moscow, Shevardnadze told reporters every measure should be taken to extinguish the conflict, according to Tass. He said the Soviet Union would take all possible measures. Less than five hours later, Tass announced the suspension of arms sales. Shevardnadze contacted Baker through the Soviet ambassador in the Mongolian capital. Baker spoke by telephone with President Bush, and the two decided Baker would fly to Moscow, Mrs. Tutwiler said. The Soviet Union temporarily suspended its sales of arms to Iraq after the Iran-Iraq war broke out in 1980 and took a neutral position in the war. But Western intelligence sources said the Soviets later resumed the arms shipments. The Iraqis strapped boosters onto the short-range SCUD-B missiles bought from the Soviets, so they could use them to bomb Tehran, the Iranian capital. Iraq makes its own Soviet T-72 tanks under license. Last year, it was reported negotiatin aid in establishing its own facility for building warplanes, including the Soviet MiG-29. The Soviet Union sold Iraq $23.47 billion in weapons between 1982 and 1989, according to a publication of the U.S. Congressional Research Service. That is about 55 percent of the total arms purchased by Iraq in that period, said the book, called ``Trends in Conventional Arms Transfers to the Third World by Major Supplier, 1982-89.'' Iraq imported nearly $2 billion in arms last year and the Soviets were their major supplier, the book said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Going to Moscow to Issue Joint Soviet-U.S. Statement on Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with Baker flying to Moscow; Pickup 3rd pvs, `Although it...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XULA8,1
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Thursday toasted the recent democratic reforms in this long-time Soviet client state in the first visit of a top American official since 1944. But Baker announced he would cut short his visit by two days and on Friday fly to Moscow, where he and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze will issue a joint statement condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Baker had planned to take a private hunting and fishing trip in the Gobi Desert. ``Although it really breaks my heart to say this I think I should return home but maybe this will give me an excuse to return (to Mongolia),'' he said at a Mongolian government banquet. Baker said he made his decision after conferring with President Bush. The banquet began an hour late, apparently because of the lengthy phone call. During a short speech at the banquet, Baker praised Mongolia's recent democratic reforms, which include free-market reforms and multiparty elections. ``Your government and your people are moving forward together toward a common goal of greater democracy, greater protection of human rights and economic reform,'' he said. ``You have joined many countries around the world on the road to reform.'' After arriving Thursday, Baker signed an agreement to send Peace Corps volunteers to teach English, along with accords on trade and consular services. He also attended a festival of Mongolian culture, and watched Mongolian wrestling, horse races and an archery competition. He shot three arrows himself; two came close to the target and one fell far short. ``I couldn't even pull it back,'' he joked, pointing to the bow. Baker, on a four-nation Asian tour, arrived from Irkutsk in the Soviet Union, where he and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze discussed a third U.S.-Soviet summit, arms control and the civil war in Afghanistan. At a joint news conference, Shevardnadze said the Soviet Union would cease production of its rail-based mobile intercontinental ballistic missile, the SS-24. The United States does not deploy such missiles and their presence in the Soviet arsenal has been an impediment to U.S.-Soviet strategic arms talks. In Ulan Bator, Baker held successive meetings with President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat, Prime Minister Sharavyn Gunjaadorg and Communist Party Chairman Gombojavyn Ochirbat. The two Ochirbats are unrelated. ``We are very heartened by the peaceful emergence of democracy in Mongolia,'' he said before talks with the president. ``We have expressed our desire to continue to support political and economic reforms in Mongolia.'' Mongolia held its first multiparty elections ever on Sunday. The Communists agreed to give the opposition a role in the Cabinet after it won a significant presence in the legislature. Baker also planned to meet with opposition leaders. Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon and Mongolia's deputy foreign minister, Olzvoi, initialed a trade agreement with an ``understanding in principle'' to exchange most-favored nation trade status, a State Department news release said. The agreement will not be signed until after further talks. The Mongolians are eager to obtain the trade status. They also want U.S. investment and loans to help develop their stagnant economy as they embark on a program of free-market reforms. Baker is the first high-level administration figure to visit Mongolia since 1944, when Vice President Henry Wallace came on his way from China to Irkutsk. At the time, the United States and Soviet Union were World War II allies. The onset of the Cold War, however, halted most U.S.-Mongolian contacts. Diplomatic relations were established only in 1987. ``For too long, Americans and Mongolians have been strangers,'' Baker said at the banquet. ``Now, we have the opportunity to become friends.'' The Mongolian-Soviet alliance began in 1921, when the Soviet Red Army helped a small band of Mongolian revolutionaries oust their Chinese overlords. Since then, Moscow has stationed troops in Mongolia and been its chief source of economic aid. Moscow plans to withdraw all its troops by 1992 and is reducing aid and investment. Mongolian officials say they want better relations with the United States and other Western countries.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Killed in Crash of Plane En Route to Nagorno-Karabakh
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with all killed; CORRECTS location of wreckage, spelling of Stepanakert; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: All 30 people were killed when a small Soviet airliner crashed while bound for the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, searchers told the Soviet news agency Tass on Thursday. The wreckage of the Aeroflot Yakovlev-40 was found Thursday morning in the Lachin district of Azerbaijan, Tass said. The aircraft had been flying from the Armenian capital of Yerevan to Stepanakert. The city of Stepanakert is capital of the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. No official cause has been given for the crash. But the plane disappeared while flying in heavy fog over the mountainous region. Nagorno-Karabakh is a mostly Armenian enclave inside the republic of Azerbaijan. It has been the focus of a bitter ethnic dispute that has left hundreds dead over the past two years. Poor weather and rough terrain hampered the search for the aircraft, which had been carrying 26 passengers and four crew members, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Resolution Demands Iraqi Troop Withdrawal, Calls For Talks
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The following is the official English version of the Security Council resolution adopted Thursday on the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait: The Security Council, Alarmed by the invasion of Kuwait on 2 August by the military force of Iraq, Determining that there exists a breach of international peace and security as regards the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Acting under Articles 39 and 40 of the Charter of the United Nations. 1. Condemns the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait; 2. Demands that Iraq withdraw immediately and unconditionally all its forces to the positions in which they were located on August 1, 1990; 3. Calls upon Iraq and Kuwait to begin immediately intensive negotiations for the resolution of their differences and supports all efforts in this regard, and especially those of the Arab League; 4. Decides to meet again as necessary to consider further steps to ensure compliance with this resolution.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Rival Rebel Factions Ready to Fight _ Each Other
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The following is based partly on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia, including Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

Rebels turned their backs on President Samuel Doe's troops on Thursday and prepared to fight each other, a source close to guerrilla leader Prince Johnson said. Diplomats said the rivalry between Johnson and his foe, Charles Taylor, could prolong this West African nation's 7-month-old civil war for weeks. Johnson's fighters withdrew Thursday from key positions they have occupied in central Monrovia. That leaves the capital open to renewed occupation by Doe's soldiers, who massacred up to 600 men, women and children Sunday in an attack on St. Peter's Lutheran Church. Those killed were among thousands of civilians who have sought sanctuary at churches and embassies from tribal reprisals by troops and rebels. Hundreds of civilians again started fleeing from the city Wednesday. Only a few fighters of Johnson's Independent Patriotic Front were visible in areas of downtown Monrovia, which they captured from Doe's troops earlier in the week. Gunfire broke out in parts of the city that were firmly under Johnson's control on Wednesday. A big fire occurred in eastern Monrovia, but it was unclear whether the blaze was touched off by the fighting. The fire raged out of control because there is no longer a fire brigade in the capital. Monrovia's 500,000 residents have been without running water, electricity and food supplies for nearly a month. An American who has lived in Liberia for years and claims to be close to Johnson said the rebel leader was turning his forces around to confront Taylor's troops, who were advancing from behind him. Like the other sources, the American spoke on condition of anonymity. Johnson broke with Taylor and his National Patriotic Front in February and accuses his rival of being a Libyan stooge and a communist. Johnson has said he does not share Taylor's aspirations to lead Liberia. Taylor appears to have the larger of the two rebel forces, but Johnson struck into the capital earlier in the bid to unseat Doe, who is holed up in his heavily fortified executive mansion. ``No faction has established clear superiority, and it's not at all clear that there will be an early end to the conflict,'' one diplomat said. In the fighting since rebels invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast last December, about 5,000 people have been killed, most of them civilians. The insurgents accuse Doe of corruption and human rights abuses. He has ruled this west African nation of more than 2 million people since taking power in a 1980 coup. Johnson told reporters on Wednesday that he would be prepared to discuss with Taylor a joint attack on Doe if both rebel forces were in a position to advance on the presidential mansion. But Taylor's troops remained blocked by government troops six miles from the city center. Johnson also said he would welcome a U.N. peacekeeping force in Liberia. ``We are not going to fight a neutral force,'' he said. ``We would lay down our arms and let the neutral people carry on their peacekeeping operation.'' He held his news conference at his headquarters on suburban Bushrod Island. The reporters' car came under fire on its way back from there, first from the rebels, then from government troops. Troops loyal to Doe kept control of the Defense Ministry in street-fighting Wednesday and of areas east of it leading to the executive mansion and Barclay Training Center. The Finance Ministry, the national bank and the telecommunications center on Wednesday were under control of rebels led by Johnson.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Says Justice Will Pursue All Allegations of S&L Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Thursday that the Justice Department will pursue all allegations of savings and loan fraud, but he declined to comment on a report that the FBI is seeking evidence of political influence-peddling in 1988 S&L bailout deals. The Los Angeles Times reported Thursday that the FBI was investigating allegations of political favoritism in selecting buyers for dozens of failed S&Ls in deals which involved billions of dollars in federal subsidies. While refusing to comment directly on that report, Thornburgh told the Senate Banking Committee, ``Any allegations of wrongdoing that relate to past or present conduct will be vigorously pursued.'' The newspaper, quoting ``knowledgeable sources,'' said that for at least a month the FBI has been conducting a major investigation in connection with the 1988 deals made by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which was dismantled by last year's S&L legislation. That legislation also required the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., to review the deals to see whether the government could save money by exercising contract options. L. William Seidman, FDIC chairman, told reporters after appearing before the Senate panel: `We look in every instance for any kind of illegal activity.'' The FDIC's report is due at the end of this month. The agency is estimating the transactions, including deals covering 87 failed Texas thrifts, will cost the government $52 billion over the next decade. Asked if the FDIC was cooperating with the FBI on the matter, Seidman said, ``I assume we are. I have not looked into it. ... I'm sure we are working with them on every case in which there is alleged illegality.'' The Times quoted an unidentified federal regulator who said an FBI agent had offered him immunity from prosecution in exchange for testimony on the deals. The regulator told the newspaper that some of the transactions went through after upper-level federal officials overruled lower-level officials who opposed the deals. Marvin Collins, U.S. attorney in Dallas, said in a telephone interview that he could not comment on specific investigations, but he said, ``We in the U.S. attorney's office in Dallas and in the Dallas Bank Fraud Task Force will follow evidence of criminal wrongdoing wherever it may lead.'' M. Danny Wall, who served as chairman of the bank board, said in a telephone interview that he had ``no indication whatsoever'' that the FBI was investigating the 1988 deals and said they were not politically influenced. ``I'm confident ... the senior people involved made the best decisions based on the information available,'' he said. The newspaper's sources would not identify which deals were under investigation by a special fraud task force headquartered in Dallas, but said not all of the deals were suspect. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, has been conducting an inquiry into one of the deals, the consolidation of 15 failed Texas thrifts into Bluebonnet Savings Bank in Dallas. Metzenbaum is asking whether GOP lobbyist Robert Thompson, an aide to President Bush when he was vice president, improperly exerted his influence in helping Arizona insurance executive James Fail acquire Bluebonnet. Separately, the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday unanimously adopted a motion to begin the process of enforcing its subpoena against Thompson, who failed to appear for a July 31 subcommittee session. The motion directs Thompson to appear at an Aug. 6 session or risk being held in contempt of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Indicts Congressman on Fraud, Tax Charges
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Floyd Flake was indicted Thursday on conspiracy and fraud charges alleging he embezzled thousands of dollars from his church and a related senior citizens' housing project. The indictment lists 17 counts against Flake, a 45-year-old ordained minister, and nine against his wife, Margarett, 42, for activities between 1983 and 1989. It alleged that Flake, a Democrat who represents New York's 6th Congressional District, illegally diverted a total of $141,700 from church and housing funds to his own use and failed to report it as taxable income. Flake denied the charges and a lawyer for Mrs. Flake said they added credence ``to the idea that even-handed treatment is not being accorded to minority politicians.'' Flake is pastor of the 156-year-old Allen African Methodist Church in Queens, which built the 300-unit Allen Senior Citizens Apartments in 1981 with a $10 million federal loan. The church operates the complex with a $100,000 monthly subsidy from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The indictment charged that between 1983 and 1987, the Flakes embezzled $75,000 from the complex. U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney said the money was siphoned off in $6,000 increments from quarterly HUD allocations of $9,000 set aside for transporting senior citizen residents of the center on local business. He said the actual transportation costs were only $3,000 a quarter. The indictment alleged that Flake took an additional $66,700 from a special church ``ministerial expense fund'' account for his own use between 1983 and 1988, again not reporting the money as taxable income. Maloney said the church's 6,000 parishoners apparently were unaware of the alleged theft because the special account was managed by the Flakes themselves. Flake's attorney, Gustave Newman, said the money was used for church purposes and the charges would not stand up in court. Newman also said the case would not affect Flake's plans to seek re-election to a third term in the House this year. Ted Wells, Mrs. Flake's lawyer, described his client as ``really only a secretary'' who signed tax forms and checks but had ``no substantive involvement'' in the operations. The charges included one count of conspiracy, two of fraud and six of tax evasion against each of the two defendants. In addition, Flake is charged with four counts of filing false tax returns and four of making false financial statements. If convicted on all 17 counts, Flake could be sentenced to a maximum of 87 years in prison and fined up to $3.95 million. His wife could face penalties of 55 years in prison and fines of up to $2.1 million. Wells accused Maloney of furthering what he said was a pattern of unfair prosecutions against minority politicians. ``This indictment is unfair treatment of a minority female and by treating her this way, you just add fuel to the fire that prosecutors are not handling these cases in an even-handed fashion,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Pioneer Embryo Screening for Test-Tube Births
DOC.TEXT: Women with family histories of serious genetic disorders now can have their embryos screened in the test-tube before they are implanted into the womb, a doctor said Thursday who pioneered the technique. Dr. Alan Handyside said the technique has been used only to determine gender but researchers at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School at Hammersmith Hospital hope the process can be refined to detect other genetic information. Handyside said the technique has produced its first children. He said he and his colleagues are screening women with a family history of so-called X-linked defects that strike only boys. In these cases, only female embryos are implanted into the mother. The new procedure builds on techniques developed for in-vitro fertilization and prenatal testing, Handyside said from the west London hospital. Like in-vitro fertilization, eggs removed from the mother are fertilized in a test tube where the embryos are allowed to grow for three days, Handyside said. ``You cannot implant an embryo beyond the third day so we begin work early in the third day when the embryo has multiplied to eight cells,'' Handyside said. He said there is a 12-hour window for completing the screening. A single cell removed from the microscopic eight-cell embryo is amplified and analyzed to determine whether it is male or female. The first children born after the screening process were twins, Natalie and Danielle Edwards. The girls, born two weeks ago, were five weeks premature but are healthy and growing, Handyside said. The mother, Debbie Edwards, approached the Hammersmith Hospital team after learning she carried the gene for adrenoleukodystrophy, a fatal disease similar to muscular dystrophy, Handyside said. Debbie's sister also carries the gene and has an 11-year-old boy who was stricken at eight and is now totally disabled. Six other couples have gone through the program and are expecting girls, Handyside said. The mothers carry the gene for any of 200 diseases, including hemophilia, Duchenne muscular dystrophy and adrenoleukodystrophy. All affect male children, Handyside said. Traditional prenatal screening takes cells from the placenta in the first 8-10 weeks of pregnancy, and if genetic defects are detected a women can opt for an abortion. Screening before an embryo is implanted reduces the risk of a woman becoming infertile after repeated abortions, Handyside said. In addition, for families that risk passing on serious genetic disease to males, the embryo procedure should be less emotionally trying than an abortion, said Dr. Kathleen Nolan, a pediatrician and ethicist at the Hastings Center in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y Since no one had removed a single cell from a 3-day-old embryo before, Handyside said there were initial concerns. ``We had no direct evidence, but every animal and mammal we looked at was able to regulate for removal of cells at early stages,'' the embryologist said. Handyside said the embryo has a natural defense mechanism that allows growth to continue normally. ``It appears to be a response to damage which could happen in the reproductive tract,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of remarks by President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as they met with reporters on Thursday. The first set of remarks came during a photo opportunity; the second set was from a news conference held later. Q: Have you ruled out military intervention in the Gulf, Mr. President? BUSH: No, Terry, listen. Here's the ground rules. We're going to have a press scrum-availability afterward with the Prime Minister and be glad to respond to questions. This is what they call a photo opportunity, and no questions will be entertained. Q: But there's a deadline every minute, sir. Q: For the sake of those British television stations who are running out of time, Mr. President, could we just have one word? BUSH: Not now, but we'll be glad to stay by the ground rules here. MRS. THATCHER: It won't be long. BUSH: It wouldn't be fair to those who aren't here yet for the press availability. Q: Have you frozen Iraqi assets, Mrs. Thatcher? BUSH: He's having trouble hearing. Q: Were you able to make contact, sir, with any Middle Eastern leaders as you indicated you wanted to? Can you tell us if you spoke to _ BUSH: I'm not going to take any questions. It's not _ it really isn't fair, Charles, to those who have been told that the press conference will be in an hour and some minutes. o, really, we have to abide by that. But it's been very interesting, very active. STAFF: Thank you all. Q: We haven't had a chance, Mr. President, to hear what Mrs. Thatcher has said at all. BUSH: Well _ MRS. THATCHER: Don't worry. You'll hear later. Q: It will be too late for us, I fear. (Referring again to British television deadline.)

BUSH: Well, let me first welcome Prime Minister Thatcher back to the United States. It's a very timely visit. And, as you can well imagine, (Audio break.) Not surprisingly, I find myself very much in accord with the views of the Prime Minister. I reported to her on contacts that I've had since I left Washington, personal contacts with King Hussein, Mr. Mubarak of Egypt _ President Mubarak, President Salih of Yemen _ a long conversation just now. I can tell you that Jim Baker has been in close touch with the Soviet leadership and indeed, the last plan was for him to stop in Moscow on his way back here. We are concerned about the situation, but I find that Prime Minister Thatcher and I are looking at it on exactly the same wavelength _ concerned about this naked aggression, condemning it and hoping that a peaceful solution will be found that will result in the restoration of the Kuwaiti leaders to their rightful place and prior to that, a withdrawal of Iraqi forces. Prime Minister, welcome to Colorado and to the United States. And, if you care to say a word on that, then we can take the questions. MRS. THATCHER: Thank you, Mr. President, and thank you for the welcome. We have, of course, been discussing the main question, as the President indicated. Iraq has violated and taken over the territory of a country which is a full member of the United Nations. That is totally unacceptable and if it were allowed to endure, then there would be many other small countries that could never feel safe. The Security Council acted swiftly last night under United States leadership, well supported by the votes of 14 members of the Security Council, and rightly demanded the withdrawal of Iraqi troops. If that withdrawal is not swiftly forthcoming, we have to consider the next step. The next step would be further consideration by the Security Council of possible measures under Chapter 7. The fundamental question is this: whether the nations of the world have the collective will effectively to see that Security Council resolution is upheld; whether they have the collective will effectively to do anything which the Security Council further agrees to see that Iraq withdraws and that the government of Kuwait is restored to Kuwait. None of us can do it separately. We need a collective and effective will of the nations belonging to the United Nations. First the Security Council, and then the support of all the others to make it effective. Q: Mr. President, when Kuwaiti shipping was in danger in the Gulf War, you put those ships under American flag. Now Kuwait itself has been invaded. The Kuwaiti ambassador says that they're desperate for help and that American intervention is of paramount importance. Will you answer that call, and how will you? BUSH: I answer that we're considering what the next steps by the United States should be, just as we strongly support what Prime Minister Thatcher said about collective action in the United Nations. Q: Are you still not contemplating military intervention? BUSH: No. I mentioned at the time we were going to discuss different options, which I did after that first press conference this morning, and we're not ruling any options in but we're not ruling any options out. And so that is about where we are right now. We had thorough briefings _ you know who was at the meeting today _ by General Powell, General Schwarzkopf and others. But I think it would be inappropriate to discuss options.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: ASPEN: contacted Israel?
DOC.TEXT: BUSH: There was _ we've had contact with Israel, yes. I have not personally, but we have. And they asked for restraint; they asked for a short period of time in which to have this Arab solution evolve and be placed into effect. And they are concerned, obviously, with this naked aggression. But it was more along that line, ``let us try now as neighbors and Arabs to resolve this.'' And I made clear to them that it had gone beyond simply a regional dispute because of the naked aggression that violates the United Nations Charter. Q: And what did Israel say it would do at this point? BUSH: I would have to think back to the details of it, but offering cooperation, I think, was about where we _ I would leave it there. Q: Mr. President, we're hearing reports now that some of the Americans, particularly in the oil fields, may have been rounded up by Iraqi troops. Do you have anything to that? How does that affect your reaction? BUSH: Well, I don't have anything on that right now. And secondly, it would affect the United States in a very dramatic way because I view a fundamental responsibility of my presidency as protecting American citizens. And if they're threatened or harmed or put into harms way, I have certain responsibilities. But, I hadn't heard that, Charles. And I hope that that is not correct. Q: May I also ask about British citizens, any word, are they safe? MRS. THATCHER: We have some British citizens in Kuwait. And you probably know that there was a British Airways flight there on its way to Africa and the passengers there are now in a hotel in Kuwait. So, we have some there and, of course, we have both _ we have some _ a number of other British citizens in Kuwait, and we, too, are concerned for their safety. Q: Mr. President, some of the smaller nations in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain, the Emirates, and the others, obviously have a reason to worry about what has happened here. What can the United States and Great Britain say to those countries and those people who are feeling very concerned today? BUSH: Well, the United States can say that ``we are very much concerned for your safety.'' And this naked aggression would understandably shake them to the core. And so, what we are trying to do is to have collective action that will reverse this action out and to make very clear that we are totally in accord with their desire to see the Iraqis withdraw _ cease-fire, withdraw, and restitution of the Kuwaiti government _ and that would be the most reassuring thing of all for these countries who, whether it's true or not, feel threatened by this action. Q: At the risk of being a hypothetical, if Iraq does not move out quickly and has gained a foothold among the smaller Gulf nations, what can the United States and other nations do militarily? BUSH: We have many options, and it is too hypothetical indeed for me to comment on them. And I'd refer that to _ also to the Prime Minister. MRS. THATCHER: Well, that's precisely why you're looking at the next stage in the Security Council and what other measures can be put into action mandatorily and why _ the very nations to whom you refer _ we should also need their cooperation in putting other actions into effect. Q: Mr. President, have you dispatched the USS Independence to the region, and have you heard from Saudi Arabia? BUSH: Well, I would not discuss the movement of any US forces. And what was the second part of your question? Q: Have you heard from Saudi Arabia? King Fahd. BUSH: No, but I have a call to King Fahd and I was supposed to have taken that call before now, but it's been delayed by a few minutes. And so, I hope before I leave here I will talk to him. I think it is very important that I do talk to him. And I'd leave it there I think. Q: (Off mike) _ him to say? BUSH: Huh? Q: What do you expect him to say? BUSH: Well, that's too hypothetical, too. But I _ Q: Prime Minister? BUSH: I know he'll be expressing the same kind of concern that we feel. Q: Prime Minister, if I could, the President, in his executive order this morning, established a US embargo on trade with Iraq. When you mentioned Chapter 7 measures, would you support in the Security Council a call for an international embargo on Iraqi oil? MRS. THATCHER: We are prepared to support in the Security Council those measures which collectively we can agree to and which collectively we can make effective. Those are the two tests. We have already frozen all Kuwaiti assets. The Kuwaitis have very considerable assets, and it's important that those do not fall into Iraq hands. Iraq, we believe, has only very, very small assets and rather a lot of debt, so the position is rather different with her. Right. BUSH: Thank you all very much. Q: Do you believe an oil embargo could be made effective? (No response to above question.)
DOC.HEAD: END OF BUSH-THATCHER TEXT, 3 TAKES
DOT Judge Recommends Japanese Air Routes For Six U.S. Airlines
DOC.TEXT: An administrative law judge recommended Thursday that five U.S. airlines be awarded direct routes to Japan from six U.S. cities. The judge picked United, Delta, American, Continental and America West airlines to fly the new routes in what is already a $6 billion annual aviation market for the two countries. Cities getting new flights would be Chicago; Los Angeles and San Jose, Calif.; Portland, Ore.; Seattle, and Honolulu. The complex, 90-page recommendation followed applications by a dozen carriers to serve various U.S.-Japan routes under a new international air agreement. A final decision on the carriers and routes is expected in November by Transportation Department officials. Judge John J. Mathias selected United Air Lines for Chicago-Tokyo, describing United as ``the number one carrier in the Pacific'' and the carrier that ``can be expected to enhance the overall structure and level of competition in these international markets.'' Mathias proposed that two routes be awarded to Delta Air Lines: Los Angeles-Tokyo and Portland, Ore.-Nagoya. Other carriers and routes he recommended were American Airlines for San Jose-Tokyo, Continental Airlines for Seattle-Nagoya, and America West Airlines for Honolulu-Nagoya. If approved, it would be the first Japanese route for America West. Mathias said his recommendations followed department guidelines for awarding the routes and would enhance competition among both airlines and cities to be served. ``It is essential that the department see to it that U.S. flag competition is maintained and enhanced by these awards,'' he said. All of the awards would give the airlines authority to fly passengers, property and mail for five years. Mathias made the decision after hearing arguments from several air carriers and officials of competing cities and airport authorities. The airlines that sought routes but got none were Hawaiian, Northwest, Pan American, and Trans World. Mathias also rejected applications that would have added direct flights between Japan and St. Louis, Houston, and the Hawaiian island of Maui. The new service could add more than 40 round-trip flights a week between the two countries, with no carrier allowed to fly more than seven flights a week on any route. U.S. carriers now operate 156 weekly flights to and from Japan. Three Japanese carriers are to get a dozen more weekly round trips between Tokyo and Washington, Chicago, Newark and Honolulu, along with 21 other flights connecting U.S. cities to Japanese cities other than Tokyo or Osaka. Those routes were part of the international air agreement between the United States and Japan, and the specific carriers will be decided by Japanese authorities. Mathias said 19 carriers now serve U.S.-Japan routes, including five U.S. flag carriers and 14 foreign airlines flying 269 weekly nonstop routes to 12 U.S. cities.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Farmers Will Have To Idle More Acreage in 1991 To Get Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: Wheat farmers will have to idle more of their base acreage next year to qualify for federal price supports and subsidies on their crop, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced Thursday. Tentatively, he said, the 1991 acreage reduction program for wheat, or ARP, probably will be in the range of 10 percent to 20 percent. Farmers were required to set aside only 5 percent of their acreage base this year. Yeutter said he could not make a final determination until Congress completes work on the 1990 farm bill and it is accepted by the administration. Both the House and Senate have passed versions of the bill. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., and others had pressured Yeutter to make a preliminary announcement of the 1991 wheat program in time for winter wheat planting this fall. In a letter to Dole, Yeutter emphasized the announcement was tentative and that it could change because of final provisions approved in the 1990 farm bill. Yeutter also pledged that the Agriculture Department would continue to use export subsidies under the Export Enhancement Program, or EEP, ``to keep wheat competitive in world markets.'' Under EEP, exporters are given surplus government-owned commodities as subsidies, or bonuses, so they can reduce prices paid by selected foreign buyers. Wheat has been the biggest beneficiary of the EEP subsidies. The program was started in 1985 to help meet export competition by foreign shippers, notably the European Economic Community. Yeutter said EEP currently is available to 41 countries. He said these initiatives ``can be utilized at any time to compete head-to-head'' with the Europeans.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Intentions Were Clear; The Timing Wasn't
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration kept close track of Iraq's intentions in recent days through intelligence and diplomatic contacts, but the timing of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait appears to have caught many officials by surprise. President Bush said Thursday he had not been taken totally by off guard Wednesday night when Iraqi tanks rolled across the border to Kuwait. ``We had good intelligence and our intelligence has had me concerned for some time now,'' he said. In an unusual step, the CIA too denied being caught unawares. ``We provided policymakers with very useful and timely information on these events. There were no surprises,'' CIA spokesman Mark Mansfield said in a statement. An administration official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said, ``This whole thing didn't come totally as a surprise. The exact moment that they moved did, but it was certainly obvious what they were preparing to do.'' Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, confirmed that U.S. intelligence on Iraq's troop buildup in recent weeks along the Kuwaiti border has been good. But speaking to reporters after closed-door briefings from Pentagon officials, Boren also said many in the administration and Congress had ``engaged in wishful thinking'' when they believed that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's only aim was to force Kuwait to lower its oil production and thereby move oil prices upward. U.S. perceptions of Iraq's benign intent were further bolstered by assurances from Arab allies such as Egypt and Saudi Arabia, said an administration official speaking on condition of anonymity. Iraq, too, apparently assured the United States of its peaceful intentions when Saddam met last week in Baghdad with U.S. ambassador April Glaspie. U.S. officials passed on the Iraqi assurances to Kuwait, said Kuwaiti Ambassador Saud Nasir al-Sabah. Glaspie, apparently convinced that all was well, then left Iraq on a long-planned vacation, said the official. Despite warnings from the CIA that Iraq would invade, U.S. officials appeared to have realized Iraq's actual intention only shortly before the actual invasion began in the pre-dawn hours. Word of the invasion reached Washington at 8:30 p.m., sending officials scurrying from their homes back to their offices at the State Department and National Security Council.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Group Sees `Dogmatic Approach' by Souter
DOC.TEXT: An abortion rights group said Thursday that the judicial approach of Supreme Court nominee David Souter in a New Hampshire case may signal his opposition to abortion rights. Souter, nominated by President Bush last week to succeed retiring Justice William Brennan, has not ruled directly on the abortion issue. His views on that and other controversial Supreme Court issues are sure to come up in Senate confirmation hearings beginning Sept. 13. The National Abortion Rights Action League said Thursday a dissent by Souter while he was on the New Hampshire Supreme Court reveals a ``dogmatic approach'' in his philosophy that the Senate Judiciary Committee should question. Thomas Jipping, legal analyst for the conservative Coalitions for America, said NARAL was ``grasping at straws'' and the case simply shows Souter to be a careful jurist. In 1986, the majority of the state's high court ruled in a case called In re Estate of Dionne that it was against the state's constitution for judges to charge fees for special court sessions. Souter was the lone dissenter. The 1784 state constitution's guarantee of the right ``to obtain justice freely, without being obliged to purchase it,'' had to be seen in the context of its time, referring to bribery and other special favors, and did not apply to modern-day fees, Souter wrote. NARAL's attorneys, in a memo distributed to reporters, said Thursday that Souter's ``dogmatic approach to original intent in Dionne is cause for alarm.'' If applied on the Supreme Court, such logic would go against not only the court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade abortion rights decision but also its landmark school desegregation decision of 1954, NARAL said. Patrick McGuigan, spokesman for Coalitions for America, said it was wrong to compare the a judge's application of state law to the Supreme Court's interpretation of the Constitution. Abortion rights advocates were less concerned with judicial philosophy than with their cause, he said. ``Will this guy vote for our agenda? That's what they're asking,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Fails at Emergency Meeting to Condemn Iraq's Invasion
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An emergency Arab League Council failed to publicly condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Thursday and adjourned its meeting for 24 hours as Arab leaders held urgent consultations on how to handle the crisis. Kuwait's Cabinet affairs minister, Abdel-Rahman el-Awadi told reporters he asked the 21-nation Arab League to condemn the attack. He accused Iraq of using the ``laws of the jungle.'' President Hosni Mubarak and Jordan's King Hussein met in Alexandria and telephoned Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, President Bush, Saudi King Fahd and Yemeni President Ali Abdallah Saleh on the crisis. Hussein later left for home. Sources close to the Arab League Council said its members agreed to convene an emergency Arab summit but decided to leave the when and where up to Arab leaders. The sources spoke on condition of anonymity. The Council meeting of foreign ministers was convened in Cairo at Kuwaiti request hours after Iraqi military forces took over the small Persian Gulf state. Some member nations sent lower-level representatives. Following its evening session, attended by Saadoon Hamadi, a member of the Iraqi Revolutionary Council, Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid of Egypt told reporters the Council would meet again Friday. Saddam promised Mubarak two weeks ago that he would not invade Kuwait in their oil dispute. At Thursday's closed session, Hamadi reiterated Iraq's claim its forces entered Kuwait at the request of a Kuwaiti revolutionary group that had overthrown the government. A conference source said several Arab foreign ministers replied that ``they considered this to be an Iraqi invasion which is against all United Nations and Arab League conventions.'' So far, only Lebanon's prime minister and foreign minister, Salim Hoss, has joined Kuwait in Cairo in publicly condemning the invasion _ the first time in modern history one Arab country invaded another to take control of the government. Hoss told reporters, ``We do not see any justification for what happened, whatever the arguments and pretexts.'' The invasion was denounced by the United States and other Western nations and by the Soviet Union. The Arab League Council met early Thursday and then adjourned to await the arrival of Hamdoon. Iraq's ambassador to Egypt, Nabil Najm, sat in until Hamdoon arrived. ``The United Nation's Security Council has condemned the invasion and the issue is now being discussed within the framework of the Arab League and we hope that it will issue a condemnation within the hour and that Arabs stand against this invasion,'' Kuwait's Awadi said. ``Arab leaders must take the initiative and stop this bloodshed and return things to their normal situation. We also call on Iraq to withdraw its troops.'' Hamadi told reporters upon arrival, ``I see this meeting as unnecessary ... There is no government presently in Kuwait. There is a group which started the revolution and which will reveal itself shortly.'' His comments were carried by the Middle East News Agency. MENA said Kuwait invoked the 1950 Arab joint defense pact and asked the Arab League Council to dispatch a joint Arab force to ``defend Kuwait against the invasion.'' In the event of military aggression against any League member, the pact all members, to ``take, individually and collectively, all steps available, including the use of armed force, to repel the aggression and restore security and peace.'' The ministers were in Cairo to attend the Organization of Islamic Conference's foreign ministers meeting. All Arab League members also belong to the Islamic conference.

DOC.HEAD: The Rhetoric Flows In Closing Arguments of Mayor's Drug Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs Barry comment at end
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As a government prosecutor reeled off Marion Barry's alleged sins to the jury for the last time, the mayor stared sadly into space. ``He smoked and snorted his way through 1987 and 1988.... He smoked and snorted his way right into 1989,'' said the prosecutor, Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts. ``It's almost as if Mr. Barry wanted to get caught.'' His blunt assessment came in the final moments of Barry's six-week drug and perjury trial. But if the government had the last words, Barry's defense lawyer had some of the most colorful. The government's witnesses were ``little Lucifers and small Satans,'' all of them survivors looking out for No. 1, attorney R. Kenneth Mundy said in his closing arguments. One of them came ``out of a crevice,'' he said. Another was ``down, destitute and desperate.'' A third, who had fled Iran, believed he would be killed if he returned. ``He was going to avoid going back to Iran no matter what the cost,'' Mundy said. Mundy reserved his most caustic descriptions for convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, a linchpin in the government's case. An artful dodger, Mundy said. The eternal salesperson selling himself to the jury. A loose cannon. The memory of an elephant _ after more than 100 hours of preparatory meetings with prosecutors. The Barry trial attracted all manner of spectators, from anonymous law students to the city's famous and flamboyant. It also inflamed racial tensions and sensitivities, even to the point where Barry's press secretary accused courtroom artists of making Roberts, a light-skinned black, look too dark. Barry and his wife, Effi, chatted and laughed Thursday during a brief break. But Mrs. Barry, sitting next to Barry's mother, sat through most of the closing arguments looking grim. On Wednesday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin had twice belittled Barry by comparing him to a child. She had apologized to the jury for the sexual nature of some of the testimony, saying it was impossible to separate the sex and drugs in Barry's life. Then came Mundy, who amidst his skewering of the government's witnesses and tactics painted an unflattering picture of his own client as a philanderer and occasional drug user. Mundy tried to justify some of Barry's behavior, such as his repeated public denials of drug use and strong support for anti-drug campaigns. He wanted to keep others from falling through the ice along with him, Mundy said. ``What else was he to do as mayor?'' Mundy asked. ``Was he to go out and say it's OK to use drugs? I use drugs?'' He was trying, ``in his own frailty,'' to say it's wrong, the defense lawyer said. But the prosecution team had other explanations _ among them hypocrisy, paranoia, compulsion and a habit of blaming others for what was his fault. ``Marion Barry was out to get himself,'' said Roberts. ``He must rise up to his responsibility and accept responsibility for his conduct.'' Barry strode out of the courthouse at the end of the day wearing a purple boutonniere, telling reporters that ``purple is for the power of God.... He gives us the strength to overcome the maliciousness of the U.S. government. We're up against Goliath.'' Barry said he had been free of chemical dependencies for 194 days. ``I've admitted my own problems,'' he said. ``There's no shame in having a problem. The shame is in not getting help.'' Later, he added, ``No one can suffer any more pain or shame or hurt than me.''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Suspends All Programs Involving Iraq
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department said Thursday it has suspended all programs involving business with Iraq, including credit arrangements and export subsidy benefits. Officials said the action followed through on President Bush's order earlier in the day which imposed a virtual trade embargo in retaliation for Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Iraq has been a large buyer of U.S. farm commodities, including wheat, barley, cattle, poultry and eggs at subsidized prices. Credit programs also have been used by Iraq to buy U.S. products, which also have included rice and sugar. In all, farm exports to Iraq have been running at about $700 million a year, according to USDA records. R.E. Anderson Jr., administrator of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the suspension of programs used by Iraq will be in effect ``until further notice.'' Additionally, he said, the department will not approve applications and issue credit guarantees for any sale of agricultural commodities for Iraq which were not exported prior to Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Committee Wants Trump To Testify on How He Got Bank Loans
DOC.TEXT: The House Banking Committee wants New York real estate developer Donald Trump to explain how he managed to persuade major banks to loan him $2 billion that he is now struggling to repay. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the panel, has twice invited Trump to an Aug. 9 committee session. So far, Trump hasn't replied. At a time when soured real estate loans are cutting into many banks' profits, the committee wants to look into ``commercial real estate lending principles ... in general and more specifically the banks' handling of the Trump organization loans,'' Gonzalez said in a letter to Trump. Gonzalez, in a notice to committee members Thursday, said the Trump loans illustrate the problems banks are having in some areas of the country. Representatives of state and federal regulatory agencies have said they will appear, as have three banking analysts. However, representatives of Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and other banks who lent to Trump haven't replied to the panel's invitations.

DOC.HEAD: Lots of Sunshine From Coast to Coast; Record Heat In Florida
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms were scattered from Texas to the south Atlantic Coast on Thursday, but most of the nation basked under sunny and partly sunny skies. Record heat continued across Florida, shattering records and straining electrical utilities' ability to serve residents who cranked up air conditioners. Daytona Beach sweltered in 97-degree heat, beating its 47-year-old record for Aug. 2 by 1 degree. Miami recorded its 13th consecutive 90-degree day Thursday, a stretch that included tying the city's all-time high of 98 degrees on Wednesday. Scattered showers and thunderstorms fell from south-central Texas through the lower Mississippi Valley to the southern Atlantic Coast states, with showers most numerous in the valley and on the Gulf Coast. A few showers and thunderstorms stretched from southwestern Nebraska to northern Iowa and southern Minnesota. Strong thunderstorms developed in Nebraska. A few showers and thunderstorms also fell over north-central Wyoming and southwest Texas. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included 1.12 inch at El Dorado, Ark. Brisk southerly winds blew over sections of the southern and central Plains, and there were strong northwesterlies over New England. Lows of 57 degrees at Roanoke, Va., and 55 degrees at Charleston, W.Va., were records for the date. The coldest spot in the Lower 48 states was West Yellowstone, Mont., where the low was 41 degrees.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti `Free Government' Statements Indicate Iraqi Control
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq says it invaded Kuwait at the request of a revolutionary organization there, but diplomats dismiss that rationale as a large-scale charade. The diplomatic world has remained largely unconviced by the flood of statements issued from Iraq in the name of the Provisional Free Kuwait Government. Britain's U.N. ambassador, Crispin Tickell, called the Iraqi action ``an invasion from the outside ... a phony coup d'etat from within.'' He said the invasion had led to ``the purported establishment of a puppet government.'' In a rare display of solidarity, the United States and the Soviet Union called for Iraq to withdraw and imposed sanctions. The U.N. Security Council voted 14-0 to condemn the invasion. But Iraq's deputy permanent U.N. representative, Sabah Talat Kadrat, said the Security Council should not be debating the issue, because the fall of the Kuwaiti Emir, Sheik Jaber Al-Ahmed Al-Sabah, was an internal matter. The official Kuwait News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, did not issue a single story all day. Its computer periodically sputtered out the phrase ``Line cut.'' On the other hand, state-run Iraqi News Agency from Baghdad came alive with a series of communiques from the ``provisional government.'' The members were not identified. The first statement said the provisional government ``finds that one of its primordial obligations is to remedy the harm done by the deposed, corrupt government to our brothers in Iraq.'' Iraq has been feuding with Kuwait over a border dispute. It has also accused Kuwait of violating its oil production quotas set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, costing Iraq of much-needed revenues because oil is cheaper when supplies are higher. The statement on the Iraqi News Agency said the border dispute would be settled with ``fraternity and Arab national interests,'' indicating Iraq would probably take the land it wants. The statement also said the Al-Sabah family, which had ruled Kuwait for almost 250 years, was working in concert with Zionist and colonial powers to plot against Iraq. That is the charge the Iraqi press leveled at Kuwait when tensions began to rise in mid-July. ``Falsification of elections, authoritarianism, persecution of patriotic personalities have always been characteristics of the Al-Sabah family,'' the statement said. Kuwait is one of the few Arab states that has experimented with a freely elected parliament. A new National Council with 50 members voted into office and 25 appointed by the emir took office after June elections. The communiques from the Iraqi News Agency said the National Council has been disbanded.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Allow Stricter Abortion Clinic Regulations
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge rejected a state attempt to implement tougher rules at Florida's abortion clinics, saying current regulations sufficiently protect women's health. The ruling by U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez of Fort Lauderdale on Wednesday marks another setback on the abortion issue for Gov. Bob Martinez. The Republican governor failed in October to persuade legislators to pass bills limiting access to abortions in the nation's first test of last summer's U.S. Supreme Court ruling in Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services. Last fall, the state Supreme Court also threw out a parental-consent law supported by the governor. ``What I think this means is that nothing will be changed, ever,'' said Charlene Carres, a lawyer with the Florida chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union who argued against any new rules. State attorneys contended that the Webster ruling, which stemmed from a Missouri case and granted states broader powers to regulate abortion, gave Florida's Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services more authority over the clinics. Assistant Attorney General Jim Peters argued at a hearing last month that an abortion clinic crackdown was warranted because of ``intolerable conditions'' found at south Florida clinics last fall after The Miami Herald published a report detailing bloodstained wrappings and leaking oxygen tanks at a clinic. But Gonzalez rejected that argument in his four-page order. ``Contrary to popular opinion, Webster does not constitute a significant modification in decisional law, nor would it justify or permit any change in the prior judgment of this court,'' the judge wrote. Robyn Blumner, executive director of the Florida ACLU, said the organization was pleased with the decision. ``What the judge said was that Roe vs. Wade is not dead,'' she said. Gonzalez ruled in 1982 that, under the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision guaranteeing a right to abortion, the Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services could only check licenses, records and disposal of fetal remains and make certain that only physicians are performing abortions. The agency could not inspect staff, equipment or medical care standards. It wanted 22 tougher rules, including being able to conduct unscheduled inspections, expand licensing procedures and set a number of standards for sanitation, medical care and infection control. ``It would certainly be disappointing that the judge wouldn't let the state do more to protect the health and safety of women,'' said Martinez's press secretary, Jon Peck. ``It's certainly in the public's interest to make sure there is quality medical care at all of these facilities.''

DOC.HEAD: PR Man's Nightmare: Selling Iraq's Version
DOC.TEXT: An article in the August issue of the glossy Washington society magazine Dossier profiling the capital's ambassadors wound up its column on Iraq's Mohamed Sadiq Al-Mashat with the note that Congress had been considering sanctions against Iraq. It concluded: ``Amid all this, Iraq's man in Washington says his priority is reversing a tide of unflattering press reports about his country.''

DOC.HEAD: New President Fails to Quell Bulgarian Turmoil
DOC.TEXT: The country's new non-Communist president pledged to work for more democracy, but protesters in the capital Thursday kept up their pressure on the governing Socialist Party. The Socialists were also reportedly plagued by defections. In some cases, entire local leaderships quit the party. Zhelyu Zhelev was elected Wednesday as the country's first non-Communist president in more than four decades. His supporters picked him as a compromise candidate in an effort to overcome growing political polarization as Bulgaria introduces greater democracy. ``It will be my basic endeavor ... to strengthen parliamentary democracy; to adopt, in the shortest possible time, a democratic constitution; and to implement the most important political and economic reforms,'' Zhelev said in an interview published in the daily Demokratsiya. The newspaper is put out by Zhelev's opposition party, the Union of Democratic Forces. Asked about the most urgent tasks in coming weeks, Zhelev said, ``First there must be active consultations between the key political forces toward creation of a strong, competent government.'' The makeup of the new government was still not clear, but Zhelev's words suggested it may have the backing of the opposition. A statement Wednesday by the Socialist Party called on all members to support ``the inevitable and necessary political compromises that are being reached by the party.'' However, anti-government protesters vowed at a jubilant rally of 15,000 Thursday night to continue their push for more democracy, despite the new president. The protesters, who have been camped outside Socialist party headquarters for almost a month, said the Socialists could pass key measures with their parliamentary majority. They demanded investigation of the party's property and an independent review of the June elections won by the Socialists. ``The supreme aim of our movement is to unite all the layers of society that want to struggle against the totalitarian system, against the gloomy presence that has blocked the ways of real democracy,'' protest leader Kolya Fevov told the rally. Bulgaria began its march toward democracy with popular demonstrations last year. In November, party members ousted longtime Communist leader Todor Zhivkov. They later changed their name to the Socialist Party. The election of the new president Wednesday appeared to have caused serious discord in their ranks. Entire local party organizations and individuals sent telegrams to the Socialist leadership in Sofia announcing they quit the party, sources close to the party said. The extent of defections was not clear in the absence of official word. More than half the 211 Socialist deputies voted against Zhelev. But the new president won 284 of the 389 votes cast.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Suspend Border Crackdown as Crowds of Stranded Travelers Grow
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government suspended its abrupt crackdown on visa-free travel along its western border Thursday after it stranded huge crowds of travelers. The Soviet television news announced the halt in visa-free travel for Soviet citizens was being postponed. It will now take effect Aug. 10. Officials said they were cracking down because store shelves near the borders were being stripped by travelers seeking bargains. Under the visa-free rule, Soviets long barred from foreign travel have been pouring back and forth across the borders to Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary carrying only their internal passports with an extra page freely available from local police stations. Obtaining an external passport is still a lengthy task. Trade by individuals has exploded as Soviets and their neighbors discovered each of their countries has different shortages of consumer goods, and varying subsidized prices. Poles are eager to buy Soviet pots and pans, vodka, caviar, champagne, radios, TVs, gold jewelry and watches because they are far cheaper. Mushrooms, for example, cost 10 times as much in Poland as in the Soviet Union. On the Polish side, travelers buy jeans, cosmetics and Taiwanese and Turkish clothes, and sell them in the Soviet Union at inflated black market prices. The Polish PAP news agency said Soviets were waiting as much as 20 hours to pass through the border. At Ogrodniki, the crossing from northwest Poland into Lithuania, the wait was four hours on the Polish side and 15 hours on the Soviet side. A Polish newspaper reported that Soviet customs officials were slow and arrogant, opening car trunks and disappearing for hours.

DOC.HEAD: Rising Iraqi Oil Dominance Poses Risks For Oil-Importing Nations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3rd graf: ``The Energy,'' no threat seen; SUBS 10th graf, pvs 9th graf: ``President Bush,'' with two grafs explaining alternate sources; ADDS two grafs with administration comment on using emergency oil reserves
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi conquest of Kuwait has catapulted Iraq to the top ranks of world oil powers and poses new economic risks for the United States and other countries dependent on imported oil, private analysts said Thursday. It was unclear whether the Iraqi invasion of its tiny neighbor at the northern tip of the Persian Gulf would slow or halt Kuwait's oil production, but the conflict seemed to signal an important shift in the balance of world oil power. The Energy Department said it did not see an imminent threat to the United States or an immediate price runup, and said it had no planws to tap the nation's emergency oil stockpile. ``Iraq being the dominant military power in the area could end up controlling ... a quarter of world oil supplies,'' said Christopher Flavin, a vice president of the Worldwatch Institute. ``Just overnight it doubled its share.'' By grabbing control of Kuwait, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein added about 94 billion barrels of oil reserves to his country's own 100 billion barrels. That makes Iraq second only to Saudi Arabia in world ranking for oil reserves, according to the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade group. The Saudis, traditional close allies of Kuwait, have 255 billion barrels of oil reserves. The United States holds about 26 billion barrels of reserves. But U.S. oil production has declined rapidly over the past four years while consumption has increased. As a result, 50 percent of oil used in the United States is imported, and many experts say this reliance makes America vulnerable to manipulation of the oil market. The top 10 U.S. oil suppliers are Saudi Arabia, which provides 15 percent of imports; Venezuela, 13 percent; Nigeria, 12.5 percent; Canada, 12 percent; Iraq, 7.6 percent; Mexico, 6 percent; Virgin Islands, 3.6 percent; and Britain, Angola and Algeria a combined 9.7 percent. Kuwait supplies about 2 percent. Like Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates at the southern end of the gulf are vulnerable to Iraqi military might. The Emirates control about 100 billion barrels of oil reserves and were the recent target of Iraqi verbal assaults against excessive oil production by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. President Bush signed an order Thursday banning U.S. imports of Iraqi products, including oil, freezing control of Iraqi financial assets in the United States and forbidding exports to Iraq _ a complete trade embargo. Iraq's oil should be easily replaceable from other sources since one barrel of oil is pretty much equivalent to any other barrel, especially in a time of glutted oil markets like the present, analysts say. Iraq, by the same token, should be able to find other sources of wheat and rice it may no longer buy from the United States under Bush's order, unless other nations also ban exports to Iraq. Oil prices on the world market jumped sharply in reaction to the Iraqi invasion, but Flavin and other analysts said the more unsettling implication of Saddam's action is his expanded clout in the gulf and his influence over future supplies. The Saudis, the world's largest oil exporters and the No. 1 supplier to the United States, ``are sitting there quaking in their boots'' out of fear that Saddam might invade their kingdom or seek a voice in running their oil affairs, said Dillard Spriggs, president of New York-based Petroleum Analysis Ltd. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said the Iraqi army might not stop at Kuwait's borders. ``If Iraq succeeds, I believe that Saudi Arabia might be next _ and then Saddam Hussein would have a stranglehold on the West's oil supply,'' Bentsen said. Bush's chief economic adviser, Michael Boskin, told the congressional Joint Economic Committee that the U.S. economy was not threatened by the impact of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, even if it led to a 25 percent jump in oil prices. Boskin conceded that such a large rise in prices would cause some economic damage in the United States but said it would be more harmful to Japan because of its greater dependence on oil imports. Japan gets virtually all its oil from foreign sources. Also on Capitol Hill, the Senate extended by one month Bush's authority to tap into the 580-million barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve, an emergency oil storage system, in the event of a supply squeeze. The Senate action was not directly linked to the Iraqi invasion, but senators said the gulf crisis served to underscore the fragile nature of Middle East oil production and transportation. ``All of the OPEC countries _ at least all of those in the Middle East _ will be intimidated by Iraq,'' said Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. ``Iraq will be able to set such prices as it wants.'' Henson Moore, the deputy secretary of energy, told reporters at Energy Department headquarters that the administration was not considering tapping into the emergency reserve, which he said contains the equivalent of 75 days worth of oil consumption. ``We do not see ... any imminent threat to the United States'' by the loss of Iraqi oil, Moore said. ``Nor do we see any long-term significant increase in prices.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Says Spill `Could be Worse' as Cleanup Continues
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bill Clements declared the effects of a 500,000-gallon oil spill were ``greatly exaggerated'' as a health department ban against fishing the rich Galveston Bay went into effect Thursday. Clements, a former oil man, toured the bay by helicopter, and initially decided to cancel a plan to use oil-eating microbes on the slick. His announcement shocked state officials, and he later backed down and decided to allow limited application of the process called bioremediation. Meanwhile, salvage crews found about 20,000 gallons of oil in a tank aboard a ruptured barge nearly sunken in the Houston Ship Channel since the collision Saturday with a Greek tanker. The Coast Guard again shut down traffic in the channel to allow crews time to remove the fragile barge. Officials said earlier in the week the delays were costing ship owners at least $1.5 million per day. The Coast Guard took over cleanup efforts Thursday because Apex Towing Co., owner of the two barges damaged in the collision, was nearing its insurance liability limit. ``We call the shots now and we pay the bills,'' said Chief Warrant Officer Rick Meidt. The Coast Guard will bill Apex Towing Co. for the cleanup costs. After his tour Thursday, Clements said: ``I think that the so-called oil spill has been greatly exaggerated. We had difficulty finding any.'' Officials had gained federal approval to use bioremediation to help clear delicate marshlands of a filmy, black oil, but Clements said the oil had dispersed too much for the microbes to be effective in most areas. His statement seemed to contradict the judgment of the Texas Health Department, which the day before had ordered the bay closed to all fishing for fear of contamination from the oil. Texas General Land Commissioner Garry Mauro was outraged. ``We know that skimmers, booms and dispersants will not save Galveston Bay. The only technology that holds even a promise is bioremediation,'' Mauro said. Clements later reversed himself, and decided to allow 100 pounds of microbes mixed with water to be pumped onto two areas of Pelican Island, adjacent to Galveston Island. Coast Guard officials said Thursday the oil sheen has thinned to a 12-mile stretch throughout the bay, with heavier patches around Redfish Island, Pelican Island, Texas City Dike, Eagle Point and Port Bolivar. ``We're fortunate,'' Clements said. ``We're blessed that it has turned out this way. It's not near as serious a problem as was first anticipated.'' The bay contains the nation's seventh largest estuary system, with rich banks of shrimp, crabs, oysters and valuable fish. Bay shrimpers put out of work by the fishing ban said they were skeptical of Clements' views. ``I hope he's right, but realistically, I think he's full of baloney,'' said C.L. Standley, a former president of Professional Involvement of Seafood Concerned Enterprises. Clements said he expected the fishing ban would be lifted soon. ``It's not really as bad as we thought,'' he said. But Standley disagreed. ``I think it could possibly be weeks, and if it is, that's going to be devastating,'' he said. The bay's commercial fishing industry generates $240 million annually, and its recreational fishing industry generates $170 million annually, said David Hankla, field supervisor for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. With Galveston Bay closed, fishing boats will have to move to other Gulf of Mexico inlets or out to the gulf itself. In another development, the captain of the Greek tanker, testifying for the second day at a federal inquiry into the collision that caused the spill, again blamed the accident on a Houston pilot. Capt. Nikolos Fioratos testified that the pilot ordered the Shinoussa to travel too fast through the ship channel, then told him to tell authorities that the accident happened because the channel was too narrow. The hearing is being held by the National Transportation Safety Board and the Coast Guard.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Draft Soldiers, Civilian Trucks, KGB For Harvest
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government is drafting tens of thousands of soldiers, 10 to 15 percent of the nation's civilian trucks, and even the KGB to harvest a huge grain crop, the Soviet news agency Tass said Thursday. It said the crop was so large it has overwhelmed the nation's ability to collect it all. Soviet officials are so worried about losing any of the unexpectedly big crop that some suggested declaring a nationwide state of emergency, Tass said. Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov rejected the idea Thursday. The grain crop is now expected to reach 260 million tons. That's a mind-boggling figure for Soviets, whose previous record was last year's 211 million tons. No reason has been given for this year's rise in harvest figures. The Soviets are already losing 2 million tons a day because they cannot harvest and store it quickly enough, said Vladilen Nikitin, head of the state food commission. Soviet media have blamed shortages of fuel, trucks and storage space, as well as the centrally planned economy's inability to adjust to the demand. The country annual loses 20 to 30 percent of its food crop on the way to market. The government has already sent 70 army battalions with 35,000 trucks to help with the harvest. Another 20 battalions with 10,000 trucks will be added, Tass said. Ryzhkov said 10 to 15 percent of the nation's trucks will also be drawn into the harvest campaign, regardless of their ownership, Tass said. The KGB state security agency and the Interior Ministry also will be asked to contribute resources, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Slaps Embargo on Iraq; US Oil Workers Taken
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 11-12: ``Later, Bush,'' call to Saudi king
DOC.TEXT: President Bush froze Iraq's assets in this country and cut off imports of 588,000 barrels a day of Iraqi oil Thursday in retaliation for the lightning invasion of Kuwait. U.S. officials were seeking word on American oil workers missing in the region. Kuwait's ambassador appealed for American military help for his country but none was forthcoming, at least for the moment. Bush said, ``We're not ruling any options in but we're not ruling any options out.'' A State Department official disclosed that the invading Iraqi troops rounded up and moved ``a few'' American oil field workers from just inside Kuwait's border. He said their whereabouts were not known. ``We are making every effort to make inquiries and find out more,'' said the official, who commented on condition he not be identified. The president, in blocking virtually all commerce with Iraq, denounced its ``naked aggression'' against a small neighbor. Some members of Congress compared Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein to Hitler and said they believed the American people would accept higher fuel prices resulting from an attempt to strangle Iraq economically. Bush flew to Aspen, Colo. to deliver a speech appealing for keeping America strong enough militarily to respond to terrorism, hostage taking and ``renegade regimes and unpredictable rulers.'' He said Iraq's ``brutal aggression'' made his point _ that despite the lessening of the Soviet threat in recent months, ``threats can arise suddenly, unpredictably, and from unexpected quarters.'' Bush conferred in Colorado with the vacationing British prime minister, Margaret Thatcher. He arranged to return to Washington earlier than planned. Mrs. Thatcher, referring to Saddam, said, ``We find his behavior intolerable.'' She called for collective action by the member states of the United Nations. Bush said he conferred by telephone with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and other Arab leaders, and said he was encouraged by their efforts to find an ``Arab answer'' to the problem. Later, Bush spoke for a half-hour by telephone with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, and ``they agreed that the attack on Kuwait was absolutely unacceptable.'' Out for a walk, Bush was asked by reporters what he talked about with the king. Bush replied, ``just reviewing options ... going to have some meetings over there.'' Before leaving Washington, Bush said the United States would do whatever more is necessary ``to defend our longstanding, vital interests'' in the Persian Gulf. He said he and his advisers would ``consider all possible options available to us.'' But he wasn't specific and said he wasn't discussing military intervention _ a course which experts said offered no easy choices to him. He added that he wouldn't talk publicly about military options in any event. ``We don't stand a chance if we don't get any aid from our friends,'' a dismayed Ambassador Saud Nasser Al-Sabah told reporters. ``U.S. intervention at this stage is of paramount importance.'' As an alternative, Bush took one of the toughest economic options open to him. He froze control of Iraqi assets in the United States _ and of Kuwait's assets, too, so they wouldn't fall into Iraqi hands. And he halted commerce between the United States and Iraq, a nation that normally provides the United States with 588,000 barrels of oil a day _ 7.6 percent of U.S. imports. Administration officials said they could not estimate the value of Kuwaiti and Iraqi assets affected by the freeze, but one Treasury official described them as ``significant.'' After a morning of closed briefings, Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said if Iraq headed for Saudi Arabia and its oil fields just 250 miles across the desert, ``I think it would be a direct threat to the security of this country.'' Saddam must calculate whether his nation, weary from its long war with Iran, is willing to support further miltary adventures, Boren said. A possible invasion by Iraq of Saudi Arabia ``cannot be ruled out,'' he said. And Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, expressed fear that if the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait succeeds ``Saudi Arabia might be next _ and then Saddam Hussein would have a stranglehold on the West's oil supply.'' The Texan said the United States should seek a worldwide embargo against Iraqi oil. ``Iraq is deeply in debt and very dependent on oil revenues and such an embargo would be an effective way to get their attention,'' he said.
