The timing of the invasion appeared to have caught many officials off guard. Bush said he had not been taken totally by surprise. ``We had good intelligence and our intelligence has had me concerned for some time now,'' he said. ``We provided policymakers with very useful and timely information on these events,'' the CIA said in an unusual statement denying it had been caught unawares. ``There were no surprises.'' Boren also said many in the administration and Congress had ``engaged in wishful thinking'' when they believed that Saddam's only aim was to force Kuwait to lower its oil production and thereby move oil prices upward. Reflecting the anger boiling up on Capitol Hill, Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., told the House, ``The attack is a financial assault on America and on the rest of the world that is dependent on Mideastern oil.'' The House gave speedy 416-0 approval to a pending economic sanctions bill aimed at Iraq. The measure would cut off Iraq's $200 million a year in Export-Import Bank credits and tighten restrictions on U.S. exports that could have military as well as civilian uses. Pentagon sources also said an evacuation of 3,000 Americans, mostly business people, from Kuwait was under consideration. About 130 are U.S. employees. The State Department said U.S. Embassy personnel were safe and the embassy grounds had not been penetrated during the fighting, but it advised Americans to postpone travel to Kuwait. The aircraft carrier USS Independence and six escorts were directed to head toward the region from the Indian Ocean but were several days from reaching a ``striking distance'' position outside the Persian Gulf, Pentagon sources said. An eight-ship force deployed on maneuvers earlier was still in the gulf but not equipped for any type of land assault. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said, ``We do not have aircraft within striking distance unless we fly land-based, long-range bombers into that region. And I do not think the time is now for us to talk about military force. We would not want to get into a ground war in that area.'' Bush, in his first public reaction, called for ``the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of all the Iraqi forces'' and said: ``There is no place for this sort of naked aggression in today's world.'' ``You're dealing with a madman here,'' Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said of Saddam. ``I'm not sure he's going to respond to sanctions.'' Presidential economic adviser Michael Boskin told Congress that the U.S. economy should be able to withstand any foreseeable increase in oil prices. Even a 25 percent rise in oil prices would likely have only a modest adverse impact on U.S. economic growth, he said. The United States gets half of its oil from abroad, and 10 percent from Iraqi and Kuwait. America imported about $2.4 billion in oil and other goods last year from Iraq, while U.S. exports to Iraq, chiefly agricultural commodities, totaled $1.17 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says 3,000 Americans in Kuwait
With AM-US-Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Most of the approximately 3,000 Americans living in Kuwait work in the oil or construction industries, the State Department said Thursday. Invading Iraqi troops rounded up six American oil field workers near the border of Kuwait, the department said in a statement. Their whereabouts were unknown. Iraq seized control of some the Persian Gulf kingdom's rich oil fields during its blitzkrieg invasion Wednesday. Texaco Inc. operates an oil refinery under a 50-50 joint venture with Kuwait Oil Co. in a ``neutral zone'' in southwestern Kuwait next to Saudi Arabia. It is the only U.S.-owned refinery operating in Iraq or Kuwait. Texaco spokeswoman Anita Larsen said 17 Americans are among 800 employees there. All were reported safe earlier in the day, and the refinery was running, she said. Many of the employees have family with them, but Larsen said she did not know the exact number. Major Middle East contractors such as Houston-based Brown & Root currently have no American employees in the area, company officials said. The U.S. government employees 130 people in Kuwait, mainly at its embassy, said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. All were reported safe after the invasion, he said. AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said its several dozen employees in Kuwait include Americans, Canadians and British. Other contractors in the area, including Bechtel International of San Francisco, did not return phone calls Thursday seeking comment about their employees. More than 60 percent of Kuwait's 1.8 million residents are foreigners. About half the population was believed to be outside the country for summer holidays. Many of the Americans work as consultants for small contracting firms, officials said. A Middle East expert said it was unlikely U.S. citizens would be singled out for violence. ``I don't think Americans and Western business people are really at risk at all,'' said Dr. Kofi Afriyie of Rutgers University. ``Look at their motivation. Iraq wants to increase its own oil revenues ... If they incur the displeasure of Western countries, it would defeat its own purpose.''

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Airport User Fees for Passengers
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDs two grafs of negative votes and those not voting in lieu of roll call
DOC.TEXT: The House on Thursday approved passenger user fees at airports as a way of financing new gates, runways and other construction designed to cut increasing congestion and delays. Fees would be limited to $3 per passenger at each airport, with a ceiling of $12 per passenger for one round-trip. ``This bill will bring our air transport system into the 21st century,'' said Rep. Lawrence Coughlin, R-Pa., as the House voted 252-171 to defeat an effort to drop the user fees from the legislation. The House then approved the bill 405-15. The measure would authorize $17 billion over two years for airport operations and development. It calls for spending more than $6 billion in the Aviation Trust Fund over the next five years to upgrade airports. The Senate has taken no action on the plan. House members clashed over the provision authorizing local airports to impose fees on passengers. Whether to impose such fees would be a decision made by local officials, subject to regulation by the federal Department of Transportation. Improvements are needed to ease crowding and delays caused by an increase in airline passengers from 266 million in 1978 to 480 million last year. Authorities are forecasting an increase to 750 million within 10 years. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., and other Chicagoans said that a third major airport to service the city could not be built without the passenger charge. The new airport is estimated to cost $4.9 billion. But critics said the fees would benefit only a few cities with major construction projects on the drawing board _ especially Chicago _ and that most travelers would reap no benefits from the airport improvements. ``Aviation passengers are being taken for a ride by the White House and Congress,'' said Rep. Norman Mineta, D-Calif. A study by airport associations has suggested that $10 billion a year would be needed for the next five years to overcome congestion at many of the nation's major airports. The Transportation Department has generally accepted the estimate. Rep. William F. Clinger Jr., R-Pa., said the critics had provided no alternative way to meet the costs. ``They can hope the tooth fairy will, under cover of night, extend the runway or build the new terminal,'' Clinger said. These members voted against the bill: Reps. Jim Bates, D-Calif.; Douglas H. Bosco, D-Calif.; Gary Condit, D-Calif.; Norman Mineta, D-Calif.; William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; George Sangmeister, D-Ill.; Philip M. Crane, R-Ill.; Lynn Martin, R-Ill.; Andrew Jacobs Jr., D-Ind.; David Bonior, D-Mich.; Bob Carr, D-Mich.; George W. Crockett Jr., D-Mich.; Dennis M. Hertel, D-Mich.; Robert S. Walker, R-Pa., and F. James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis. These members did not vote: Reps. Michael Bilirakis, R-Fla.; Floyd H. Flake, R-N.Y.; Harold E. Ford, D-Tenn.; William D. Ford, D-Mich.; Ralph M. Hall, D-Texas; Marvin Leath, D-Texas; Thomas Luken, D-Ohio; Matthew G. Martinez, D-Calif.; Bruce A. Morrison, D-Conn.; Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; Solomon P. Ortiz, D-Texas, Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., who by custom does not normally vote, and Chalmers P. Wylie, R-Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: `Just Like the Movies, We Dived for Cover,' Says Canadian in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, About 4,000 ... CORRECTING to 3,000 to conform with later official U.S. estimate. Picks up 9th graf, White House ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Canadian Kathy McGregor said from Kuwait that one explosion was close enough to shake her house when Iraqi forces invaded the small sultanate before dawn on Thursday. ``You know when you see a movie, when people dive for cover? We did it. The explosion blew inside the house, shaking it,'' the 32-year-old Ms. McGregor reported by telephone. ``It's chaos, military jets are flying over all the time,'' she added, looking out her window. She said that later Thursday, the violence of war lifted considerably _ ``There is not much noise or gunfire. I feel better with more people around now.'' Other expatriates, also reached by telephone from Bahrain, said they heard gunfire, explosions and jets and helicopters overhead as the Iraqis moved in. ``We were totally unprepared. One feels like there should have been a bit of warning,'' said 37-year-old Catherine Baker of Illinois, an employee of a British design firm in Kuwait. She said it was ``unbelievable. ... It doesn't seem real.'' About 3,000 Americans are among the large expatriate community in Kuwait, where more than 60 percent of the 1.9 million residents are foreigners. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said no Americans were reported harmed. Diplomatic sources in the Persian Gulf estimated that more than 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded in the invasion. The British Embassy was hit by shellfire and the Sheraton and Hilton hotels evacuated their guests, diplomats reported. Serge Sejournet, 30, an artist from Paris, said, ``I think it will be over soon, somehow. I don't think I want to get out of Kuwait.'' He said he thought the United States would ``bring the situation under control.'' Sejournet said Iraqi soldiers on the street in front of his home in downtown Kuwait were ``very friendly with everyone, saying hello to all.'' He, Ms. Baker and other expatriates said they gathered in homes of friends, listening to the fighting. Herb Linnen, a spokesman for AT&T, said in Washington that calls to Kuwait reached 2,000 every five minutes. Friends and relatives of those living in Kuwait found it hard or impossible to contact them. Linnen said the company itself got through only once to its employees in Kuwait on Thursday and ascertained that the dozens of workers and their families were safe. The State Department set up a 24-hour hotline for people seeking information about the safety of American relatives and friends in Kuwait and Iraq. The number is (202) 647-0900.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Preserves Funding For Stealth Bomber
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs with Senate rejecting amendment to ban use of U.S. dollars for new base in Italy. Informatively, Senate plans to work on legislation through the evening but votes on SDI unlikely.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Thursday left intact President Bush's 1991 budget request for the B-2 bomber but imposed restrictions on the $4.6 billion until critical tests on the stealth aircraft have been conducted. By a vote of 97-2, the Senate adopted the amendment to the $289 billion defense bill as Republicans fought to salvage the aircraft and GOP leader Bob Dole argued that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was the ``wake-up call'' against deep cuts in defense spending. Just moments later, proponents of the B-2 narrowly managed to fight off the most serious effort yet to gut the program. An amendment that would have stalled the program at 15 planes already authorized failed, 53-45. ``This just about defeats the program,'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee and a supporter of the B-2, warned shortly before the vote. The measure's sponsor, Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, argued against the bomber, citing the expensive cost of a single plane _ $865 million _ and the Justice Department's recommendation that the manufacturer, Northrop Corp., be prohibited from future defense contracts due to fraud charges. ``Let's fund what we have on line right now but no more B-2s until you prove them,'' Cohen said. The Senate action comes on the heels of the House Armed Services Committee's adoption of a $283 billion defense bill that halts production of the program at the 15 planes. Opponents of the plane have argued that since the Cold War has ended and the budget deficit has grown the plane's worth is questionable. The Senate did approve an amendment, sponsored by Nunn and the panel's ranking Republican, Sen. John Warner of Virginia, that calls for the plane to pass 13 requirements before about $2 billion in procurement money can be spent. Ten of those tests were included in last year's defense bill. All total, the administration is seeking $4.6 billion for two B-2 bombers in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. ``I understand the case against the B-2. All of us are suffering from sticker shock,'' Nunn said on the Senate floor. But the panel chairman argued that the plane is ``indeed a revolutionary change in capability to conduct air warfare.'' In its bill, the House panel also slashed nearly $2 billion from Bush's request for the Strategic Defense Initiative as it adopted a defense package that chops $24 billion from Bush's Pentagon budget of $307 billion for fiscal 1991. In the wake of the cuts, the Bush administration was relying on the Senate to salvage its prized weapons programs, including the B-2 bomber and SDI. In its bill, the Senate Armed Services Committee approved the president's proposal for two B-2 bombers in fiscal 1991 and trimmed $1 billion from the budget for SDI, or Star Wars. The first Senate vote on the B-2 bomber followed the Senate GOP leader's prediction. ``I think this vote ought to be overwhelming today,'' Dole said during the afternoon of debate. ``Maybe yesterday it might have been close but we need something to wake us up from time to time. We need a wake-up call. We need to be alerted that we're not going to be able to control the events in the world.'' The Air Force envisions the B-2 bomber to be used after a nuclear missile war, to seek out the remaining targets in the Soviet Union. Warner argued that the government has already invested more than $26 billion, and terminating the program at 15 planes would increase the per unit cost to more than $2.3 billion per plane. Later in the evening, the Senate rejected an amendment that would have prohibited using U.S. dollars in the NATO Infrastructure Fund for a new air base in Crotone, Italy, to house the 401st Tactical Wing. The vote was 51-47. The House Armed Services Committee earlier this week banned the use of American money for the installation made necessary by Spain's decision to force out the 72 F-16 jet fighters from Torrejon de Ardoz. The Senate vote came after Warner said he had just received a telephone call from Gen. John Galvin, head of the European command, who argued that if he was left with only two bases, one had to be in Crotone.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Invasion Widely Condemned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with new information and editing, UPDATING with Thatcher comments, Islamic conference denunciation, other nations denounce invasion, Lloyd's introducing war-risk premiums. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Thursday was condemned around the world, with rival nations uniting in calls for Iraq to withdraw its forces from its Persian Gulf neighbor. At least two Arab nations cautioned against outside intervention, however, in response to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's takeover of oil-rich Kuwait. Other fellow Arab states were reluctant to speak against Iraq. The United Nations demanded Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. China, Iran, Australia and Algeria were among nations echoing the call. NATO officials met in Brussels and the United States said it was ``reviewing all options.'' Israel said it was ready to meet any military threat posed by Iraq. The Soviet Union, Iraq's largest arms supplier, suspended shipments, according to the Soviet news agency Tass. The United States, which gets 5 percent of its oil from Iraq and Kuwait, slapped an embargo on Iraqi oil. The United States, France and Britain froze Kuwaiti assets to protect them from Iraq, and the United States and France froze Iraqi assets as well. Switzerland ordered its banks to increase vigilance over Kuwaiti assets to prevent their seizure. Kuwait's U.S. ambassador, Sheikh Saud Nasir al-Sabah, appealed for U.S. military assistance ``in order to survive.'' But Libya said any foreign intervention would be considered ``an aggressive act.'' Jordan's official news agency said King Hussein was also concerned about avoiding foreign intervention. Iran, which fought an eight-year war with Iraq, condemned the invasion and called for immediate Iraqi withdrawal. A Foreign Ministry statement warned that Iran ``cannot remain indifferent to any development which could endanger her national security and regional stability.'' The Arab League Council met in emergency session in Cairo to consider a Kuwaiti demand to send a joint Arab force ``to defend Kuwait against the Iraqi invasion,'' Egypt's state-run Middle East News Agency reported. But the council adjourned without condemning the overthrow, the first by one Arab nation against another in modern history. In Washington, President Bush called the invasion ``naked aggression'' but said ``we're not discussing'' military intervention. Nonetheless, a Defense Department source said a naval battle group was being diverted to the region. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, meeting with Bush near Aspen, Colo., said ``we need a collective and effective will of the nations belonging to the U.N.'' to resolve the conflict. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France said in a TV interview that the Security Council resolution, co-sponsored by France, was ``the prelude to the leveling of sanctions.'' France, Iraq's second-largest supplier, had already suspended arms deliveries because Baghdad failed to pay about $4.5 billion in debts, Dumas said. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said it is ``perfectly clear that collective measures will be necessary if the Security Council resolution is not complied with.'' He called the new government of Kuwait ``a puppet regime.'' Within the Arab world, the invasion prompted urgent consultations. Hussein flew to Alexandria for consulations with Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak. Both talked to Bush, Saddam, Saudi President King Fahd and Yemeni President Ali Abdallah Saleh by telephone, the Egyptian news agency reported. It gave no details. Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi telephoned leaders of Saudi Arabia and Tunisia on Thursday to discuss the crisis, according to a Libyan Radio broadcast monitored in London. ``Foreign intervention on the part of imperialist powers is something which we utterly reject because Arabs are capable of resolving problems on their own,'' Libya's foreign minister said in a statement broadcast by Libyan Radio. Hamed el-Ghabid, secretary-general of the 45-national Organization of Islamic Conference, issued a statement in Cairo asking Iraq to withdraw. ``What is going on is of great danger for the security, stability and peace of the whole gulf region,'' he said. Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens said the attack proved Saddam was ``a threat to the entire world.'' He said Israel was ready to meet any military threat posed by Iraq but would not take action unless attacked. Statements of condemnation were issued by the 12-nation European Community, by Austria, Singapore, Romania, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Algeria, Venezuela, Mexico, Turkey, Norway, Morocco and Niger. China said ``no one should resort to force of arms in resolving their disputes,'' and Japan, which is heavily dependent on Persian Gulf oil, expressed hope for a peaceful solution. Oil prices jumped on fears the conflict would disrupt oil supplies. Late Thursday's price was more than $22 a barrel, up from $15.85 on July 12. Lloyd's of London, the insurer, introduced war risk premiums for shipping in the Persian Gulf for the first time since the Iran-Iraq war. The fighting ended in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Scenes of Occupied City: Iraqi Troops Make Sheraton Their Hqtrs
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Occupying Iraqi troops have adopted the Sheraton Hotel in a Kuwaiti suburb as their interim headquarters, eschewing the government buildings they seized earlier Thursday for the hotel's more comfortable lodgings. Much has changed overnight in this capital since tank-led Iraqi troops crossed the border 80 miles away before dawn and charged into Kuwait. Iraq issued a statement in Baghdad saying the troops were in Kuwait at the request of a revolutionary council. Most people here seemed unaware what revolutionary council had called for their government's ouster. Instead, scenes from the occupied city Thursday bordered on the bizarre: _In one area of the city, about 30 Kuwaitis stood patiently in line, waiting to rent videocassette movies for the night. The reason, in the words of one woman, is that most residents are staying at home ``sitting tight.'' _Many Kuwait autos have been left in the streets, some not even parked but merely abandoned as if the drivers saw the approaching troops and fled. Roads and sidewalks in parts of the city have been damaged and churned up by the hundreds of tanks that entered Kuwait. _Some of the Iraqi troops have been seen driving around the capital in newly confiscated Kuwaiti police cars. _At a circular intersection, Iraqi troops mill about, sitting, eating and talking; ground rocket-launchers stand idle nearby, ready to be fired if necessary. About 100 soldiers meander about outside the newly occupied Sheraton Hotel, in groups of 10. _In downtown Kuwait, the streets are largely deserted, with none of the usual bustle of taxis and buses. Only in the suburbs do local residents dare to go outside for long, though some are still fearful of further incidents with the invading forces. Life in the suburbs however seems basically normal. _The only sign of domestic unrest was spot panic-buying in the supermarkets, where residents shopped quickly and headed right home.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Backs Bush Stand in Iraq-Kuwait Conflict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 10th graf: ``Later, the,'' with Senate resolution
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Congress moved rapidly Thursday to endorse President Bush's economic sanctions against Iraq, and some lawmakers said they would support U.S. military action if it is coordinated with allies in the Middle East. Lawmakers said they believed the American public would support a total cutoff of U.S. economic ties with Iraq even it it meant a short-term increase in fuel prices, because of fears that an unstable ruler could gain a long-term strangehold on Persian Gulf oil supplies. ``You're talking about something that could totally unravel the whole Middle East,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. ``Talk about the analogy of the fuse being lit, it's being lit in Kuwait.'' Some Democrats welcomed Bush's tough embargo but questioned why he had not acted sooner. They said a policy of ``appeasement'' by Bush and President Reagan, his predecessor, might have emboldened Iraqi ruler Saddam Hussein to invade Kuwait. ``The administration, finally, this morning, as a result of the invasion, has a good policy,'' said Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif. Berman's proposed legislation to impose economic sanctions on Iraq, strengthened by Bush's executive order, was sent on a fast track to the House floor, where it was approved on a 416-0 vote. One lawmaker, Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., voted ``present'' because he said the action was too hasty and included a grain embargo like the ill-fated 1980 ban imposed by President Carter against the Soviet Union. The bill also would cut off Iraq's $200 million in annual Export-Import Bank credits and tighten restrictions on U.S. exports that could have either civilian or military uses. ``We want to indicate through legislation that we are in full support of the president's action,'' said Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Later, the Senate voted 97-0 for a resolution condemning the invasion, praising Bush's sanctions and calling for a worldwide boycott of Iraqi oil and an end to arms sales as part of a full economic blockade. If those measures fail to pressure Iraq to leave Kuwait, the United Nations should pursue multilateral military actions, it said. Berman said Americans will be willing to make economic sacrifices to show their opposition to Iraq's invasion. ``In the end, I don't think the people of the United States want to appease a bully'' to ensure the uninterrupted flow of Mideast oil, Berman said. If unchecked, he said, Saddam could take ``total control'' of the region's oil reserves. But in a sense, that may already have happened, said Rep. Matthew McHugh, D-N.Y. Iraq's powerful presence in Kuwait may intimidate Saudi Arabia, the peninsula's largest oil producer, into going along with any oil policy dictated from Baghdad, he said. ``The Saudis are going to be very cautious'' about stepping up production to stabilize prices, said McHugh, a member of the House Intelligence Committee. They may not do so without a promise of U.S. support if attacked, he suggested. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said it was too early to say what military steps the United States might take. But Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, held open the option of a military response. ``Together with our friends in the region, we should consider defensive military measures that might be needed to guard against any further Iraqi aggression,'' Bentsen said, cautioning that ``I don't foresee the need for U.S. combat involvement.'' Instead, Bentsen urged a worldwide embargo on purchases of Iraqi oil. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., and some other legislators said military action in coordination with gulf allies eventually might be necessary. ``You're dealing with a madman here,'' said Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., likening Saddam to Adolf Hitler. ``I'm not sure he's going to respond to sanctions.'' Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., said Bush had acted ``boldly and comprehensively'' in severing U.S. trade with Iraq and freezing the U.S. assets of Iraq and Kuwait. But Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., accused Bush of a ``policy of appeasement'' toward Iraq. ``There was a total misjudgment of the policies and goals of Saddam Hussein to the very moment his troops invaded a neighboring country,'' he said. Added Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif.: ``Many have been urging this administration to take Saddam Hussein much more seriously than they have.'' Berman said problems began when Reagan ``tilted'' in favor of Iraq during its eight-year war with Iran, urging U.S. allies to arm the Baghdad government while overlooking Iraq's human rights violations and support for terrorism. Foley said it would be ``foolish'' to think the invasion could have been averted if Bush had ordered sanctions earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Basic Facts of Iraq's Invasion of Kuwait
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
THE INVASION: Iraq's troops, led by about 350 tanks, crossed the border at dawn Thursday, and seized the Kuwaiti palace and government buildings 40 miles away. Early Friday, the invaders controlled Kuwait city, the capital. The soldiers were also making sweeps through the southern oilfields, according to residents and Lloyds' insurance service in London. Diplomatic sources estimate more than 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded, mainly from the Emiri Guard which bore the main brunt of the invasion. Kuwait's Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah fled to safety in Saudi Arabia.
THE FORCES: Iraq, a country of more than 17 million, has the Arab world's most battle-trained army, and had massed more than 100,000 soldiers on the Kuwaiti border. Kuwait, an oil-rich city-state, has 1.9 million residents _ 60 percent foreigners _ and an army of 20,300 soldiers.
CAUSE OF CONFLICT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accused Kuwait of stealing oil from its territory and forcing down oil prices through overproduction. Kuwait and U.N. diplomats dismissed Iraq's claim that it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries.
REACTION: The U.N. Security Council voted 14-0 to condemn the invasion. President Bush denounced it as ``naked agression.'' He froze Iraq's assets in the United States and blocked almost all Iraqi imports, including oil. The order also froze Kuwait property under U.S. jurisdiction _ a move intended to keep Iraq from seizing it. The Soviets also condemned the invasion and stopped arms sales to Iraq. Kuwait's U.S. ambassador said the nation had asked for American military intervention. A Pentagon source said a U.S. naval group was diverted toward the Persian Gulf. Oil prices soared in frenzied trading amid fears the invasion would reduce the supply of oil.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troops Take Six US Oil Workers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd and penultimate grafs to remove outdated reference to six workers.
DOC.TEXT: Eight American oil field workers were reported missing near the border of Kuwait and company officials suspected they had been picked up by the invading Iraqi army, the State Department said on Thursday. The whereabouts of the eight were unknown. ``Our embassy in Baghdad has asked the government of Iraq for information on the whereabouts of these ... American citizens, reminding the government of Iraq of its commitment to respect the security and welfare of U.S. citizens,'' the department said in an unattributed statement. Word of the detention came from a U.S. oil company for whom the eight worked, and the department asserted it was not at liberty to identify that company or any of the eight because of provisions of the Privacy Act. A State Department official said the company reported the roundup by the Iraqis, but the United States has not been able to confirm whether that is what happened. Texaco Inc. is the only U.S. oil company with operations in Kuwait. Texaco has 17 Americans among 800 employees working in the joint Saudi Arabian-Kuwaiti neutral zone, said spokeswoman Anita Larsen in New York. The spokeswoman said all 17 had been reported safe earlier in the day. Meanwhile, a Texas television station identified one of the eight as Charles Amos of Gilmer, an employee of Santa Fe Drilling Co. of California. Amos' family was notified by the State Department on Thursday morning, according to the report on KLTV-TV. A short time before a State Department official disclosed the suspected roundup, President Bush was asked about reports that American workers in Kuwait had been rounded up. ``I don't have anything on that right now,'' he said. ``Secondly, it would affect us in a very dramatic way because I view a fundamental responsibility of my presidency is protecting American citizens. If they're put into harm's way I have certain responsibilities.'' An estimated 3,000 Americans live in Kuwait, many of them with ties to the oil business. Iraqi troops seized control of some of Kuwait's rich oil fields during their blitzkrieg invasion of the Persian Gulf kingdom on Wednesday. Officials did not want to conclude that the eight workers had been taken hostage. ``All we know is that they are missing,'' said a U.S. official who asked not to be further identified. ``They are in a situation where we are very concerned about there whereabouts. But at this point we are not drawing conclusions.''

DOC.HEAD: House Puts Caps Punitive Damages for Women in Civil Rights Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops with 12 grafs; House adds damages cap, puts off action on LaFalce plan; picks up 15th graf pvs: ``Women's groups,'' Should stand for AMs
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON (AP) The House began debate on a major civil rights bill Thursday and voted to put a ceiling on punitive damages that courts can award to women who are victims of intentional job discrimination. ``This will lay the unfounded fears to rest,'' said the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, said as the House approved the cap, 289-134. Punitive damages for women, religious minorities and the disabled could be no more than $150,000 or the amount of compensatory damages awarded by the court, whichever is larger. The House worked into the night Thursday on the but put off a vote on passage and other major floor action until Friday. The bill is the top item on the civil rights community's congressional shopping list and would effectively reverse five Supreme Court decisions last year. It is advancing under threat of a presidential veto, with the Bush administration saying it would lead to hiring quotas for members of minority groups. Provisions range from a ban on racial harrassment in the workplace to barriers against reopening court-approved fair-hiring plans. The most controversial provisions would make it easier for those claiming to be victims of job discrimination to win lawsuits against employers based on statistics. The ceiling on damages was designed to ease business concerns about the potential for huge, open-ended jury awards for women victimized by discrimination. It also was aimed at winning support among southern Democrats. Liberal sponsors of the bill split over the issue. Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., chairman of the civil rights subcommittee of the Judiciary Committee, voted against it. Education and Labor Committee Chairman Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., voted for it. ``The southern Democrats voted with us on this cap and most of them will now support us'' when the House turns to a major amendment that would limit not only punitive but all damages to $100,000, said Hawkins. That proposal has been championed by Rep. John LaFalce, D-N.Y., and has been praised by the Bush administration as a step away from quotas. Sponsors say it would wreck the bill. Hawkins said sponsors would beat back the LaFalce amendment by ``a whopping good vote.'' Women's groups have been opposing such ceilings, saying they would be unfair in view of unlimited punitive damages allowed in the case of deliberate racial discrimination in the workplace. The House earlier had approved, 397-24, an amendment making clear that no hiring quotas would be required under the bill. Similar language was included in the measure when it was approved by the Judiciary Committee, but lawmakers wanted a chance to vote on it separately. Republican critics scoffed that the no-quotas amendment amounted to nothing more than a cosmetic exercize. ``I can't believe the charade of it all,'' declared Rep. Nancy Johnson, R-Conn. Civil rights forces scoff at the charge that the bill would lead to quotas. ``If anyone raises the subject of quotas, I want to know where it is,'' said Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich. ``There is no reference to quotas in this bill.'' Women's groups have been crusading against the LaFalce measure, noting that there is no cap on damages that courts can now award to victims of racial discrimination in the workplace. The decision by LaFalce to sponsor the rival plan plainly irked fellow Democrats who positioned the proposed amendment for floor action in such a way that it could be offered only by Republican Leader Bob Michel of Illinois or someone designated by him. As debate began, Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., R-Wis., blasted the bill sponsors for fashioning a measure that exempts Congress itself. ``The same thing ought to apply in the Congress of the United States,'' Sensenbrenner said. He urged lawmakers to ``end the hypocrisy of us insulating ourselves from our own laws, once and for all this afternoon.'' Black lawmakers launched the debate by pleading for approval of the bill. ``This is the single most important civil rights legislation since the 1964 civil rights act,'' said Rep. Al Wheat, D-Mo. He said it carried ``a simple message that discrimination and particularly intentional discrimination based on race is not acceptable in America.'' Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., attacked the LaFalce substitute, declaring, ``There is no substitute for justice.''

DOC.HEAD: Phone Calls to Iraq, Kuwait Cut Off
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 8th graf: ``A US,'' with US Sprint unable to complete calls to Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Public phone calls through AT&T were cut off Thursday between the United States and Kuwait and Iraq, an AT&T spokesman said. Two other telephone companies were still getting some calls through Thursday evening, according to their spokesmen. The AT&T spokesman, Herb Linnen, said some calls got through to Kuwait as Iraqi troops invaded, but there were long delays because of the heavy volume of calls _ at one point 2,000 every five minutes. Calls between the United States and Iraq, however, were cut off from the Iraqi end without any explanation at about 10 a.m. EDT, he said. Efforts to route calls to both countries through Britain were not very successful because of the heavy number of calls already on those lines, he said. Linnen said the company itself had managed to get only ``six or seven'' calls through to Kuwait before service was stopped about 6:30 p.m. MCI was having trouble completing calls between Kuwait and the United States because of ``technical difficulties'' but was able to get calls through to Iraq, spokesman John Houser. A US Sprint spokesman, John Landsberg, said the large number of attempted calls between the United States and Kuwait clogged circuits and prevented calls from going through. Calls to Iraq were still possible, he said. Japanese telecommunications authorities reported Kuwait-Japan service interrupted about the same time, but British authorities said some calls were still getting through, Linnen said. AT&T employees include Americans, Canadians, British, Filipinos and one Sri Lankan who were working on a project with the Kuwaiti government to improve communications, the spokesman said.

Congress, responding to a spate of ethics scandals, is taking its first step toward curtailing lawmakers' ``money chase'' for campaign funds as senators also vote to quit accepting outside speaking fees. The Senate's Democratic majority overrode Republican opposition Wednesday night to approve the first change in federal election laws since Congress voted 16 years ago to publicly finance and limit spending on presidential elections in wake of the Watergate scandal. On a 59-40, largely party-line vote, the Senate approved a campaign finance bill to place similar limits on congressional candidates' spending, provide them with subsidies to buy television advertising and outlaw special-interest political action committees. ``We have a system out of control,'' said Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., the bill's chief author. ``The money chase has not slowed down.''

The House easily approved a 1990 farm bill that limits subsidies but is faulted by the Bush administration for not achieving enough savings. ``I think the basic skeleton of legislation will stay together,'' Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said Wednesday night after the House's 327-91 vote. ``The main problem is going to be numbers, with the budget summit.'' The administration has threatened a veto if costs in the bill are not decreased. ``The administration wants no program,'' said de la Garza. ``They are trying to use the budget to achieve that end.''

Smokers carrying a still-unidentified gene are more likely to develop lung cancer at an early age, according to a study that traced smoking and lung cancer histories in 337 Louisiana families. The study, published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute on Wednesday, said there was a clear genetic component to the early onset of lung cancer among smokers. However, it said the gene plays a lesser role in cancer among smokers late in life. ``If you smoke long enough, it'll get to you eventually, regardless of what genes you are carrying,'' said Thomas A. Sellers, a University of Minnesota scientist who was the lead researcher in the study. ``The genetic component influences the age of onset of the disease.'' He said that statistically, about 27 percent of the smoking population will get lung cancer over a lifetime.

Mayor Marion Barry occasionally used cocaine, but that doesn't justify government use of uncorroborated testimony from legally tainted witnesses in an attempt to bring him down, his lawyer contends. ``I will start right from the beginning by telling you that Mr. Barry used cocaine,'' R. Kenneth Mundy said Wednesday during closing arguments in the mayor's drug and perjury trial. ``We do not intend to give you the impression for one moment that there was not occasional drug use by Mr. Barry.'' But the government adopted the philosophy of ``the ends justify the means'' to catch the mayor using drugs, Mundy argued. ``Everything that the government could amass against him was put forward.'' Earlier Wednesday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin in her closing argument called Barry a ``general in the war'' on drugs ``who was working with the other side.''

The federal savings and loan bailout agency wants America to know it's ready to deal. Under mounting political pressure to speed the pace of the thrift cleanup, the Resolution Trust Corp. announced a ``clearance sale'' Wednesday, aimed at unloading $50 billion in assets from failed S&Ls. L. William Seidman, chairman of the agency, called it an ambitious goal that, if met, would ``move the process along in a really expeditious way.'' But Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a House Banking task force on the bailout, said he wasn't impressed by the sales push, given the huge task ahead.

Commuters in the land where the automobile reigns supreme are making like veteran straphangers and taking Los Angeles' new rail system to work. OK, not many are doing it, but officials say it's a start. After an 18-day introductory period during which the ride was free, the new 22-mile Blue Line began charging the $1.10 fare Wednesday. Ridership plummeted by more half, to about 11,000, but Rapid Transit District spokesman Ken Echard said that was anticipated. Many passengers said they had given up the workday drive for good and adapting to the lifestyle of straphangers in cities with established rail systems.

DOC.HEAD: Mayfair: Integrated Past, Hope for the Future
DOC.TEXT: Half-white, half-Indian Mayfair was never meant to be, but the Indians refused to leave and the result is an example of what South Africa could become after apartheid. The residential area on the fringe of Johannesburg's downtown area was designated white, but the government eventually acknowledged the presence of Indians by declaring part of it open to them. Indian families later moved into the white area too, making Mayfair truly multiracial. ``You see the emergence of a geniune non-racial outlook,'' said Cassim Saloojee, an Indian resident and activist who has fought for integrated neighborhoods. ``Mayfair in fact gives one a glimpse of what could happen in South Africa once apartheid has been done away with,'' Saloojee said. As President F.W. de Klerk moves ahead with plans to dismantle apartheid, the issue of segregated neighborhoods is among the most emotional. Anti-apartheid groups say living where one chooses is a fundamental right, but right-wing whites vow never to allow integration in their neighborhoods. The Group Areas Act of 1950, which segregates neighborhoods, is part of the official apartheid race policy that preserves supremacy for South Africa's 5 million whites over the 28 million blacks. Since last year, the government has opened 10 small neighborhoods to all races and has promised to amend, but not repeal, the Group Areas Act next year. Blacks, Indians and people of mixed race have lived in many white urban areas illegally for years, usually because of housing shortages in zones designated for their own racial groups. The ``whites only'' Hillbrow neighborhood of Johannesburg, for example, has become overwhelmingly black. Change in Mayfair and other integrated areas has been achieved by the persistence of many ordinary people, like Gladys Govender, of Indian descent. Mrs. Govender, 60, says she has never lived in an area set aside for Indians, who account for just under 1 million of South Africa's 38 million people. She and her family moved to Mayfair in 1979, into a house on Hanover Street, a slightly seedy area that was the unofficial dividing line between the white and Indian sections. They chose Mayfair, Mrs. Govender said, because they needed a bigger house and the closest officially Indian area, Lenasia, was nearly 20 miles outside Johannesburg. The Hanover Street house was rented in the name of a white person in an attempt to get around the law, but within months, police were calling on the Govenders regularly. ``Even at night,'' she said, and told of an evening when the family had ``just laid laid the table to have supper, then they rushed in.'' Authorities charged Mrs. Govender with violating the Group Areas Act. With the help of an anti-apartheid group called Actstop, she won a landmark case in 1982 that allowed her to remain in Mayfair. In its ruling, the court said the government must provide alternative accommodations for anyone evicted from an area for racial reasons. Because of the critical housing shortage for non-whtes, the decision makes it much more difficult for the government to evict or prosecute then. Soon after Mrs. Govender's victory, the government declared part of Mayfair an Indian neighborhood and families in overcrowded Indian areas began buying houses there. More Indian families also crossed the line into the white part of Mayfair. The Johannesburg City Council now estimates Mayfair has 7,000 white residents and about 2,500 Indians, not counting Indians who live illegally in the white sector. Several relatively minor racial incidents have occurred in Mayfair in recent years, but no serious ones.

DOC.HEAD: Use of Inhalants Increasing in Mexico
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: A mariachi band was playing for tourists in Garibaldi Plaza when the stink of paint thinner began to overpower the fragrance of roses sold by strolling vendors. A thin, disheveled woman stood in the middle of the square with a folded piece of cloth in one hand and a plastic bottle of clear liquid in the other. ``This is my only vice,'' said the 23-year-old prostitute, who gave her name as Gloria and swayed as she held the solvent-soaked rag to her face. ``This, a little wine and my cigarettes.'' Narcotics abuse has not reached epidemic proportions in Mexico; a national drug prevention program and a troubled economy have helped keep the use of hard drugs from expanding. Cheap inhalants like glue, paint thinner and other industrial solvents are becoming popular among the lower economic classes and fears are growing that Mexico is fertile ground for drug addiction. One reason is the wide variety of illegal drugs available here. Mexico grows marijuana and opium poppies, and is a transit point for cocaine and heroin bound for the United States from South America. More than half the 85 million people are under 19 and an estimated 800,000 enter the glutted job market each year. ``They have no opportunity for employment or school,'' said Mario Alberto, who works at Drug Addicts Anonymous. ``There is a great number of people at risk.'' The latest National Survey of Addictions found that 4.3 percent of Mexicans, more than half of them under age 34, had experimented with drugs at least once. It was conducted in 1988 and released this year by the General Directorate of Epidemeology and the Mexican Psychiatric Institute. It said drug use was significantly more prevalent in northwestern states like Baja California, Sonora and Sinaloa that are close to the U.S. border or serve as bases for large-scale traffickers. Of the estimated 500,000-plus drug addicts in Mexico, the federal attorney general's office says, 300,000 use inhalants, 200,000 use marijuana, 30,000 use cocaine and the rest use heroin or opium. People working in prevention and rehabilitation programs worry about the increased use of inhalants. Money determines the drug of choice in a nation whose minimum wage is equivalent to $3.60 a day. ``We are a poor country,'' said Martha Nelda Morales, assistant director of the Adolescent Orientation Center, a health service group. ``We are trying to satisfy our basic needs, like food, clothing and shelter.'' A half pint of paint thinner costs 7 cents and a tube of glue $1.07. It is illegal to sell either to anyone under 18, but enforcement is lax. Street prices for marijuana and cocaine, respectively, are about $1.80 a cigarette and $35 a gram. ``They give it away,'' a 14-year-old user named Jose said of inhalants. He was walking in Garibaldi Plaza, a tourist area of curio shops, bars and food stands where mariachis play for tips. Inhalants can cause permanent damage to the brain, liver, lungs and stomach, but Jose and other users show little concern about that. ``It takes away my hunger, my sleepiness and my problems,'' Jose said, gripping a tiny container of paint thinner. ``I'll stop when I get older.'' Some people say a ``higher morality'' has kept hard drugs from getting a strong hold on this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic nation. ``The concept of the family is stronger,'' Ms. Morales said. Dr. Raul Zapata Aguilar, medical director for the national Youth Integration Centers, said a decision to focus on prevention had made the difference. ``Twenty years ago, Mexico decided the only way to stem the tide of drug use was to stem the demand for drugs,'' he said. Most Mexican drug programs do not use the fear themes popular in the United States, such as ``Drugs Kill.'' Zapata believes the appeal to fear has only a short-term effect: ``It's like speeding on a highway and seeing an accident,'' he said. ``You will slow down for the next five miles, but eventually you will speed up again.'' The usual Mexican approach is to de-emphasize drugs and teach adolescents, parents and teachers how to achieve a healthy emotional, family and physical life. Advertisements show young people river rafting, for example, with the words ``Say yes to life'' across the top in large letters and ``Say no to drugs'' in smaller print on the bottom. Direct-action programs organize activities like weight lifting, street theater, poetry workshops and sports teams in poorer neighborhoods to keep children away from narcotics. A Roman Catholic priest known as Father Chimchachoma runs Providence House. He collects kids from the street and takes them to one of its 15 homes, where they can live until they finish school or learn a trade. One morning, he told three new arrivals of a diamond left in a muddy field. Passers-by ignored the dirty, seemingly worthless object, he said, but someone finally picked it up and washed it. ``And what did he find?'' the priest asked. ``A diamond!'' the boys shouted in unison. ``And what are you?'' ``Diamonds!''

DOC.HEAD: Anthropologist Explores the Cultural Diversity of America
DOC.TEXT: There's a moment in Alan Lomax's wonderful ``American Patchwork'' series on PBS when you understand the incredible power of cultural forces and the ingenuity of his anthropologist's vision. Lomax takes us to a joyous New Orleans neighborhood parade at Carnival time, when black men don gorgeously ornate ``Mardi Gras Indian'' costumes and take to the streets for ritual dance duels with rival tribes. He shows us their regalia and little-known rituals and then, almost casually, his video camera tilts down to show their feet, which slide along to the music in a distinctive, ground-hugging step. They he cuts to a shot of bare feet, dancing the identical step. The camera pulled back to reveal the dancers of a West African village street parade. It is a thoughtful, clever touch: Immutable as chromosomes, that gliding, ground-hugging dance step has come here from Africa and has survived, intact, for hundreds of years in the proud cultural heritage of black Americans. ``African culture arrived here along the non-verbal route,'' he explains. ``Deprived of language, it kept its body language, its enormously rich oral and non-verbal traditions.'' The final episode of his fine, five-part series airs tonight on PBS. Like the others, it's filled with music, color, stories and songs from the patchwork quilt of American culture that somehow is more than the sum of its parts. ``The human species for 90,000 years has devoted itself to communications systems, to music, dance, songs,'' said Lomax, who, with his father, John A. Lomax, compiled the Library of Congress' distinguished Archive of American Folk Song. ``Now that it's beginning to slip away from us, it begins to look mighty precious,'' he said. The series' second episode explored the musical traditions of southwest Louisiana's vital Cajun culture, from the rowdy, horseback gathering of the community's Mardi Gras gumbo to its pastoralist origins in western France. The third episode, ``The Land Where Blues Began,'' was a moving look at the music of the Mississippi Delta, what Lomax calls ``the powerful bitter poetry of an oppressed people.'' Lomax interviews the mule skinners who hauled the earth to build the Mississippi River levees. To hear the work songs and ``hollers'' they sing is to see the human face of a fundamentally American music. It's powerful stuff. ``Appalachian Journey'' followed the Britons who settled the eastern mountains, where the isolation ``gave their heritage time to reorganize itself,'' and led to the creation of bluegrass music, ``our first genuine folk orchestra.'' The final episode, ``Dreams and Songs of the Noble Old,'' features elderly balladeers and musicians who pass their music to the young. ``It's not preservation, it's process,'' Lomax said. ``It's keeping things going.'' Lomax, a research associate in anthropology for Columbia University and Hunter College, believes that our centralized electronic communications system is imposing ``standardized, mass-produced and cheapened cultures everywhere.'' Human beings and human affairs, he says, are 90 percent cultural. Our cultures give us ways of thinking, feeling, communicating and adapting to our environment that are unique to human beings. ``If those absolutely important things are ignored, of how we speciated, how we adapted to the planet, then we're going to lose something precious,'' he said. ``There won't be anywhere to go and no place to come home to.'' ``American Patchwork'' is a joint production of the University of North Carolina Center for Public Television, the National Endowment for the Arts's Media Program, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and PBS. Although the series wraps up Friday night, check your local listings carefully. North Carolina public TV spokeswoman Chancy Kapp said the success of the show was such that local rebroadcasts and even a PBS repeat may be in the cards.

Elsewhere in television ... ANOTHER SPIKE LEE JOINT: Filmmaker Spike Lee and actor Kadeem Hardison will be hosts of an unusual tribute to jazz late tonight (actually, very EARLY Saturday) on a special edition of NBC's ``Friday Night Videos.'' Lee selected most of the videos, including three from his newest feature film, ``Mo' Better Blues.'' The artists to be featured include Duke Ellington, Harry Connick Jr., B.B. King and Miles Davis. ``There's a role for all types of music,'' Lee said. ``Artists like Bobby Brown are OK and rap is OK, but young people need to know who Duke Ellington is. ... If you like something you hear on the show, go out to the record store and buy it. Support jazz.'' The show also will feature the broadcast premier of a new Public Enemy video of ``Fight the Power,'' the rap anthem of Lee's 1989 hit, ``Do the Right Thing.'' End Adv PM Fri Aug. 3

DOC.HEAD: Political Exiles Begin To Return
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Lindiwe Phillip, an anti-apartheid activist, fled into exile and expected to return triumphantly in a few months. That was 14 years ago. She came home in June, when the government granted temporary amnesty to dozens of African National Congress leaders so they could return and prepare for talks on ending apartheid, the racial policy that gives 5 million whites supremacy over the nation's 28 million blacks. Ms. Phillip, now 32, was among thousands of young blacks who left after the the 1976 student uprisings. Hundreds of people were killed in 1976 and the uprising helped shape a generation of militant activists. ``I thought (exile) would be very temporary, about three months,'' she said. ``As time went on, I had to grapple with the fact that I am in exile and that I can no longer go home.'' The ANC, South Africa's leading black opposition movement, has an estimated 20,000 members in exile and their return is one of the main obstacles to negotiations on power-sharing between blacks and whites. While Ms. Phillip was in exile in Zambia, her parents died. After she was in touch with her brother about the deaths, he was killed, and then her younger brother was found stabbed to death. She still does not know who killed either of them. ``I was just heartbroken,'' she said. ``I was almost on the verge of going nuts, crazy.'' During her exile, Ms. Phillip received military training and studied in Cuba and Tanzania. She also worked in the ANC Women's Section and the Department of Information and Publicity in Lusaka, Zambia, the ANC's exile headquarters. Her feelings were mixed when she returned in June with a group sent to recruit members for the ANC Women's League. ``We had so longed to be back home, but at the same time we were not sure it was the correct time,'' she said. African National Congress members began trickling out of South Africa when the organization was banned in 1960. President F.W. de Klerk lifted the 30-year ban in February, but the ANC has been hesitant to arrange a mass return of exiles without a guarantee of immunity from prosecution. A law passed in February empowers de Klerk to grant immunity, but so far he has given only temporary amnesty to a few dozen ANC leaders and officials. ANC and government delegations met for the first time in May and have been working on a document that would allow all exiles to return. Mathews Phosa, a lawyer who is in the ANC delegation, fled South Africa five years ago when he was told his life was in danger, but had to leave his wife and 3-year-old daughter behind. ``It is one of the most traumatic decisions one could take in one's life, a very, very painful experience _ shattering, terrible,'' he said. What sustained exiles, Phosa said, was unshakeable belief in the struggle to end apartheid. ``You don't know where you are going to exactly,'' he said. ``You are being uprooted from your loved ones. ... You know you are going to comrades, but that's not enough. You still have to make new friends.'' After the initial shock, life in exile becomes normal, the lawyer said: ``People get married, they fall in love, they work, and home is not something that haunts you every day.'' Finding a place to live is a major problem for returning exiles. There is a severe shortage of housing for blacks. Many will want to catch up on education they missed while fighting for Spear of the Nation, the ANC military wing, but black schools are overcrowded, qualified teachers are rare and violence has disrupted classes for years. Recent right-wing violence against blacks and against whites opposed to apartheid is a source of fear for returning exiles, Phosa said, ``but that can't be a reason for us not to come home.'' With ``the political space being there to organize and build our organization, it would be irresponsible for us not to deploy our cadres inside the country,'' he said. ``I think I am optimistic that we will get over the stumbling blocks. There is a willingness on the part of the government. They are very slow ... hesitant, but I think they are moving forward and they should be credited for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Economic Crisis Raises Concerns About Democracy
DOC.TEXT: In one day, the defense minister was replaced and 143 officers retired. It was peaceful, unlike many military changes in Latin America, but some Venezuelans wonder how long that will contine. Similar promotions and retirements have occurred often in Venezuela's 32 years as one of the stablest democracies of Latin America, with no problems or thought of a coup. Fears of the military taking a hand arise now because of an economic crisis that never seems to ease, a sharp increase in crime and reports of corruption scandals involving billions of dollars. A dozen prominent members of the governing Democratic Action party were cleared of corruption charges by the party's executive committee, which caused a storm of protest from opposition and independent politicians. On July 11 a public court issued arrest warrants on corruption charges for 12 other Democratic Action leaders, including former Interior Minister Jose Angel Ciliberto. All went into hiding before police arrived and most are believed to have left the country. Jose Vicente Rangel, a political analyst and former congressman, said on a television program that a coup was possible even after such a long period of democracy. He quoted surveys conducted by ``organizations of the utmost reliability'' as indicating 20 percent of Venezuelans openly favored a military takeover and another 20 percent were indifferent. ``Venezuelans always supported democracy, but now democracy is being associated with evils committed by political parties and politicians,'' he told an Associated Press reporter. ``The surveys mean four out of 10 Venezuelans are potential supporters of a coup d'etat.'' Luis Herrera Campins, a Social Christian who was president in 1978-83, said democracy in Venezuela ``is not 100 percent guaranteed ... especially if dissatisfaction and social protest keep growing.'' Others see coup rumors as a warning, but not a real possibility. ``It could be a way to wish evil on the thing blamed for so many frustrations: the government,'' said Teodoro Petkoff of the Socialist Movement party. Venezuelan leaders learned early last year that dissatisfaction can turn to violence. At least 300 people were killed in riots after President Carlos Andres Perez administered an economic shock treatment that included raising bus fares 30 percent and ending food subsidies. Perez slowed the program because of the riots, and after 18 months, 72 percent of Venezuelans still spend 70 percent of their incomes on food. Unemployment is slightly more than 10 percent by official figures, but at least 14 percent according to labor unions. When the underemployed are added, the rate is well above 50 percent. The bloated bureacracy has not been affected, however. It provides jobs for 1.2 million Venezuelans, or 20 percent of the nation's labor force. ``At least 30 percent of our population suffers from malnutrition,'' said Jose Curiel, a member of Congress from the opposition Social Christians. ``Our hospitals simply don't work. Water is scarce. Public services are collapsing.'' In its attempt at economic reform, the government said most of the 400-odd public companies would be sold quickly to private investors. Those companies are blamed for most of the nation's $35 billion foreign debt and chronic deficits estimated at up to $2 billion annually. No significant company has yet been sold, partly due to fears of massive layoffs and labor unrest. State-owned companies provide jobs for members of political parties, mainly Democratic Action and the Social Christians, and are a major base of union power. The Venezuelan Labor Confederation recently warned the government against layoffs at the main steel plant, which has 18,000 employees. Technical studies say at least 3,000 should be dismissed if the plant is to stop losing money. Unions describe the studies as ``socially and politically destabilizing.'' Many Venezuelans see increasing crime as an outgrowth of unemployment. In two recent cases, thieves killed the son of a former government minister and gunmen took over the home of the Argentine ambassador. Tony Bianchi, editor of The Daily Journal in Caracas. said 25 of the newspaper's 80 staff members had been attacked in recent months. They included Jules Waldman, the founder and chairman, who died of injuries inflicted by thieves who invaded his home in June. Waldman, 77, was a New Yorker who spent more than 40 years in Venezuela. Robberies and killings have become so frequent, Rangel said, that ``Venezuelan society is defenseless. Nobody is safe, not even at home, and streets are a trap for all.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, Aug. 10

DOC.HEAD: I Don't Care Who You Call Me, but Get My Title Right
DOC.TEXT: Every Malay who is anybody has a title, from the duli yang maha mulia seri paduka baginda yang di-pertuan agong _ that's the king _ to each haji and hajah who makes the Moslem pilgrimage to Mecca. Tun, tan seri and datuk are among the many hereditary or conferred titles borne by leading citizens. Proper ways of addressing a Malay are diverse and complicated. Family names are relatively unimportant as long as the title is used correctly. Improper usage may cause offense. Some titles are gained at birth, others given as rewards for service to government or nation. To the ordinary encik (mister), titles and forms of address can be confusing. The king's title means, approximately, ``his most glorious majesty who is raised most high.'' In English, ``your majesty'' is usually enough. The queen, or seri baginda raja permaisuri agong, also is ``your majesty.'' Malaysia is unique in having a monarchy that rotates among royal families. Nine of the 13 states have royal families, whose leaders take turns being king of the entire nation for five years. Passing the throne around solved a sticky protocol problem when Malaysia shed colonial ties with Britain in 1957. None of the nine state rulers would have been accepted by the other eight as permanent king and Tunku Abdul Rahman, who was prime minister, divised the method of sharing glory. Children of the state rulers usually are called tunku or tengku, loosely equivalent to prince or princess. Tunku Rahman, for example, is of royal descent. Niks and megats are those with royal blood on the mother's side. Syeds and their female counterparts, sharifahs, claim to be directly descended from the prophet Mohammed, from royal families of the Malay archipelago, or both. A man honored for distinguished service to the nation becomes a tun and his wife a toh puan. The title is Malaysia's highest order of chivalry, limited to 25 living men. When Prime Minister Dato Seri Dr. Mahathir Mohamad retires, officials say, he probably will become Tun Mahathir. He is a medical doctor and was made a dato seri years ago for his contributions to public life. The non-hereditary title tan seri is given to the recipient of either of Malaysia's two second-highest orders of chivalry for non-royals. Datuks, and the variants datuk seri and dato, are numerous and their wives are datins. The title is non-hereditary and its basic meaning is grandfather. In higher social circles, practically everybody is a datuk, whether Malay, Chinese or Indian. A common compliment is to call a man dato before he has been so designated. Few object, except the very modest. The highlight of the king's official birthday, celebrated on the first Wednesday of June, is the conferment of hundreds of awards and titles. Hundreds more are issued each year by the 13 states, with datuk in the majority. Tuan means sir in Malay, and is used informally to address an elderly person or someone of prominence or wealth. Tuan yang terutama, the Malay translation of excellency, is applied to heads of diplomatic missions and the governors of the four states without royal families. Puan, or madame, often is used to refer to married women. A single women is called cik. Haji and hajah are the titles for men and women who have made a pilgrimage, or haj, to Mecca and performed certain acts required on a pilgrimage. In Malay usage, bin means ``son of'' and binte means ``daughter of.'' The part of the name before it is the given name, and the part after is the name of the person's father. Names can be as confusing as titles. The prime minister is Mahathir Mohamad, the information minister is Mohamed Rahmat and thousands of others spell the name Mohamat, Muhamat, Muhhammad and even Mohd. In 1988, the goverment decreed the official version of the prophet's name to be Muhammad. Those already born and named with other spellings were excused from compliance.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Advertising Giant Holds All the Cards
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto TOK2 of July 31
DOC.TEXT: In the world of advertising, Dentsu is king. In Japan, it's also a kingmaker. Dentsu, which grew out of Japan's wartime propaganda machine, controls most government public relations and the largest chunk of all domestic advertising. But critics charge Dentsu also controls people's minds, an accusation that isn't exactly refuted by the company's own corporate credo: ``Manipulate those around you. In the end, the manipulative rise way above the manipulated.'' ``I can't think of any other institution in the world that has the kind of molding power in society that Dentsu does,'' said Karel van Wolferen, author of ``The Enigma of Japanese Power.'' The way in which the firm uses its power underscores the role of big coporations in general in postwar Japan. ``Large Japanese corporations ... have a certain interest in social control. There's a strong sense of responsibility to maintain the social order,'' said Wolferen, a Dutch journalist who has lived in Japan for 25 years. One recent example of Dentsu's powers came last year when the nation was preparing for its first sales tax. Although the loudest protests against the levy came from housewives, Dentsu Eye, a Dentsu subsidiary that focuses on the woman's point of view, promoted the tax. ``This was because a group of Dentsu Eye executives came to a personal decision that the consumption tax was necessary,'' said Naoe Wakita, Dentsu Eye president. Her company designed a newspaper campaign that featured Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto _ because he is considered handsome _ soliciting women's opinions on the tax. The once vigorous movement to revise the tax has all but died. Dentsu, with an army of 6,000 employees and earnings last year of $1.31 billion, bills itself as a total communications company involved in market research, product testing, sales promotion, public relations, mega-event planning and media brokering. What the company's slick brochures don't say is that Dentsu dominates the mass media in Japan through its interlocking web of subsidiaries and contractors which, among other things, produce television programs and the ratings for those programs. ``To an American, that sounds like having your hand in the cookie jar, but it's common for large Japanese companies to be affiliated with many other companies,'' said Caroline Yamashita, an American who worked at Dentsu's Tokyo headquarters for two years. Dentsu spokesman Ken Kusuhara said, ``Dentsu grew up in the postwar period with today's large corporations so it's natural that there's a close connection between us. We're like children who grew up together.'' Dentsu's influence with the media is striking. Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens recently tried to place ads in major Japanese newspapers accusing Toyota Motor Corp. and other automakers of forcing high prices on consumers through collusive business practices. Pickens claimed that Dentsu, on client Toyota's behalf, used its clout with the media to block the ads. His lawyer, Kanji Ishizumi, said Dentsu told one of the newspapers that members of the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association were ``very concerned'' about the ad appearing in newspapers. The ads, as originally submitted by Pickens, named Toyota, Nissan Motor Co. Ltd., and Honda Motor Co. Ltd. as the collusive culprits. But when they were published a week after Pickens went public with his charges, the carmakers' names were missing. Dentsu executive director Teruyoshi Kastsurada dismisses Pickens' charges. ``Dentsu does not have that kind of power. And Japanese newspapers are not so weak in their editorial positions that they would accept whatever Dentsu tells them to do,'' he said. But Japanese magazines have also accused Dentsu of strictly controlling news reports of milk contaminated by a major client and reports of deaths linked to a cold medicine made by a client. A Dentsu executive boasted in a 1971 speech that Japan's largest newspaper, the Yomiuri Shimbun, after having invited consumer advocate Ralph Nader to Japan, heeded a warning from Dentsu by toning down coverage of the visit. That executive, Shohei Kogure, is now Dentsu's president. Dentsu handles close to 25 percent of all advertising budgets in Japan, placing more than 20 percent of ads in major newspapers, and major chunks of advertising in magazines and on prime time television. Dentsu's influence also extends to TV and the big screen. The company and its affiliates produce a number of high-profile TV programs and movies. It often uses the stars to offer clients advertising tie-ins, merchandise sales and other promotional opportunities. Then there's Dentsu's role as a media broker. It buys blocks of media time and sells it to advertisers, thereby deciding who can sponsor a TV program and when. For public relations work, Dentsu has been the top choice of the long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party since Japan's first general election after the U.S. occupation. Part of the company's power stems from its onetime merger with the monopolistic Domei news service, which churned out government propaganda between 1936 and 1945. Of Japan's two major news agencies today, Kyodo News Service owns 28.3 percent of Dentsu stock and Jiji Press owns 20.1 percent. With 90 percent of its business in Japan, Dentsu's one weakness is a lack of international experience, observers say. But the company has expansion plans. Since 1987, it has operated in 19 countries as HDM in partnership with U.S. advertising giant Young & Rubicam Inc. and France's Eurocom. It also formed a joint venture in 1988 with the American public relations firm Burson-Marsteller. Dentsu executives say they want to expand into countries where their clients, mostly Japanese companies that have gone multinational, are doing business.
