DOC.HEAD: Visitors Find Americans Friendly, Cities Bustling, but Softball Boring
DOC.TEXT: The electrical worker from Czechoslovakia says he must have met a hundred Americans in his 2{ months in America _ but everyone was too busy to become real friends. Whenever he talked to the owner of the Virginia publishing company where he interned, ``I was seeing that the time was running in his head.'' The young lawyer from Poland bemoaned Americans' lack of knowledge about Europe _ or even about America. In an after-hours competition with his fellow summer clerks at a prestigious Washington law firm, he was able to name 45 states of the union. The best any of his new Harvard-educated friends could do was 36 or 37. These young East Europeans _ a translator, a civil engineer, a law professor, a legal advisor to the Hungarian parliament, a Polish radio and television worker and others, many of them with a history of dissidence _ had been in America since mid-May, learning the ropes of capitalism and democracy. They worked in banks, in bookstores, in congressional offices and state government, chiefly in Washington and North Carolina, side-by-side with American counterparts in a program run by the non-profit National Forum Foundation. Recently, they spent the morning discussing what they liked, what they disliked and what surprised them. Piotr Kochanski, 28, a lawyer, was the Pole who outshined the other summer clerks at Hogan & Hartson by listing 45 states ``and all the presidents of the U.S. in the 20th Century.'' He played softball with the firm's young lawyers, but found it ``a boring game.'' What dismayed him was how little Americans in turn knew about Europe. ``They know nothing about our country, our history, our culture,'' he said. ``I was asked very funny questions many times,'' agreed Mirek Kleber, a novice Polish businessman who speaks Russian, French and German and interned with a bank in Lumberton, N.C. ``Do we have television in Poland? Do we have cars?'' On the other hand, Kochanski marveled, ``Americans can organize something in an hour. Everybody has confidence in the others. Everybody can trust one another. I love it _ this ability for working together.'' And he was struck by how Americans can tear down a perfectly fine building ``and in two months a new beautiful building can go up.'' ``We have all this history in Poland,'' he said. ``I love this history _ but I think we can learn from your creativity, your pragmatism, this modern mentality.'' ``I am from a city one thousand years old,'' said Beata Kalczynska-Gasic, a civil engineer from Krakow. In Raleigh, N.C., where she worked with the state Department of Transportation, she was shown a picture of the city. What struck her was that no building was more than 40 years old. ``Americans seem to be running toward the future and don't look back,'' she said. But, she asked, ``Where is the soul in your cities?'' Kalliope Bakirdzi, 31, press secretary for a new political party in Hungary, the Alliance of Free Democrats, worked in the office of the lieutenant governor of North Carolina and observed the Democratic Senate primary campaign. She liked the civility of American politics, the acceptance of compromise. ``Whatever you are _ Republican or Democrat _ you know there will always be Republicans and Democrats and you have to get along with the other side,'' she said. In Hungary, she said, ``We hate each other much more than is needed for normal political life.'' She was impressed, too, that American politicians can spend 80 percent of their time talking to, meeting, dealing with the voters. ``Our politicians never cared about the people,'' she said. But she was puzzled by the fuss over flag-burning in this country. Recalling a television news report, she said, she was ``a little shocked how they allowed the Ku Klux Klan to march but they try to ban burning the flag. If you burn a flag, you don't hurt anybody, but the Ku Klux Klan can hurt people.'' Daria Golebiowska, 22, advertising director for a Warsaw fashion house, interned at Roll Call, a Capitol Hill newspaper. She liked the way people assumed responsibility without direction. ``Everybody's working away,'' she said, describing a newsroom's chaos. ``Everything seems to be so loose. People are coming in and out and talking on the telephone. And suddenly a newspaper comes out! ``This responsibility for their own work gives people a feeling they are really important.'' Jan Lamper, 35, a Czechoslovak worker at an electrical plant, translator and former dissident, said he thinks Americans work too hard, much harder than he expected. His friendships didn't have time to develop. ``People are too busy to get involved deeper,'' he said. ``They're working all the time.'' Andrzej Slaski, 35, a sanitary engineer from Poland, was struck by the friendliness of the people of Raleigh. ``A lot of people in the street say, `hello,' `good morning,' `hi,''' he said. In Poland, he said, that would happen only in a village. And he couldn't get over of the purity of the water that emerged from the modern North Carolina sewerage treatment plant he had visited _ 99.8 percent pure, cleaner than river water. He kept saying, ``99.8 percent clean!'' Gabor Nagy, 29, legal adviser to Hungary's Alliance of Young Democrats and teacher of sociology, worked in a congressman's office and told of seeing how easily someone was fired for incompetence. He wasn't dismayed. ``That's good!'' he exclaimed. ``This is a competitive society. Our society was too egalitarian, socialist.'' Nagy marvelled at the separation of powers, the disdain of the legislative branch toward the executive branch of government. ``People's attitude toward power is not to obey,'' he said. ``It is almost a kind of distrust of power. Lawmaking is always a compromise, negotiations between different factions, finding a common answer. This is very inspiring.''

DOC.HEAD: Mary Wickes is Rectory Housekeeper for Father Dowling'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mary Wickes plays a no-nonsense rectory housekeeper in ABC's ``Father Dowling Mysteries,'' but that's nothing new. Wickes has appeared in nine series, five of them as housekeepers. Wickes has kept house on television for Ronald Colman, Ezio Pinza and Peter Lind Hayes. She was the Irish housekeeper in a production of ``The Canterville Ghost''; she was the original English nanny ``Mary Poppins'' in a 1949 special. Her ``Father Dowling'' character, Marie, is the kind of role _ crusty, outspoken, yet totally endearing _ that Wickes has honed to perfection. Tom Bosley stars as the crime-solving priest Father Dowling, Tracy Nelson is Sister Steve and James Stephens is Father Prestwick. Wickes said she sometimes gets letters from Catholic priests. ``They always say, `Boy, have we got somebody in the rectory like you,''' she said. ``She's no dope. She tells you what she thinks. She and Father Prestwick don't see eye-to-eye. He's apple-polishing the bishop, and she keeps him in line,'' Wickes said. Occasionally, Marie _ admittedly, a supporting character _ gets to play a more central role in the detective work, and Wickes relishes the opportunity. ``I hope we can keep it up because it's fun,'' she said. Of course, Wickes has played roles with a religious bent before _ she played nuns in two movies with Rosalind Russell. She was Sister Clarissa in ``The Trouble With Angels'' and ``Where Angels Go ... Trouble Follows.'' But the bread and butter of her career has been maids, with an occasional sortie as a nurse. She was Miss Preen, called ``Miss Bedpan'' by the intimidating Sheridan Whiteside, played by Monty Woolley, in ``The Man Who Came to Dinner,'' on Broadway and in the movie, her first. She also played the role on radio and television with Fred Allen, Edward Everett Horton and Orson Welles. She was a nurse in two series, ``Julia'' and ``Doc.'' And she was the most decorated nurse in the Korean War in an episode of ``M-A-S-H'' written for her. Her career has been a long one, and despite the maid-nun-nurse typecasting, a varied one. She was only 18 when she graduated from Washington University in St. Louis and joined the Berkshire Playhouse in Massachusetts for seven seasons. Her father wouldn't allow it until he had ``auditioned'' the director. Her stage career has had many stops, including the St. Louis Municipal Opera, where she's appeared in 14 production; it is the topic of the master's thesis she is writing at UCLA. ``The Man Who Came to Dinner'' was just one of five plays by George S. Kaufman in which she had roles; the dean of comic playwrights once called her ``my favorite comedienne.'' Wickes has appeared in 44 movies. The most recent is the as-yet-unreleased ``Postcards from the Edge,'' the film version of Carrie Fisher's autobiographical novel which features Meryl Street, Shirley MacLaine and Richard Dreyfuss. And she has been a television mainstay since the earliest days of the medium, a time she remembers with both fondness and discomfort. The lights were so hot, she says, that ``they used to give us salt tablets.'' She recently paid $300 for a kinescope of ``Mary Poppins,'' presented live on ``Studio One,'' and reports that, ``You can hear the cameras and cables moving on the floor.'' Some of her shows are still well-known _ ``Dennis the Menace'' and ``Julia,'' among them _ but others have been buried by the sands of time: ``Bonino,'' ``Inside U.S.A. With Chevrolet,'' ``The Peter Lind Hayes Show,'' ``The Halls of Ivy,'' and ``The Gertrude Berg Show,'' among them. She remembers ``Bonino,'' which lasted 3{ months in 1953: ``Pinza played an Italian opera star, and I was his housekeeper. What else? Pinza had been in this country 26 years, but they had to translate the jokes into Italian for him before he could understand them.'' She also has been a guest on other shows _ ``Make Room for Daddy,'' ``Sesame Street'' (she played the Plant Lady), ``Match Game'' and the various Lucille Ball shows. She and Lucy were close friends, and says some of Lucy's off-camera adventures could be as funny as those on screen. ``Once Lucy and I went shopping _ this was for real, not on the show,'' she said. ``She brought the Marquis Chimps with her. One of the chimps was a baby in diapers and another was an alcoholic. Lucy was shopping for sheets, and we had these chimps parading along with us.''

DOC.HEAD: Darlanne Fluegel Is New Woman Police Partner on NBC's `Hunter'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Darlanne Fluegel was about to accept another series offer from NBC when she heard a new partner was being sought for Fred Dryer on ``Hunter.'' ``It had to happen for me very fast,'' she said. ``If not, I'd have to accept the other show. I knew this was going to be my role. I went into the meeting and _ pow _ I got it. Fred was very supportive. He went with me to the network to audition.'' Fluegel plays Officer Joanne Molenski, a member of the Los Angeles Police Department's Metro Squad and Sgt. Rick Hunter's new partner. She replaces Stepfanie Kramer, who quit her role as Sgt. Dee Dee McCall after six seasons. It's probably a good thing Fluegel got the role. The other show hasn't yet shown up on the NBC schedule. Fluegel, a former model, played Dennis Farina's wife in the NBC series ``Crime Story,'' and has been in such movies as ``Once Upon a Time in America,'' ``The Eyes of Laura Mars,'' ``To Live and Die in L.A.,'' ``Tough Guys'' and ``Freeway.'' She was cast in ``Hunter'' after returning from Canada and a guest role on CBS' ``Wiseguy.'' ``There are so few good, interesting roles for women on television,'' she said. ``You have to take what's available and make it interesting. I told myself, `If a role comes along with screen time, I'm going to take it.' This was it. ``I like the feeling at `Hunter.' It's like working with friends. Too often when you walk on a set, it's every man for himself.'' In the upcoming fall season, Hunter has been transferred from homicide to the Metro Squad, where he's teamed up with Molenski. ``Fred and I will work out how our partnership goes,'' she said. ``We didn't want it to be the typical `I don't like you, you don't like me, all of a sudden we're friends' thing. I think a lot of relationships depend on the day. They can bounce a lot of ways. It'll be strictly a professional relationship, because a policeman has to know that he can depend on his partner. ``Being in the Metro Squad will allow us to work on a wide variety of cases, not just homicides,'' she said. Before beginning her role, Fluegel spent time talking to women police officers and riding with them on patrol. ``I've never played a police officer before,'' she said. ``I went to several different police departments because I wanted to see how different police forces handled things. I'm usually on the other side of the law. I was a cop's wife on `Crime Story.' On `Wiseguy,' I was a madam.'' Fluegel grew up in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and Binghamton, N.Y., where she wanted to be an actress before she even started school. ``Once, I almost said I wanted to be an actress, but I knew I'd be ridiculed,'' she said. ``So I said ballerina. In high school, I was so shy I never even considered going out for school plays. My aspiration was to go to London. I graduated high school early so I could go to New York. London was a little out of my reach. All I had was fare to New York.'' Fluegel studied acting in New York, and worked as a model with the Ford Agency. Her first film role was in ``The Eyes of Laura Mars,'' in which she played a model. ``I got a lot of offers,'' she said, ``but dramatic Darlane was a Stella Adler student and said no to everything. I was such a snob. I expected the roles to be better. I wouldn't play roles where they treated women in a demeaning way. I didn't like the way they treated women in L.A. _ `Here, baby, I've got a script for you.' ``When I finally did move to Los Angeles, it was after spending four months in Japan. I wanted to get away from all influences. I'd just ended a relationship. I gave up acting.'' That was seven years ago. Now, she lives on a five-acre horse ranch with her husband, actor Michael Moore, whom she met in an acting class. They have a 2-year-old daughter, Jenna Carey. In addition to her new role in ``Hunter,'' Fluegel will be before audiences in the not-yet-released movie ``No Cause For Alarm,'' which also stars Michael Nouri and Charles Durning. It was made in Yugoslavia. ``It's a romantic adventure and I get involved in the action,'' she said. ``I play a pilot.''

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Women Fighting for a Right They've Taken for Granted
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Marie is a 33-year-old school teacher and the mother of two young boys. She is happily married, lives in a cozy two-story house, loves children and has had an abortion. ``It was a painful choice ... but it was the only choice,'' said Marie, whose husband supported her decision. When Louisiana's legislature voted last month to foreclose that choice, passing what would have been the nation's toughest abortion law, Marie and others were forced to examine life before and after abortion was legalized. Many for the first time imagined what they, their daughters and granddaughters would do if the option no longer existed. Their vigils, marches, petitions and letters reached Gov. Buddy Roemer, and his veto secured abortion rights, at least momentarily _ Louisiana lawmakers are pondering an override, and abortion rights supporters are apprehensive. ``We've been fighting for our lives,'' Marie said. Marie, who like others interviewed for this story spoke on condition of anonymity, was the victim of protracted childhood incest. With the birth of each of her sons, long-suppressed memories crept closer to the surface. The fresh-scrubbed redhead became increasingly depressed and alcoholic. Her home near this small town about 25 miles from New Orleans became a cage in which she sat, sometimes cradling her husband's revolver. Doctors warned that a third child could trigger irreversible psychosis. ``It wasn't anything either of us wanted to do, but we already had two children who needed a father and a mother,'' her husband said. ``She couldn't have come out of another pregnancy without permanent damage to her psyche.'' She had the abortion four years ago. Had the bill initially proposed by Louisiana lawmakers been law at the time, the doctor who performed Marie's abortion would have faced up to 10 years in prison and fines of up to $100,000. The original bill made no exceptions for rape or incest; Roemer vetoed it. The second bill excepted pregnancies caused by aggravated rape and incest reported to police and a physician within a week; Roemer rejected it, as well. ``Some common-sense, decent exceptions should be made,'' he said. The legislature is considering whether to reconvene for a first-ever emergency override session Aug. 18. Some lawmakers have proposed trying to revive the first bill, but the state's constitution may prohibit the move. While they sympathize with the plights of women like Marie, opponents of abortion in this heavily Roman Catholic and fundamentalist state are pressing the legislature to override. They say it's a mistake for women to assume that terminating a problematic pregnancy will ease their despair. ``Abortion is not solving anything,'' said Phyllis Osborne, who today still regrets the illegal abortion she underwent in 1970. ``We have to get to the heart of the problem of why a woman chooses abortion: because she feels she has no alternative.'' Anti-abortion activists offer adoption as an alternative that protects both the mother and her unborn child. ``With abortion, there are two victims: the baby is killed and the woman is wounded,'' said Linda Jefferson, who cannot bear children. The 37-year-old woman had an hysterectomy more than a decade ago following complications from the second of two abortions. ``I was ignorant, immature and very uneducated about abortion,'' said Jefferson, who founded a pregnancy counseling service affiliated with the Roman Catholic church two years ago. ``(Abortion providers) tell women it doesn't hurt. But it does hurt _ emotionally, spiritually and physically.'' Other women, such as the victims of rape or incest, say the wounds already inflicted could go no deeper. Jacquelyn's 15-year-old daughter was raped last year. The mother knew members of her interdenominational church in a Baton Rouge suburb would not approve, but abortion was the only way to keep her baby from having a baby. ``Her virginity was taken from her. I didn't want her life taken too,'' said Jacquelyn. She herself is a 34-year-old single mother, who until recently was living on about $130 a month in government aid. Her daughter ``has plans. She's always wanted to be a doctor. (The pregnancy) would have shattered that dream,'' said Jacquelyn. ``If she were being permissive, maybe I wouldn't have considered abortion. But under the circumstances I felt _ we felt _ it was the only choice.'' Jacquelyn said nothing could have stopped her from finding her daughter help ``somewhere, somehow.'' If abortions had been outlawed in Louisiana, she might have taken the girl to Mississippi or Florida. That's if she could have scraped money together to make the trip. Many women who could not afford that option would likely resort to the illegal and dangerous methods that prevailed prior to the Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision, which restricted the right of the states to outlaw abortion. A ban on abortions ``would just make them deadly,'' said Dorothy West, 69. She remembers how it was in 1950, the year she nearly bled to death following an illegal abortion. Dorothy was a young mother of two trying to run her deceased husband's bulldozing business when she discovered she was pregnant by a man she would later marry. She tried every way she knew how to induce a miscarriage: quinine, scalding baths, gin and pills prescribed by back-alley doctors. ``I don't believe in baby killing,'' said the Roman Catholic grandmother. ``I'm not even for capital punishment. But my back was against the wall and I was frightened. I was thinking about the two children already living.'' Three decades later, her 35-year-old daughter Velvet West also had an abortion. She too cited concerns for the three children she already had. Her father _ Dorothy's third husband _ was an alcoholic, given to furniture-throwing rages. She felt those same impulses herself, and she was frightened. ``I was afraid I would hurt my own children,'' said Velvet. She had an abortion, sought counseling and has since remarried and had another son. ``It was the best parenting decision I ever made. I was a ticking time bomb.'' Not all women cite rape or psychological scars as reason for abortions; abortion opponents says the procedure is too often a form of birth control, a ``quick fix'' in the words of Linda Jefferson. Michelle, 25, has ended four accidental pregnancies with abortions: ``Two were out of irresponsibility. Two were failed birth control,'' she said. ``If I hadn't had access, I would have tried to self-abort ... or suicide,'' she said, blowing cigarette smoke into the rafters of the New Orleans nightclub where she works. ``I did not want to be a mother at 17.'' And such choices, said Norma McCorvey, are what the battle is all about. McCorvey, a native of Louisiana, is known in the legal canon as Jane Roe _ the woman whose challenge ultimately overturned the nation's abortion laws, though she herself carried her child to term and gave her up for adoption. McCorvey, 42, traveled from her home in California to Baton Rouge to join the fight against the Louisiana bill. She feels ``the hands of time being turned back'' on her Supreme Court victory. ``It hurts. It hurts real bad,'' she says. ``It's not like anybody is pro-abortion. But a lot of women really aren't capable of (raising) children,'' she said. ``I didn't have a choice.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug. 5

DOC.HEAD: Debate Mounting Over Acute Reactions to Chemicals
DOC.TEXT: A whiff of perfume or a breeze from the neighbor's lawn can leave chemically sensitive people speechless. And they are becoming increasingly vocal about it. They complain they're getting sick _ very sick _ from everyday exposure to common levels of chemicals in the home, office and environment. Chemical sensitivity can leave sufferers vulnerable to headaches, burning in the throat and lungs, and a paralyzing disorientation that can render one incapable of speaking. Skeptics in the insurance, medical and chemical industries say they are not convinced the misery isn't all in the sufferers' heads. The condition has yet to win recognition in those circles, or the insurance benefits that would result. But some scientists insist society is seeing the first casualties of the proliferation of chemicals. Since World War II, annual U.S. production of synthetic organic chemicals has exploded from less than 1 billion pounds to 273 billion by 1988. ``These may indeed be the canaries,'' said Claudia Miller, a University of Texas Health Science Center allergist and immunologist who co-wrote a study on the malady for the Department of Health of New Jersey, the state with the nation's second-biggest chemical industry, behind Texas. ``We don't understand the mechanisms,'' she said. ``It may be neurological or immunological. It may be biochemical.'' Whatever the mechanism, the effect can be dramatic, say experts and those who suffer from chemical sensitivity, also known as environmental illness. The illness often begins with a single exposure _ installation of a new carpet in the office or an accidental release of toxic materials from a sewage plant _ that seems to traumatize the body into a permanent, hypersensitive state, sufferers say. What follows is a bewildering array of symptoms and a search for diagnosis and treatment. Patients try to avoid contact with the pesticides, plastics and building materials they fear will trigger an episode. Some sufferers find breathing relief with use of adrenaline, but drugs are not too useful because many sufferers react to pharmaceuticals. How many people are affected still is unknown. According to the New Jersey report, the National Academy of Sciences suggested about 15 percent of the population has heightened sensitivity to chemicals, though fewer people face intense symptoms. But an academy spokeswoman later said the estimate was off-the-cuff and should not have been cited by the authors. The medical establishment remains dubious. Psychiatrist Carroll Brodsky of the University of California, San Francisco, who has written extensively on the subject, said it is more likely a psychological disability. ``If you believe you couldn't walk outside or walk anywhere where there were exhaust fumes, you would be disabled. If that is the issue, have I seen people like this who are disabled? Certainly,'' Brodsky said. ``Now, whether they have anything wrong with them physically is quite another matter. ... If physical doctors can't find anything physically wrong with them, it must be within the realm of the psyche.'' Some credible, neutral organizations have given at least some credence to a physical basis for the disorder. The Environmental Protection Agency, in a report to Congress on indoor air pollution, urges financing for research on chemical sensitivity. The Congressional Research Service calls chemical sensitivity one of the consequences of poor indoor air quality. And the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development has ruled that people with environmental illness who live in subsidized housing cannot be forced to have their homes exterminated with chemicals. Some doubters blame malingering employees aiming for workers compensation benefits. They also point to sufferers' subconscious fear of workplace pressures and to fright over frequent media reports about chemicals. Clinical ecologists, doctors who specialize in chemical sensitivity, also have met with skepticism. Mainstream allergists, for example, have urged the Health Care Financing Administration to deny reimbursement for clinical ecologists' work. But Ms. Miller and her co-author on the New Jersey report contend the psychological explanation ignores the stunning similarity of triggering exposures and symptoms reported. ``They're all so diverse, yet they're all coming up with the same thing. Is it all psychological when everyone is coming up with the same symptoms?'' they ask. She and co-author Nicholas Ashford of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology agree that more research is needed. Among dozens of proposals to federal and state governments, they want to set up an ``environmental unit,'' a contaminant-free chamber in which subjects would be placed and observed as chemicals were introduced. New Jersey officials have not said what recommendations, if any, they will follow. So far, the scientists have found four groups of people most prone to chemical sensitivity. They are industrial workers, occupants of well-insulated, poorly ventilated offices, residents of contaminated communities, and people exposed to chemicals in household air. ``It is widespread in nature and is not limited to what some observers would describe as malingering workers, hysterical housewives and workers experiencing mass psychogenic illness,'' the report says. Believers in chemical sensitivity as a physical illness say the skeptics fear an ominous message: If people are getting sick from the chemical-laden world, it bodes ill for a huge industry. It might mean constructing buildings with better ventilation, settling for a less-than-perfect lawn or scrubbing toilets with baking soda. And, an industry briefing paper warns, more formal recognition of chemical sensitivity could bring a torrent of lawsuits and insurance obligations. ``The primary impact on society would be the huge cost associated with the legitimization of environmental illness,'' says the paper by the Chemical Manufacturers Association. ``It would mean we had a new and very different problem to deal with,'' said Gordon Strickland, a Chemical Manufacturers Association vice president. ``(But) we have looked through the data and looked through the arguments ... and found nothing supportive'' of a physical explanation. Mary Lamielle, a chemical sensitivity sufferer from Voorhees, N.J., and leader of a national group working for official recognition of the condition, said economics, more than science, is behind the industry skepticism. Lamielle pressured her state senator, Lee Laskin, who in turn got the Department of Health to do the study. Her group has roughly 2,000 members, mostly sufferers.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Leads Chemical Sensitivity Sufferers' Movement
With BC-EXP--Chemical Sensitivity, b0904
DOC.TEXT:
After years of searching, Mary Lamielle figured out what was making her so miserably, dramatically sick. It was the world. Ms. Lamielle, who lives in Voorhees, is chemically sensitive, a condition that is not recognized by the medical establishment or the insurance industry but that sufferers say can be debilitating. She founded and leads the National Center for Environmental Health Strategies, a 2,000-member organization working to win recognition and help for victims. For herself, she struggles with an isolation forced by the nausea, vertigo and breathing difficulties she said will occur if she subjects herself to perfume, gasoline vapors, even her new car. Her crusade began six years ago, with the belief that her worsening illness had something to do with malfunctions at the nearby sewage treatment plant, exhaust from idling diesel trucks at the local chicken processing plant and other things around her. ``The property around us was just unbearable,'' Ms. Lamielle said. ``So my own involvement became a way of self-protection.'' DOC.HEAD: Archaeologists Unearthing More About Vikings
DOC.TEXT: The center of the Viking world 1,000 years ago is under siege by archaeologists who are trying to pry secrets from beneath the pastures that now cover this farming island. Historians believe that Birka, a settlement on an island in Lake Maleren just west of Stockholm, was home to about 1,000 people. The site now is covered with grids, in which workers dig by hand through the seven feet of dirt covering the settlement. Two sections have been excavated since the dig began this spring and although the findings have not been startling, they hint at a wealth of artifacts to come. The project is to last until 1994. Animal bones, remnants of meals, colorful beads, combs and household utensils that could shed light on Viking home life have turned up. Archaeologists also found Arab coins, evidence of how the Vikings roamed. The Vikings thrived from the late 8th century to the 11th century. Their raids struck terror throughout Europe, and their spirit of adventure drove them far afield, to Iceland and North America. Birka has been recognized since the Middle Ages as the cradle of Christianity in Sweden. It was here that Ansgar, a missionary from Bremen and later bishop of Bremen-Hamburg, first preached around 830. But while some Viking towns flourished, Birka was deserted at the end of the first millennium. Where traders once exchanged goods from all of the known world, sheep graze in meadows and on grassy mounds containing the graves of Viking traders. Historians say Vikings from the Birka region, a people known then as Rus, sailed eastward across the Baltic Sea and lent their name to the land of Russia. They reached the Caspian Sea. Although Birka was the Vikings' center, it has remained mostly unexamined while extensive digs were conducted at Viking settlements in York, England; Dublin, Ireland; Hedeby, West Germany; Kaupang, Norway; and Staraya Ladoga, Soviet Union. The Viking era generally is regarded as having begun in 792, the year a raiding party attacked the Lindisfarne monastery on Britain's North Sea Coast. But evidence could be uncovered indicating that the era began earlier, said Bjorn Ambrosiani of Stockholm's Museum of National History. The only previous excavation of Birka was conducted 100 years ago by Hjalmar Stolpe, a zoologist who came in search of insect fossils in 1871 and stayed 24 years to dig up many of the 2,500 Viking age graves. Stolpe touched very little of the town of Birka, which stood at the focus of a heroic chapter in Scandinavian history. Ambrosiani and other experts are eager to find out how it was built and developed. The project is being financed by one of Sweden's richest men, industrialist Gad Rausing. ``If you go digging you should have proper resources, otherwise you do more damage than good,'' Ambrosiani said. Rausing, who has a doctorate in archaeology, said he pursuaded the board of directors of his family's Tetra-Pak packaging company to donate $2.4 million to the project for high-tech assistance _ computers to register the findings daily, and video equipment to document the objects.

DOC.HEAD: How Safe Is Your Kitchen?
DOC.TEXT: Here is the third of five quizzes from the book, ``The Tufts University Guide to Total Nutrition,'' by Stanley Gershoff, Ph.D., with Catherine Whitney and the Editorial Advisory Board of the Tufts University Diet and Nutrition Letter. Copyright by the Tufts University Diet and Nutrition Letter. By permission of Harper Collins Publishers.

You may know that raw pork is not safe, or that a bulging can spells trouble. But how aware are you of the safety of other items in your kitchen? Take this quiz to find out. Is it safe or risky to eat ... 1. Hot dogs that have been stored in an unopened package in the refrigerator for 10 days? 2. A bruised or moldy piece of fruit? 3. Frozen ham that was thawed on the counter? 4. An unopened jar of mayonnaise that has been in the refrigerator for six months? 5. A baked potato left out on the counter from the night before? 6. Meat loaf that's pink in the middle after cooking? 7. Raw ground beef that turns brown after a day or two of refrigeration? 8. An uncooked potato with a greenish cast? 9. Lettuce or other produce moistened by poultry drippings in a grocery bag? 10. Steak that was thawed in the refrigerator and then refrozen? 11. Cooked shrimp that was never deveined? 12. Mustard or ketchup with a black, crusty ring around the rim of the jar? 13. Moldy or shriveled peanuts?

ANSWERS 1. Safe. Hot dogs that come in vacuum-sealed packages can be kept in the refrigerator for up to two weeks. Once opened, you can keep them for about seven days, carefully wrapped in plastic. 2. Safe if it's just bruised. But possibly risky if the bruised portion has become moldy. Some molds can produce harmful toxins, and it's not yet clear whether fruit molds are among them. The best bet is to cut away the moldy section, which should also remove any toxins that might be pesent. 3. Risky. Many people think they can take chances with ham because it has been smoked or salted. But these processes don't make the meat immune to bacterial contamination, especially since a number of manufacturers are lowering the salt content of cured meats. As with any meat, the safest way to thaw ham is in the refrigerator. 4. Safe. It's a misconception that foods prepared with mayonnaise may go bad sooner. In fact, its high acid and salt content may actually inhibit bacterial growth somewhat. You can keep an opened jar of mayonnaise in the refrigerator for up to a year, provided you don't let it sit at room temperature for extended periods. 5. Risky. We usually don't think of potatoes as a likely source of food poisoning, but there have been reports of deadly botulism in people who ate foil-wrapped baked potatoes left at room temperature for a day or more, even when they were reheated. Leftovers of most foods should be promptly refrigerated. 6. Risky. Ground meat undergoes a great deal of handling, compared to other forms. This increases the likelihood of bacterial contamination. For this reason, the USDA suggests cooking meat loaf until it is brown or at least brownish-pink in the center. An even better guide is to cook it to an internal temperature of 170 degrees Fahrenheit, cheching with a thermometer, particularly if the meat loaf contains pork. 7. Safe. Whether it's brown or pink has to do with the amount of oxygen with which it has come into contact. As a general rule, however, don't keep raw ground beef in the refrigerator longer than two days, and don't use it under any circumstances if it doesn't smell right or was left unrefrigerated for any length of time. 8. Risky. Green-skinned potatoes contain a chemical called solanine, which can cause gastrointestinal illness. You can use green potatoes if you peel them well and remove a layer of flesh underneath the skin. 9. Risky. Uncooked poultry juices may contain harmful bacteria that could lead to trouble when they get into foods that are eaten raw. If the produce is really saturated, you'd better not use it. But if contact was minimal, you can remove outer sections or rinse and peel. 10. Safe _ especially if some ice crystals remain. Make sure to thaw the frozen meat in the refrigerator the second time around. Be aware, too, that refreezing might cause flavor and texture deterioration. You might get better flavor and texture if you cook the meat the first time it is thawed, then refreeze it. 11. Safe. You can eat shrimp that hasn't been deveined as long as you cook it. The black line running down the back is actually the intestines of the shrimp, which are more susceptible to contamination. 12. Safe. The ring is the result of an interaction of the contents with air, not a sign of spoilage. Simply wipe it off and use the remaining contents. 13. Risky. When you crack open peanut shells only to find sickly looking nuts, don't eat them. The types of mold that grow on nuts (as well as on grains) can produce aflatoxins, some of which are very potent carcinogens.

DOC.HEAD: Swallowed Bay Leaves Can Require Emergency Treatment, Doctors Warn
DOC.TEXT: Swallowing a bay leaf can mean a trip to the emergency room, warn doctors who suggest that packages of the herb carry warning labels. Only one of five bay leaf victims they studied clearly knew what had caused the distress in their throats, so the problem is probably often overlooked, the doctors said. Bay leaves, most often dried, are used during cooking to enhance flavor, but usually are removed before the food is served and are not eaten. The five cases occurred over two years, suggesting the problem is common, said a report from Evanston Hospital in Illinois in a recent issue of the Annals of Internal Medicine. Four patients complained they felt that something was caught in their throats after eating chowder, chicken soup, chicken or lamb stew. The fifth had sudden throat pain while drinking onion soup. A stuck leaf can be retrieved or pushed into the stomach, depending on the circumstances, the doctors said. In a case reported in 1983, general anesthesia was required to fix the problem, the doctors said. ``Prevention could begin with packaging labels that warn of the hazards of bay leaf ingestion,'' they wrote. ``Cooks could use mesh bags to contain the leaves, removing the bag of leaves when cooking was completed.''
DOC.HEAD: Letters Protest Captive Breeding Program
DOC.TEXT: More than 300 people have written to the federal government protesting a plan to snare endangered Florida panthers and put them in zoos for a captive breeding program. Wildlife officials say that may be the only way to save the panther, an endangered species with only 30 to 50 animals remaining. ``Please do not breed them in captivity. What kind of society are we that we would take our state panther and put them on display, in zoos, in captivity?'' Greg Ray of Gainesville wrote in a letter to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Many of the 331 letters were mistaken about various aspects of the program, in which up to half the remaining panthers would be captured. Although the cats might be turned over to zoos, they wouldn't necessarily be on display. Fewer than a dozen letters were in favor of the project. The program is designed to increase the number of panthers to a point that a second population could be established in the wild, probably in northern Florida, officials said. Many of the letters contained emotional pleas to save the tawny cat, Florida's state animal. Eleven letters came from a third-grade class in Bronson. ``How would you like to live in a cage all your life? I would be sad if someone came and took me out of my home and put me in a cage,'' wrote student Shawn Voorhees. Dennis Jordan, Florida panther coordinator for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Agency, said only scientific data, not emotion, will save the Florida panther. The public has until Aug. 15 to comment.
DOC.HEAD: Park Officials: Sponge Harvesting Jeopardizing Park
DOC.TEXT: The hot market for natural sponges is jeopardizing this offshore park because some harvesters are hooking the sponges at an alarming rate, park administrators say. ``These sponges, in addition to filtering waters, provide habitats for the juveniles of various species. When you just clear an area of them, it's like clear-cutting a forest,'' said Bob Kelley, a board member of the Tropical Audubon Society. ``There's nothing left to live in for the small species.'' The harvesters, who produced reported sales of 16,600 pounds last year, say an attempt to regulate them could put an end to a tradition they brought with them from Cuba. ``The majority of us have sons, we bring them with us to fish and they learn,'' said Victorino Sanchez. ``It's a tranquil and healthy way to make a living.'' Harvesters now need only a general state license to sponge fish at the park in Biscayne Bay, south of Miami and the only water in Dade County clean enough to sustain large sponge beds. Park administrators want the regulatory plan to reduce harvests to 4,000 pounds a year as soon as possible and to gradually phase out the trade. ``What we are proposing is that we have a break in the generations, that the families living off of it now be permitted to continue, but they wouldn't be allowed to pass permits on to their relatives,'' said park Superintendent James Sanders. Wholesale prices soared from as low as $4 a dozen to as high as $45 a dozen, Sanders said. The number of boats went from about four to 20, and harvesters from a handful to 80 or more in the last two years.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Aug. 6

DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge failed to budge in June, the Commerce Department said. Analysts said the report portended a listless economy in the months ahead. The department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, was unchanged for the second month this year, the government said Wednesday. It had risen in March and May and fallen in February and April. In a separate report, the government said construction spending was flat in June.

In another sign of sluggishness in the nation's economy, businesses in July slashed orders for manufactured goods and reduced inventories, the National Association of Purchasing Management said. The association said Wednesday its Purchasing Managers Index fell to 47.4 percent in July from 51.1 percent the previous month, ending three months of increases. A reading below 50 indicates the manufacturing economy generally is declining.

Acting to free resources to focus on its main high- technology businesses, IBM announced it will place its typewriter, keyboard and certain printer operations into a new company in which it will retain a minority interest. A firm specializing in buyouts, Clayton & Dubilier Inc., will acquire the majority stake in the new firm, but no purchase price was announced Wednesday. Executives of International Business Machines Corp. and Clayton & Dubilier said negotiations are expected to conclude by the end of the year. Industry analysts have estimated the businesses would be worth $2.5 billion to $3 billion.

Congressional Democrats proposed a $5 billion program to help workers who lose their jobs because of defense cuts or environmental rules designed to clean the air and protect the spotted owl. The legislation unveiled Wednesday would provide extra unemployment and health benefits to families affected by the policy changes. The proposal is specifically aimed at defense workers, including military people, laid off because of Pentagon spending cuts, along with loggers idled by the effort to preserve the spotted owl and coal miners left above ground by tougher clean-air laws.

Karsten Mahlmann resigned as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's largest commodity futures exchange, amid charges of wrongdoing at the trading company he headed. Mahlmann said Wednesday he was stepping down ``in the overwhelming interest of the Board of Trade and because of my deep love and respect for the institution.'' Earlier, Mahlmann announced his resignation as head of Stotler Group Inc., a beleaguered commodities firm that operates a subsidiary accused of violating the Commodity Exchange Act.

In a ruling that could expose the government to millions of dollars in liability, a federal appeals court said three asbestos makers can sue for compensation paid to sick workers at U.S. Navy shipyards. Attorneys said the decision would lead to lawsuits by dozens of companies that are trying to force the government to share in payments already exceeding $1 billion for asbestos-related diseases afflicting tens of thousands of workers. The ruling Monday by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington allows Eagle-Picher Inc., Keene Corp. and UNR Industries Inc. to pursue reimbursement from the government for payments made to asbestos victims who worked for the Navy as long ago as the 1930s.

The savings and loan bailout agency announced its ``great fall inventory clearance sale'' to unload $50 billion in assets from failed thrifts by the end of the year. The sales push announced Wednesday marks the second phase of the Resolution Trust Corp.'s cleanup effort. In the first phase, dubbed ``Operation Clean Sweep,'' the agency concentrated on selling the failed institutions and their deposits.

Five European countries, meeting for the first time as a new regional alliance, agreed to step up political and economic cooperation to promote stability on the changing continent. The leaders of Italy, Czechoslovakia, Austria, Hungary and Yugoslavia reached a wide range of accords Wednesday aimed at strengthening democracy and spurring economic development in eastern and central Europe.

Robert Stempel took over as chairman of General Motors Corp. and quickly announced management changes aimed at improving vehicles and sales at the nation's largest automaker. One day after succeeding Roger Smith as chairman and chief executive officer, Stempel unveiled an altered GM organizational chart he said cuts levels of upper-level management and turns responsibilities such as advertising and marketing decisions to the company's eight car and truck operations.

Worries about economic growth in general and the banking industry in particular combined to push stock prices lower in an erratic session Wednesday. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 5.94 to 2,899.26. The dollar regained some ground in foreign exchange. Bond prices surged. Reports of heightened tensions in the 2-week-old dispute between Iraq and Kuwait helped boost gold and petroleum futures prices; copper futures soared; grains and soybeans were sharply lower; and livestock and meat futures also fell.

DOC.HEAD: Stempel Moves Decidedly into GM Chairmanship
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Robert Stempel took the wheel of General Motors Corp. and steered the company more toward its factories than to Wall Street. Stempel, who Wednesday officially became the huge corporation's chairman and chief executive officer, is the first engineer to sit in GM's corner office in the company's 82-year history. He succeeds Roger Smith, who retired after 9{ years as chairman, a tenure marked by criticism that the accountant concentrated too much on earnings and not enough on engineering. Stempel and the six men he tapped to lead GM into the 1990s met with reporters Wednesday morning and outlined changes in the corporation's top management. In essence, Stempel said, responsibility lines were straightened between the company's eight car- and truck-making operations and GM's top brass. ``These are not major changes, but they're indicative of where we're going,'' he said. ``We're not taking General Motors apart and putting it back together again.'' Stempel's ascension to the chairmanship was widely hailed by industry observers who said the No. 1 automaker's product development programs had been unnecessarily put on a back burner as the company concentrated on boosting profits. While Smith was chairman, GM's balance sheet moved from a $333.4 million profit in 1981 to a $4.2 billion profit last year. But the company's share of the U.S. car and truck market dropped from 46 percent to 35 percent during that same time. Stempel said the company planned to boost its market share, but only if it can do it profitably. ``The '90s will be a time of adapting and building what we have in place,'' Stempel said. GM shuts down its Lakewood assembly plant in Atlanta on Monday, putting about 2,000 employees out of work. The company says no further plant closings are in the works, other than those already announced. Lloyd Reuss, who became the company's new president Wednesday, said he expects 100 percent of GM's assembly plants to be operating by 1992. He declined to say what percentage of GM's plant capacity is being used now. Since 1987, when the company signed its last contract with the United Auto Workers union, GM has shut down four assembly plants, including the Lakewood factory, and plans to close part of its huge Lordstown, Ohio, complex when it consolidates full-size van production in Flint by 1992. GM has said the four plants are ``indefinitely idled'' with no new products scheduled for them. Reuss said those plants were not included in his forecast of 100 percent plant utilization in two years, and those factories would remain closed. The UAW has contended that GM has no intention of putting any new manufacturing in the plants, and Reuss' comments Wednesday seems to support that. Like Stempel, Reuss and Vice Chairman Robert J. Schultz came up through GM's engineering ranks. Members of Stempel's team with financial backgrounds are Vice Chairman John F. Smith Jr., Executive Vice President William Hoglund and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer Robert T. O'Connell. Stempel's move to chairman comes at a time when GM's financial matters appear to be in good shape. Some Wall Street analysts have suggested that investors switch from Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. stock to GM because GM is the only one of the Big Three that could boost dividends in the near future. Last week, GM reported it earned $1.6 billion the first half of this year, 46.5 percent less than in the first six months of 1989. However, GM's profits were higher than the $1.4 billion reported by Ford and the $251 million reported by struggling Chrysler. Stempel, 57, joined the company in 1958 as a senior detailer in the Oldsmobile Division's chassis design department. In succeeding years, he concentrated on powertrain design. In 1972, Stempel was named assistant chief engineer at Oldsmobile. Six years later, he joined the legion of nearly four dozen vice presidents and became general manager of the Pontiac Division. Stempel went to Europe in 1980 to head the company's profitable Adam Opel AG carmaking operations in West Germany. Two years later, he returned to the United States to head GM's Chevrolet Division, the company's largest carmaking operation. In February 1986 he joined the GM board as executive vice president for the Truck & Bus and Overseas groups, before becoming its 17th president. On Wednesday, his first day as GM's 11th chairman, Stempel said: ``I felt terrific getting up this morning.''

DOC.HEAD: The Energy Problem Drifts Into The Background
Also moved in advance
DOC.TEXT: Americans have had their fill of crises, real or imagined, and can hardly tolerate another. It probably explains why the energy problem has fallen into the background. But there is uncomfortable news in the background, and it might be summarized in three sentences: American production of crude oil is falling. Consumption is rising. Imports account for half of U.S. supplies. These ingredients mean an inevitable crisis, the only unknown being its timing and extent. The timing could be sometime in the next century; it also could be as imminent as the next time warfare threatens in the Middle East. The U.S. economy runs on energy. That is, the nation's factories, homes and means of transportation depend on it. As history has demonstrated, a shortage can stall an automobile or an economy with equal effectiveness. Recognizing this, America went on an energy-saving crusade beginning in the 1970s. Old homes and factories were insulated and standards for new ones were raised. Alternative energy supplies were encouraged and businesses for that purpose were founded. Much of that seems like a memory now, akin to the lingering thoughts some people have of blackouts and ration cards during World War II. That deprivation ended suddenly; people resumed their lives and said ``never again.'' But the energy war never was won. Its ingredients remain and they're just as explosive as ever: a country totally dependent on a stable supply but with no assurance of it; a country increasing energy usage but not its production. Domestic crude oil production in June fell to 7.1 million barrels a day, the lowest on record. That month's output was 7.7 percent below a year earlier and no less than 2 million barrels a day below the rate in February 1986. Drilling crews have disbanded, and while exploration continues it is at a reduced rate. Increasingly, the demand for oil runs headlong into the demands of environmentalists to protect the planet's water, wildlife and beauty. The alternative is to import. Oil imports now are at a record high, slightly exceeding the record of December 1977, when 47.9 percent of the nation's supply came from abroad. While domestic output runs into environmental restrictions, imported oil runs in opposition to balance of payment efforts. No matter how it is viewed, therefore, energy in the form of crude and refined oil is a problem of deadly proportions, potential or actual. And it can erupt as easily as, for example, hostilities in the Mideast. In spite of this vulnerability _ of just about every individual, business and governmental unit _ you don't hear much talk these days about energy supplies except perhaps to hear about another nuclear power facility unbuilt. All the creative ideas of a decade ago are warehoused like old inventory. Many of the briefly successful alternative energy companies have collapsed. The old conservation methods seem like holdovers from another time. Except for another oil spill, energy doesn't make big news these days. It has receded into the background, overwhelmed by what are considered to be more urgent problems. But the ingredients of crisis still are there. Everyone knows it, and they know too that experience teaches that knowing is not enough.

DOC.HEAD: Court Backs Asbestos Makers Right To Sue Government
DOC.TEXT: The government has been ordered to prove in court why it shouldn't have to compensate tens of thousands of workers made sick inhaling asbestos fibers in U.S. Navy shipyards. Attorneys said the 2-1 ruling by the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington could subject the government to millions of dollars in liability for asbestos-related exposure dating to the 1930s. ``The government specified products with asbestos in it, the government controlled working conditions and the government in the view of many people has the primary responsibility for what happened,'' Andrew Berry, a Newark, N.J., attorney for several asbestos makers, said Wednesday. Companies that made asbestos are trying to force the government to reimburse them for at least a portion of liability payments already exceeding $1 billion. The government to date has not admitted responsibility or agreed to pay compensation. The court ruling allows Eagle-Picher Inc., Keene Corp. and UNR Industries Inc. to pursue reimbursement from the government for payments made to asbestos victims who worked for the Navy. ``So far only our clients have paid the tab,'' said Joe G. Hollingsworth, a Washington attorney representing UNR and Eagle-Picher. ``The government has escaped liability by virtue of technical arguments. We'd like to prove what (its) real responsibility was.'' David S. Fishback, a Justice Department lawyer handling the case, declined to comment. More than 100,000 asbestos cases involving workers afflicted with lung cancer and other severe and often fatal diseases are clogging federal and state court dockets nationwide. The bulk of the payouts has been made by a trust created in Manville Corp. bankruptcy proceedings. The trust has run out of money and is being restructured to speed payments to needy victims. Other companies also have been pushed into bankruptcy by asbestos lawsuits and want to reduce their liability. Widespread illnesses from inhaling fibers of asbestos _ a mineral used widely for its heat resistance and fire retardant qualities _ did not appear until the 1970s, in some cases after decades of exposure. Manufacturers have argued the government should be held liable because it allegedly failed to tell them about asbestos' health hazards and because the government was contractually responsibile for maintaining a safe workplace. But in numerous decisions in the last 10 years, courts have shielded the government from liability on the grounds that it has immunity against lawsuits filed by federal employees. Other procedural arguments have helped keep cases from proceeding to trial. Berry said the latest ruling ``places pressure on the government to assist in resolving the cases.'' The decision orders the U.S. Claims Court to hear anew the three companies' claims. It would be the first time that the merits of whether the government is liable _ rather than jurisdictional issues _ are argued in court. The U.S. Claims Court in Washington handles all claims against the federal government. The companies had been blocked from pursuing lawsuits against the government simultaneously in claims court and federal district court. But the appellate ruling said the claims court case involving the government's contractual obligations with the companies should be heard again because it had been dismissed by other courts. A group of defendants in more than 500 asbestos lawsuits in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday filed a motion seeking to add the government to the list of defendants in the consolidated case. The government has been held liable in only one case and was required to pay one-third of an asbestos settlement of about $50,000 to a Maine woman who contracted a lung disease from cleaning her father's asbestos-tainted clothes. The government's claim of immunity did not apply in the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals case because the woman was not a federal employee. Hollingsworth, who represented the Maine woman, Joan Dube, said the government has not paid its portion of the settlement in that case or agreed to hold settlement negotiations in a similar case.

DOC.HEAD: Mahlmann Resigns as CBOT Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Karsten Mahlmann, who resigned as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade and head of Stotler Group Inc., said he hasn't been involved in day-to-day affairs at the struggling brokerage for two years. Mahlmann, who was in an unprecedented fourth term as the CBOT's chief, said he was stepping down Wednesday ``in the overwhelming interest of the Board of Trade and because of my deep love and respect for the institution,'' according to a statement from the exchange's board of directors. The board said it regretfully accepted the resignation, effective immediately. The board also said it had elected CBOT Vice Chairman William F. O'Connor to serve the remainder of Mahlmann's one-year term, ending Dec. 31. Hours earlier he resigned from Stotler Group Inc., whose main subsidairy has fallen from one of the biggest players on the CBOT to the target of a Commodities Futures Trading Commission civil complaint. The subsidiary, Stotler and Co. has withdrawn from the futures business because of shaky finances. ``I have had no day-to-day management responsibilities (at Stotler) since early 1988, and my position at Stotler was constantly eroded,'' Mahlmann said Wednesday. ``I simply was not a party to the financial decisions (at Stotler) which are now being scrutinized by the exchange and the regulators,'' he added. Mahlmann said had he been aware of Stotler's recent financial decisions, ``I would not have condoned them, and I would have taken action to reverse them.'' He said he remains Stotler Group's largest shareholder. On Tuesday federal regulators filed a civil complaint in U.S. District Court accusing a Stotler subsidiary, Stotler Funds Inc., of violating the Commodity Exchange Act. The complaint filed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission says the commodity pool operator improperly used pools of clients' money which had been set up for investing in commodity futures contracts. Some CBOT members believe Stotler's woes damaged Mahlmann's ability to lead the CBOT's battle over regulation of the futures industry and had called for him to resign, said John Frazier, director of the agricultural division at Chicago-based Gerald Inc., an exchange member. The exchange wants the CFTC to maintain control over stock-index futures, but the Bush administration wants to transfer that authority to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which oversees the stock market. Several ranking industry officials, though, said they didn't see Mahlmann's departure as having much effect on that fight. Meanwhile, both the CFTC and the SEC have been called to account for their handling of the Stotler situation. The House Committee on Energy and Commerce has ordered the chairmen of both commissions to submit reports on Stotler by Aug. 24. ``These events raise serious questions about the adequacy of regulation and oversight in the futures industry,'' said a letter Tuesday from committee chairman Rep. John D. Dingle, D-Mich., and Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance. ``Press reports suggest that Stotler was thinly capitalized as early as 1987 but that the Commodities Futures Trading Commission and the Chicago Board of Trade took no action,'' the letter added.

DOC.HEAD: Mahlmann Resignation Latest Blow to Market Credibility
With PM-Stotler, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Karsten Mahlmann's resignation as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade is only the latest woe to befall the commodities industry in recent years. Since the 1987 stock market crash, questions have been raised on whether the Commodities Futures Trading Commission is adequately regulating the industry and on the honesty of traders on the Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Also given a serious look was the way the Board of Trade handled an alleged attempt to corner the soybean market by Ferruzi Trading International SpA. Mahlmann resigned Wednesday as chairman of the CBOT, the world's largest commodity futures exchange, amid allegations of wrongdoing at a trading company he headed. He was midway through an unprecedented fourth term as the CBOT's chief. Mahlmann's resignation came hours after he announced his resignation as head of Stotler Group Inc., a beleaguered commodities company that operates a subsidiary accused of violating the Commodity Exchange Act. On Tuesday the Commodity Futures Trading Commission filed a federal complaint accusing a Stotler subsidiary of violating the Commodity Exchange Act. The complaint names Stotler Funds Inc., a commodity pool operator owned by Stotler Group. The CFTC contends Stotler Funds improperly used pools of clients' money which had been set up for investing in commodity futures contracts to invest in Stotler Group. Stotler Funds also lent $1 million from another pool to its parent company. Much more publicized problems in the futures industry culminated last month with the trial of three Swiss franc futures traders. But a federal jury ended up convicting two of the traders of only relatively minor trading violations and acquitting the third defendant of some offenses. The jury couldn't reach verdicts on scores of other charges, including a racketeering count against one defendant and mail- and wire-fraud charges against all three. Officials of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, where the traders worked, said the jury's action somewhat redeemed the market's reputation. The two-month trial was the first to result from an undercover FBI investigation of corruption at the Merc and the Board of Trade. In all, 48 people have been indicted since August. Sixteen have pleaded guilty to reduced charges. Two other groups _ 13 soybean traders from the Board of Trade and 15 yen traders from the Merc _ face trials in September. The heavy scrutiny of commodities industry followed the one-day drop of more than 500 points in the Dow Jones Industrial Average _ a key market indicator _ in October 1987 and a 190-point single-day drop last year. A CFTC study after the second drop indicated index arbitrage was not a major factor in the stock slide. Index arbitrage is a computerized program trading strategy that seeks to profit from differences between the stock and futures markets. The study found no evidence of stock index futures market manipulation. The Security and Exchange Commission and other critics of index arbitrage contend it causes wild price swings. Index arbitragers try to take advantage of small price differences between the stock and futures markets by simultaneously buying large orders in one market while selling in another. Most stock index futures are traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. To curb volatility, the Bush administration wants to move authority for stock-index futures from the CFTC to the SEC. The CFTC and the futures industry oppose any shift, saying it will cripple the agency's ability to regulate other futures porducts and overregualate a segment of an industry that is trying to stave off foreign competition. The Board of Trade came under heavy criticism from farmers and others last year after it moved to break up an attempt to corner the soybean market. The CBOT issued an emergency order requiring the liquidation of large positions in the July soybean futures contract. The order targeted Ferruzzi, an Italian agricultural and financial firm and one of the world's largest soybean processors. The order prompted soybean prices to tumble sharply, with agricultural groups saying the action led to lower prices paid to producers. CBOT board members also were accused of conflict of interest in ordering the liquidations. The CFTC said reasonable grounds existed for the liquidation order and said it found no evidence of self-dealing by CBOT officials who might have sold off their holdings after voting to issue the order.

DOC.HEAD: USX Faces Contract Talks In December
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. Chairman Charles A. Corry said the steel and energy giant won't take its cue from other major steel makers in upcoming contract talks with the United Steelworkers of America. ``Our employees and our company need a contract that will ensure that they are part of a competitive enterprise that can make it and that will provide them some job security,'' he said Wednesday at a news conference. ``Forget the concept of a pattern,'' he said when asked about the similarity of contracts agreed to last year by other major steel companies. The chairman previously said those contracts, which restored labor concessions made during the recession years of the 1980s, were too generous. Corry said negotiations with the union should begin around Dec. 1. The current four-year pact, approved in January 1987 after a six-month work stoppage, expires Jan. 31. It covers about 18,500 employees. He said many of USX's competitors have lower labor costs. He cited non-union mini mills, union mills with lower labor costs and financially ailing steel makers that have lower costs while reorganizing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court. ``Our employees have to look at our situation and come up with something that this company can afford,'' he said. Corry said he expects the price of steel, oil and natural gas to climb in the next five months, boosting profits following a 15 percent drop in second-quarter earnings. ``I think the outlook for the second half looks pretty good,'' he said. ``During the first half we lived through one hell of a lot of volatility in the prices of our primary products.'' Corry attributed his optimism to the onset of colder weather, an expected increase in demand for steel and recent efforts by OPEC oil ministers to raise the price of crude. USX said on Tuesday that its second-quarter profit slid to $212 million from $250 million in 1989 as oil gains failed to offset reduced steel profits and losses from the sale of the company's natural gas business. USX's steel segment earnings dropped 53 percent in the second quarter, largely due to price erosion that begin in the second half of 1989 and only recently began to reverse. Corry said there is ``no conscious plan'' to shrink the company's steel division, which he said fared well in the quarter compared to other large steel makers. ``It's making quite a contribution. ... In not a robust environment in the industry we're able to hold our own,'' he said. The future of steel was a central issue May 7 when shareholders rejected takeover strategist Carl Icahn's proposal to spin off at least 80 percent of the company's steel division and return proceeds to shareholders. Corry said he has not talked to Icahn, the company's largest shareholder, since the vote. ``I'm not aware of any activities or change in thinking he's had with respect to his USX stock,'' Corry said. Icahn said following his proposal's defeat he had no intention of selling his stock and would not ``fade into the background.'' On another matter, Corry said he wrote a letter July 27 to President Bush, outlining his opposition to initiatives to increase taxes on energy in an effort to lower the federal budget deficit. ``This is a very serious thing for this company because we're in a unique position of being a big producer of energy products and we are at the same time, through steel operations, a major consumer of energy,'' he said. He said an increase in energy taxes would hinder the competitiveness and profitability of American manufacturers and energy producers. Meanwhile, Thomas Graham, president of the steel division, said the company will begin work Sept. 7 on a continuous slab caster that will modernize the Edgar Thompson Works south of Pittsburgh in Braddock. He said the $200 million project will take about two years to complete.

Losers swamped gainers by more than 3 to 1 in the early tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 241 up, 895 down and 297 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 43.11 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street.
