Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Philip Morris, down 1[ at 46}; International Business Machines, down 1} at 109~, and General Motor $2.62 per bushel, the wheat would have a farm value of around $24 million. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $20.40 per ton, or about 56 cents per bushel. The subsidized sales were handled by Continental Grain Co., 207,900 tons; and Cargill Inc., 40,000 tons. With the latest sales, China has bought about 2.2 million tons of U.S. wheat for delivery in the 1990-91 wheat marketing year that began June 1, compared with 5.6 million tons in 1989-90.

Rural development councils will be started this summer in eight states as a forerunner of a nationwide project to boost development in rural America, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced. The councils will be started in Kansas, Maine, Mississippi, Oregon, South Carolina, South Dakota, Texas and Washington, he said Wednesday. Existing resources will be used to form the councils, which will have full-time coordinators, Yeutter said. A goal will be to form state-level partnerships between federal and state governments and the private sector. ``The participants will create a long-term strategy for applying federal rural development resources and will carry out joint actions to implement the strategy,'' Yeutter said. Councils will be made up of federal officials representing various departments and agencies that have significant rural development roles. Such agencies would include the Extension Service and the Farmers Home Administration, for example.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Iraqi Invasion Could Boost Consumer Energy Prices
DOC.TEXT: Consumers may have to pay more to gas up their cars and heat their homes by the end of the year if oil shipments are disrupted because of Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait, oil experts said today. Prices already have shot up on the wholesale level. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, soared $2.06 to $23.70 a 42-gallon barrel in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Among refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, unleaded gasoline for September delivery jumped 5.23 cents to 69.50 cents a gallon. Heating oil was up 4.31 cents to 65.50 cents a gallon. ``The costs will have to be passed down to consumers,'' said Brian Tagler, an oil trader with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. But it's hard to predict how much more consumers will have to pay, experts say. ``You may not see the impact on the consumer level for at least four to eight weeks,'' said Edward Ryan, an oil trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``The current supplies on hand are adequate and I just don't see retail prices reacting in the same way as on the wholesale level.'' Oil producers already are facing a world glut of crude, partly due to high production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. In the United States, supplies of unleaded gasoline are up about 10 percent from a year ago to 167.2 million barrels from 156.32 million. Crude stocks are up 50 million from 1989, to 338.7 million barrels from 330.6 million. The general rule of thumb, according to industry experts, is that for every dollar rise in the barrel of crude oil means a rise of two cents to a nickel at the pumps. Tagler said, ``if the United States intervenes on Kuwait's behalf ... that (also) could bring prices back down.'' U.S. assistance, he said, could alleviate any possible disruptions in oil production and shipments in the area, where the United States gets a significant portion of its oil supplies. Iraq and Kuwait produce one-fifth of the total oil produced by OPEC, but their oil accounts for only an estimated 5 percent of daily U.S. consumption. Iraq's powerful army was reported to have invaded Kuwait early today, seizing the ruler's palace and government buildings. The assault followed three weeks of tension between Kuwait and Iraq caused by Iraqi accusations that Kuwait stole oil from its territory. The Revolutionary Command Council led by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein claimed it invaded Kuwait at the request of revolutionaries who had already overthrown the government. Kuwait and U.N. diplomats labeled the coup reports a farce.

DOC.HEAD: Factory Orders Fell 1.5 Percent in June
DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods fell 1.5 percent in June, continuing their roller-coaster ride through the first half of 1990, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $237.4 billion after a 2.2 percent gain in May. The choppy performance began in January with a 5.5 percent decline _ the sharpest drop since a 7.0 percent decrease in December 1974. Orders also fell 2.1 percent in April and rose 4.0 percent in March and 1.8 percent in February. Factory orders are a key economic barometer of manufacturing industry plans for production. A decrease in orders may forecast a slump in that sector and layoffs in the future. The June decline was led by a 2.8 percent drop in orders for durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years _ to $125.1 billion. But the decline was not as sharp as the 3.2 percent drop when durable goods orders were first reported last week. Non-durable goods orders were unchanged at $112.3 billion. Over half of the durables decline was in defense goods, which dropped 20.3 percent to $8.0 billion. Excluding defense, orders would have dropped 0.7 percent. In the key category of non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, orders advanced 0.6 percent to $36.1 billion after falling 1.8 percent a month earlier. Each of the durable categories posted losses. Transportation orders were down 4.9 percent to $33.8 billion after rising 10.2 percent in May. Excluding transportation, orders were off 1.0 percent. Other durable declines included electrical machinery, down 3.7 percent to $20.0 billion following a 1.4 percent gain the previous month; primary metals, down 3.0 percent to $11.5 billion after a 2.5 percent advance in May, and non-electrical machinery, off 2.5 percent to $21.7 billion after increasing 3.6 percent. Shipments of factory goods in June increased 0.5 percent to $240.1 billion on top of a 2.0 percent gain in May. But the June increase in shipments resulted in a 0.5 percent drop in unfilled orders to $517.7 billion. Inventories fell 0.5 percent to $370.5 billion, the third decrease this year altlhough they were unchanged in May.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney Plans Job Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Aerospace giant Pratt & Whitney, facing leaner U.S defense budgets, will eliminate 4,000 jobs by 1993, mostly in Connecticut and Florida, the company announced today. The company plans to eliminate about 2,000 jobs from its Connecticut, Maine and Georgia operations, which have a combined staff of about 28,300, said Curtis Linke, Pratt & Whitney's vice president of communications. Most of the jobs are in Connecticut, which has a total work force of about 25,400. The remaining 2,000 jobs will cut from Pratt & Whitney's Florida work force, which now stands at 8,400. The reductions will be accomplished primarily through attrition, but the jet-engine maker has not ruled out the possibility of some layoffs, Linke said. Pratt & Whitney has a worldwide work force of about 45,000. The cutbacks would be the second big work force reduction in two years. The company eliminated 2,650 salaried jobs in 1988 and 1989, citing intense competition. Pratt & Whitney, which depends on defense contracts for about 35 percent of its business, in recent times, has been trying to shift its operation to a more commercially oriented one to offset losses due to defense cutbacks. The company, the largest division of Hartford-based United Technologies Corp., has plants in East Hartford, Middletown, Southington and North Haven. In addition to cutbacks here, and Pratt's complex in Palm Beach, Fla., the company may eliminate jobs at plants in Maine and Georgia, Linke said. Because of its huge business supplying engines for passenger jets, Pratt & Whitney had hoped to avoid the sweeping cuts under way at manufacturers more dependent on defense contracts. In February, the president of Pratt & Whitney's commercial engine group, Selwyn D. Berson, said the growing airliner market was expected to forestall layoffs in Connecticut for the foreseeable future. The company has a $20 billion backlog of civilian engine orders. Assembly work for those orders have been spread out over a 10 year period, lessening the company's ability to cushion immediate defense cuts. With easing world tensions, the budget ax is expected to come down on Pratt-powered Air Force planes, such as the F-15 and F-16 jet fighters, the advanced tactical fighter and the C-17 transport. UTC has already been forced to layoff hundreds of workers at other divisions, including Sikorsky Aircraft in Stratford and Norden Systems in Norwalk, because of defense cuts.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 429.73 down 6.18 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Adviser: Economy Should Be Able to Shoulder Oil Price Increase
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th graf pvs `In June, ...' to UPDATE with other US-Iraq export-import figures. Picks up 6th graf pvs `Christopher Flavin ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has nearly doubled its share of world oil supplies by taking control of Kuwait, raising new risks for the United States and other nations heavily dependent on imported oil, private energy experts said today. That assessment came as President Bush's chief economic adviser said the U.S. economy should be able to withstand an increase in oil prices without being pushed into a recession. Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, said even if the turmoil in the Mideast resulted in a 25 percent rise in oil prices, it would likely have only a modest adverse impact on U.S. economic growth. Fully one-half of U.S. oil supplies are imported, although the combined shares of the American market for Iraq and Kuwait are less than 10 percent, according to industry figures. In June, the latest month for which figures are available, Persian Gulf oil represented 24.7 percent of total U.S. oil imports, according to the American Petroleum Institute, the trade group for major oil companies. A year earlier the figure was 22.2 percent. The United States imported about $2.4 billion in oil and other goods last year from Iraq, while U.S. exports to Iraq _ led by agricultural commodities _ totaled $1.17 billion in 1989. Iraq is one of the United States' biggest trading partners in the Arab world, surpassed only by Saudi Arabia. Iraq's leading exports to the United States are crude oil and dates. Kuwait's exports to the United States, also mainly oil, totaled $973 million last year. Kuwait imported $855 million in U.S. goods, led by motor vehicles and parts. Christopher Flavin, a vice president of the Worldwatch Institute, said Iraq's invasion of tiny Kuwait may have little immediate effect on world oil supplies if the conflict does not escalate and Kuwaiti oil workers cooperate with Iraq. A more troubling question, Flavin said, is what step Iraqi President Saddam Hussein might take toward seeking control of oil fields elsewhere on the Arabian Peninsula. By grabbing Kuwait, Saddam has boosted his share of world oil reserves to 20 percent. Iraq has about 100 billion barrels of reserves, while Kuwait has about 94 billion, according to figures published this summer by British Petroleum. If Iraq gained control of Saudi Arabia, which ranks as the world's largest oil exporter and the No. 1 supplier to the United States, it could garner enough economic clout to hold the world economy at risk, Flavin said. Saudi Arabia, with reported oil reserves of 255 billion barrels, is the most oil-rich nation in the world. Flavin estimated that an Iraqi military move against Saudi Arabia and the smaller United Arab Emirates could give Saddam control of 60 percent of total world oil reserves. Boskin told the congressional Joint Economic Committee that the gross national product would be trimmed by ``a few tenths of a percentage point'' by a 25 percent rise in oil prices. ``Even if the higher price is enforced, our economy today is much better able to absorb modest price increases,'' Boskin said. But he conceded that a rise in world oil prices would have ``some deleterious impact on our economy.'' The impact, he said, would be more harmful on the Japanese economy because of its greater dependence on imports from OPEC. Boskin's scheduled appearance before Congress was to explain the administration's downward economic forecasts for 1990 and 1991 and the impact those revisions have had on the budget deficit.

For Release PMs Thursday, Aug. 2
DOC.HEAD: The Energy Problem Drifts Into The Background
DOC.TEXT: Americans have had their fill of crises, real or imagined, and can hardly tolerate another. It probably explains why the energy problem has fallen into the background. But there is uncomfortable news in the background, and it might be summarized in three sentences: American production of crude oil is falling. Consumption is rising. Imports account for half of U.S. supplies. These ingredients mean an inevitable crisis, the only unknown being its timing and extent. The timing could be sometime in the next century; it also could be as imminent as the next time warfare threatens in the Middle East. The U.S. economy runs on energy. That is, the nation's factories, homes and means of transportation depend on it. As history has demonstrated, a shortage can stall an automobile or an economy with equal effectiveness. Recognizing this, America went on an energy-saving crusade beginning in the 1970s. Old homes and factories were insulated and standards for new ones were raised. Alternative energy supplies were encouraged and businesses for that purpose were founded. Much of that seems like a memory now, akin to the lingering thoughts some people have of blackouts and ration cards during World public emotion _ hostility and compassion, frustration and sympathy _ has escalated as the ranks of the homeless swell. ``People are frustrated it's not over. We're into quick fixes,'' said Mary Ann Gleason, director of the Denver Healthcare for the Homeless Clinic, which serves about 6,500 people a year. ``There are hundreds of thousands of people we've gotten off the streets, but there are more falling in behind them.'' No one knows how many Americans are homeless. Estimates range from 300,000 to 3 million. But no one disputes the fact that the number is increasing, and greater numbers mean greater visibility. ``It's a common perception that at least among some parts of society, there's not only less compassion but more organized hostility'' toward the homeless, said Gary Blasi, president of the National Coaltion for the Homeless and a Legal Aid Foundation attorney in Los Angeles, a city with a homeless population estimated at more than 150,000. ``A large part of the source of the hostility is that it's not great to have a lot of homeless people around when you're a tourist city,'' Blasi said. ``It's not just the cable cars and the Golden Gate anymore.'' What passes for heartlessness often is case of empty municipal pockets, with compassionate programs succumbing to financial pressures. The city council in Washington, faced with a $95 million budget deficit, voted in June to gut its policy of guaranteeing overnight shelter to anyone who requested it. That ordinance was championed by the late homeless activist Mitch Snyder and passed six years ago by more than 70 percent of the vote. In Philadelphia, 80 members of the Mayor's Public-Private Task Force on Homelessness resigned in July to protest massive cuts in the city's budget for homeless services after the amount dropped from $34 million to $10 million in two years. At the same time, the city plans to spend $1 million closing off spaces under train platforms in a downtown station where people like to sleep. ``I see no abatement whatsoever in people's concern, people calling, people coming in, people of all ages making an effort and reaching out,'' said Phyllis Ryan, director of the Philadelphia Committee for the Homeless and one of the former task force members. ``The government resources have just not been sufficient. I think they just looked out there and decided who's a voter and who isn't.'' In some places, voters aggravated by the homeless problem are using their electoral clout to protest. Residents in Santa Monica, Calif., have collected thousands of signatures to place a proposition on the November ballot to make the city attorney's office an elected one. The current city attorney, Robert Myers, has refused to prosecute people for sleeping outdoors. ``I think there's an increasing feeling of helplessness,'' said Barbara Stinchfield, Santa Monica's community development manager. ``We get proposals weekly ... on how to solve the homeless problem. It's frustrating, it's troubling, it's unsettling, it's not getting better. But most people are not reacting in a really destructive way.'' Citizens in Santa Cruz, Calif., took their anger to the streets. When 200 homeless activists rallied outside the Santa Cruz County Courthouse demanding an end to the city's camping ban, they were outnumbered by 600 counterdemonstrators who said they were tired of giving ``bums'' and ``squatters'' a free ride in the seaside town about 75 miles south of San Francisco. ``I think what happened in Santa Cruz and San Francisco has to do with something much bigger than homelessness,'' Gleason said. The American public, she believes, feels angry but helpless over things like the HUD scandal and the savings-and-loan bailout: ``I think people are feeling so frustrated from being bamboozled and taken advantage of on every front, homelessness gets lumped in with the rest of it. It's very easy to take your anger out on the poor.'' It's more difficult to find effective solutions to the problem, but citizens in Seattle are trying, said Martha Dilts, executive director of Seattle Emergency Housing Service. Seattle residents are trying to raise $1 million for transitional housing for homeless families, and a local real estate company's agents are donating part of their commissions to fight homelessness. ``I see people starting to realize that homelessness is affecting more people, that it could happen to your family or your neighbor. There's a feeling of community and a sense of `We can do it,''' said Dilts, a member of the governor's homeless task force. Advocates agree that homelessness will persist until society deals with the lack of affordable housing, access to drug treatment and mental health facilities and absence of affordable childcare and other support services for the working poor. Meanwhile, cities are being forced to expand and improve shelter facilities, something many communities are loathe to do. Although Washington has been under court order to expand its shelter system, council members say neighborhoods will not accept one without a fight. In one area, a homeless man's arrest on murder charges galvanized the neighbors; they held bake sales to finance their effort to close the shelter in which he lived. In a suburban Westchester County, N.Y., community, neighbors have filed five lawsuits to try to stop construction of a 108-unit complex for homeless women and children. In a San Jose, Calif., neighborhood, residents are fighting a homeless shelter they believe is responsible for a 120 percent increase in felonies in their area. ``If there was a shred of sympathy in me before,'' one resident said, ``after seeing this, I have lost all compassion.'' Sometimes, however, neighbors find the cure far less painful than they had anticipated. A project to help mentally ill homeless women in Denver was welcomed into a neighborhood after residents' fears were allayed by the project's planners. The house has been a smashing, problem-free success: 78 percent of those who passed through there in the first year now have homes, and neighbors now drop by to donate lawn chairs and tomato plants. ``I don't think the American public knows what's going on in homeless services today,'' Gleason said. ``Part of it is misinformation, part of it is honest-to-God displaced anger. When people understand both what the homeless reality is, and what we're trying to do about it, it paints a whole different picture.''

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 152,036 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 165,960, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 156,976 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 82,351 cars this week, compared with 88,650 a week ago and 84,752 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 69,685, compared with last week's 77,310 and last year's 72,224. Canadian automakers were to build 10,935 cars this week, down from 17,341 a week ago and from last year's 12,594. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 5,419, compared with 11,302 a week ago and 9,233 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Midland Bank Posts Slim Profit, Announces 4,000 Job Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Midland Bank PLC, hurt by high interest rates and smaller margins, on Thursday posted a slim net profit of 22 million pounds, or about $40.5 million, in the first half of the year. Midland also announced it was cutting 4,000 jobs from its work force of 33,000. The firm said the cuts should be implemented by the end of 1991, mostly through attrition and voluntary departures. Midland said its net profit for the six months ended June 30 came to 1.3 pence, or about 2.4 cents per share. That compared with a net loss of 383 million pounds, or about $705 million, in the 1989 period, when the bank substantially raised its provisions against bad loans to Third World countries. On a pre-tax basis, the company had a profit of 36 million pounds, or about $66 million, compared with a loss of 531 million pounds, or $977 million, in the year-earlier period. Pre-tax profit before loan provisions and exceptional charges fell 19 percent to 363 million pounds, or about $668 million, from 440 million pounds ($810 million). Midland Chairman Sir Kit McMahon said the results were unacceptable but that refocusing the bank's operations toward investment banking, coupled with reducing assets and propping up the bank's capital for future growth, should help generate some added profitability over the next six months. Operating income was little changed at 1.55 billion pounds ($2.9 billion). Operating costs, partly due to a move to improve technology and expand certain British operations, rose 10 percent to 1.2 billion pounds ($2.2 billion). The bank is not required to report quarterly results. All figures were converted at the current exchange rate of 1.84 American dollars to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Rise Following Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing figures in Europe, midday prices in New York.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose today against major currencies in trading in Europe following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Gold prices rose. News of the Iraqi invasion early Thursday drove world oil prices sharply higher and sent foreign exchange traders scrambling to buy dollars, a potentially safe haven currency. The dollar's advance was underpinned by news of U.S. economic sanctions against Iraq and strong condemnations from other major industrialized nations against the Baghdad government's actions. The hardest-hit currency was the yen, which is especially vulnerable to oil price fluctuations because Japan imports nearly all its oil. As the day wore on, the dollar fell back from its peaks in thin trading, dealers said. Mike Lovell, senior corporate dealer for Bank of America in London, said the dollar was ``trading off what the next headline is'' about Iraq and Kuwait. ``It had been very choppy and prone to react to rumors,'' he added. William Simpson, money market economist with Barclays Bank, added that the threat of oil-supply disruptions in the Persian Gulf was helping to draw interest back to the dollar. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 148.90 yen, up 2.25 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 149.60 yen and it was quoted at 149.275 yen at midday in New York. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8495 from $1.8550 late Wednesday. In New York, the pound was quoted at midday at $1.85375. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.5970 West German marks, up from 1.5920; 1.3570 Swiss francs, up from 1.3555; 5.3510 French francs, up from 5.3355; 1.7985 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7935; 1,168.50 Italian lire, up from 1,164.75, and 1.1519 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1530. Selected dollar rates at midday in New York included: 1.5915 West German marks, 1.3560 Swiss francs, 1,166.00 Italian lire and 1.15225 Canadian dollars. Gold rose in London to $378.75 a troy ounce from $374.30 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to $379.00 an ounce from $371.50 late Tuesday. The market was closed Wednesday for a holiday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $7.93 an ounce to close at $379.39. Silver bullion rose in London to $4.87 a troy ounce from $4.82 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Close Sharply Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished sharply lower Thursday, following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Excluding the oil sector, stocks were knocked broadly lower as the market interpreted the events in the Persian Gulf to mean that higher oil prices would boost British inflation beyond its current 9.8 percent level and keep U.K. interest rates at the very least at their present 15 percent levels. ``We see the non-oil Western economies, with the exception of the U.S., facing the possibility of now having to tighten interest rates to counteract increased inflationary prospects,'' said Paul Harrison, a vice president at Salomon Brothers International in London. Wall Street also acted as a drag on the London market, dealers said. By the close of the European day, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 38.86 points at 2,860.40. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 34.5 points, or 1.5 percent, at 2,304.5 at the close. The session peak was 2,347.9. The Financial Times 30-share index fell 41.4 points to close at 1,811.4. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 16.04 points to close at 1,248.86. Volume came to 561.5 million shares, compared with 419.2 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bear, Stearns Quarterly Profits Down 30 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Bear Stearns Cos. said Thursday that earnings tumbled about 30 percent in its fourth quarter and full fiscal year, reflecting a continued slowdown in investment banking and retail brokerage. Bear Stearns reported profits of $33.5 million, or 32 cents a share, in its fourth quarter ended June 30. That was down 29.6 percent from profits of $47.6 million, or 43 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue totaled $640 million, up 16 percent from $630 million a year earlier. ``Fiscal 1990, particularly the first six months, was a tough year for the investment banking and brokerage industry,'' Bear Stearns Chairman Alan C. Greenberg said in a statement. ``I have heard that we are in a cyclical business. I am eagerly awaiting the next upward cycle,'' he said. Greenberg said the firm's fourth-quarter profits were helped by good performances in mortgage-backed securities, government bond and equity trading areas. For its full fiscal year, Bear Stearns reported profits of $119.4 million, or $1.10 a share, down 30.7 percent from $172.4 million, or $1.54 a share, in fiscal 1989. Annual revenue was $2.4 billion, about the same as in fiscal 1989. Bear Stearns is the parent of the investment firm Bear, Stearns & Co.

DOC.HEAD: Allied-Signal to Build $160 Million Plant in France
DOC.TEXT: Allied-Signal Inc. on Thursday announced it will build a $160 million plant in France to manufacture polyester fiber for passenger car tires, seat belts and other products. The advanced technology company said the plant would be built in Longwy, a city near the Belgian border, for $160 million. It is expected to begin operating by 1993 and employ about 300 workers. Allied-Signal has been manufacturing polyester since 1971 in Monroe, N.C., and has yearly industrial polyester sales of about $150 million, including exports to Europe, officials said in a statement. ``The Longwy site is strategically located so that we have excellent access to all our European customers,'' Fred Poses, president of Allied-Signal Engineered Materials, said in a statement. ``It will also allow us to take advantage of new markets in Eastern Europe as they develop.'' Allied-Signal is an advanced technology company with businesses in aerospace, automotive products and engineered materials.

Stock prices fell sharply today as news of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait jolted markets around the world. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 33.17 points to 2,866.09 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 380 up, 1,232 down and 330 unchanged. Stock prices tumbled in financial centers of the major industrialized countries following the overnight news that Iraqi forces had invaded and taken control of neighboring Kuwait on the Persian Gulf. World oil prices surged upward on the news, propelled by visions of possible disruptions in the supply of oil from the Middle East. That, in turn, raised fears of increased inflationary pressures in the United States and other oil-consuming economies. In addition, analysts said investors were fearful that any oil shock could hit the American economy at a vulnerable time, given its recent weak pace of growth. One of the few pockets of strength among U.S. stocks was the energy group. Texaco jumped 1} to 65}; Amoco 2 to 57]; Atlantic Richfield 4} to 135\; Exxon 1| to 53}, and Unocal 2 to 33[. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Boeing, down 1~ at 53~; American Express, down 1[ at 27{; Philip Morris, down ~ at 47, and General Motors, down 1| at 43}. The NYSE's composite index ots at controlling production. Iraq assaulted its much-smaller neighbor less than a week after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries signed an accord designed to restore production discipline to the sometimes unruly organization. ``It takes that piece of paper, puts a light to it and sends it up the chimney,'' said Peter Gignoux, director of the international energy department at Shearson Lehman Hutton in London. The invasion also reinforced suspicions that the cartel might be increasingly controlled by the whims of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Hussein's military threats against Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates were seen as a motivating factor in last week's agreement. He had complained that his country lost $14 billion in oil revenue in the past year because Kuwait and the U.A.E cheated on their OPEC supply quotas and forced down crude prices. ``It weakens the organization because one country now dominates completely and imposes its will on (the others),'' said Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris. But others said the invasion reflected changes that might signal greater discipline. ``Up until now, the cartel lacked an enforcement mechanism,'' said Nauman Barakat in Shearson's energy department in New York. ``We do now have that mechanism _ Saddam Hussein _ to make sure policies are enforced very vigorously.'' There was no comment from OPEC. ``This is a political thing,'' said one cartel official, demanding anonymity. ``It has nothing to do with us.'' The agreement, signed last Friday by all 13 nations, boosted OPEC's target price to $21 a barrel from the $18 mark in effect since December 1986. Iraq had argued for a $25 price. Analysts said the target was likely hit _ or even surpassed _ when crude prices surged Thursday on worries that the Iraqi invasion could disrupt supplies in the Persian Gulf. The average price of a basket of crudes monitored by the cartel was $17.50 last week. As part of their accord, OPEC ministers promised to limit total output to 22.5 million barrels a day for the rest of the year, above the ceiling of 22.1 million barrels in the first half of 1990. Actual output was put at about 23.2 million barrels in July. The arrangement also lifted the U.A.E.'s production quota by 400,000 barrels to 1.5 million barrels a day to try to end that country's cheating. the U.A.E. pumped 2 million barrels daily in July, according to new estimates from the International Energy Agency. With Iraq's aggression, the U.A.E. _ another small Gulf state _ will be even more inclined to halt excess production, analysts said. Kuwait's supply cap remains at 1.5 million barrels a day. It was producing about 100,000 barrels over that last month, although it had gone much higher earlier in the year, analysts said. Iraq, because of its oil might, long has been a powerful OPEC member. With Iran, it holds the second largest production quota at 3.1 million barrels a day each. Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, pumps about a quarter of the cartel's oil, with a quota of 5.4 million barrels.

DOC.HEAD: CPC International's President Elected Chief Executive Officer
DOC.TEXT: CPC International President Charles R. Shoemate on Thursday assumed the additional title of chief executive officer of the worldwide food company, officials said. James R. Eiszner, 62, who has been chief executive officer for the past six years, will continue as chairman. He has been with CPC International for 27 years. ``Both the board of directors and I have every confidence in Dick Shoemate's ability to build on the progress CPC has achieved over the past several years,'' said Eiszner, who has been undergoing treatment for cancer. Last year, CPC International had sales of $5.1 billion, making it one of the largest food companies in the United States. Its worldwide consumer foods business accounts for about 80 percent of total sales. Its products include Hellmann's and Best Foods mayonnaise, Mazola corn oil and margarine, Skippy peanut butter, Thomas' English muffins and Mueller's pasta products. Shoemate, 50, joined CPC International in 1962 and held a variety of positions in manufacturing, finance and business management before becoming president of the company's Canadian subsidiary in 1981. He became a vice president in 1983, president of the corn refining division in 1987 and was elected company president in October 1988, according to a statement. The Illinois native also became a member of the board of directors in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Soar in Frenzied Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 17 new grafs to update with later prices and developments in financial markets. Picks up 14th graf pvs, Peter Nichol ...
DOC.TEXT: Oil and gold prices and the dollar soared today on world financial markets after Iraq's invasion of Iraq, but then fell back when buyers decided they had overeacted. Oil prices were nearly $2 a barrel higher late in the day after rising more than $3 in frenzied trading earlier on concerns the invasion would disrupt supplies. Iraq and Kuwait are among the world's biggest oil producers and represent more than 20 percent of OPEC's output. The dollar jumped most sharply against the Japanese yen, because the American currency is viewed as a haven and Japan imports 99 percent of its oil. Gold, also regarded as a safe investment during times of turmoil, finished in London with a gain of more than $4 a troy ounce, after having moved as much as $14 higher than Wednesday's finish earlier in the day. Stock prices fell on inflationary fears but oil-related shares benefited. There was confusion in the financial markets following today's invasion. ``There are a lot of wild cards out there,'' said Peter Gignoux, manager of the international energy desk at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in London. Ted Arnold, a metals specialist at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith Ltd. in London, said: ``The market at this stage is very, very confused. No one is certain what is going to happen.'' The spot price of North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, stood at $22.39 a barrel by late Thursday afternoon, up from Wednesday's London close of $20.40. The last time oil prices moved up this sharply was during the Iranian revolution in 1979, Gignoux said. Trading on the Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp spot oil market was disorderly, and one Rotterdam broker complained of difficulty in getting accurate price quotes. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 148.90 yen, up 2.25 yen from Wednesday's close and later in London, the dollar was quoted at a higher rate of 149.60 yen. Gold was quoted at a late spot bid of $378.75 per ounce in London, up from $374.30 late Wednesday. A main concern is that higher oil prices will fuel inflation in major industrial countries. London's Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index dropped 34.5 points, or 1.5 percent, to close at 2,304.5. In light of Britain's decision to freeze all Kuwaiti assets, the London Stock Exchange late Thursday advised members to review all its securities transactions entered into on behalf of the government or residents of Kuwait. The Stock Exchange advised member firms not to undertake any further business on behalf of such investors and suggested that its members ``explore the possibility of cancelling all such transactions entered into'' today. Peter Nicol, an analyst with the London investment firm Warburg Securities, said he didn't expect any actual disruption of oil supplies, and that prices could drift back down if there is not ``major escalation of news.'' But Nicol said the fear of disruption ``is genuine and people are right to be concerned. It makes people focus again on the security of supplies.'' Countries that depend on Kuwait and Iraqi oil could easily switch to other suppliers in a global market that, at the moment, is awash in oil. However, North Sea production currently is down to 1.9 million barrels a day, instead of up to 2.3 million barrels a day, because fields are shut down for routine summer maintenance. Today, oil workers began a 24-hour wildcat strike to protest safety standards. At the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries last week, Iraq pressed for a target price of $25 a barrel and for output curbs. Under last week's pact, Iraq has a quota of 3.14 million barrels a day, and Kuwait of 1.5 million barrels a day under OPEC's production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day for the second half of the year. The 13-member cartel's oil target price is $21 a barrel. OPEC currently is producing about 23 million barrels a day, Nicol said.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Gains; Corn, Soybeans Slip on Weather
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices closed slightly higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade but the corn and soybean markets fell, extending Wednesday's losses amid forecasts for more good crop weather in the Midwest. The markets got an early boost from the overwhelmingly bullish sentiment that flooded the crude oil and precious metal markets following news that Iraq invaded Kuwait. But the event had no real effect on grain supply and demand, so traders returned their attention to predictions that a beneficial weather pattern of mild temperatures and occasional showers will continue in the Midwest, said William Biedermann, research director with the futures brokerage Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to 3{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.83 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 3{ cents lower with September at $2.52{ a bushel; oats were 2{ cents to 4{ cents lower with September at $1.18{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 4{ cents lower with August at $5.80{ a bushel.
The stock market fell sharply in heavy trading today, unsettled by the news of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 36.88 at 2,862.38.

DOC.HEAD: Grace Board Names Bolduc As President
DOC.TEXT: Chemical giant W.R. Grace & Co. said Thursday its board has selected vice chairman J.P. Bolduc as president and chief operating officer. Bolduc, 51, will succeed Charles H. Erhart Jr., 65, who is retiring as president but will continue as a director. Erhart had been president for a little more than a year. The post of chief operating officer has been vacant since 1986. The selection was announced by J. Peter Grace, chairman and chief executive of the $6.1 billion diversified specialty chemical company. It appears to put Bolduc in line to succeed Grace should the 77-year-old chairman decide to step down. Grace has given no indication he intends to step down. But Grace spokesman Fred Bona said that with the new assignment, Bolduc ``is clearly No. 2 in the company.'' Bolduc had been one of three Grace vice chairmen who since 1986 have had operating control over various facets of the company. The others are J. Murfree Butler and Joseph R. Wright Jr. who will continue as vice chairmen and report to a restructured office of the chairman and president. Bolduc will be the company's ninth president since its incorporation in 1899. He joined the company in 1983 as a senior vice president and later became executive vice president and chief financial officer. He was involved in Grace's restructuring that began in 1986 and most recently had corporate operating responsibility for Grace's energy, health care and specialty businesses groups that include cocoa production, book distribution and specialty textiles and agriculture. Before joining Grace in February 1983, he was vice president and partner at Booz-Allen & Hamilton Inc., a management and technical consulting firm. He served as an assistant secretary for the U.S. Department of Agriculture under Presidents Nixon and Ford. He also was chief operating officer for President Reagan's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control in the Federal Government, better known as the Grace Commission, that recommended ways the government could operate more efficiently. W.R. Grace employs about 51,000 people in 46 states and 44 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rallies, Then Steadies Amid Iraq-Kuwait Conflict
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rocketed higher Thursday after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent currency investors scrambling to a safe haven. But the buying frenzy faded in later trading and the dollar ended the day well off its peaks. Gold gained strongly on world markets. Foreign exchange dealers in Asia, Europe and the United States reported business was extremely brisk, particularly in the first hours after news broke that Iraqi troops had moved into neighboring Kuwait. ``It has been a little bit crazy looking back over the last 24 hours,'' said Peter Wild, treasurer at the Swiss bank Bank Julius Baer & Co. in New York. The dollar rode a roller coaster. It was driven up steeply against all its major foreign counterparts in the early going as panicky investors poured money into dollars as a way of protecting themselves against the instability caused by the Persian Gulf turmoil. Later, the U.S. currency fell back to earth when dealers took advantage of the surge to sell and collect profits on their dollar holdings. Concern about weak U.S. economic growth in light of recent poor reports damped enthusiasm for dollars. Statistics due Friday on unemployment during July were widely awaited by the financial markets. Only the Japanese yen failed to regain much of the ground it lost to the dollar. Dealers unloaded yen due to concern that Japan would be hurt more than any other major industrialized country by disruptions in Mideast oil supplies. Japan depends on imports for nearly all its oil needs. By the time trading was done in New York, the dollar stood at 149.30 yen, up from 147.30 yen Wednesday but below an earlier high of nearly 150 yen. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 148.90 yen, up 2.25 yen from Wednesday's close and in London the dollar was quoted at 149.60 yen. The dollar's advance was underpinned by news of U.S. economic sanctions against Iraq and strong condemnations from other major industrialized nations against the Baghdad government's actions. British sterling lost some ground against the dollar. A pound was quoted at $1.8545 late in New York, compared to $1.8552 late Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8495 from $1.8550 late Wednesday. Precious metals, often considered a safe haven in times of international tension, rose in world trading. Gold for current delivery added $3.50 a troy ounce on New York's Commodity Exchange, settling at $376.80. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $376.90 a troy ounce, up $3.40 from Wednesday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. In London, gold rose to $378.75 a troy ounce from $374.30 late Wednesday.
