DOC.HEAD: Judge: Former Striking Pilots Can Bump Trainees
DOC.TEXT: Union pilots who joined a strike against Eastern Airlines have the right to replace trainees hired during the carrier's rebuilding, a federal judge ruled Thursday. ``It's clearly a major victory,'' said E.J. Breen, spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association, which challenged an Eastern claim that returning pilots were not needed. But Eastern planned to appeal the decision and officials said there will be no immediate effect on current employees or operations. A statement by Eastern indicated its ``appeal is likely to take some time.'' All but 200 of the 3,600 ALPA pilots walked off the job in sympathy with striking Machinists in March 1989. Pilots ended their strike last November, but fewer than 50 have been recalled to the Miami-based airline, ALPA officials said. In a 12-page ruling, U.S. District Court Judge Edward Davis agreed with ALPA's claims that the federal Railway Labor Act guarantees returning strikers job rights ahead of the newly hired trainees. ``The court must balance competing interests: the right of striking pilots to return to jobs against management's efforts to maintain the status quo throughout the strike,'' Davis wrote. ``This court concludes the balance weighs in favor of reinstating in place of trainees.'' Breen said the exact number of jobs affected by the ruling likely will be determined through further hearings. But ALPA contends that at least 404 pilots were in training when pilots ended their strike in November and are subject to replacement. Eastern spokewoman Karen Ceremsak said the airline estimates 180 jobs are affected by the ruling. About 1,400 former Eastern pilots may still be interested in returning, said ALPA spokesman Lou Baldwin in Miami. Many of the pilots were hired by other airlines following the strike that began March 4, 1989. Eastern filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection five days after the strike began and presently operates about 800 flights from its pre-strike service of 1,040. Ms. Ceremsak said she does not believe Davis' ruling must receive bankruptcy court approval. Davis concluded Eastern's hiring of pilot trainees violated the Railway Labor Act because the company did not bring on workers already qualified to fly regular flights. The purpose of the act it to provide ``uninterrupted transportation service,'' Davis ruled. ``Contracting with unqualified persons for future employment as pilots does not serve to fill the void left by the striking pilots _ as least not until some later date,'' Davis wrote. The ruling stems from an August 1989 court filing by Eastern seeking a judgment that it need not replace newly hired pilots with returning pilots. Baldwin said the Eastern pilots trainees' annual pay of about $27,000 is significantly higher than the industry average. The average pre-strike pay at Eastern for fully accredited pilots was about $65,000, he said. If Davis' ruling is upheld on appeal, all returning pilots would need to go through several weeks of recertification training under the Federal Aviation Administration, Eastern officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $800.1 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 521 money market mutual funds rose $800.1 million in the latest week to a new high, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise, to $395.42 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $1.88 billion revised increase in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The total was revised back to July 4 to include eight newly reporting institutional funds with assets of $2.8 billion. The previous high in the funds' assets was $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21, 1990. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 251 general purpose funds rose $541.5 million to $136.44 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds rose $258.7 million to $161.01 billion, and assets of 168 institutional funds fell $100,000 to $97.97 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.56 percent from 7.59 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.62 percent from 7.65 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 44 days, unchanged from the previous week, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.11 percent as of Wednesday from 6.12 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, fell to 5.02 percent from 5.03 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.81 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.86 the previous week. Yields were 7.97 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.03 percent; 8.02 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 8.06 percent; and 8.11 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.14 percent.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices sustained widespread losses Thursday in the heaviest trading of the year as news of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait jolted markets around the world. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 34.66 points to 2,864.60. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 464 up, 1,211 down and 349 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board reached 253.09 million shares, up from 176.81 million Wednesday and the heaviest total since a 416.29 million-share day last Oct. 16. Stock prices tumbled in financial centers of the major industrialized countries following the overnight news that Iraqi forces had invaded and taken control of neighboring Kuwait on the Persian Gulf. World oil prices surged upward on the news, propelled by visions of possible disruptions in the supply of oil from the Middle East. That, in turn, raised fears of increased inflationary pressures in the United States and other oil-consuming economies. In the bond market, which is especially sensitive to changes in inflationary expectations, prices of long-term government bonds fell more than $10 for each $1,000 in face value, raising their yields to the 8.45 percent-8.48 percent range. In addition, analysts said investors were fearful that any oil shock could hit the American economy at a vulnerable time, given its recent weak pace of growth. One of the few pockets of strength among U.S. stocks was the energy group. Texaco jumped 2{ to 66{; Amoco 2~ to 58\; Atlantic Richfield 4~ to 135]; Exxon 1 to 53[, and Unocal 2[ to 33\. Among oil-service stocks, Schlumberger climbed 2\ to 68}; Halliburton 1} to 57], and Baker Hughes 1\ to 33\. Precious-metals stocks also moved up along with the price of gold. ASA Ltd. gained } to 49{; Newmont Gold 1\ to 50~, and Homestake Mining \ to 20[. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Boeing, down 2{ at 53\; American Express, down | at 28; Philip Morris, down 1[ at 46}, and General Motors, down 1{ at 43~. Fund American, which agreed to sell its Fireman's Fund Insurance operations to Allianz of West Germany, shot up 11| to 49}. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 302.71 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $36.52 billion, or 1.08 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 2.02 to 192.36. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 4.55 to 415.29, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 4.04 at 351.48. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slumped 7.02 to 428.89. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 352.15, down 1.15.

DOC.HEAD: Gold's Reaction to Iraq News Disappoints Bulls
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices ended moderately higher Thursday on New York's Commodity Exchange after paring gains of more than $10 an ounce in a move inspired by Iraq's conquest of Kuwait. The performance disappointed market bulls, but analysts said it could be several days before the dust settles and reveals whether gold has ended its recent upward trend. On other commodity markets, oil futures soared; livestock and meat futures were down sharply; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Gold futures settled $3.40 to $3.50 higher with the contract for delivery in August at $376.80 a troy ounce; silver was 1 cent to 1.3 cents higher with August at $4.835 a troy ounce. August gold traded as high as $386.50 during the session, posting its strongest gains just after the opening as traders reacted to news of the Iraq-Kuwait conflict. Demand for gold typically rises during times of international hostitility and economic uncertainty. Reports that Iraqi troops had seized the Kuwaiti capital prompted frenzied buying of petroleum futures and aggressive selling of stocks. Those events also sent strong buy signals to the gold market. Analysts said the conquest of Kuwait catapulted Iraq to the top ranks of world oil powers and posed new economic risks for the United States and other countries dependent on imported oil. But after the early price spike, selling gradually eroded most of gold's gains. And even though the market settled at or above a level that only a day before had been considered a key test of the market's underlying strength, analysts said the close was disappointing. ``It's really hard to feel exuberant about the gold market considering it finished near the lows of the day,'' said Craig Sloane, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. But Sloane said the market typically takes a day or two to adjust after a major event such as Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``I would regard tomorrow as a real good test,'' he said. ``If this market wants to trade well, we'll have to do better tomorrow.'' Petroluem futures also closed below the day's highs on the New York Mercantile Exchange. But prices still ended dramatically higher in reaction to a swiftly imposed U.S. ban on Iraqi imports in response to the attack. Iraqi oil accounts for about 8 percent of U.S. oil imports. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 72 cents to $1.57 higher with September at $23.11 a barrel; heating oil was 2.15 cents to 3.5 cents higher with September at 64.69 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 3 cents to 3.8 cents higher with September at 68.07 cents a gallon. Weak cash markets sent pork futures down sharply for the second straight day on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. All frozen pork belly contracts plunged the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound; near-term hog futures fell their limit of 1.5 cents. Cattle futures also fell but closed above the day's lows. Live cattle settled .30 cent to .65 cent lower with August at 77.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .62 cent lower with August at 88.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .65 cent to 1.5 cents lower with August at 58.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents lower across the board with August at 47.22 cents a pound. Wheat futures prices rose slightly on the Chicago Board of Trade but the corn and soybean markets fell, extending Wednesday's losses amid forecasts for more good crop weather in the Midwest. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 3{ cents higher with September at $2.83 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 3 cents lower with September at $2.52} a bushel; oats were 3} cents to 4\ cents lower with September at $1.18} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 4} cents lower with August at $5.80\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Markets Shaken by Persian Gulf Hostilities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Oil Prices.
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's invasion of Iraq shook financial markets around the world Thursday, sending oil prices, the dollar and interest rates soaring and stock prices reeling. Crude oil rose $1.57 a barrel in New York futures trading and nearly $2 in London, unleashing fears of a resurgence of inflation and a possible recession in the United States that affected other markets Oil prices were boosted by the possibility the invasion eventually could affect output from the two nations or other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose $1.57 to $23.11 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later months advanced $1, the limit for one-day advances in those contracts. Prices soared on the opening of trading, with the September contract reaching $23.80, but lost ground after reports circulated that Iraq might withdraw its troops within 48 hours. Earlier in London, the spot price of North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, finished at $22.39 a barrel, up nearly $2 from Wednesday but down from its highs of the day. ``It's been a rumor-driven market,'' said Greg Dreis, a trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. Traders said they had not seen oil prices shoot up as fast since 1979, when the Iranian revolution also raised concerns about the flow of oil from the Middle East. But trading was checked somewhat by the knowledge that other oil producers, including OPEC's biggest member, Saudi Arabia, could increase their output and provide a safety valve against a severe drop in oil shipments. ``They have the potential to make up for a substantial portion if not all of any deficit,'' said William Byers, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Co. Trading was similar for the dollar, which rose in early trading before falling back somewhat. The U.S. currency got a two-fold boost: The dollar is considered a safe haven for investors during world strife, and it is the medium of exchange for crude oil. Analysts said traders who have shied away from it recently were buying heavily in early trading to adjust their holdings. But the dollar, which has been depressed in recent weeks because of the weakening U.S. economy, gave up some of its gains as foreign exchange traders later grew pessimistic about the economic ramifications of surging oil prices. With oil and other energy sources crucial for every segment of the economy, rising crude prices can reinvigorate inflation. That would make the Federal Reserve _ which considers fighting inflation one of its top priorities _ less likely to move interest rates lower. ``Even if the Fed eased (credit), it would be more tentative,'' said Raymond Stone, a managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. ``If these oil prices stick, it means the country will be that much closer to recession,'' Stone said. The dollar closed at 1.5910 West German marks, up from 1.58885 late Wednesday in New York trading. The British pound, which has stormed higher against the dollar recently, slipped to $1.8545 from $1.8552. The Japanese yen fell sharply, as Japan imports 99 percent of its oil and would be hurt by a surge in oil prices. The dollar rose to 149.30 yen from late Thursday's 147.30. Stock and bond prices also were depressed by fears about the economy. On Wall Street, traders were concerned about the effect oil prices would have on corporate profits. Heavy selling sent stock prices broadly lower. The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue chip stocks dropped 34.66 points to 2,864.60. On the broader market, declining issues outpaced advancers by a margin of more than 5 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange. One sector of stocks that bucked the downward trend was energy issues, which advanced on the expectation of higher profits for oil producers. Stocks also fell in London, where the widely followed Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index dropped 34.5 points to 2,304.5. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 592.81 points, or 1.92 percent, to close at 30,245.18 in Thursday trading. Investors were panicked by the effect that oil prices would have on business in Japan. Bond prices were hit hard by the prospect of higher inflation, which erodes the valued of fixed-income securities, and by the possibility that interest rates won't be dropping soon. Bond prices rise when rates decline, so higher rates depress prices. In late trading, the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was down about $12.18 per $1,000 in face value. The bond's yield, considered a benchmark for interest rates throughout the economy, soared to 8.46 percent from 8.35 percent late Wednesday. The rising prices of crude boosted prices for refined products traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The September contract for home heating oil rose 3.50 cents to 64.69 cents a gallon, while wholesale unleaded gasoline for September delivery jumped 3.80 cents to 68.07 cents a gallon. In natural gas trading, the September contract closed at $1.432 per 1,000 cubic feet, up from $1.402.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Mixed
DOC.TEXT: One measure of the nation's money supply rose while another fell in the week ended July 23, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,268.5 billion from $3,273.9 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,054.9 billion from $4,052.0 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $808.0 billion from $807.9 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 3.1 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.0 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged 3,269.0 billion, a 1.0 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,055.8 billion, down 0.5 percent, while M1 rose 2.2 percent to an average of $807.9 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks rose $383 million. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $523 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $654 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $123 million in the two weeks ended July 18, down from $280 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $310.8 billion in the two-week period ended July 25, up from $307.7 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Montgomery Ward, Sears End Talks
DOC.TEXT: Montgomery Ward & Co. and Sears, Roebuck & Co. announced Thursday the two retailers had terminated joint talks, but declined to indicate what the discussions had entailed. The retail chains said in separate, but nearly identical one-paragraph statements that the companies had discussed ``certain joint opportunities.'' However, the chains decided to remain independent retailers, the statements said. Spokesmen for both companies would not comment on whether the retailers had considered merging. ``Certain joint opportunities doesn't mean a merger,'' said Charles H. Thorne, a spokesman for Montgomery Ward. ``We're standing on the statement as it has been provided,'' said Jerry Buldak, Sears' director of external communication. The companies released the announcements in Chicago, where they are headquartered, and in New York. The announcement was in response to media inquiries, the statements said.

DOC.HEAD: KG&E Urges Stockholders To Reject Tender Offer From KCPL
DOC.TEXT: Kansas Gas and Electric Co. urged stockholders Thursday to reject a $27-per-share, $875 million takeover offer from Kansas City Power and Light Co. KG&E said the offer, made last month, of $857 million in cash for its common stock and $18 million cash for three series of preferred stock was inadequate. KCPL spokesman Turner White said the utility still was willing to negotiate with KG&E. But he said KCPL officials needed to study KG&E's full response before deciding on their next move. Federal lawsuits have been filed by both utilities and two groups of KG&E stockholders in connection with the takeover attempt. In documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, KG&E said its board decided last Friday that the offer was inadequate and not in the best interests of the company and its shareholders. KG&E did not indicate how much the offer fell short of its perceived value of the company. KG&E said it was not involved in merger, sale or reorganization talks with anyone. The company said it does not believe KCPL has met conditions needed to require KG&E to provide a list of stockholders and call a special shareholders meeting. The utility said it believes the offer could have adverse tax consequences for some shareholders and significant effects on employees, customers and the communities KG&E serves. White said KCPL does not plan to lay off any KG&E workers. He said the utility would freeze customer rates until Jan. 1, 1993, and has a strong record of commitment to communities in its service area. KG&E has excess generating capacity that KCPL would like to utilize to postpone building new generating plants. KG&E said its strategies for the future include a ``carefully structured long-term plan for revenue enhancement from increased sales of power and energy in both wholesale and retail markets.'' The filings also said KG&E was instituting further controls on capital and operating costs that would improve earnings without significantly increasing rates. KG&E, headquartered in Wichita, has 1,330 employees and 254,000 customers in south central and southeast Kansas. Its 1989 revenue was $533.5 million and it reported net profits of $47.5 million. KCPL, headquartered in Kansas City, Mo., employs 2,800 people and serves 409,000 customers in western Missouri and eastern Kansas. It made $108.6 million on $730 million in revenue in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Mahlmann's Problems Fuel SEC-CFTC Turf War
DOC.TEXT: The scandal-ridden resignation of Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann has helped revive a regulatory turf war that appeared to be winding down for lack of fuel. Within hours of Mahlmann's announcement Wednesday, U.S. Reps. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., and Edward J. Markey, D-Mass, announced an investigation into the collapse of his brokerage firm with an emphasis on ``the adequacy of regulation and oversight in the futures industry.'' On Thursday, one futures industry leader countered that the Securities and Exchange Commission, which regulates securities trading, might be more to blame than the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which regulates futures trading, for any failure to protect customers of Mahlmann's trading company, Stotler Group Inc. After all, said David Vogel, chairman of the Futures Industry Association, as a futures brokerage trade group, the SEC had jurisdiction over Stotler's offering of shares in two commodity investment funds that are at the center of federal allegations that Stotler defrauded customers. ``If anybody wants to start throwing stones, it's a little difficult to figure out who to throw stones at,'' said Vogel, chief executive of the futures brokerage LIT America Inc. ``I don't want to say the SEC's responsible but I don't think the CFTC's responsible at all,'' Vogel said in a telephone interview. The argument signals another round in the long-running SEC-CFTC brawl for jurisdiction over stock-index futures. The fall of ``Cash'' Mahlmann had nothing to do with stock-index futures, which are contracts traded on futures exchanges that allow investors to speculate on stock-market movements without ever owning stocks. But Mahlmann's problems have much to do with critics' perceptions that the CFTC is a lax regulator with a too-cozy relationship with the industry it is supposed to be overseeing. William Hegen, deputy regional administrator of the Chicago SEC office, has said the SEC tipped off the CFTC to an allegedly improper transfer of $13.4 million in debt from a Stotler unit to the parent company. Critics of the futures industry are likely to complain that the CFTC should have been keeping a closer watch on Stotler, said James McGurk, a Chicago commodities lawyer who has followed the SEC-CFTC turf battle. ``The foes of the industry are going to use this,'' he said. ``The battle rages.'' The fight had cooled recently amid waning congressional support for a Bush-administration bill transferring jurisdiction over stock-index futures to the SEC. But Stotler's collapse gives the SEC and its supporters more ammunition, McGurk said. ``Now they've got an answer: `We're trying to do it better than these guys who couldn't do it.' That's the argument that's going to be advanced,'' he said. The fraud charges filed Tuesday by the CFTC were prompted by an alleged separate attempt to inject cash into the financially ailing Stotler. Court documents allege that Stotler Funds Inc., an affiliate of Stotler that operates commodity investment pools, improperly transferred more than $5 million in customer funds to the parent company. The funds were supposed to be used only for investment in commodity markets. Mahlmann has denied any involvement in Stotler's recent financial decisions, saying he was spending almost all his time running the Board of Trade.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings of Secondary Mortgage Company Rise 11 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Freddie Mac, the secondary mortgage market company, said Wednesday that earnings rose 11 percent in the April-June quarter to a 20-year record. Earnings were $118 million, or $1.97 per share, compared with $106 million, $1.77 per share, in the same period of 1989. Freddie Mac, the nickname for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., is a congressionally chartered, shareholder-owned company that purchases mortgages from lenders and packages many of them into securities for resale to investors. Its activities account for financing of about one in eight home purchases. Robert J. Quinlan, Freddie Mac's senior vice president of control, attributed the earnings rise to increased fee income and a widening in the spread between the interest it earns on its mortgages and the interest it pays on its securities. The earnings increase came despite a rise in Freddie Mac's provision for mortgage losses, which totaled $87 million in the second quarter, up from $61 million a year ago. The company's purchase of mortgages declined 4 percent to $17.6 billion in the second quarter, compared with $18.4 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Gramm Breezes Through Senate Hearing
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top futures regulator denied that a commodities firm linked to former Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann received special treatment in a probe of alleged wrongdoing. Commodity Futures Trading Commission Chairman Wendy Gramm told a Senate panel Thursday night that Mahlmann, who resigned as CBOT head amid charges of wrongdoing against a company he headed, was not treated as ``a fellow insider by industry insiders.'' Gramm, the wife of Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, also denied allegations that she did polticial work for her husband and was paid out of campaign funds, which might be a conflict of interest if any contributors were regulated by the CFTC. ``I don't involve myself in my husband's campaign,'' Gramm told the Senate Agriculture Committee, adding that she did not know who contributors were. Except for those two issues, the one-hour hearing seemed more like a testimonial dinner as senator after senator among the handful of committee members present late Thursday praised Gramm and her agency. The panel was expected to vote favorably on her renomination and send it to the full Senate Friday or Saturday, Senate aides said. On Wednesday, the same day he resigned as chief of the world's largest commodity futures exchange, Mahlmann also stepped down as head of Stotler Group Inc., the parent company of a firm accused by the CFTC of fraud. But in answer to a question by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., the committee's chairman, Gramm said neither the CBOT nor the CFTC moved slowly against Stotler because of Mahlmann's position. ``Certainly this commission has never shied away from taking action against well respected members'' of exchanges, Gramm told the panel. But another committee member, Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., said in a written statement that ``incidents such as the Stotler case only serve to strengthen'' support for a Bush administration-backed bill to strip the CFTC of authority over stock index futures and give it to the rival Securities and Exchange Commission. The SEC and the Treasury Department claim control of stock index futures, which allow investors to trade on the market's movement through a large array of stocks without actually buying the underlying stocks, is necessary to avoid sharp market fluctuations like the 1987 stock market crash. The CFTC and the futures industry oppose the move, saying it will impede the futures markets. An attempt to work out a compromise measure and include it in the Senate farm bill ran out of time late last week. Bond said if a compromise to eliminate the turf battle between the CFTC and the SEC isn't reached he could ``easily be among those pushed into the Treasury camp.'' But Leahy used the hearing to repeat his opposition to a jurisdictional swap. ``I feel that the Treasury Department and the SEC have acted in a highly irresponsible manner by pressing this idea in a way that has created a bitter political stalemate'' blocking reform bills for both the futures and securities markets,'' said Leahy. He conceded that a compromise would have to be worked out or a bill reauthorizing the CFTC and giving it added anti-fraud powers ``stands no chance of becoming law in the final weeks of this Congress.'' Critics have questioned Gramm's numerous trips to Texas in the two-and-a-half years as CFTC chairman. She said she made nine trips in 1988, nine more last year and four so far this year. While she conceded accompanying him to ``some fundraising events'' Gramm said she didn't know who contributed ``because I don't look at the list of contributors.'' Her husband does not accept honoraria from organizations regulated by the CFTC to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest but ``I don't know if there are any regulatees of the commission who contribute to Phil's campaign because I'm not involved in that area,'' she said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, Iraqi troops ... six work, to CLARIFY that State Department has not confirmed Iraqi army picked them up, UPDATE number; PICK UP eighth graf, Among other ...
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Oil Companies Largely Unaffected By Invasion
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait-Markets Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Major U.S oil companies said Thursday they had small or no operations in Kuwait and did not expect infrequent crude shipments from the country to be disrupted because of the invasion by neighboring Iraq. Texaco Inc. operates the only refinery in either country _ a 50-50 joint venture with state-owned Kuwait Oil Co.in an area known as the neutral zone between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Texaco spokeswoman Anita Larsen said about 80 percent of the refinery's 800 employees are Saudi nationals and are 17 American. She said operations were continuing despite the invasion. Gerald Lastelic, spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute in Washington, said the Texaco-Kuwait venture is the only U.S.-owned refinery operating in Iraq or Kuwait. The Texaco-Kuwait refinery produces about 135,000 barrels a day out of three fields, Larsen said. Eight American oil field workers were reported missing near the border of Kuwait and company officials suspected they had been picked up by the invading Iraqi army, the State Department said. The whereabouts of the eight were unknown and State Department officials would not identify the company for whom they work. Among other large American oil companies, Exxon Corp., Mobil Inc., Atlantic Richfield Co., Amoco Corp. and Chevron Corp. all said they had no operations in Kuwait and did not rely on oil from the Middle East nation. Amoco spokesman Michael Thompson in Chicago said that less than 5 percent of the oil used in its U.S. refineries was Kuwaiti crude. ``We have no reason to believe shipments from Kuwait will be threatened,'' he said. ``And even if they were, a short-term loss of Kuwait oil would not hinder our U.S. refining operations.'' Chevron spokesman Larry Shushan said from his company's San Francisco headquarters: ``We do from time to time of course take oil from ports in that area. It obviously is something we are quite concerned about because we are not going to be sending any ships into a war zone.'' Royal Dutch Shell Group, the European parent of Shell Oil Co., has one employee of a lubricants subsidiary in Kuwait, spokesman Norman Altstedter said, but no other operations. He said Shell Oil imports no oil from Kuwait but 60,000 to 80,000 barrels a day from Iraq, about 6 percent of its crude oil capacity. Short-term needs would be covered by inventories but Altstedter said some adjustments may be needed on the company's longer term purchasing requirements. Exxon issued a statement saying it has imported some oil from Iraq to the United States in recent months. ``We are currently evaluating our situation and taking steps to minimize any impact on our customers worldwide,'' it said. Although none of the companies was directly affected, U.S. oil company stocks rose sharply on news of the invasion, which boosted oil prices. In New York Stock Exchange trading, Texaco gained $2.50 to $66.50, Amoco rose $2.87{ to $58.25, Chevron rose $1.62{ to $80.37{, Mobil was up $1.87{ to $67.25, Atlantic Richfield was up $4.87{ to $135.37{, Exxon rose $1 to $53.12{ and Unocal was up $2.12{ to $33.25.

DOC.HEAD: Delta, Pilots Union Reach Contract Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines and the Air Line Pilots Association agreed Thursday to a new contract that the union said included 12.5 percent pay raises that would make the carrier's pilots the industry's best-paid. The tentative agreement follows 19 months of direct negotiations between the company and ALPA, which represents about 7,600 pilots at Delta. ``We are pleased that we've been able to reach a tentative agreement without having to resort to mediation,'' said Capt. Gary Holcombe, chairman of the Delta pilots' Master Executive Council. ``This contract is industry-leading in all aspects, and one that will both compensate Delta pilots fairly and give Delta the resources it needs to continue to grow,'' Holcombe said. Delta spokesman Neil Monroe said the airline was pleased the agreement was made, but said the company had no further comment. ALPA said the agreement calls for pay increases totaling 12.5 percent until the contract can be amended in 1993. A statement by the union said it would make the Delta pilots highest paid in the industry, however the union was not able to provide figures on top-scale salaries. ALPA spokesman Rhea Nicolls said under the terms of the agreement, the starting salary for new hires, including hourly pay during their training, would rise from $1,800 a month to $2,500. The agreement also calls for the elimination of Delta's two-tier wage system, which pays newer employees at a lower rate than veterans, in the fourth and fifth years of a pilot's employment beginning Sept. 1, 1992. Nicolls said such pay scales have been common in the industry, though disliked by pilots, since airline deregulation. ``This is a big breakthrough in the airline industry,'' he said. The contract will be formally written over the next four weeks, and will be submitted to Delta pilots for ratification.

DOC.HEAD: Grumman Reports 37 Percent Increase in Second Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Grumman Corporation reported Wednesday that net income for the second quarter of the year increased 37 percent on higher revenues from its aerospace business, the company said. Net income was $26.7 million, or 78 cents per share, on sales of $1.05 billion in the April-June period. For the same period last year, net income was $19.5 million, or 56 cents per share, on revenue of $881.4 million. Both sales and profit increases were primarily related to the F-14D fighter plane program that has higher unit prices than the F14A Plus aircraft delivered last year, the company said. Renso Caporali, Grumman's newly appointed chairman, said the favorable results indicate the company is doing a good job of managing its business in a difficult environment for the aerospace industry. In the second quarter, sales in the aerospace segment of the company increased to $799.3 million from $618.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: KCPL Takeover Bid Generates Court Action
DOC.TEXT: Kansas Gas and Electric Co. Wednesday asked a judge to dismiss a lawsuit seeking to force the utility to call a special shareholder meeting to consider a takeover bid by Kansas City Power and Light Co. KG&E asked that the suit filed by KCPL in U.S. District Court in Kansas City, Mo., be dismissed or transferred to Wichita's federal court. The KCPL suit seeks a court order requiring the special shareholders' meeting. KCPL launched a $27 cash per share tender offer for KG&E on July 23. KG&E has said it will respond to the offer, which amounts to $875 million, by Friday. KG&E accused KCPL of forum shopping _ trying to find a friendly court jurisdiction in which to file suit, hoping for favorable treatment. ``KCPL has reversed the roles of plaintiff and defendant in a transparent attempt to select the forum,'' KG&E said in its court papers. A KG&E stockholder filed a class action lawsuit in federal court in Kansas City, Mo., Tuesday echoing the allegations made in a similar suit filed July 26 by another stockholder. The Tuesday suit accuses KG&E management of entrenching itself in office and trying to thwart an auction of the company. KG&E filed suit Tuesday in Witchita federal court challenging the legality of the unsolicited takeover bid. The action seeks to block KCPL's requests for a list of KG&E stockholders and a special meeting of shareholders in late August or September. KG&E claims the takeover bid is illegal because KCPL hasn't asked for Securities and Exchange Commission approval. Therefore, the request for the list and shareholders' meeting is invalid, the lawsuit claims. KCPL contends the acquisition doesn't require SEC approval.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Oil Move Higher On Iraqi Offensive News
DOC.TEXT: The dollar moved higher along with oil prices during morning trading in Tokyo Thursday on news of Iraq's offensive into Kuwait. The dollar tends to rise in times of world unrest because it is regarded as a safe haven. The dollar closed the morning session at 147.70 yen, up 1.05 yen from Wednesday's close of 146.65 yen. After opening at 147.13 yen, the currency ranged between 146.50 yen and 148.15 yen. Tokyo traders reported the marker price for North Sea oil, Brent crude, was bid up to 21.30 dollars a barrel, about 30 to 40 cents higher than in New York late Wednesday. No sellers were reported, however. Currency dealers said the news that Iraqi troops crossed the border with Kuwait set off sharp buying of the dollar, which had been pushed to its morning lows against the yen. ``The dollar was bought briskly and suddenly when the news came '' of the Iraqi troop movement, said Masakazu Kimura, a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. Kimura said the dollar moved up to 147.85.-.95 yen from 146.50 yen, soon after the Iraqi action was reported at around 11:30 a.m. local time. The offensive came after negotiations between Iraq and Kuwait in their dispute over oil, borders and money collapsed Wednesday. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 255.55 points, or 0.82 percent, closing the morning session at 30,582.44. The index lost 197.67 points on Wednesday. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 7.530 percent from Wednesday's close of 7.480 percent. Their price stood at 85.50 points, down from 85.72 points. On the stock market, the Nikkei index started falling with many market players taking a wait-and-see position amid the yen's depreciation and the weakening bond market, securities dealers said. ``The index lost as much as 353 points at one point, but it made some recovery by index-related buying coupled with those buying on a share's weakness,'' said a Nomura Securities dealer who spoke anonymously.
